--Word--
O 
--Type--
noun, abbreviation
UnKnownKind, exclamation
--Meanings--
The fifteenth letter of the alphabet.
Denoting the next after N in a set of items, categories, etc.
A human blood type (in the ABO system) lacking both the A and B antigens. In blood transfusion, a person with blood of this group is a potential universal donor.
Nought or zero (in a sequence of numerals, especially when spoken)
A shape like that of a capital O; a circle.
Ohio.
(on scorecards) over(s).
The chemical element oxygen.
Used before a name in direct address, as in prayers and poetry.
--Examples--
‘two seven o seven point six’
‘he made an O with his mouth’
‘give peace in our time, O Lord’
--Word--
o' 
--Type--
preposition, prefix
--Meanings--
In Irish patronymic names such as O'Neill.
--Examples--
‘a cup o' coffee’

o- 
--Type--
abbreviation
--Meanings--

--Type--
suffix
--Meanings--
Used as the terminal vowel of combining forms.
--Examples--
‘chemico-’
‘Gallo-’

--Word--
os 
--Type--
abbreviation, noun, noun
UnKnownKind
--Meanings--
(in calculating dates) Old Style.
Open-source.
Operating system.
Ordinary Seaman.
(in the UK) Ordnance Survey.
(as a size of clothing) outsize.
Out of stock.
Overseas.
A bone (used chiefly in Latin names of individual bones, e.g. os trapezium).
An opening or entrance to a passage, especially one at either end of the cervix of the uterus.
The chemical element osmium.

--Word--
Oahu 
--Type--
proper noun
--Meanings--
The third largest of the Hawaiian islands; population 905,000 (est. 2008). Its principal town, Honolulu, is the state capital of Hawaii. The island is the site of the US naval base Pearl Harbor.
--Examples--
--Word--
oak 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A large tree which bears acorns and typically has lobed deciduous leaves. Oaks are dominant in many north temperate forests and are an important source of durable timber used in building, furniture, and (formerly) ships.
A smoky flavour or nose characteristic of wine aged in barrels made from oak wood.
Used in names of other trees or plants that resemble the oaks in some way, e.g. she-oak, silky oak.
An annual flat horse race for three-year-old fillies run on Epsom Downs, over the same course as the Derby. It was first run in 1779.
A flat horse race similar to the Oaks but run on another course.
--Examples--
‘scents of toasty oak’
‘soft oak overtones’
‘the Irish Oaks’
--Word--
oak apple 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A spongy spherical gall which forms on oak trees in response to the developing larvae of a gall wasp.
--Examples--

--Type--
adjective

--Word--
Oakboy 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A member of an Irish protest organization of the 1760s called Hearts of Oak, whose badge was a sprig of oak worn in the hat.
--Examples--
--Word--
clad 
--Type--
verb, adjective, verb
--Meanings--
Clothed.
Covered with cladding.
Encase (a structure) with a covering or coating.
--Examples--
‘they were clad in T-shirts and shorts’
‘leather-clad boys’
‘copper-clad boards’
‘he cladded the concrete-frame structure in stainless steel’

--Word--
Oakley, Annie 
--Type--
proper noun
--Meanings--
(1860–1926), American markswoman; full name Phoebe Anne Oakley Mozee. In 1885 she joined Buffalo Bill's Wild West Show, of which she became a star attraction for the next seventeen years.
--Examples--
--Word--
oakling 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A small or young oak tree; an oak sapling.

oar 
--Type--
noun, verb
--Meanings--
A pole with a flat blade, used to row or steer a boat through the water.
An oarsman; a rower.
Propel with or as if with oars; row.
--Examples--
‘she pulled hard on the oars’
‘I was stroke oar and John was in the bow’
‘oaring the sea like madmen’
‘oaring through the weeds’
--Word--
oarage 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
Apparatus or fittings associated with oars; rowing equipment.
The action of oars, rowing; movement of limbs, etc., in a manner resembling that of oars.

--Word--
oasis 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A fertile spot in a desert, where water is found.
A pleasant or peaceful area or period in the midst of a difficult or hectic place or situation.
A type of rigid foam into which the stems of flowers can be secured in flower arranging.
--Examples--
‘a country of oases and burning desert sands’
‘the park is an oasis of calm in the centre of the city’
‘cover the ball of Oasis with leaves and moss’
--Word--
oasis 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--

--Examples--
--Word--
oat 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
An Old World cereal plant with a loose, branched cluster of florets, cultivated in cool climates and widely used for animal feed.
The grain yielded by the oat plant, used as food.
Used in names of wild grasses related to the cultivated oat, e.g. wild oat.
An oat stem used as a musical pipe by shepherds, especially in pastoral or bucolic poetry.
--Examples--
‘oats are great health value’
‘porridge oats’
--Word--

--Word--
Oates, Titus 
--Type--
proper noun
--Meanings--
(1649–1705), English clergyman and conspirator, remembered as the fabricator of the Popish Plot. Convicted of perjury in 1685, Oates was imprisoned in the same year, but subsequently released and granted a pension.
--Examples--
--Word--
oat 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
An Old World cereal plant with a loose, branched cluster of florets, cultivated in cool climates and widely used for animal feed.
The grain yielded by the oat plant, used as food.
Used in names of wild grasses related to the cultivated oat, e.g. wild oat.
An oat stem used as a musical pipe by shepherds, especially in pastoral or bucolic poetry.
--Examples--
‘oats are great health value’
‘porridge oats’
--Word--
growing 
--Type--
adjective
--Meanings--
(of a living thing) undergoing natural development by increasing in size and changing physically.
Becoming greater over a period of time; increasing.
--Examples--
‘the needs of the growing child’
‘the growing concern over ozone levels’
--Word--
oath 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A solemn promise, often invoking a divine witness, regarding one's future action or behaviour.
A sworn declaration, such as the promise to tell the truth, in a court of law.
A profane or offensive expression used to express anger or other strong emotions.
--Examples--
‘they took an oath of allegiance to the king’
‘each took the oath and then gave evidence’
‘he exploded with a mouthful of oaths’
‘he was muttering foul oaths’

--Word--
oathed 
--Type--
adjective
--Meanings--
That is corroborated by an oath; promised or assured by the swearing of an oath; that has sworn an oath. Also: prone to or characterized by oaths of a specified kind or number (only in compounds, as "many-oathed", etc.).
--Examples--
--Word--
oathful 
--Type--
adjective
--Meanings--
Full of oaths, prone to oaths.
--Examples--
--Word--
oathlet 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A brief oath, a petty oath.
--Examples--

oatmeal 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
Meal made from ground oats, used in porridge, oatcakes, or other food.
Porridge made from oatmeal or rolled oats.
A greyish-fawn colour flecked with brown.
--Examples--
‘medium Scottish oatmeal’
‘oatmeal porridge’
‘an oatmeal jacket’
--Word--
oatmeal 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
Meal made from ground oats, used in porridge, oatcakes, or other food.
Porridge made from oatmeal or rolled oats.
A greyish-fawn colour flecked with brown.
--Examples--
‘medium Scottish oatmeal’
‘oatmeal porridge’
‘an oatmeal jacket’
--Word--
oat 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
An Old World cereal plant with a loose, branched cluster of florets, cultivated in cool climates and widely used for animal feed.
The grain yielded by the oat plant, used as food.
Used in names of wild grasses related to the cultivated oat, e.g. wild oat.
An oat stem used as a musical pipe by shepherds, especially in pastoral or bucolic poetry.
--Examples--
‘oats are great health value’
‘porridge oats’

Oaxaca 
--Type--
proper noun
--Meanings--
A state of southern Mexico.

--Examples--
--Word--
ob 
--Type--
proper noun, abbreviation
--Meanings--
The principal river of the western Siberian lowlands and one of the largest rivers in Russia. Rising in the Altai Mountains, it flows generally north and west for 5,410 km (3,481 miles) before entering the Gulf of Ob (or Ob Bay), an inlet of the Kara Sea, a part of the Arctic Ocean.
Outside broadcast.
--Examples--
--Word--
ob- 
--Type--
prefix
--Meanings--
Denoting exposure or openness.
Expressing meeting or facing.
Denoting opposition, hostility, or resistance.
Denoting hindrance, blocking, or concealment.
Denoting finality or completeness.
(in modern technical words) in a direction or manner contrary to the usual; inversely.

‘obverse’
‘occasion’
‘opponent’
‘obviate’
‘obsolete’
‘obconical’

Obama, Barack 
--Type--
proper noun
--Meanings--
(born 1961), US Democratic statesman, 44th president of the US 2009–17; full name Barack Hussein Obama. He was the first African American to be elected to the presidency, and was re-elected in 2012 for a second term. He was awarded the Nobel Peace Prize in 2009.

--Word--
obey 
--Type--
verb
--Meanings--
Submit to the authority of (someone) or comply with (a law)
Carry out (a command or instruction)
Behave in accordance with (a general principle, natural law, etc.)
--Examples--
‘I always obey my father’
‘the officer was convicted for refusing to obey orders’
‘when the order was repeated, he refused to obey’
‘the universe was complex but it obeyed certain rules’

--Word--
obelus 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A symbol (†) used as a reference mark in printed matter, or to indicate that a person is deceased.
A mark (– or ÷) used in ancient manuscripts to mark a word or passage as spurious, corrupt or doubtful.
--Examples--
--Word--
Oberammergau 
--Type--
proper noun
--Meanings--
A village in the Bavarian Alps of south-western Germany; population 5,400 (est. 2006). It is the site of the most famous of the few surviving passion plays, which has been performed by the villagers every tenth year (with few exceptions) from 1634 as a result of a vow made during an epidemic of plague.
--Examples--
--Word--
Oberhausen 
--Type--
proper noun
--Meanings--
An industrial city in western Germany, in the Ruhr valley of North Rhine-Westphalia; population 218,200 (est. 2006).
--Examples--
--Word--
Oberon 
--Type--
proper noun
--Meanings--
A satellite of Uranus, the furthest from the planet, which has a heavily cratered surface and was discovered by W. Herschel in 1787 (diameter 1,550 km).

--Word--
obitual 
--Type--
adjective
--Meanings--
Originally: of or relating to an obit or a person's death (especially in "obitual day"). In later use also: of the nature of, or reminiscent of, a newspaper obituary; obituarial.
--Examples--
--Word--
obituary 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A notice of a death, especially in a newspaper, typically including a brief biography of the deceased person.
--Examples--
‘his obituary of Samuel Beckett’
‘an obituary notice’
‘it is premature to write the obituary of British science’

--Examples--
--Word--
object 
--Type--
noun, verb
--Meanings--
A material thing that can be seen and touched.
A thing external to the thinking mind or subject.
A person or thing to which a specified action or feeling is directed.
A goal or purpose.
A noun or noun phrase governed by an active transitive verb or by a preposition.
A data construct that provides a description of anything known to a computer (such as a processor or a piece of code) and defines its method of operation.
Say something to express one's opposition to or disagreement with something.
Cite as a reason against something.
--Examples--
‘he was dragging a large object’
‘small objects such as shells’
‘disease became the object of investigation’
‘he hated being the object of public attention’
‘the Institute was opened with the object of promoting scientific study’
‘in Gaelic the word order is verb, subject, object’
‘the interface treats most items, including cells, graphs, and buttons, as objects’
‘residents object to the volume of traffic’
‘the boy's father objected that the police had arrested him unlawfully’
‘‘It doesn't seem natural,’ she objected’
‘Bryant objects this very circumstance to the authenticity of the Iliad’

--Word--
object 
--Type--
noun, verb
--Meanings--
A material thing that can be seen and touched.
A thing external to the thinking mind or subject.
A person or thing to which a specified action or feeling is directed.
A goal or purpose.
A noun or noun phrase governed by an active transitive verb or by a preposition.
A data construct that provides a description of anything known to a computer (such as a processor or a piece of code) and defines its method of operation.
Say something to express one's opposition to or disagreement with something.
Cite as a reason against something.
--Examples--
‘he was dragging a large object’
‘small objects such as shells’
‘disease became the object of investigation’
‘he hated being the object of public attention’
‘the Institute was opened with the object of promoting scientific study’
‘in Gaelic the word order is verb, subject, object’
‘the interface treats most items, including cells, graphs, and buttons, as objects’
‘residents object to the volume of traffic’
‘the boy's father objected that the police had arrested him unlawfully’
‘‘It doesn't seem natural,’ she objected’
‘Bryant objects this very circumstance to the authenticity of the Iliad’

--Word--
objectify 
--Type--
verb
--Meanings--
Degrade to the status of a mere object.
Express (something abstract) in a concrete form.
--Examples--

‘good poetry objectifies feeling’
--Word--
objectification 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
The action of degrading someone to the status of a mere object.
The expression of something abstract in a concrete form.
--Examples--
‘the objectification of women in popular entertainment’
‘the objectification of images may be astonishingly vivid in dreams’
‘the church says that we are the visible objectifications of sin’

--Word--
objectivize 
--Type--
verb
--Meanings--
View or interpret objectively without the influence of personal feelings or opinions.
Degrade to the status of a mere object; objectify.
--Examples--
‘research statistics help us objectivize and explain the world around us’
‘we risk objectivizing what is essentially an internal set of experiences’
‘porn that objectivizes women’

--Word--
objective 
--Type--
adjective, noun
--Meanings--
(of a person or their judgement) not influenced by personal feelings or opinions in considering and representing facts.
Not dependent on the mind for existence; actual.
Relating to or denoting a case of nouns and pronouns serving as the object of a transitive verb or a preposition.
A thing aimed at or sought; a goal.
The objective case.
The lens in a telescope or microscope nearest to the object observed.
--Examples--
‘historians try to be objective and impartial’
‘a matter of objective fact’
‘the system has achieved its objective’
‘examine with high power objective’
--Word--
objectively 
--Type--
adverb
--Meanings--
In a way that is not influenced by personal feelings or opinions.
In a way that is not dependent on the mind for existence; actually.
--Examples--
‘events should be reported objectively’
‘the researchers are objectively assessing risk factors’
‘the physical world we think of as objectively true’

noun
--Meanings--

--Word--
objectivism

noun

--Word--
oblata 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
Unpaid debts owed to the Crown, carried forward from previous years by the Exchequer, and placed in the hands of the incoming sheriff for collection; (also) gifts or offerings made to the monarch by a subject or subjects, especially in return for favours. Now only in "Oblata Roll"noun an exchequer roll containing a record of the oblata; see also Oblate Roll, fine roll; usually in plural.

--Word--
obligate 
--Type--
verb, adjective
--Meanings--
Require or compel (someone) to undertake a legal or moral duty.
Commit (assets) as security.
Restricted to a particular function or mode of life.
--Examples--
‘the medical establishment is obligated to take action in the best interest of the public’
‘the money must be obligated within 30 days’
‘an obligate intracellular parasite’

--Word--
obligation 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
An act or course of action to which a person is morally or legally bound; a duty or commitment.
The condition of being morally or legally bound to do something.
A debt of gratitude for a service or favour.
A binding agreement committing a person to a payment or other action.
--Examples--
‘I have an obligation to look after her’
‘they are under no obligation to stick to the scheme’
‘she didn't want to be under an obligation to him’

--Word--
obligatory 
--Type--
adjective
--Meanings--
Required by a legal, moral, or other rule; compulsory.
(of a ruling) having binding force.
So customary or fashionable as to be expected of everyone or on every occasion.
--Examples--
‘use of seat belts in cars is now obligatory’
‘a sovereign whose laws are obligatory’
‘it was a quiet little street with the obligatory pub at the end’

--Word--
oblige 
--Type--
verb
--Meanings--
Make (someone) legally or morally bound to do something.
Do as (someone) asks or desires in order to help or please them.
Be indebted or grateful.
Bind (someone) by an oath, promise, or contract.
--Examples--
‘doctors are obliged by law to keep patients alive while there is a chance of recovery’
‘oblige me by not being sorry for yourself’
‘tell me what you want to know and I'll see if I can oblige’
‘if you can give me a few minutes of your time I'll be much obliged’
‘my father had obliged me to the improvement of my stock’

oblique 
--Type--
adjective, noun
--Meanings--
Neither parallel nor at right angles to a specified or implied line; slanting.
(of a line, plane figure, or surface) inclined at other than a right angle.
(of an angle) acute or obtuse.
(of a cone, cylinder, etc.) with an axis not perpendicular to the plane of its base.
(especially of a muscle) neither parallel nor perpendicular to the long axis of a body or limb.
Not expressed or done in a direct way.
Denoting any case other than the nominative or vocative.
An oblique muscle.
--Examples--
‘we sat on the settee oblique to the fireplace’
‘an oblique abdominal muscle’
‘he issued an oblique attack on the President’
‘it is the obliques and abdominals which create the well-trained look’
--Word--
oblique-angled 
--Type--
adjective
--Meanings--
Of a geometrical figure: having all its angles oblique.
--Examples--
--Word--
obliquity 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
--Examples--
--Word--
oblique 
--Type--
adjective, noun
--Meanings--
Neither parallel nor at right angles to a specified or implied line; slanting.
(of a line, plane figure, or surface) inclined at other than a right angle.
(of an angle) acute or obtuse.
(of a cone, cylinder, etc.) with an axis not perpendicular to the plane of its base.
(especially of a muscle) neither parallel nor perpendicular to the long axis of a body or limb.
Not expressed or done in a direct way.
Denoting any case other than the nominative or vocative.
An oblique muscle.
--Examples--
‘we sat on the settee oblique to the fireplace’
‘an oblique abdominal muscle’
‘he issued an oblique attack on the President’
‘it is the obliques and abdominals which create the well-trained look’
--Word--
obliquely 
--Type--
adverb
--Meanings--
Not in a direct way; indirectly.
In an oblique direction; slantwise.
--Examples--
‘he referred only obliquely to current events’
‘the strings of the instrument run obliquely away from the player’
--Word--
obliqueness 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
--Examples--

--Meanings--

--Word--
obliterate 
--Type--
verb
--Meanings--
Destroy utterly; wipe out.
Make invisible or indistinct; conceal or cover.
Cancel (something, especially a postage stamp) to prevent further use.
--Examples--
‘the memory was so painful that he obliterated it from his mind’
‘clouds were darkening, obliterating the sun’
‘the special stamp should be placed on the left-hand side and not be used to obliterate the postage stamp’

--Word--
oblivion 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
The state of being unaware or unconscious of what is happening around one.
The state of being forgotten, especially by the public.
Destruction or extinction.
Amnesty or pardon.
--Examples--
‘they drank themselves into oblivion’
‘his name will fade into oblivion’
‘only our armed forces stood between us and oblivion’

--Meanings--

--Word--
obliviscence 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
Forgetting; an instance of this; (Psychology) deterioration of the ability to remember learned material or perform a learned task which occurs after the learning has ceased.
--Examples--

medulla oblongata 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
The continuation of the spinal cord within the skull, forming the lowest part of the brainstem and containing control centres for the heart and lungs.

oboe 
--Type--
noun

obol 
--Type--

--Meanings--
An ancient Greek coin worth one sixth of a drachma.
--Examples--
--Word--
obole 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A small silver coin in medieval Europe; specifically (a) an English halfpenny; (b) a small French coin (originally of silver, later of billon) in use from the 10th to 15th centuries and having the value of half a denier (also called a maille). Also (more generally): any coin of low value.
--Examples--
--Word--
obole 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A small silver coin in medieval Europe; specifically (a) an English halfpenny; (b) a small French coin (originally of silver, later of billon) in use from the 10th to 15th centuries and having the value of half a denier (also called a maille). Also (more generally): any coin of low value.
--Examples--
--Word--
obol 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
An ancient Greek coin worth one sixth of a drachma.
--Examples--
--Word--
obolus 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
Ancient History= "obol". Now rare.
Palaeontology (In form Obolus) a genus of fossil brachiopods having a smooth orbicular shell, widespread in Cambrian and Ordovician rocks; (also obolus) a brachiopod of this genus.
--Examples--
--Word--
Obote, Milton 
--Type--
proper noun
--Meanings--
(1924–2005), Ugandan statesman, prime minister 1962–6, president 1966–71 and 1980–5; full name Apollo Milton Obote. Overthrown by Idi Amin in 1971, he was re-elected president in 1980. He was removed in a second military coup in 1985.

obpyriform

--Meanings--

--Word--
O'Brien, Flann 
--Type--
proper noun
--Meanings--
(1911–66), Irish novelist and journalist; pseudonym of Brian O'Nolan. Writing under the name of Myles na Gopaleen, he contributed a satirical column to the Irish Times for nearly twenty years. Notable novels: At Swim-Two-Birds (1939) and The Third Policeman (1967).
--Examples--
--Word--
ob 
--Type--
proper noun, abbreviation
--Meanings--
The principal river of the western Siberian lowlands and one of the largest rivers in Russia. Rising in the Altai Mountains, it flows generally north and west for 5,410 km (3,481 miles) before entering the Gulf of Ob (or Ob Bay), an inlet of the Kara Sea, a part of the Arctic Ocean.
Outside broadcast.

obs.

--Meanings--

Obsolete.
--Examples--
--Word--
obscene 
--Type--
adjective
--Meanings--
(of the portrayal or description of sexual matters) offensive or disgusting by accepted standards of morality and decency.
Offending against moral principles; repugnant.
--Examples--
‘obscene jokes’
‘using animals' skins for fur coats is obscene’
--Word--
obscenely 
--Type--
adverb
--Meanings--
In a sexually offensive, disgusting, or indecent manner.
To a disgustingly or immorally extreme degree.
--Examples--
‘the boys used vulgar language and gestured obscenely’
‘obscenely overpaid executives’

obscenity 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
The state or quality of being obscene.
Obscene behaviour, language, or images.
An extremely offensive word or expression.
--Examples--
‘the book was banned for obscenity’
‘a stream of invective and obscenity’
‘the men scowled and muttered obscenities’
--Word--
obscenity 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
The state or quality of being obscene.

--Word--
camera obscura 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A darkened box with a convex lens or aperture for projecting the image of an external object on to a screen inside, a forerunner of the modern camera.
A small round building with a rotating angled mirror at the apex of the roof, projecting an image of the landscape on to a horizontal surface inside.
--Examples--
--Word--
obscurancy 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
Obscurantism.
--Examples--
--Word--
obscurant 
--Type--
noun, adjective
--Meanings--
A person who deliberately prevents the facts or full details of something from becoming known; an obscurantist.
Something used to hinder visibility.
Deliberately preventing the facts or full details of something from becoming known; obscurantist.
Having the effect of hindering visibility.
--Examples--
‘he is no pious obscurant wishing for a return to the days when issues were never discussed’
‘smoke and other obscurants have been used in wars dating back to the ancient Greeks’
‘the use of obscurant language’
‘obscurant clouds’
--Word--
obscurantic 
--Type--
adjective
--Meanings--
That obscures or conceals; specifically = "obscurantist".
--Examples--
--Word--
obscuranticism 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
Obscurantism.

--Word--
obscurantism 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
The practice of deliberately preventing the facts or full details of something from becoming known.
--Examples--
‘allegations in the Press about government obscurantism’
--Word--
obscurantist 
--Type--
noun, adjective
--Meanings--
A person who deliberately prevents the facts or full details of something from becoming known.

--Examples--
‘political obscurantists’
‘an obscurantist agenda’
‘obscurantist language’

--Type--

--Meanings--
The quality or condition of being obscure, unclear, or unknown.
--Examples--
--Word--
obscure 
--Type--
adjective, verb
--Meanings--
Not discovered or known about; uncertain.
Not important or well known.
Not clearly expressed or easily understood.
Hard to define; vague.
Dark or dim.
Keep from being seen; conceal.
Make unclear and difficult to understand.
Keep from being known.
--Examples--
‘his origins and parentage are obscure’
‘a relatively obscure actor’
‘obscure references to Proust’
‘I feel an obscure resentment’
‘the obscure light of dawn’
‘grey clouds obscure the sun’
‘the debate has become obscured by conflicting ideological perspectives’
‘none of this should obscure the skill and perseverance of the workers’

--Word--
obscurism 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
The tendency to favour obscurity of style, meaning, factual knowledge, etc.; wilful obscurity.
--Examples--
--Word--
obscurist 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
An obscurantist; (also, more generally) a person, especially a creative artist, who prefers obscurity to clarity.
--Examples--
--Word--
obscurity 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
The state of being unknown, inconspicuous, or unimportant.
The quality of being difficult to understand.
A thing that is unclear or difficult to understand.
--Examples--
‘he is too good a player to slide into obscurity’
‘poems of impenetrable obscurity’
‘the obscurities in his poems and plays’
--Word--
obscurity 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
The state of being unknown, inconspicuous, or unimportant.
The quality of being difficult to understand.
A thing that is unclear or difficult to understand.
--Examples--
‘he is too good a player to slide into obscurity’
‘poems of impenetrable obscurity’
‘the obscurities in his poems and plays’

--Word--
obsequent 
--Type--
adjective, adjective, noun
--Meanings--
Compliant, yielding, obedient; deferential, servile.
Of a stream, stream valley, or drainage pattern: having a course or character opposite to that of a consequent stream, stream valley, or drainage pattern, i.e. against the direction of dip of the strata.
Of a fault-line scarp or related feature: having (as a result of differential erosion) a relief the reverse of that originally produced by the faulting.
An obsequent stream.
--Examples--

--Word--
observation 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
The action or process of closely observing or monitoring something or someone.
The ability to notice things, especially significant details.
The act of taking the altitude of the sun or another celestial body to find a latitude or longitude.
A statement based on something one has seen, heard, or noticed.
--Examples--
‘she was brought into hospital for observation’
‘units kept enemy forces under observation for days’
‘detailed observations were carried out on the students' behaviour’
‘his powers of observation’
‘he made a telling observation about Hughie’
--Word--
observational

adjective
--Meanings--
Relating to the action or process of closely observing or watching something or someone.
Drawing on things that one has seen, heard, or noticed in everyday life.
--Examples--
‘long-term observational data suggested an improvement in survival’
‘the observational skills of a journalist’
‘our study was purely observational’
‘a master of observational comedy’
--Word--
observationalism 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
The theory that all knowledge is based on observation. Also: the belief that observation, rather than theory, is the basis of science. In recent use in the arts, and especially in film: a strictly factual and descriptive approach to documentary narrative.
--Examples--

adverb
--Meanings--

--Word--
observe 
--Type--
verb
--Meanings--
Notice or perceive (something) and register it as being significant.
Watch (someone or something) carefully and attentively.
Take note of or detect (something) in the course of a scientific study.
Make a remark.
Fulfil or comply with (a social, legal, ethical, or religious obligation)
Maintain (silence) in compliance with a rule or custom, or temporarily as a mark of respect.
Perform or take part in (a rite or ceremony)
Celebrate or acknowledge (an anniversary)
--Examples--
‘she observed that all the chairs were already occupied’
‘Rob stood in the hallway, from where he could observe the happenings on the street’
‘the behaviour observed in groups of chimpanzees’
‘‘It's chilly,’ she observed’
‘a stockbroker once observed that dealers live and work in hell’
‘a tribunal must observe the principles of natural justice’
‘a minute's silence will be observed’
‘relations gather to observe the funeral rites’
‘they observed the one-year anniversary of the flood’

--Word--
observer 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A person who watches or notices something.
A person who follows events closely and comments publicly on them.
A person posted in an official capacity to an area to monitor political or military events.
A person who attends a conference, inquiry, etc., to note the proceedings without participating in them.
A person trained to spot and identify enemy aircraft or to reconnoitre enemy positions from the air.
--Examples--
‘to a casual observer, he was at peace’
‘some observers expect interest rates to rise’
‘elections scrutinized by international observers’
‘he had been invited to attend the meeting as an observer’
‘the Royal Observer Corps’
--Word--
observer 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--

‘to a casual observer, he was at peace’
‘some observers expect interest rates to rise’
‘elections scrutinized by international observers’
‘he had been invited to attend the meeting as an observer’
‘the Royal Observer Corps’

--Word--
obsidional 
--Type--
adjective
--Meanings--
Of or relating to a siege; specifically designating a wreath of grass or weeds conferred as a mark of honour upon a Roman general who raised a siege, especially in "obsidional crown", or designating coins struck, or another object serving the purpose of a coin, in a besieged town as a substitute for regular coins.
Of disease: that assails or surrounds.

--Word--
obsolete 
--Type--
adjective, verb
--Meanings--
No longer produced or used; out of date.
(of a part or characteristic of an organism) less developed than formerly or in a related species; rudimentary; vestigial.
Cause (a product or idea) to become obsolete by replacing it with something new.
--Examples--
‘the disposal of old and obsolete machinery’
‘the phrase was obsolete after 1625’
‘we're trying to stimulate the business by obsoleting last year's designs’

--Word--
non obstante 
--Type--
noun, adjective, preposition
--Meanings--
A clause in a statute or letter patent conveying a dispensation from a monarch or other executive to perform an action notwithstanding any statute to the contrary. Also in "clause of non-obstante". Now historical.
Designating a clause, licence, etc., beginning with the expression non obstante.
Notwithstanding. Frequently used postpositively; also in "non obstante veredicto": notwithstanding the verdict.
--Examples--

--Word--
obstruct 
--Type--
verb
--Meanings--
Block (an opening, path, road, etc.); be or get in the way of.
Prevent or hinder (movement or someone or something in motion)
Deliberately make (something) difficult.
Commit the offence of intentionally hindering (a police officer)
(in various sports) impede (a player in the opposing team) in a manner which constitutes an offence.
--Examples--
‘she was obstructing the entrance’
‘they had to alter the course of the stream and obstruct the natural flow of the water’
‘fears that the regime would obstruct the distribution of food’
‘the appellants were arrested, and later convicted of obstructing the police’
‘an indirect free kick is awarded for intentionally obstructing an opponent’
--Word--
obstruct 
--Type--
verb
--Meanings--
Block (an opening, path, road, etc.); be or get in the way of.
Prevent or hinder (movement or someone or something in motion)
Deliberately make (something) difficult.
Commit the offence of intentionally hindering (a police officer)
(in various sports) impede (a player in the opposing team) in a manner which constitutes an offence.
--Examples--
‘she was obstructing the entrance’
‘they had to alter the course of the stream and obstruct the natural flow of the water’
‘fears that the regime would obstruct the distribution of food’
‘the appellants were arrested, and later convicted of obstructing the police’
‘an indirect free kick is awarded for intentionally obstructing an opponent’
--Word--
obstructedly 
--Type--
adverb
--Meanings--
With or in the face of obstruction.
--Examples--
--Word--
obstructer 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A person who or thing which obstructs or hinders; = "obstructor".
--Examples--
--Word--
obstructer 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A person who or thing which obstructs or hinders; = "obstructor".
--Examples--
--Word--
obstruct 
--Type--
verb
--Meanings--
Block (an opening, path, road, etc.); be or get in the way of.
Prevent or hinder (movement or someone or something in motion)
Deliberately make (something) difficult.
Commit the offence of intentionally hindering (a police officer)
(in various sports) impede (a player in the opposing team) in a manner which constitutes an offence.
--Examples--
‘she was obstructing the entrance’
‘they had to alter the course of the stream and obstruct the natural flow of the water’
‘fears that the regime would obstruct the distribution of food’
‘the appellants were arrested, and later convicted of obstructing the police’
‘an indirect free kick is awarded for intentionally obstructing an opponent’
--Word--
obstruction 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
The action of obstructing or the state of being obstructed.
A thing that impedes or prevents passage or progress; an obstacle or blockage.
(in various sports) the action of unlawfully obstructing a player in the opposing team.
Blockage of a bodily passage, especially the gut.
The action of impeding the movement of traffic on a highway.
The action of deliberately hindering the police in their duties.
--Examples--
‘walkers could proceed with the minimum of obstruction’
‘the tractor hit an obstruction’
‘they presented with severe intestinal obstruction’
‘they were held for obstruction and other public order offences’
‘he was charged with obstruction of a police officer in the execution of his duty’
--Word--
obstructionism 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
The practice of deliberately impeding or delaying the course of legal, legislative, or other procedures.
--Examples--

--Word--
obstructive 
--Type--
adjective
--Meanings--
Causing a blockage or obstruction.
Relating to obstruction of a passage in the body, especially the gut or the bronchi.
Causing or tending to cause deliberate difficulties and delays.
--Examples--
‘all tubing should be cleared of obstructive algae and detritus’
‘the child developed severe obstructive symptoms’
‘he denied the council had been obstructive’

obtundent 
--Type--
noun, adjective
--Meanings--

--Word--
obtuse 
--Type--
adjective
--Meanings--
Annoyingly insensitive or slow to understand.
Difficult to understand, especially deliberately so.
(of an angle) more than 90° and less than 180°
Not sharp-pointed or sharp-edged; blunt.
--Examples--
‘he wondered if the doctor was being deliberately obtuse’
‘some of the lyrics are a bit obtuse’
‘an obtuse angle of 150°’
‘it had strange obtuse teeth’

obverse 
--Type--
noun, adjective
--Meanings--
The side of a coin or medal bearing the head or principal design.
The design or inscription on the principal side of a coin.
The opposite or counterpart of a fact or truth.
Of or denoting the obverse of a coin or medal.
Corresponding to something else as its opposite or counterpart.
Narrower at the base or point of attachment than at the apex or top.
--Examples--
‘true solitude is the obverse of true society’
‘the obverse fates of the principals’
‘an obverse leaf’

obviative 
--Type--
noun, adjective
--Meanings--
A grammatical marker or category in the Algonquian family of North American Indian languages for a third person other than the principal (or proximate) third person in a given context.
Of, relating to, or designating the obviative; belonging to the category of, or marked by, the obviative.

--Type--
adjective

Easily perceived or understood; clear, self-evident, or apparent.

--Word--
occasion 
--Type--
noun, verb
--Meanings--
A particular event, or the time at which it takes place.
A special or noteworthy event, ceremony, or celebration.
A suitable or opportune time for doing something.
Reason; cause.
Cause (something)
--Examples--
‘on one occasion I stayed up until two in the morning’
‘she was presented with a gold watch to mark the occasion’
‘Sunday lunch has a suitable sense of occasion about it’
‘by-elections are traditionally an occasion for registering protest votes’
‘it's the first time that I've had occasion to complain’
‘something vital must have occasioned this visit’
‘his death occasioned her much grief’
--Word--
occasioner 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A person who or thing which occasions something.
--Examples--
--Word--
occasional 
--Type--
adjective
--Meanings--
Occurring, appearing, or done infrequently and irregularly.
(of furniture) made or adapted for use on a particular occasion or for infrequent use.
(of a literary composition, speech, religious service, etc.) produced on or intended for a special occasion.
Employed for a particular occasion or on an irregular basis.
--Examples--
‘the occasional car went by but no taxis’
‘an occasional table’
‘he wrote occasional verse for patrons’
‘occasional freelancer seeks full-time position’

noun
--Meanings--
A person who or thing which occasions something.
--Examples--
--Word--
occasionless 
--Type--
adjective
--Meanings--
Without occasion; not made or intended for a special occasion.
--Examples--
--Word--
occasion 
--Type--
noun, verb
--Meanings--
A particular event, or the time at which it takes place.
A special or noteworthy event, ceremony, or celebration.
A suitable or opportune time for doing something.
Reason; cause.
Cause (something)
--Examples--
‘on one occasion I stayed up until two in the morning’
‘she was presented with a gold watch to mark the occasion’
‘Sunday lunch has a suitable sense of occasion about it’
‘by-elections are traditionally an occasion for registering protest votes’
‘it's the first time that I've had occasion to complain’
‘something vital must have occasioned this visit’
‘his death occasioned her much grief’
--Word--
occasioner 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A person who or thing which occasions something.
--Examples--
--Word--
Occident 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
The countries of the West, especially Europe and America.
--Examples--
--Word--
occidental 
--Type--
adjective, noun
--Meanings--
Relating to the countries of the West.
A native or inhabitant of the West.
--Examples--
‘modern occidental society’
‘he was gently apologetic when confronted by an angry Occidental’
--Word--
occidentalize 
--Type--
verb
--Meanings--
Give Western features or characteristics to; make occidental.
--Examples--
‘an attempt to occidentalize the East’
‘occidentalized societies’
--Word--
occidentalize 
--Type--
verb
--Meanings--
Give Western features or characteristics to; make occidental.
--Examples--
‘an attempt to occidentalize the East’
‘occidentalized societies’

occidentalism

noun
--Meanings--

--Word--
occidentalist 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
--Examples--
--Word--
occidentality 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
Astronomy and Astrology. The position of a planet when in the western part of the sky or visible after sunset.
Western style or character; a Western trait or peculiarity.
--Examples--
--Word--
occidentalization 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
The action or process of making occidental in character or appearance.

--Word--
Occident 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
The countries of the West, especially Europe and America.
--Examples--
--Word--
occipital 
--Type--
adjective
--Meanings--
Relating to or situated in the back of the head.
--Examples--
‘the occipital bone’
‘tumours in the occipital lobe’
--Word--
occipitally 
--Type--
adverb
--Meanings--
As regards the occiput; in the region or direction of the occiput.
--Examples--
--Word--
occipito- 
--Type--
combining form
--Meanings--
Relating to the occipital lobe or the occipital bone.
--Examples--
‘occipitotemporal’
--Word--
occipitoanterior 
--Type--
adjective
--Meanings--
Designating a type of cephalic presentation in which the fetal occiput is directed towards the anterior half of the mother's pelvis (usually towards the left or right acetabulum).
--Examples--
--Word--
occipitoatlantal 
--Type--
adjective
--Meanings--
Of or relating to the occiput and the atlas (first cervical vertebra).
--Examples--
--Word--
occipito-atloid 
--Type--
adjective
--Meanings--
= occipitoatlantal.
--Examples--
--Word--
occipitoaxial 
--Type--
adjective
--Meanings--
Of or relating to the occiput and the axis (second cervical vertebra).
--Examples--
--Word--
occipitofrontal 
--Type--
noun, adjective
--Meanings--
Obstetrics. The occipitofrontal diameter of the skull.
Of or relating to the occipital and frontal bones of the skull, or the occipital and frontal lobes of the brain; specifically designating a diameter or circumference of the skull measured between the external occipital protuberance and the frontal bone (now usually the glabella).
Designating the occipitofrontalis muscle. rare.
--Examples--
--Word--
occipitofrontalis 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
More fully "occipitofrontalis muscle". A large flat muscle of the scalp, consisting of an occipital portion (arising from the occipital and temporal bones) and a frontal portion that are separated by the epicranial aponeurosis, and serving to draw the scalp backwards, raising the eyebrows.
--Examples--
--Word--
occipitomastoid 
--Type--
adjective
--Meanings--
Of relating to the occipital and mastoid bones.
--Examples--
--Word--
occipitomental 
--Type--
adjective
--Meanings--
Of or relating to the occiput and the chin; (specifically in Obstetrics) designating the diameter of the fetal skull measured from the occiput to the tip of the chin.
--Examples--
--Word--
occipito-otic 
--Type--
adjective
--Meanings--
Of or relating to the occipital bone and bones of the ear.
--Examples--
--Word--
occipitoparietal 
--Type--
adjective
--Meanings--
Of or relating to the occipital and parietal bones or lobes.
--Examples--
--Word--
occipitoposterior 
--Type--
adjective
--Meanings--
Designating a type of cephalic presentation in childbirth in which the fetal occiput is directed towards the posterior half of the mother's pelvis (usually towards the sacrum or left or right sacroiliac joint).
--Examples--
--Word--
occipitotemporal 
--Type--
adjective
--Meanings--
Relating to the occipital and temporal bones.
--Examples--
--Word--
occiput 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
The back of the head.
--Examples--
--Word--
occiput 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
The back of the head.
--Examples--
--Word--
occlude 
--Type--
verb
--Meanings--
Stop, close up, or obstruct (an opening, orifice, or passage)
Shut in.
Cover (an eye) to prevent its use.
(of a tooth) come into contact with another tooth in the opposite jaw.
(of a solid) absorb and retain (a gas or impurity)
--Examples--
‘thick make-up can occlude the pores’
‘they were occluding the waterfront with a wall of buildings’
‘it is placed at eye level with one eye occluded’
‘in monkeys and apes, the upper canine occludes with the lower first premolar’
‘occluded within these crystals are other molecules’
--Word--
occlude 
--Type--
verb
--Meanings--

--Word--
occludent 
--Type--
noun, adjective
--Meanings--
Something that occludes; an occluder. rare.
Zoology. Having the function of, involved in, or undergoing closure or occlusion; specifically designating the edges of the opercular plates of a barnacle which come into contact when the aperture is closed.
--Examples--

--Word--
occlusal 
--Type--
adjective
--Meanings--
Relating to or involved in the occlusion of teeth.
Denoting a surface of a tooth that comes into contact with a tooth in the other jaw.
--Examples--
--Word--
occlusion 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
The blockage or closing of a blood vessel or hollow organ.
A process by which the cold front of a rotating low-pressure system catches up the warm front, so that the warm air between them is forced upwards off the earth's surface between wedges of cold air.
An occluded front.
The position of the teeth when the jaws are closed.
--Examples--

--Word--
occlusor 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A muscle (or, rarely: other structure) that serves to close an opening or passage. Frequently attributive, especially in "occlusor muscle".
--Examples--
--Word--
occult 
--Type--
noun, adjective, verb
--Meanings--
Mystical, supernatural, or magical powers, practices, or phenomena.
Involving or relating to mystical, supernatural, or magical powers, practices, or phenomena.
Communicated only to the initiated; esoteric.
(of a disease or process) not accompanied by readily discernible signs or symptoms.
(of blood) abnormally present, e.g. in faeces, but detectable only chemically or microscopically.
Cut off from view by interposing something.
(of a celestial body) conceal (an apparently smaller body) from view by passing or being in front of it.
--Examples--
‘a secret society to study alchemy and the occult’
‘an occult ceremony’
‘a weird occult sensation of having experienced the identical situation before’
‘the typically occult language of the time’
‘careful palpation sometimes discloses occult spina bifida’
‘a wooden screen designed to occult the competitors’
‘the Moon occults Mars during daylight on March 22’
--Word--
occultation 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
--Examples--
--Word--
occult 
--Type--
noun, adjective, verb

--Word--
occulter 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
Something that occults; specifically (a) a device for temporarily cutting off a lighthouse light; (b) a device in a telescope or other instrument for cutting off the direct light of the sun or other bright object.
--Examples--
--Word--
occulter 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
Something that occults; specifically (a) a device for temporarily cutting off a lighthouse light; (b) a device in a telescope or other instrument for cutting off the direct light of the sun or other bright object.
--Examples--

occupancy 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
The action or fact of occupying a place.
The proportion of hotel or office accommodation occupied or used.
--Examples--
‘the palace proved unready for occupancy’
‘70 per cent occupancy is needed to give a profit’
‘average daily room occupancies’

--Word--
occupant 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A person who resides or is present in a house, vehicle, seat, etc., at a given time.
The holder of a position or office.
A person in actual possession of property, especially land.
A person who establishes a title by taking possession of something that previously did not have an established owner.
--Examples--
‘the previous occupant of her room’
‘occupants of the moral high ground’
‘the first occupant of the Chair of Botany’

--Word--
occupation 
--Type--
noun, adjective
--Meanings--
A job or profession.
A way of spending time.
The action, state, or period of occupying or being occupied by military force.
The action of entering and taking control of a building.
The action of living in or using a building or other place.
For the sole use of the occupiers of the land concerned.
--Examples--
‘people in professional occupations’
‘a game of cards is a pretty harmless occupation’
‘the Roman occupation of Britain’
‘the workers remained in occupation until 16 October’
‘a property suitable for occupation by older people’
‘an occupation bridge’
--Word--
occupational 
--Type--
adjective
--Meanings--
Relating to a job or profession.
--Examples--
‘an occupational pension scheme’
--Word--
occupationally 
--Type--
adverb
--Meanings--
--Examples--
--Word--
occupationless 
--Type--
adjective
--Meanings--
Characterized by absence of occupation; having no occupation; unoccupied, idle.
--Examples--

--Word--
occupy 
--Type--
verb
--Meanings--
Reside or have one's place of business in (a building)
Fill or take up (a space or time)
Be situated in or at (a position in a system or hierarchy)
Hold (a position or job)
Fill or preoccupy (the mind)
Keep (someone) busy and active.
Take control of (a place, especially a country) by military conquest or settlement.
Enter and stay in (a building) without authority and often forcibly, especially as a form of protest.
--Examples--
‘the rented flat she occupies in Hampstead’
‘two long windows occupied almost the whole of the end wall’
‘the Bank of England occupies a central position in the UK financial system’
‘a very different job from any that he had occupied before’
‘her mind was occupied with alarming questions’
‘Sarah occupied herself taking the coffee cups over to the sink’
‘Syria was occupied by France under a League of Nations mandate’
‘the workers occupied the factory’
--Word--
occupiable 
--Type--
adjective
--Meanings--
Able or fit to be occupied.
--Examples--
--Word--
occupied 
--Type--
adjective
--Meanings--
(of a building, seat, etc.) being used by someone.
Busy and active.
(of a place, especially a country) taken control of by military conquest or settlement.
--Examples--
‘only the ground floor is fully occupied’
‘tasks which kept her occupied for the day’
‘the occupied territories’
--Word--
occupier 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A person or company residing in or using a property as its owner or tenant, or (illegally) as a squatter.
A member of a group that takes possession of a country by force.
--Examples--
‘the occupiers were reported to have rounded up civilians and carried them off to unknown fates’

--Word--
occur 
--Type--
verb
--Meanings--
Happen; take place.
Exist or be found to be present in a place or under a particular set of conditions.
(of a thought or idea) come into the mind of.
--Examples--
‘the accident occurred at about 3.30 p.m.’
‘radon occurs naturally in rocks such as granite’
‘it occurred to him that he hadn't eaten’

--Word--
occurrence 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
An incident or event.
The fact or frequency of something happening.
The fact of something existing or being found in a place or under a particular set of conditions.
--Examples--
‘vandalism used to be a rare occurrence’
‘the occurrence of cancer increases with age’
‘the occurrence of natural gas fields’

occur 
--Type--
verb
--Meanings--
Happen; take place.
Exist or be found to be present in a place or under a particular set of conditions.
(of a thought or idea) come into the mind of.
--Examples--
‘the accident occurred at about 3.30 p.m.’
‘radon occurs naturally in rocks such as granite’
‘it occurred to him that he hadn't eaten’
--Word--
OCD 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
Obsessive-compulsive disorder.
(in general use) obsessive-compulsive personality disorder.
--Examples--
‘Hughes suffers from OCD and repeatedly washes his hands’
‘she thinks Virgos have a predisposition to OCD, because of their desire for perfectionism’

--Word--
oceanic 
--Type--
adjective
--Meanings--
Relating to the ocean.
Of or inhabiting the part of the ocean beyond the edge of a continental shelf.
(of a climate) governed by the proximity of the ocean.
Of enormous size or extent; huge; vast.
Relating to Oceania.
--Examples--
‘oceanic atolls’
‘stocks of oceanic fish’
‘he attributes forest decline to our oceanic climate’
‘an oceanic failure’
‘a gallery specializing in Oceanic art’

--Word--
ochratoxin 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
Any of a series of mycotoxins which are produced by various moulds of the genera Aspergillus and Penicillium and are derivatives of l-phenylalanine and a compound related to coumarin; especially "ochratoxin A", produced chiefly by A. ochraceus and having the empirical formula C₂₀H₁₈ClNO₆.

William of Occam 
--Type--
proper noun

--Word--
o'clock 
--Type--
adverb
--Meanings--
Used to specify the hour when telling the time.
Used following a numeral to indicate direction or bearing with reference to an imaginary clock face, 12 o'clock being thought of as directly in front or overhead.
--Examples--
‘the gates will open at eight o'clock’
‘“I think we've got some action at 11 o'clock,” he said, gesturing toward the eastern plains’
--Word--
o'clock 
--Type--
adverb
--Meanings--
Used to specify the hour when telling the time.
Used following a numeral to indicate direction or bearing with reference to an imaginary clock face, 12 o'clock being thought of as directly in front or overhead.
--Examples--
‘the gates will open at eight o'clock’
‘“I think we've got some action at 11 o'clock,” he said, gesturing toward the eastern plains’
--Word--
Oconee bells 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A small herbaceous plant, Shortia galacifolia (family Diapensiaceae), found in the southern Appalachians (where it is very rare) and cultivated elsewhere as a rockery plant for its small, white, bell-shaped flowers and evergreen foliage, resembling that of galax.
--Examples--
--Word--
O'Connell, Daniel 
--Type--
proper noun
--Meanings--
(1775–1847), Irish nationalist leader and social reformer; known as the Liberator. His election to Parliament in 1828 forced the British government to grant Catholic Emancipation in order to enable him to take his seat in the House of Commons. In 1839 he established the Repeal Association to abolish the union with Britain.
--Examples--
--Word--
O'Connor, Flannery 
--Type--
proper noun
--Meanings--
(1925–64), American novelist and short-story writer; full name Mary Flannery O'Connor. Notable novels: Wise Blood (1952) and The Violent Bear It Away (1960).

octadecane 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
Any of the series of saturated hydrocarbons (alkanes) having the formula C₁₈H₃₈; specifically (also "n-octadecane") the unbranched isomer CH₃(CH₂)₁₆CH₃.
--Examples--
--Word--
octadecyl 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
Any of the series of hydrocarbon radicals —C₁₈H₃₇ derived from the octadecanes; specifically the straight-chain radical —CH₂(CH₂)₁₆CH₃ (also called stearyl). Usually attributive or a formative element in chemical names.
--Examples--
--Word--
octadic 
--Type--
adjective
--Meanings--
Of or relating to an octad or octads. "octadic surface"noun Geometry. a quartic surface having eight nodes which can be thought of as the intersections of three quadric surfaces.

--Word--
octaeteris 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
In the ancient Greek calendar: a period of eight years, in the course of which three months of 30 days each were intercalated so as to make the year of 12 lunar months correspond with the solar year.

--Word--
octahedron 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A three-dimensional shape having eight plane faces, especially a regular solid figure with eight equal triangular faces.
A body, especially a crystal, in the form of a regular octahedron.
--Examples--
--Word--
octakishexahedron 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A solid figure having forty-eight scalene triangular faces.
--Examples--
--Word--
octal 
--Type--
adjective, noun
--Meanings--
Relating to or using a system of numerical notation that has 8 rather than 10 as a base.
The octal system; octal notation.
--Examples--
‘the calculation should be done in binary or octal’
--Word--
octamer 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A polymeric molecule or structural unit consisting of eight monomers, especially (a section of) a polynucleotide or polypeptide.
--Examples--
--Word--
octamerous 
--Type--
adjective
--Meanings--
Having parts arranged in groups of eight.
Consisting of eight joints or parts.
--Examples--
--Word--
octameter 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A line of verse consisting of eight metrical feet.
--Examples--
--Word--
Octans 
--Type--
proper noun
--Meanings--
A faint southern constellation (the Octant), containing the south celestial pole.
Used with preceding letter or numeral to designate a star in the constellation Octans.
--Examples--
‘the star Delta Octantis’
--Word--
octane 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A colourless flammable hydrocarbon of the alkane series, present in petroleum spirit.

--Examples--
--Word--
octanol 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
Any saturated aliphatic monohydric alcohol of the formula C₈H₁₇OH, of which many isomeric forms exist; especially (a) (also "n-octanol" or "1-octanol") the primary straight-chain isomer, CH₃(CH₂)₆CH₂OH, or (b) (also "2-octanol") the secondary straight-chain isomer, CH₃(CH₂)₅CH(OH)CH₃, both of which are colourless odoriferous liquids used chiefly in the perfume and plastic industries.
--Examples--
--Word--
octanol 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
Any saturated aliphatic monohydric alcohol of the formula C₈H₁₇OH, of which many isomeric forms exist; especially (a) (also "n-octanol" or "1-octanol") the primary straight-chain isomer, CH₃(CH₂)₆CH₂OH, or (b) (also "2-octanol") the secondary straight-chain isomer, CH₃(CH₂)₅CH(OH)CH₃, both of which are colourless odoriferous liquids used chiefly in the perfume and plastic industries.
--Examples--
--Word--
Octans 
--Type--
proper noun
--Meanings--
A faint southern constellation (the Octant), containing the south celestial pole.
Used with preceding letter or numeral to designate a star in the constellation Octans.
--Examples--
‘the star Delta Octantis’
--Word--
octant 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
An arc of a circle equal to one eighth of its circumference, or the area enclosed by such an arc with two radii of the circle.
Each of eight parts into which a space or solid body is divided by three planes which intersect (especially at right angles) at a single point.
An obsolete instrument in the form of a graduated eighth of a circle, used in astronomy and navigation.
--Examples--
--Word--
octantal 
--Type--
adjective
--Meanings--
Of or relating to an octant; specifically recurring in each octant of the compass.
--Examples--
--Word--
octant 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
An arc of a circle equal to one eighth of its circumference, or the area enclosed by such an arc with two radii of the circle.
Each of eight parts into which a space or solid body is divided by three planes which intersect (especially at right angles) at a single point.
An obsolete instrument in the form of a graduated eighth of a circle, used in astronomy and navigation.
--Examples--
--Word--
octapeptide 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A peptide whose molecules are composed of eight amino-acid residues.
--Examples--
--Word--
octapla 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A text consisting of eight versions in parallel columns, especially of the Old or New Testament.
--Examples--
--Word--
octoploid 
--Type--
adjective, noun
--Meanings--
Containing eight homologous sets of chromosomes (i.e. four times the diploid complement); made up of somatic cells of this kind.
An octoploid individual, type, or species.
--Examples--
--Word--
octoploidy 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
The state or condition of being octoploid.

--Type--
adjective
--Meanings--
Relating to, characterized by, or designating a vascular bundle having eight strands of xylem arising from eight distinct points of origin.

--Word--
octastichous 
--Type--
adjective
--Meanings--
Designating or relating to a spiral arrangement of leaves in which there are eight leaves in each turn of the spiral about the stem, and thus eight vertical rows of leaves in the phyllotaxis.
--Examples--
--Word--
octastyle 
--Type--
adjective, noun
--Meanings--
(of a building or portico) having eight columns at the end or in front.
An octastyle portico or building.
--Examples--
--Word--
Octateuch 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
The first eight books of the Old Testament and Hebrew Scriptures collectively; the Pentateuch together with the books of Joshua, Judges, and Ruth.

--Type--

--Meanings--

--Examples--
--Word--
octave 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A series of eight notes occupying the interval between (and including) two notes, one having twice or half the frequency of vibration of the other.
The interval between the two notes at the extremes of an octave.
Each of the two notes at the extremes of an octave.
The two notes at the extremes of an octave sounding together.
A group or stanza of eight lines; an octet.
The seventh day after a Church festival.
A period of eight days beginning with the day of a Church festival.
The last of eight parrying positions.
A wine cask holding an eighth of a pipe.
--Examples--
--Word--
octave 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A series of eight notes occupying the interval between (and including) two notes, one having twice or half the frequency of vibration of the other.
The interval between the two notes at the extremes of an octave.
Each of the two notes at the extremes of an octave.
The two notes at the extremes of an octave sounding together.
A group or stanza of eight lines; an octet.
The seventh day after a Church festival.
A period of eight days beginning with the day of a Church festival.
The last of eight parrying positions.
A wine cask holding an eighth of a pipe.

--Type--
proper noun
--Meanings--
(1838–1912), English housing reformer and co-founder of the National Trust (1895).

Octavian 
--Type--
proper noun
--Meanings--
The name generally used for Augustus, the first Roman emperor, in reference to events before 27 BC.

--Word--
octavic 
--Type--
adjective, noun
--Meanings--
Of the eighth degree or order; = octic.
An octavic equation, expression, or curve; = octic.
--Examples--
--Word--
octavo 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A size of book page that results from folding each printed sheet into eight leaves (sixteen pages)
A book of octavo size.
--Examples--
‘foolscap octavo’
‘three octavo volumes’

noun

octile 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
Statistics. Each of the seven values of a variate which divide a frequency distribution into eight groups each containing one eighth of the total population; (usually) specifically the first or seventh of these values.

Octodon 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A genus of rat-like rodents (the degus) of the family Octodontidae, native to the Andes and western coastal areas of South America; (also octodon) a rodent of this genus, a degu (now rare).
--Examples--
--Word--
octodont 
--Type--
adjective, noun
--Meanings--
Of or relating to the genus Octodon or the family Octodontidae, containing the degus and related rodents.
An octodont rodent; a degu.

--Word--
octonion 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A type of hypercomplex number with eight coefficients, having the form x = x0 + x1e1 + x2e2 + x3e3 + x4e4 + x5e5 + x6e6 + x7e7, where the xn are real numbers and the en are imaginary units which, in conjunction with 1 and −1, form a closed, non-commutative, non-associative system under multiplication.
--Examples--
--Word--
octopartite 
--Type--
adjective
--Meanings--
Divided into or consisting of eight parts. Formerly: (Law) †(of a contract, indenture, etc.) drawn up in eight corresponding parts, one for each party (obsolete)..
--Examples--
--Word--

--Word--
octopine 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
An amino acid of the opine group, C₉H₁₈N₄O₄, found in the tissues of some cephalopods and lamellibranch molluscs and also synthesized by plant cells infected by certain strains of the crown gall pathogen Agrobacterium tumefaciens.
--Examples--
--Word--

octopodous 
--Type--
adjective
--Meanings--
Originally: of, relating to, or designating the order Octopoda of cephalopod molluscs, comprising the octopuses; = "octopod". Later (also): = "octopoid".

--Type--
noun
--Meanings--

--Word--
octuple 
--Type--
adjective, verb
--Meanings--
Consisting of eight parts or things.
Eight times as many or as much.
Make or become eight times as numerous or as large.
--Examples--
‘each over-amplified leap or octuple pirouette’
‘their album went octuple-platinum’
‘the new town populations have trebled the additions to the rural community, and in the case of Massachusetts have octupled them’
‘prices doubled and quadruple and octupled’

--Word--
oculate 
--Type--
adjective
--Meanings--
Chiefly Botany and Zoology. Originally: having markings resembling an eye or eyes, ocellated; (also) †having holes resembling eyes (obsolete). Later (also): having eyes, or large or well-developed eyes.
--Examples--
--Word--
oculated 
--Type--
adjective
--Meanings--
Ocellated.
--Examples--
--Word--

adjective
--Meanings--
Of or relating to the eyes and the head; specifically designating or relating to reflex movement of the eyes when the head is passively turned (normally to the side opposite to that in which the head is turned), used in the assessment of level of consciousness.
--Examples--

oculus 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A round or eye-like opening or design.
A circular window.
The central boss of a volute.
An opening at the apex of a dome.
--Examples--
--Word--
od 
--Type--
noun, noun, verb, noun, abbreviation
--Meanings--
A hypothetical power once thought to pervade nature and account for various phenomena, such as magnetism.
An archaic euphemism for God, used in exclamations.
Take an overdose of a drug.
Have too much of something.
An overdose of a narcotic drug.
Ordnance datum.
Odisha.
--Examples--
‘ods blood!’
‘Spike had OD'd on barbiturates’
‘I almost OD'd on mushroom salad’
--Word--
oda 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
In the Ottoman Empire and Turkey: a room or chamber; specifically (now historical) (a) the barracks of the janissaries; (b) a room in a harem; (also, in extended use) the women in a harem collectively.
--Examples--
--Word--
odic 
--Type--
adjective
--Meanings--
--Examples--
--Word--
odalisque 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A female slave or concubine in a harem, especially one in the seraglio of the Sultan of Turkey.
An exotic, sexually attractive woman.
--Examples--
‘you do not have to learn to paint an odalisque like Matisse’
--Word--
odd 
--Type--
adjective
--Meanings--
Different to what is usual or expected; strange.
(of whole numbers such as 3 and 5) having one left over as a remainder when divided by two.
In the region of or somewhat more than a particular number or quantity.
Denoting a single goal by which one side defeats another, especially where each side scores at least once.
Happening or occurring infrequently and irregularly; occasional.
Spare; unoccupied.
Separated from a usual pair or set and therefore out of place or mismatched.
--Examples--
‘the neighbours thought him very odd’
‘it's odd that she didn't recognize me’
‘atoms which possess an odd number of electrons’
‘she looked younger than her fifty-odd years’
‘they lost a close-fought game by the odd goal in five’
‘we have the odd drink together’
‘when you've got an odd five minutes, could I have a word?’
‘he's wearing odd socks’
--Word--
oddball 
--Type--
noun, adjective
--Meanings--
A strange or eccentric person.
Strange; bizarre.
--Examples--
‘she was seen as a bit of an oddball’
‘oddball training methods’

--Word--
odd-come-short 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
An unspecified day or time in the future; = odd-come-shortly. Usually in "one of these odd-come-shorts": one of these days.
An odd or eccentric person; a misfit.
--Examples--
--Word--
odd-come-shortly 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
Used to denote an unspecified time in the near future. Usually in "one of these odd-come-shortlies" (also "some odd-come-shortly"): one of these days; some day shortly.
--Examples--

--Word--
odds 
--Type--
plural noun
--Meanings--
The ratio between the amounts staked by the parties to a bet, based on the expected probability either way.
The chances or likelihood of something happening or being the case.
The balance of advantage; superiority in strength, power, or resources.
--Examples--
‘Nicer is starting at odds of 8-1’
‘it is possible for the race to be won at very long odds’
‘the odds are that he is no longer alive’
‘the odds against this ever happening are high’
‘she clung to the lead against all the odds’
‘the odds were overwhelmingly in favour of the banks rather than the customer’

odds-on

adjective

--Word--
sounding 
--Type--
noun, adjective
--Meanings--
The action of measuring the depth of a body of water.
A measurement taken by sounding.
The determination of any physical property at a depth in the sea or at a height in the atmosphere.
The area of sea close to the shore which is shallow enough for the bottom to be reached by means of a sounding line.
Information or evidence ascertained as a preliminary step before taking action.
Giving forth sound, especially loud or resonant sound.
Having an imposing sound but little substance.
--Examples--
‘he took soundings about the possibility of moving offices’
‘he went in with a sounding plunge’
‘the orator has been apt to deal in sounding commonplaces’

noun
--Meanings--

--Type--
proper noun
--Meanings--

Odets, Clifford 
--Type--
proper noun
--Meanings--
(1906–63), American playwright. He was a founder member in 1931 of the avant-garde Group Theatre, which staged his best-known play, Waiting for Lefty (1935).
--Examples--
--Word--
Hallowes, Odette 
--Type--
proper noun
--Meanings--
(1912–95), French heroine of the Second World War; born Marie Céline. She worked as a British secret agent in occupied France from 1942 until captured in 1943. Imprisoned for two years, she refused to betray her associates in spite of torture and was awarded the George Cross in 1946.

--Type--
proper noun
--Meanings--

Odyssean 
--Type--
adjective
--Meanings--
Relating to or characteristic of the Odyssey, especially in being long and eventful.
--Examples--

--Word--
Odyssey 
--Type--
proper noun
--Meanings--
A Greek hexameter epic poem traditionally ascribed to Homer, describing the travels of Odysseus during his ten years of wandering after the sack of Troy. He eventually returned home to Ithaca and killed the suitors who had plagued his wife Penelope during his absence.
A long and eventful or adventurous journey or experience.
--Examples--
‘his odyssey from military man to politician’
--Word--
Odyssey 
--Type--
proper noun
--Meanings--
A Greek hexameter epic poem traditionally ascribed to Homer, describing the travels of Odysseus during his ten years of wandering after the sack of Troy. He eventually returned home to Ithaca and killed the suitors who had plagued his wife Penelope during his absence.
A long and eventful or adventurous journey or experience.
--Examples--
‘his odyssey from military man to politician’

Odysseus 
--Type--

--Meanings--
The king of Ithaca and central figure of the Odyssey, renowned for his cunning and resourcefulness.

odograph 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A device for automatically recording the course of a vehicle. Also (in early use): an instrument for measuring the length of stride of a person, animal, etc., and the number of paces taken.

--Word--
Odonata 
--Type--
plural noun
--Meanings--
An order of predatory insects that comprises the dragonflies and damselflies. They have long, slender bodies, two pairs of membranous wings, large compound eyes, and aquatic larvae.
Insects of the order Odonata; dragonflies and damselflies.
--Examples--
‘Tyndall blue occurs in some odonata’
--Word--
odonate 
--Type--

--Meanings--

Relating to or denoting odonates.

--Word--
O'Donnell, Rosie 
--Type--
proper noun
--Meanings--
(born 1962), US comedian, actress, and talk show host; full name Roseann O'Donnell. On television, she hosted The Rosie O'Donnell Show (1996–2002) and cohosted The View (2006–07). Her acting credits include the revival of the Broadway musical Grease (1994) and the movies A League of Their Own (1992) and Harriet the Spy (1996).

odontoma 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A tumour arising in connection with the teeth; (later) specifically a growth resulting from anomalous odontogenesis and consisting of dental tissues of epithelial and mesodermal origin (enamel, dentine, and cementum), sometimes organized into the form of a tooth or teeth.

oestrogen 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
Any of a group of steroid hormones which promote the development and maintenance of female characteristics of the body. Such hormones are also produced artificially for use in oral contraceptives or to treat menopausal and menstrual disorders.

--Word--
of 
--Type--
preposition
--Meanings--
Expressing the relationship between a part and a whole.
With the word denoting the part functioning as the head of the phrase.
After a number, quantifier, or partitive noun, with the word denoting the whole functioning as the head of the phrase.
Expressing the relationship between a scale or measure and a value.
Expressing an age.
Indicating an association between two entities, typically one of belonging, in which the first is the head of the phrase and the second is something associated with it.
Expressing the relationship between an author, artist, or composer and their works collectively.
Expressing the relationship between a direction and a point of reference.
Expressing the relationship between a general category or type and the thing being specified which belongs to such a category.
Following a noun derived from or related to a verb.
Followed by a noun expressing the subject of the verb underlying the first noun.
Followed by a noun expressing the object of the verb underlying the first noun.
Where the head of the phrase is a predicative adjective.
Indicating the relationship between a verb and an indirect object.
With a verb expressing a mental state.
Expressing a cause.
Indicating the material or substance constituting something.
Expressing time in relation to the following hour.
--Examples--
‘the sleeve of his coat’
‘in the back of the car’
‘the days of the week’
‘nine of the children came to the show’
‘a series of programmes’
‘a piece of cake’
‘an increase of 5%’
‘a height of 10 metres’
‘a boy of 15’
‘the son of a friend’
‘the government of India’
‘a photograph of the bride’
‘a former colleague of John's’
‘the plays of Shakespeare’
‘the paintings of Rembrandt’
‘north of Watford’
‘the city of Prague’
‘the idea of a just society’
‘the population of interbreeding individuals’
‘this type of book’
‘the arrival of the police’
‘the decision of the County Council’
‘the howling of the wind’
‘the murder of the two boys’
‘payment of his debts’
‘an admirer of Dickens’
‘I am certain of that’
‘it was kind of you to ask’
‘I am certain of that’
‘I don't know of anything that would be suitable’
‘he died of cancer’
‘the house was built of bricks’
‘walls of stone’
‘it would be just a quarter of three in New York’

--Word--
off 
--Type--
adverb, preposition, adjective, noun, verb
--Meanings--
Away from the place in question; to or at a distance.
Away from the main route.
So as to be removed or separated.
Absent; away from work.
Starting a journey or race; leaving.
So as to bring to an end or be discontinued.
Cancelled.
(of an item on a menu) temporarily unavailable.
(of an electrical appliance or power supply) not functioning or so as to cease to function.
Having access to or possession of material goods or wealth to the extent specified.
(with preceding numeral) denoting a quantity produced at one time.
Moving away and often down from.
Situated or leading in a direction away from (a main route or intersection)
Out at sea from (a place on the coast)
So as to be removed or separated from.
Absent from.
Abstaining from.
Having a temporary dislike of.
Characterized by performing or feeling worse than usual; unsatisfactory or inadequate.
Unwell.
(of food) no longer fresh.
Located on the side of a vehicle that is normally furthest from the kerb; offside.
Annoying or unfair.
Unfriendly or hostile.
The half of the field (as divided lengthways through the pitch) towards which the batsman's feet are pointed when standing to receive the ball.
The start of a race, journey, or experience.
Leave.
Kill; murder.
--Examples--
‘the man ran off’
‘she dashed off to her room’
‘we must be off now’
‘turn off for Ripon’
‘he whipped off his coat’
‘a section of the runway had been cordoned off’
‘take a day off’
‘he is off on sick leave’
‘we're off on holiday tomorrow’
‘the gunmen made off on foot’
‘they're off!’
‘the Christmas party rounded off a hugely successful year’
‘she broke off her reading to look at her husband’
‘tell them the wedding's off’
‘strawberries are off’
‘switch the TV off’
‘the electricity was off for four days’
‘we'd been rather badly off for books’
‘how are you off for money?’
‘he rolled off the bed’
‘the coat slipped off his arms’
‘trying to get us off the stage’
‘single wires leading off the main lines’
‘in a little street off Whitehall’
‘anchoring off Blue Bay’
‘six miles off Dunkirk’
‘threatening to tear the door off its hinges’
‘they knocked $2,000 off the price’
‘it's a huge burden off my shoulders’
‘I took a couple of days off work’
‘he managed to stay off alcohol’
‘he's running a temperature and he's off his food’
‘even the greatest athletes have off days’
‘I felt decidedly off’
‘the fish was a bit off’
‘His boss deducted the money from his pay. That was a bit off’
‘there's no one there except the barmaid, and she's a bit off’
‘now Ian is ready for the off’
‘supposedly loyal workers suddenly upped and offed to the new firms’
‘I finally snapped and offed the guy’
--Word--
off 
--Type--
adverb, preposition, adjective, noun, verb
--Meanings--
Away from the place in question; to or at a distance.
Away from the main route.
So as to be removed or separated.
Absent; away from work.
Starting a journey or race; leaving.
So as to bring to an end or be discontinued.
Cancelled.
(of an item on a menu) temporarily unavailable.
(of an electrical appliance or power supply) not functioning or so as to cease to function.
Having access to or possession of material goods or wealth to the extent specified.
(with preceding numeral) denoting a quantity produced at one time.
Moving away and often down from.
Situated or leading in a direction away from (a main route or intersection)
Out at sea from (a place on the coast)
So as to be removed or separated from.
Absent from.
Abstaining from.
Having a temporary dislike of.
Characterized by performing or feeling worse than usual; unsatisfactory or inadequate.
Unwell.
(of food) no longer fresh.
Located on the side of a vehicle that is normally furthest from the kerb; offside.
Annoying or unfair.
Unfriendly or hostile.
The half of the field (as divided lengthways through the pitch) towards which the batsman's feet are pointed when standing to receive the ball.
The start of a race, journey, or experience.
Leave.
Kill; murder.
