‘threatening to tear the door off its hinges’
‘they knocked $2,000 off the price’
‘it's a huge burden off my shoulders’
‘I took a couple of days off work’
‘he managed to stay off alcohol’
‘he's running a temperature and he's off his food’
‘even the greatest athletes have off days’
‘I felt decidedly off’
‘the fish was a bit off’
‘His boss deducted the money from his pay. That was a bit off’
‘there's no one there except the barmaid, and she's a bit off’
‘now Ian is ready for the off’
‘supposedly loyal workers suddenly upped and offed to the new firms’
‘I finally snapped and offed the guy’

--Type--

--Word--
offa 
--Type--
preposition, proper noun
--Meanings--
Off.
(d.796), king of Mercia 757–96. He organized the construction of Offa's Dyke.
--Examples--
‘get offa your horse!’

question of fact 
--Type--
phrase
--Meanings--
An issue to be decided by a jury.

--Word--
offal 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
The entrails and internal organs of an animal used as food.
Waste material.
Decomposing animal flesh.
--Examples--
‘eating pieces of braised offal turned his stomach’
‘a ban on infective offals being fed to pigs’
‘beef offal’
‘the packing plant dumped its offal into the stream’
‘gulls pecking at piles of offal from the narwhal hunt’

verb

--Type--
adjective, noun
--Meanings--
Not coinciding with the beat.

‘the horns come in full-force on the offbeats’

--Word--
off-Broadway 
--Type--
UnKnownKind, noun
--Meanings--
(in New York City) of, in, or denoting a class of theatres which are smaller than and located apart from those in the Broadway theatre district and typically stage less expensive or commercial productions.
Off-Broadway theatres and productions collectively.
--Examples--
‘off-Broadway musicals’
‘this was a surprise hit when it opened off-Broadway in the spring’
‘he won off-Broadway's equivalent of the Tony’

--Word--
off 
--Type--
adverb, preposition, adjective, noun, verb
--Meanings--
Away from the place in question; to or at a distance.
Away from the main route.
So as to be removed or separated.
Absent; away from work.
Starting a journey or race; leaving.
So as to bring to an end or be discontinued.
Cancelled.
(of an item on a menu) temporarily unavailable.
(of an electrical appliance or power supply) not functioning or so as to cease to function.
Having access to or possession of material goods or wealth to the extent specified.
(with preceding numeral) denoting a quantity produced at one time.
Moving away and often down from.
Situated or leading in a direction away from (a main route or intersection)
Out at sea from (a place on the coast)
So as to be removed or separated from.
Absent from.
Abstaining from.
Having a temporary dislike of.
Characterized by performing or feeling worse than usual; unsatisfactory or inadequate.
Unwell.
(of food) no longer fresh.
Located on the side of a vehicle that is normally furthest from the kerb; offside.
Annoying or unfair.
Unfriendly or hostile.
The half of the field (as divided lengthways through the pitch) towards which the batsman's feet are pointed when standing to receive the ball.
The start of a race, journey, or experience.
Leave.
Kill; murder.
--Examples--
‘the man ran off’
‘she dashed off to her room’
‘we must be off now’
‘turn off for Ripon’
‘he whipped off his coat’
‘a section of the runway had been cordoned off’
‘take a day off’
‘he is off on sick leave’
‘we're off on holiday tomorrow’
‘the gunmen made off on foot’
‘they're off!’
‘the Christmas party rounded off a hugely successful year’
‘she broke off her reading to look at her husband’
‘tell them the wedding's off’
‘strawberries are off’
‘switch the TV off’
‘the electricity was off for four days’
‘we'd been rather badly off for books’
‘how are you off for money?’

‘the coat slipped off his arms’
‘trying to get us off the stage’
‘single wires leading off the main lines’

--Word--
Offenbach, Jacques 
--Type--
proper noun
--Meanings--
(1819–80), German composer, resident in France from 1833; born Jacob Offenbach. He is associated with the rise of the operetta, whose style is typified by his Orpheus in the Underworld (1858). Other notable works: The Tales of Hoffmann (1881).
--Examples--
--Word--
offence 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A breach of a law or rule; an illegal act.
A thing that constitutes a violation of what is judged to be right or natural.
Annoyance or resentment brought about by a perceived insult to or disregard for oneself.
The action of attacking someone or something.
The attacking team or players in a sport, especially in American football.
--Examples--
‘the new offence of obtaining property by deception’
‘the outcome is an offence to basic justice’
‘he made it clear he'd taken offence’
‘I didn't intend to give offence’
‘reductions in strategic offence arsenals’
‘he is a wide receiver, playing on offense’
--Word--

--Meanings--

offensive 
--Type--
adjective, noun
--Meanings--
Causing someone to feel resentful, upset, or annoyed.
(of a sight or smell) disgusting; repulsive.
Actively aggressive; attacking.
(of a weapon) meant for use in attack.
Relating to the team in possession of the ball or puck in a game.
An attacking military campaign.
An organized and forceful campaign to achieve something, typically a political or social end.
--Examples--
‘the allegations made are deeply offensive to us’
‘offensive language’
‘an offensive odour’
‘offensive operations against the insurgents’
‘he is also accused of possessing an offensive weapon’
‘Shell was an outstanding offensive tackle during his 15 years with the Raiders’
‘an impending military offensive against the guerrillas’
‘the need to launch an offensive against crime’

--Word--
offer 
--Type--
verb, noun
--Meanings--
Present or proffer (something) for (someone) to accept or reject as desired.
Express readiness to do something for or on behalf of someone.
Make available for sale.
Present (a prayer or sacrifice) to a deity.
Provide (access or an opportunity)
Make an attempt at or show one's readiness for (violence or resistance)
Give an opportunity for (battle) to an enemy.
Put something in place to assess its appearance or fit.
An expression of readiness to do or give something if desired.
An amount of money that someone is willing to pay for something.
A specially reduced price.
A proposal of marriage.
--Examples--
‘may I offer you a drink?’
‘I was offered a job on the spot’
‘he offered to fix the gate’
‘‘Can I help you, dear?’ a kindly voice offered’
‘the product is offered at a very competitive price’
‘villagers have gone to offer prayers for the souls of the sailors’
‘the three imams offer up prayers on behalf of the dead’
‘the Coast Road offers easy access to the Nine Glens of Antrim’
‘the opportunities which the economic recovery will offer’
‘he had to offer some resistance to her tirade’
‘Darius was about to meet him and to offer battle’
‘the infill panels are offered up and bolted in position’
‘sympathetic offers of help’
‘he had accepted Mallory's offer to buy him a drink’
‘the prospective purchaser who made the highest offer’
‘the offer runs right up until Christmas Eve’
‘the conceited wretch chose to interpret my amiability of temper his own way, and at length he actually made me an offer’

--Word--
off-falling 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--

--Word--
off-flavour 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A stale, rancid, or unnatural flavour in food.
--Examples--
--Word--
flow 
--Type--
verb, noun
--Meanings--
(of a liquid, gas, or electricity) move steadily and continuously in a current or stream.
(of the sea or a tidal river) move towards the land; rise.
Go from one place to another in a steady stream, typically in large numbers.
Proceed or be produced continuously and effortlessly.
(of clothing or hair) hang loosely in an easy and graceful manner.
Be available in copious quantities.
Be caused by.
(of a solid) undergo a permanent change of shape under stress, without melting.
The action or fact of moving along in a steady, continuous stream.
The rate or speed at which something flows.
The rise of a tide or a river.
A steady, continuous stream or supply of something.
A watery swamp; a morass.
The gradual permanent deformation of a solid under stress, without melting.
--Examples--
‘from here the river flows north’
‘ventilation channels keep the air flowing’
‘people flowed into the huge courtyard’
‘talk flowed freely around the table’
‘her red hair flowed over her shoulders’
‘their talk and laughter grew louder as the excellent brandy flowed’
‘there are certain advantages that may flow from that decision’
‘the flow of water into the pond’
‘under the ford the river backs up, giving a deep sluggish flow’
‘a constant flow of people’
‘the flow of words was interrupted by painful sobs’
--Word--
off-glide 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A glide terminating the articulation of a speech sound, when the vocal organs either return to a neutral position or adopt a position anticipating the formation of the next sound.
--Examples--
--Word--
go off 
--Type--
phrasal verb
--Meanings--
(of a gun, bomb, or similar device) explode or fire.
(of an alarm) begin to sound.
(of food or drink) begin to decompose and become inedible.
Begin to dislike.
Go to sleep.
Gradually cease to be felt.
--Examples--
‘the pistol suddenly went off’
‘milk went off so quickly in hot weather’
‘I went off chocolate when i was pregnant’
‘I had a bad headache but it's going off now’
--Word--
off-going 
--Type--
adjective
--Meanings--
That goes off or away, or is being removed.
--Examples--

off guard 
--Type--
phrase
--Meanings--

--Examples--
‘the government was caught off guard by the unexpected announcement’
--Word--
offhand 
--Type--
adjective, adverb
--Meanings--
Ungraciously or offensively nonchalant or cool in manner.
Without previous thought or consideration.
--Examples--
‘you were a bit offhand with her this afternoon’
‘I can't think of a better answer offhand’

--Type--
abbreviation
--Meanings--
Office.
Officer.
--Examples--
--Word--
office 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A room, set of rooms, or building used as a place for commercial, professional, or bureaucratic work.
The local centre of a large business.
A room, department, or building used to provide a particular service.
The consulting room of a professional person.
A position of authority or service, typically one of a public nature.
Tenure of an official position, especially that of a Minister of State or of the party forming the government.
The quarters, staff, or collective authority of a particular government department or agency.
A service done for another or others.
A duty attaching to one's position.
The series of services of prayers and psalms said (or chanted) daily by Catholic priests, members of religious orders, and other clergy.
A service conducted daily as part of the office.
The parts of a house given over to household work or to storage.
A toilet.
--Examples--
‘an office job’
‘a company which has four US and four European offices’
‘a ticket office’
‘a Post Office’
‘a patient walks in to a doctor's office’
‘the office of chief constable’
‘a year ago, when the President took office’
‘he was ejected from office in 1988’
‘the Foreign Office’
‘rescued through the good offices of the Italian Ambassador, he was returned safely to England’
‘the offices of a nurse’
‘the noon office’

--Word--
officer 
--Type--
noun, verb
--Meanings--
A person holding a position of authority, especially one with a commission, in the armed services, the mercantile marine, or on a passenger ship.
A policeman or policewoman.
A bailiff.
A holder of a public, civil, or ecclesiastical office.
A holder of a senior post in a society, company, or other organization.
A member of a certain grade in some honorary orders, such as the grade next below commander in the Order of the British Empire.
Provide with military officers.
Act as the commander of (a unit)
--Examples--
‘he is also a serving officer in the army’
‘Special Constables provide valuable support to full-time officers’
‘tougher sentences for attacks on police officers’
‘a probation officer’
‘the Chief Medical Officer’
‘a chief executive officer’
‘the aristocracy wielded considerable power, officering the army’
‘foreign mercenaries were hired to officer new regiments’

--Word--
official 
--Type--
adjective, noun
--Meanings--
Relating to an authority or public body and its activities and responsibilities.
Having the approval or authorization of an authority or public body.
Employed by an authority or public body in a position of authority.
A person holding public office or having official duties, especially as a representative of an organization or government department.
The presiding officer or judge of an archbishop's, bishop's, or archdeacon's court.
--Examples--
‘the prime minister's official engagements’
‘members would know when industrial action is official’
‘official statistics’
‘an official spokesman’
‘a union official’

noun

--Word--
officially 
--Type--
adverb
--Meanings--
In a formal and public way.
With the authority of the government or other organization.
In public and for official purposes but not necessarily so in reality.
--Examples--
‘on June 24 the election campaign will officially begin’
‘it was officially acknowledged that the economy was in recession’
‘there is a possibility he was murdered—officially, he died in a car smash’

--Word--
offlap 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A progressive diminution in the lateral extent of sedimentary deposits in passing upwards from older to younger strata, so that each stratum leaves a portion of the underlying one exposed; a set of strata exhibiting this, typically as a result of regression of a shoreline. Contrasted with onlap.
--Examples--
--Word--
offlet

--Meanings--

--Word--
offload 
--Type--
verb
--Meanings--
Unload (a cargo)
Rid oneself of (something) by selling or passing it on to someone else.
Relieve oneself of (a problem or worry) by talking to someone else.
Move (data or a task) from one processor to another in order to free the first processor for other tasks.
--Examples--
‘a delivery could be offloaded immediately on arrival’
‘a dealer offloaded 5,000 of these shares on a client’
‘it would be nice to have been able to offload your worries on to someone’
‘a system designed to offload the text on to a host computer’

--Word--
loading 
--Type--
noun, adjective
--Meanings--
The application of a mechanical load or force to something.
The amount of electric current or power delivered to a device.
The maximum electric current or power taken by an appliance.
The provision of extra electrical inductance to improve the properties of a transmission wire or aerial.
An increase in an insurance premium due to a factor increasing the risk involved.
An increment added to a basic wage for special skills or qualifications.
(of a gun, machine, or lorry) loaded in a specified way.
--Examples--
‘the branches of a tree diminish in cross section according to their loading’
‘a front-loading dishwasher’

--Word--
look 
--Type--
verb, noun, exclamation
--Meanings--
Direct one's gaze in a specified direction.
(of a building or room) have an outlook in a specified direction.
Ignore (someone) by pretending not to see them.
Express (something) by one's gaze.
Inspect something with a view to establishing its merits.
Peruse (a book or other written material)
Walk round (a place or building) in order to view any interesting features.
Ascertain with a quick glance.
Regard in a specified way.
Examine (a matter) and consider what action to take.
Investigate.
Attempt to find.
Have the appearance or give the impression of being.
Show a likelihood of.
Appear one's normal, healthy self.
Rely on (someone) to do or provide something.
Hope or expect to do something.
Take care; make sure.
An act of directing one's gaze in order to see someone or something.
An expression of a feeling or thought by looking.
A scrutiny or examination.
The appearance of someone or something, especially as expressing a particular quality.
A person's facial appearance considered aesthetically.
A style or fashion.
Used to call attention to what one is going to say.
--Examples--
‘people were looking at him’
‘they looked up as he came into the room’
‘the room looks out over Mylor Harbour’
‘he glanced up once but looked right through me’
‘Poirot looked a question’
‘they looked over a property in Great Marlborough Street’
‘we looked through all the books and this was still the one we liked best’
‘he spent the day looking round Edinburgh’
‘people finishing work don't look where they're going’
‘I look at tennis differently from some coaches’
‘a committee is looking at the financing of the BBC’
‘the police looked into his business dealings’
‘Howard has been looking for you’
‘mum looked unhappy’
‘the home looked like a prison’
‘a funny-looking bloke’

off-reckoning 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
Usually in plural A deduction, specifically one formerly made from the pay of a British soldier, sailor, etc., and put into a special account made available by the government to the commanding officers of regiments to provide for the men's expenses and needs (as food, clothing, etc.). Hence also: the account or fund itself.
--Examples--
--Word--
off 
--Type--
adverb, preposition, adjective, noun, verb
--Meanings--
Away from the place in question; to or at a distance.
Away from the main route.
So as to be removed or separated.
Absent; away from work.
Starting a journey or race; leaving.
So as to bring to an end or be discontinued.
Cancelled.
(of an item on a menu) temporarily unavailable.
(of an electrical appliance or power supply) not functioning or so as to cease to function.
Having access to or possession of material goods or wealth to the extent specified.
(with preceding numeral) denoting a quantity produced at one time.
Moving away and often down from.
Situated or leading in a direction away from (a main route or intersection)
Out at sea from (a place on the coast)
So as to be removed or separated from.
Absent from.
Abstaining from.
Having a temporary dislike of.
Characterized by performing or feeling worse than usual; unsatisfactory or inadequate.
Unwell.
(of food) no longer fresh.
Located on the side of a vehicle that is normally furthest from the kerb; offside.
Annoying or unfair.
Unfriendly or hostile.
The half of the field (as divided lengthways through the pitch) towards which the batsman's feet are pointed when standing to receive the ball.
The start of a race, journey, or experience.
Leave.
Kill; murder.
--Examples--

‘she dashed off to her room’
‘we must be off now’
‘turn off for Ripon’
‘he whipped off his coat’
‘a section of the runway had been cordoned off’

‘he is off on sick leave’
‘we're off on holiday tomorrow’
‘the gunmen made off on foot’

--Word--
offset 
--Type--
noun, verb
--Meanings--
A consideration or amount that diminishes or balances the effect of an opposite one.
The amount or distance by which something is out of line.
A short distance measured perpendicularly from the main line of measurement.
A small deviation or bias in a voltage or current.
A side shoot from a plant serving for propagation.
A spur in a mountain range.
A sloping ledge in a wall or other feature where the thickness of the part above is diminished.
A bend in a pipe to carry it past an obstacle.
A method of printing in which ink is transferred from a plate or stone to a uniform rubber surface and from that to the paper.
Counteract (something) by having an equal and opposite force or effect.
Place out of line.
(of ink or a freshly printed page) transfer an impression to the next leaf or sheet.
--Examples--
‘widow's bereavement allowance is an offset against income’
‘these wheels have an offset of four inches’
‘offset adjustment circuits’
‘a present of tulip bulbs, offsets, and seeds for his garden’
‘allow for any bend you need including offsets for connecting the downpipe’
‘they produced banknotes by offset’
‘offset printing’
‘donations to charities can be offset against tax’
‘his unfortunate appearance was offset by a compelling personality’
‘several places where the ridge was offset at right angles to its length’
‘there was some offsetting on to text’

--Word--
tone 
--Type--
noun, verb
--Meanings--
A musical or vocal sound with reference to its pitch, quality, and strength.
A modulation of the voice expressing a particular feeling or mood.
A musical note or other sound used as a signal on a telephone or answering machine.
The general character or attitude of a place, piece of writing, situation, etc.
An atmosphere of respectability or class.
A basic interval in classical Western music, equal to two semitones and separating, for example, the first and second notes of an ordinary scale (such as C and D, or E and F sharp); a major second.
The particular quality of brightness, deepness, or hue of a shade of a colour.
The general effect of colour or of light and shade in a picture.
A slight degree of difference in the intensity of a colour.
(in some languages, such as Chinese) a particular pitch pattern on a syllable used to make semantic distinctions.
(in some languages, such as English) intonation on a word or phrase used to add functional meaning.
The normal level of firmness or slight contraction in a resting muscle.
The normal level of activity in a nerve fibre.
Give greater strength or firmness to (the body or a muscle)
(of a muscle or other bodily part) became stronger or firmer.
Harmonize with (something) in terms of colour.
Give (a monochrome picture) an altered colour in finishing by means of a chemical solution.
tone something down
Make something less harsh in sound or colour.
Make something less extreme or intense.
--Examples--
‘they were speaking in hushed tones’
‘the piano tone appears lacking in warmth’
‘a firm tone of voice’
‘my friend and I lowered the tone with our oafish ways’
‘there was a general tone of ill-concealed glee in the reporting’
‘they don't feel he gives the place tone’
‘the B flat clarinet's part is written one tone higher than the pitch required’
‘stained glass in vivid tones of red and blue’
‘an attractive colour which is even in tone and texture’
‘a reduction of muscle tone’
‘a certain amount of daily exercise is essential to maintain proper body tone and function’
‘vagal tone’
‘exercise tones up the muscles’
‘his leg muscles had toned up’
‘the rich orange colour of the wood tones beautifully with the yellow roses’
‘it's a good idea to sepia tone the whole print first’
‘a green-tinged moisturizer helps to tone down a ruddy complexion’
‘I just hope we can now begin to tone down the rhetoric’

--Word--
wheel 
--Type--
noun, verb
--Meanings--
A circular object that revolves on an axle and is fixed below a vehicle or other object to enable it to move easily over the ground.
A circular object that revolves on an axle and forms part of a machine.
Used in reference to the cycle of a specified condition or set of events.
A large wheel used as an instrument of punishment or torture, especially by binding someone to it and breaking their limbs.
A machine or structure having a wheel as its essential part.
The steering wheel of a vehicle or vessel.
A device with a revolving disc or drum used in various games of chance.
A system, or a part of a system, regarded as a relentlessly moving machine.
A car.
A thing resembling a wheel, in particular a cheese made in the form of a shallow disc.
An instance of wheeling; a turn or rotation.
A set of short lines, typically five in number and rhyming, concluding the stanza of a poem.
Push or pull (a vehicle with wheels)
Carry in or on a vehicle with wheels.
Produce something that is unimpressive because it has been frequently seen or heard before.
(of a bird or aircraft) fly in a wide circle or curve.
Turn round quickly so as to face another way.
Turn or seem to turn on an axis or pivot.
--Examples--
‘a chair on wheels’
‘the final release from the wheel of life’
‘a man sentenced to be broken on the wheel’
‘his crew know when he wants to take the wheel’
‘the wheels of justice’
‘she's got wheels now’
‘a small wheel of Brie’
‘the tea trolley was wheeled out’
‘a young woman is wheeled into the operating theatre’
‘the old journalistic arguments have been wheeled out’
‘the birds wheeled and dived’
‘Robert wheeled round to see the face of Mr Mafouz’
‘the stars wheeled through the sky’

Oghuz 
--Type--
noun, adjective
--Meanings--
A member of a group of Turkic peoples who invaded Persia, Syria, and Asia Minor from central Asia in the 11th cent. and settled in Anatolia, or a descendant of these peoples.
Of or relating to the Oghuz; designating an Ohguz.
Designating or relating to a branch of the Turkic language family (in some classifications called south-western Turkic, in others southern Turkic), including Turkish and Azerbaijani. Also: designating or characteristic of the ancient language of the Oghuz or modern dialects of Uzbek and Turkish influenced by it.

--Word--
Oglethorpe, James 
--Type--
proper noun
--Meanings--
(1696–1785), British soldier and politician; full name James Edward Oglethorpe. A member of Parliament 1722–54, he received the charter for the colony of Georgia in 1732 and founded Savannah 1733. In 1742, he assured the survival of Georgia by defeating the Spanish at Bloody Marsh.

OGPU 
--Type--
proper noun
--Meanings--

O'Higgins, Bernardo 
--Type--
proper noun
--Meanings--
(c.1778–1842), Chilean revolutionary leader and statesman, head of state 1817–23. With the help of José de San Martín he led the army which defeated Spanish forces in 1817 and paved the way for Chilean independence the following year.

--Word--
oil 
--Type--
noun, verb
--Meanings--
A viscous liquid derived from petroleum, especially for use as a fuel or lubricant.
Petroleum.
Any of various viscous liquids which are insoluble in water but soluble in organic solvents and are obtained from animals or plants.
A liquid preparation used on the hair or skin as a cosmetic.
Any of a group of natural esters of glycerol and various fatty acids, which are liquid at room temperature.
Oil paint.
An oil painting.
Information or facts.
Lubricate, coat, or impregnate with oil.
Supply with oil as fuel.
--Examples--
‘400 birds were coated with oil which spilled out from an opened valve’
‘the oil industry’
‘potatoes fried in vegetable oil’
‘suntan oil’
‘a portrait in oils’
‘a dark discoloured oil of an elderly cleric’
‘Young had some good oil on the Adelaide races’
‘a lightly oiled baking tray’
‘attempts should not be made to oil individual tanks too rapidly’
--Word--
oil bag 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A bag containing oil or for containing oil; (Nautical) a bag used to drip oil on to the sea to calm the waves. Also (formerly): †a bag to contain a substance from which oil is to be expressed (obsolete).
--Examples--
--Word--
bearing 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A person's way of standing or moving.
The way a person behaves or conducts themselves.
Relation; relevance.
The ability to tolerate something bad or to be tolerated.
A part of a machine that allows one part to rotate or move in contact with another part with as little friction as possible.
The direction or position of something, or the direction of movement, relative to a fixed point. It is usually measured in degrees, typically with magnetic north as zero.
Awareness of one's position relative to one's surroundings.
A device or charge.
--Examples--
‘a man of precise military bearing’
‘she has the bearing of a First Lady’
‘the case has no direct bearing on the issues being considered’
‘school was bad enough, but now it's past bearing’
‘the Point is on a bearing of 015°’
‘there were no steeples or bridges from which to take a bearing’
‘he flashed the torch around, trying to get his bearings’
‘armorial bearings’

--Type--
noun, verb

--Word--
dispensing 
--Type--
adjective
--Meanings--
(of a machine or container) able to supply or release a product or cash.

‘the card can be recharged at the same dispensing machine’

--Word--
distribute 
--Type--
verb
--Meanings--
Give a share or a unit of (something) to each of a number of recipients.
Supply (goods) to retailers.
Separate (metal type that has been set up) and return the characters to their separate compartments in a type case.
Occur throughout an area.
Spread (a load) over an area.
(of a computer system) spread over several machines, especially over a network.
Use (a term) to include every individual of the class to which it refers.
--Examples--
‘information leaflets are being distributed to hotels’
‘the journal is distributed worldwide’
‘the birds are mainly distributed in marshes and river valleys’
‘the seat is designed to ensure the weight of the passenger is evenly distributed’
‘a distributed system’
‘the middle term must be distributed, at least once, in the premises’

--Word--
driven 
--Type--
verb, adjective
--Meanings--
Operated, moved, or controlled by a specified person or source of power.
Motivated or determined by a specified factor or feeling.
(of a person) relentlessly compelled by the need to accomplish a goal; very hard-working and ambitious.
(of snow) piled into drifts or made smooth by the wind.
--Examples--
‘a chauffeur-driven limousine’
‘wind-driven sand’
‘a market-driven response to customer needs’
‘my husband is a driven man’
--Word--
oil 
--Type--
noun, verb
--Meanings--
A viscous liquid derived from petroleum, especially for use as a fuel or lubricant.
Petroleum.
Any of various viscous liquids which are insoluble in water but soluble in organic solvents and are obtained from animals or plants.
A liquid preparation used on the hair or skin as a cosmetic.
Any of a group of natural esters of glycerol and various fatty acids, which are liquid at room temperature.
Oil paint.
An oil painting.
Information or facts.
Lubricate, coat, or impregnate with oil.
Supply with oil as fuel.

--Word--
heat 
--Type--
noun, verb
--Meanings--
The quality of being hot; high temperature.
Heat seen as a form of energy arising from the random motion of the molecules of bodies, which may be transferred by conduction, convection, or radiation.
Hot weather conditions.
A source or level of heat for cooking.
A spicy quality in food that produces a burning sensation in the mouth.
The amount of heat that is needed to cause a specific process or is evolved in such a process.
A single operation of heating something, especially metal in a furnace.
Intensity of feeling, especially of anger or excitement.
Intensive and unwelcome pressure or criticism, especially from the authorities.
A preliminary round in a race or contest.
Make or become hot or warm.
(of a person) become excited or impassioned.
Become more intense and exciting.
Inflame; excite.
--Examples--
‘the fierce heat of the sun’
‘the oppressive heat was making both men sweat’
‘remove from the heat and beat in the butter’
‘chilli peppers add taste and heat to food’
‘the heat of formation’
‘about 100 tons is removed in each heat’
‘conciliation services are designed to take the heat out of disputes’
‘a flurry of legal proceedings turned up the heat in the dispute’
‘the heat is on’
‘winners of the regional heats’
‘the room faces north and is difficult to heat’
‘the pipes expand as they heat up’
‘he seemed to calm down as quickly as he had heated up’
‘the action really begins to heat up’
‘this discourse had heated them’

oil-nut 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
More fully "oil-nut tree". Any of various trees or shrubs that produce oil-rich nuts or large seeds; specifically (a) the castor oil plant, Ricinus communis; (b) the butternut, Juglans cinerea; (c) the buffalo-nut, Pyrularia pubera; (d) the oil palm, Elaeis guineensis.
The nut or large seed of such a plant.

oil plant 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
Any of various plants yielding an oil; specifically (a) sesame, Sesamum indicum; (b) bok choy, Brassica chinensis; (c) regional (Irish English), sundew, Drosera rotundifolia. Now usually with distinguishing word, as in castor-oil plant.

--Word--
seal 
--Type--
noun, verb
--Meanings--
A device or substance that is used to join two things together so as to prevent them from coming apart or to prevent anything from passing between them.
The state or fact of being joined or rendered impervious with a seal.
The water standing in the trap of a drain to prevent foul air from rising, considered in terms of its depth.
A piece of wax, lead, or other material with an individual design stamped into it, attached to a document as a guarantee of authenticity.
A design resembling a seal embossed in paper as a guarantee of authenticity.
An engraved device used for stamping a seal.
A decorative adhesive stamp.
A thing regarded as a confirmation or guarantee of something.
The obligation on a priest not to divulge anything said during confession.
Fasten or close securely.
Prevent something from escaping by closing a container or opening.
Isolate an area by preventing or monitoring access to and from it.
Apply a non-porous coating to (a surface) to make it impervious.
Fry (food) briefly at a high temperature to prevent it from losing moisture during subsequent cooking.
Conclude, establish, or secure (something) definitively.
Fix a piece of wax or lead stamped with a design to (a document) to authenticate it.
--Examples--
‘attach a draught seal to the door itself’
‘many fittings have tapered threads for a better seal’
‘for most domestic applications, a 75 mm seal is required’
‘the monarchy is the seal of the unbroached integrity of the Isles’
‘I was told under the seal’
‘he folded it, sealed the envelope, and walked to the postbox’
‘ice formation at the surface can seal in water contained within pores in the rock’
‘anti-terrorist squad officers sealed off the area to search for possible bombs’
‘the pine boarding should be sealed with polyurethane’
‘heat the oil and seal the lamb on both sides’
‘to seal the deal he offered Thornton a place on the board of the company’

oyster 
--Type--
noun, verb
--Meanings--
Any of a number of bivalve molluscs with rough irregular shells. Several kinds are eaten (especially raw) as a delicacy and may be farmed for food or pearls.
A shade of greyish white.
An oyster-shaped morsel of meat on each side of the backbone in poultry.
Raise, dredge, or gather oysters.
--Examples--
‘oystering is still the lifeblood of this town’

--Meanings--
A person who gathers, sells, or prepares oysters.
--Examples--
--Word--
oysterfish 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
Chiefly United States regional. Any of various fishes which frequent oyster beds; especially (a) the oyster toadfish, Opsanus tau; (b) the tautog, Tautoga onitis; (c) the naked goby, Gobiosoma bosci.
--Examples--
--Word--
oysterfish 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
Chiefly United States regional. Any of various fishes which frequent oyster beds; especially (a) the oyster toadfish, Opsanus tau; (b) the tautog, Tautoga onitis; (c) the naked goby, Gobiosoma bosci.
--Examples--
--Word--
oyster-green 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
Sea lettuce, Ulva lactuca, a green alga frequent in oyster beds.
--Examples--
--Word--
oysterhood 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
The condition of being an oyster.
--Examples--
--Word--
oystery 
--Type--
adjective
--Meanings--
Characteristic or reminiscent of an oyster.
Consisting of or abounding in oysters.
--Examples--
--Word--
oyster 
--Type--
noun, verb
--Meanings--
Any of a number of bivalve molluscs with rough irregular shells. Several kinds are eaten (especially raw) as a delicacy and may be farmed for food or pearls.
A shade of greyish white.
An oyster-shaped morsel of meat on each side of the backbone in poultry.
Raise, dredge, or gather oysters.
--Examples--
‘oystering is still the lifeblood of this town’
--Word--
oysterer 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A person who gathers, sells, or prepares oysters.
--Examples--

--Type--
adjective
--Meanings--

--Examples--

oysterishness 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
The quality of resembling an oyster.
--Examples--
--Word--
oyster-like 
--Type--
adjective
--Meanings--
Resembling an oyster; especially (of a person) reserved or uncommunicative (staying inside one's ‘shell’).
--Examples--
--Word--

noun

--Word--
OK 
--Type--
exclamation, adjective, adverb, noun, verb, abbreviation
--Meanings--
Used to express agreement or acceptance.
Used to introduce an utterance.
Used at the end of a statement to invite agreement, approval, or confirmation.
Satisfactory but not especially good.
In a satisfactory physical or mental state.
Permissible; allowable.
In a satisfactory manner or to a satisfactory extent.
An authorization or approval.
Give approval to.
Oklahoma (in official postal use).
--Examples--
‘OK, I'll pass on your message’
‘OK, OK, I give in’
‘‘OK, let's go’’
‘humour me, OK?’
‘the flight was OK’
‘are you okay, Ben?’
‘it's not OK to say that to a teacher’
‘the computer continues to work OK’
‘the officer gave me the OK’
‘despite objections, the committee ok'd the construction’
--Word--
oka 
--Type--
noun, noun
--Meanings--
An Egyptian and former Turkish unit of weight, variable but now usually equal to approximately 1.3 kg (23/4 lb).
An Egyptian and former Turkish unit of capacity equal to approximately 0.2 litre (1/3 pint).
A variety of cured Canadian cheese, made by Trappist monks.
--Examples--

okapi 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A large browsing mammal of the giraffe family that lives in the rainforests of northern Democratic Republic of Congo (Zaire). It has a dark chestnut coat with stripes on the hindquarters and upper legs.

--Word--
Okavango 
--Type--
proper noun
--Meanings--
A river of south-western Africa which rises in central Angola and flows 1,600 km (1,000 miles) south-eastwards to Namibia, where it turns eastwards to form part of the border between Angola and Namibia before entering Botswana, where it drains into the extensive Okavango marshes of Ngamiland.
--Examples--
--Word--
Okazaki 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
Attributive Designating the segments of DNA formed as intermediates in the discontinuous replication of the lagging strand during the replication of double-stranded DNA.

--Type--
proper noun
--Meanings--

--Meanings--

--Word--
okenite 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A triclinic hydrous silicate of calcium occurring as minute needle- or blade-shaped crystals of a whitish colour in vesicles in eruptive rocks. Compare "dysclasite". Also: the mineral wollastonite, misidentified as a form of okenite (rare, now historical).
--Examples--

--Word--
Olaf 
--Type--
proper noun
--Meanings--
The name of five kings of Norway.
Olaf I Tryggvason (969–1000), reigned 995–1000.
Olaf II Haraldsson (c.995–1030), reigned 1016–30; canonized as St Olaf for his attempts to spread Christianity in his kingdom. He is the patron saint of Norway. Feast day, 29 July.
Olaf III Haraldsson (d.1093), reigned 1066–93.
Olaf IV Haakonson (1370–87), reigned 1380–7.
Olaf V (1903–91), reigned 1957–91; full name Olaf Alexander Edmund Christian Frederik.
--Examples--

--Examples--
--Word--
Olbers' paradox 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
The apparent paradox that if stars are distributed evenly throughout an infinite universe, the sky should be as bright by night as by day, since more distant stars would be fainter but more numerous. This is not the case because the universe is of finite age, and the light from the more distant stars is dimmed because they are receding from the observer as the universe expands.
--Examples--
--Word--
old 
--Type--
adjective
--Meanings--
Having lived for a long time; no longer young.
Made or built long ago.
Possessed or used for a long time.
Boring or tiresome, especially as a result of repetition or overfamiliarity.
Having the characteristics or showing the signs of age.
Belonging to the past; former.
Used to refer to a thing which has been replaced by something similar.
Dating from far back; long-established or known.
Denoting someone who formerly attended a specified school.
(of a form of a language) as used in former or earliest times.
Of a specified age.
A person or animal of the age specified.
Used to express affection, familiarity, or contempt.
--Examples--
‘the old man lay propped up on cushions’
‘the old quarter of the town’
‘he gave his old clothes away’
‘I wish she'd shut up—it's getting old’
‘he complained of being old beyond his years’
‘valuation under the old rating system was inexact’
‘we moved back into our old house’
‘we greeted each other like old friends’
‘I get sick of the same old routine’
‘an old Etonian’
‘he was fourteetn years old’
‘a seven-month-old baby’
‘a nineteen-year-old’
‘good old Mum’
‘I didn't like playing with silly old dolls’
--Word--
old age

--Meanings--

The state of being old.
--Examples--
‘loneliness affects many people in old age’
‘old age itself is not a disease’

--Word--
Oldenburg, Claes 
--Type--
proper noun
--Meanings--
(born 1929), US pop artist and sculptor; born in Sweden; full name Claes Thure Oldenburg. During the 1960s, he conducted “happenings, ” participatory art events such as Autobodys (1964), in which he used actual cars and crowds of people. He later worked with soft materials and foam rubber to create soft sculptures of everyday objects.
--Examples--
--Word--
olden 
--Type--
adjective
--Meanings--
Relating to former times.
--Examples--
‘the olden days’

--Meanings--
Relating to former times.
--Examples--

Boring or tiresome, especially as a result of repetition or overfamiliarity.
Having the characteristics or showing the signs of age.
Belonging to the past; former.
Used to refer to a thing which has been replaced by something similar.
Dating from far back; long-established or known.
Denoting someone who formerly attended a specified school.
(of a form of a language) as used in former or earliest times.
Of a specified age.
A person or animal of the age specified.
Used to express affection, familiarity, or contempt.
--Examples--
‘the old man lay propped up on cushions’
‘the old quarter of the town’
‘he gave his old clothes away’
‘I wish she'd shut up—it's getting old’
‘he complained of being old beyond his years’
‘valuation under the old rating system was inexact’
‘we moved back into our old house’
‘we greeted each other like old friends’
‘I get sick of the same old routine’
‘an old Etonian’
‘he was fourteetn years old’
‘a seven-month-old baby’
‘a nineteen-year-old’
‘good old Mum’
‘I didn't like playing with silly old dolls’
--Word--
old-established 
--Type--
adjective
--Meanings--
Having existed or continued for a long time.
--Examples--
‘old-established businesses could be driven out by high rents’
--Word--
olde worlde 
--Type--
adjective
--Meanings--
In or relating to an old-fashioned style that is intended to be quaint and attractive (often used to suggest a lack of authenticity)
--Examples--
‘olde worlde inns’
--Word--
old-faced 
--Type--
adjective
--Meanings--
Chiefly literary. Having a face characteristic of age.
--Examples--

--Word--
old-fashioned 
--Type--
adjective, noun
--Meanings--
In or according to styles or types no longer current; not modern.
Favouring traditional or conservative ideas or customs.
(of a facial expression) disapproving.
A cocktail consisting chiefly of whisky, bitters, water, and sugar.
--Examples--
‘an old-fashioned kitchen range’
‘she's stuffy and old-fashioned’
‘Jonas gave her an old-fashioned look’

oldhamite 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A mineral of the galena group, a cubic sulphide of calcium, CaS, that occurs as transparent pale brown spherules, especially in meteorites.

ivory 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A hard creamy-white substance composing the main part of the tusks of an elephant, walrus, or narwhal, often (especially formerly) used to make ornaments and other articles.
An object made of ivory.
The keys of a piano.
A person's teeth.
The creamy-white colour of ivory.
--Examples--
‘a dagger with an ivory handle’
‘Derek tinkled the ivories for us’
‘an ivory silk blouse’

noun, adjective

--Word--
Old Testament 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
The first part of the Christian Bible, comprising thirty-nine books and corresponding approximately to the Hebrew Bible. Most of the books were written in Hebrew, some in Aramaic, between about 1200 and 100 BC. They comprise the chief texts of the law, history, prophecy, and wisdom literature of the ancient people of Israel.
--Examples--
--Word--
old-time 
--Type--
adjective
--Meanings--
Relating to or characteristic of the past; long-standing.
Denoting traditional or folk styles of American popular music, such as gospel or bluegrass.
Denoting ballroom dances in which a sequence of dance steps is repeated throughout, as opposed to modern dancing in which steps may be varied.
--Examples--
‘the charm of old-time steam engines’
‘as far as old-time sounds go, he's the current Nashville kingpin’
‘lessons in ballroom or old-time dancing’

--Word--
oleandomycin 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A macrolide antibiotic, C₃₅H₆₁NO₁₂, produced by a strain of the bacterium Streptomyces antibioticus, which is active against a wide range of Gram-positive bacteria and has been used as the phosphate in treating staphylococcal enteritis and skin infections.
--Examples--
--Word--
oleandrin 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A toxic cardiac glycoside, C₃₂H₄₈O₉, with diuretic properties present in the leaves of the oleander.
--Examples--
--Word--
oleandrin 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--

--Word--
Olearia 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A genus of the family Asteraceae (Compositae) consisting of evergreen shrubs and trees bearing clusters of daisy-like white, mauve, etc., flowers, native to Australasia and often grown in coastal districts elsewhere; (also olearia) a tree or shrub of this genus (also called daisy bush, daisy tree).

oleic series 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A series of unsaturated aliphatic acids of the general formula CₙH₂ₙ₋₁COOH, in which there is a chain of carbon atoms containing one double bond. Now rare.
--Examples--
--Word--
oleiferous 
--Type--
adjective
--Meanings--
(of seeds, glands, etc.) producing oil.
--Examples--
--Word--
olein 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A glyceryl ester of oleic acid; specifically glyceryl trioleate, C₃H₅(C₁₈H₃₃O₂)₃, a colourless oily liquid which is a very common natural fat (also called triolein). Also (more widely): any liquid fat (consisting chiefly of such esters) separated from a solid or semi-solid fat; (formerly, also) †a glyceride of a fatty acid other than oleic acid (obsolete).
--Examples--
--Word--
olein 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A glyceryl ester of oleic acid; specifically glyceryl trioleate, C₃H₅(C₁₈H₃₃O₂)₃, a colourless oily liquid which is a very common natural fat (also called triolein). Also (more widely): any liquid fat (consisting chiefly of such esters) separated from a solid or semi-solid fat; (formerly, also) †a glyceride of a fatty acid other than oleic acid (obsolete).
--Examples--
--Word--
olein 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A glyceryl ester of oleic acid; specifically glyceryl trioleate, C₃H₅(C₁₈H₃₃O₂)₃, a colourless oily liquid which is a very common natural fat (also called triolein). Also (more widely): any liquid fat (consisting chiefly of such esters) separated from a solid or semi-solid fat; (formerly, also) †a glyceride of a fatty acid other than oleic acid (obsolete).
--Examples--
--Word--

oleoyl 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
The hydrocarbon radical —CH₃(CH₂)₇CH=CH(CH₂)₇CH₂, derived from oleic acid; cis-9-octadecen-1-oyl. Usually attributive.

oleostearin 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
The solid portion of fat extracted from purified beef fat under pressure, used for making candles and soaps; specifically the main constituent of this, a glyceride of oleic and stearic acids.

Oligocene 
--Type--
adjective
--Meanings--

--Examples--
--Word--
Oligochaeta 
--Type--
plural noun
--Meanings--
A class of annelid worms which includes the earthworms. They have simple setae projecting from each segment and a small head lacking sensory appendages.

--Examples--
--Word--
Olympia 
--Type--
proper noun
--Meanings--
A plain in Greece, in the western Peloponnese. In ancient Greece it was the site of the chief sanctuary of the god Zeus, the place where the original Olympic Games were held, after which the site is named.
The capital of the state of Washington, a port on Puget Sound; population 45,322 (est. 2008).
--Examples--
--Word--
Olympiad 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
An occasion when the ancient or modern Olympic Games were or are held.
A period of four years between Olympic Games, used by the ancient Greeks in dating events.
A major international contest in a particular game, sport, or scientific subject.
--Examples--
‘the 42nd International Mathematics Olympiad’

Olympiad 
--Type--
noun

--Word--
Olympian 
--Type--
adjective, noun
--Meanings--
Associated with Mount Olympus in north-eastern Greece, or with the Greek gods whose home was traditionally held to be there.
Resembling or appropriate to a god, especially in superiority and aloofness.
Relating to the ancient or modern Olympic Games.
Any of the pantheon of twelve Greek gods regarded as living on Olympus.
A person of great attainments or exalted position.
A competitor in the Olympic Games.
--Examples--
‘a temple of Olympian Zeus’
‘the court is capable of an Olympian impartiality’
‘an Olympian champion’
‘as the greatest Olympian, he is something of a sporting god’
--Word--
Olympianism 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
The polytheistic religious system of the ancient Greeks, in which the Olympians were the chief gods and goddesses. In extended use: any polytheistic religious system.
An attitude or demeanour of godlike power, superiority, or personal excellence.
--Examples--
--Word--
Olympianize 
--Type--
verb
--Meanings--
To endow with the attributes of an Olympian god or goddess; to exalt to the position of an Olympian.
--Examples--
--Word--
Olympianly 
--Type--
adverb
--Meanings--
In an Olympian manner; loftily, condescendingly.
--Examples--
--Word--
Olympian 
--Type--
adjective, noun
--Meanings--
Associated with Mount Olympus in north-eastern Greece, or with the Greek gods whose home was traditionally held to be there.
Resembling or appropriate to a god, especially in superiority and aloofness.
Relating to the ancient or modern Olympic Games.
Any of the pantheon of twelve Greek gods regarded as living on Olympus.
A person of great attainments or exalted position.
A competitor in the Olympic Games.
--Examples--
‘a temple of Olympian Zeus’
‘the court is capable of an Olympian impartiality’
‘an Olympian champion’
‘as the greatest Olympian, he is something of a sporting god’
--Word--
Olympia 
--Type--
proper noun
--Meanings--
A plain in Greece, in the western Peloponnese. In ancient Greece it was the site of the chief sanctuary of the god Zeus, the place where the original Olympic Games were held, after which the site is named.
The capital of the state of Washington, a port on Puget Sound; population 45,322 (est. 2008).

--Examples--
--Word--
Olympic Games 
--Type--
proper noun
--Meanings--
A sports festival held every four years in different venues, instigated by the Frenchman Baron de Coubertin (1863–1937) in 1896. Athletes representing more than 200 countries compete for gold, silver, and bronze medals in more than twenty sports.
An ancient Greek festival with athletic, literary, and musical competitions held at Olympia every four years, traditionally from 776 BC until abolished by the Roman emperor Theodosius I in AD 393.
--Examples--
--Word--
Olympus 
--Type--
proper noun
--Meanings--
The home of the twelve greater gods, identified in later antiquity with Mount Olympus in Greece.

--Word--
oliva 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
Zoology (In form Oliva) a genus of marine gastropod molluscs of the family Olividae, characterized by glossy cylindrical shells; (also oliva; more fully "oliva shell") a member of this genus; an olive shell.
Anatomy. The olivary body (more fully "oliva inferior"). Also (in full "oliva superior"): the superior olivary nucleus.
--Examples--
--Word--

--Meanings--

olivaster

--Examples--
--Word--
olive 
--Type--
noun, adjective
--Meanings--
A small oval fruit with a hard stone and bitter flesh, green when unripe and bluish black when ripe, used as food and as a source of oil.
The small evergreen tree which produces olives and which has narrow leaves with silvery undersides, native to warm regions of the Old World.
Used in names of other trees which are related to the olive, resemble it, or bear similar fruit, e.g. Russian olive.
A greyish-green colour like that of an unripe olive.
A slice of beef or veal made into a roll with stuffing inside and stewed.
A marine mollusc with a smooth, roughly cylindrical shell which is typically brightly coloured.
Each of a pair of smooth, oval swellings in the medulla oblongata.
A metal ring or fitting which is tightened under a threaded nut to form a seal, as in a compression joint.
Greyish-green.
(of the complexion) yellowish-brown; sallow.
--Examples--
‘a dish of cauliflower with black olives’
‘a cucumber and olive salad’
‘shades of gold, olive, and black’
‘a small figure in olive fatigues’
‘his full lips and olive skin’
--Word--
olive-backed thrush 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
= oliveback.
--Examples--
--Word--
olive 
--Type--
noun, adjective
--Meanings--
A small oval fruit with a hard stone and bitter flesh, green when unripe and bluish black when ripe, used as food and as a source of oil.
The small evergreen tree which produces olives and which has narrow leaves with silvery undersides, native to warm regions of the Old World.
Used in names of other trees which are related to the olive, resemble it, or bear similar fruit, e.g. Russian olive.
A greyish-green colour like that of an unripe olive.
A slice of beef or veal made into a roll with stuffing inside and stewed.
A marine mollusc with a smooth, roughly cylindrical shell which is typically brightly coloured.
Each of a pair of smooth, oval swellings in the medulla oblongata.
A metal ring or fitting which is tightened under a threaded nut to form a seal, as in a compression joint.
Greyish-green.
(of the complexion) yellowish-brown; sallow.
--Examples--
‘a dish of cauliflower with black olives’
‘a cucumber and olive salad’
‘shades of gold, olive, and black’
‘a small figure in olive fatigues’
‘his full lips and olive skin’

--Word--
Olivella

noun

olivenite 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
Native basic copper arsenate, occurring as orthorhombic crystals or masses, usually of an olive-green colour.
--Examples--
--Word--
pale 
--Type--
adjective, verb
--Meanings--
Light in colour or shade; containing little colour or pigment.
(of a person or their complexion) having less colour than usual, typically as a result of shock, fear, or ill health.
(of a light) not strong or bright.
Inferior or unimpressive.
Become pale in one's face from shock or fear.
Seem or become less important.
--Examples--
‘choose pale floral patterns for walls’
‘she looked pale and drawn’
‘a pale dawn’
‘the new cheese is a pale imitation of continental cheeses’
‘I paled at the thought of what she might say’
‘all else pales by comparison’

Oliverian 
--Type--
adjective
--Meanings--
Of or relating to Oliver Cromwell or his period in power as Lord Protector of the Commonwealth.
--Examples--
--Word--
olive 
--Type--
noun, adjective
--Meanings--
A small oval fruit with a hard stone and bitter flesh, green when unripe and bluish black when ripe, used as food and as a source of oil.
The small evergreen tree which produces olives and which has narrow leaves with silvery undersides, native to warm regions of the Old World.
Used in names of other trees which are related to the olive, resemble it, or bear similar fruit, e.g. Russian olive.
A greyish-green colour like that of an unripe olive.
A slice of beef or veal made into a roll with stuffing inside and stewed.
A marine mollusc with a smooth, roughly cylindrical shell which is typically brightly coloured.
Each of a pair of smooth, oval swellings in the medulla oblongata.
A metal ring or fitting which is tightened under a threaded nut to form a seal, as in a compression joint.
Greyish-green.
(of the complexion) yellowish-brown; sallow.
--Examples--
‘a dish of cauliflower with black olives’
‘a cucumber and olive salad’
‘shades of gold, olive, and black’
‘a small figure in olive fatigues’
‘his full lips and olive skin’
--Word--
Oliver 
--Type--
proper noun
--Meanings--
The companion of Roland in the Chanson de Roland.
--Examples--
--Word--
long-shaded 
--Type--
adjective
--Meanings--
= long-shadowed.
--Examples--
--Word--
olive 
--Type--
noun, adjective
--Meanings--
A small oval fruit with a hard stone and bitter flesh, green when unripe and bluish black when ripe, used as food and as a source of oil.
The small evergreen tree which produces olives and which has narrow leaves with silvery undersides, native to warm regions of the Old World.
Used in names of other trees which are related to the olive, resemble it, or bear similar fruit, e.g. Russian olive.
A greyish-green colour like that of an unripe olive.
A slice of beef or veal made into a roll with stuffing inside and stewed.
A marine mollusc with a smooth, roughly cylindrical shell which is typically brightly coloured.
Each of a pair of smooth, oval swellings in the medulla oblongata.
A metal ring or fitting which is tightened under a threaded nut to form a seal, as in a compression joint.
Greyish-green.
(of the complexion) yellowish-brown; sallow.
--Examples--
‘a dish of cauliflower with black olives’
‘a cucumber and olive salad’
‘shades of gold, olive, and black’
‘a small figure in olive fatigues’
‘his full lips and olive skin’
--Word--
olive-sided flycatcher 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A North American tyrant flycatcher, Contopus cooperi, which is related to the pewees and has olive-brown and white plumage.
--Examples--
--Word--
olive-skinned 
--Type--
adjective
--Meanings--
(of a person) having yellowish-brown skin.
--Examples--
‘an olive-skinned Italian goddess’
--Word--
olivet 
--Type--
noun, noun
--Meanings--
In full "Mount (of) Olivet". The Mount of Olives on the east side of Jerusalem, the scene of Christ's Ascension.
An oval button or piece of wood covered with silk or worsted and used for fastening a garment by means of a loop of braid.
Angling. In form olivette. A small oval weight, threaded on to a fishing line.
--Examples--

--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A member of this religious order.

olivette 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A small oval weight threaded on a fishing line.

Olivetti 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A trademark for: a make of typewriter. Hence (more widely): any (especially portable) typewriter.
--Examples--
--Word--
olive wood 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
The wood of an olive tree, especially of Olea europaea var. europaea, used chiefly in ornamental work.
Caribbean. A tropical American evergreen shrub or small tree, Capparis odoratissima (family Capparidaceae).
Woodland or a wood consisting wholly or chiefly of olive trees. Now chiefly poetic.
--Examples--
--Word--
Manning, Olivia 
--Type--
proper noun
--Meanings--
(1908–80), English novelist; full name Olivia Mary Manning. Her experiences in Bucharest, Athens, and Egypt between 1939 and 1946 formed the basis for her Balkan and Levant trilogies, written 1960–1980.
--Examples--
--Word--
Messiaen, Olivier 
--Type--
proper noun
--Meanings--
(1908–92), French composer; full name Olivier Eugène Prosper Charles Messiaen. His music was influenced by Greek and Hindu rhythms, birdsong, Stravinsky and Debussy, and the composer's Roman Catholic faith. Notable works: Quartet for the End of Time (1941).
--Examples--
--Word--
oliviform 
--Type--
adjective
--Meanings--
Shaped like an olive, oval; (Conchology) resembling an olive shell.
--Examples--
--Word--
olivil 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A crystalline carbohydrate, C₂₀H₂₄O₇, which is a lignan obtained from the gum of the olive tree.
--Examples--
--Word--
olivine 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
An olive-green, grey-green, or brown mineral occurring widely in basalt, peridotite, and other basic igneous rocks. It is a silicate containing varying proportions of magnesium, iron, and other elements.
--Examples--

ollamh 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A rank of Irish learned man, the most distinguished kind of file; a master of a particular field of knowledge, especially a master poet or chronicler. Revived as a symbolic rank in 20th-century festivals.

--Word--
ollie 
--Type--
noun, verb
--Meanings--
(in skateboarding and snowboarding) a jump performed without the aid of a take-off ramp, executed by pressing the foot down on the tail of the board to rebound the deck off the ground.
Perform an ollie.
--Examples--
‘they taught me to ollie and stuff’

olm 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A pale-skinned blind salamander with external gills which lives in limestone caves in south-eastern Europe.

Olmsted, Frederick Law 
--Type--
proper noun
--Meanings--
(1822–1903) US landscape architect. He designed Central Park in New York City, Fairmount Park in Philadelphia, and the Capitol grounds in Washington, DC.

Palme, Olof 
--Type--
proper noun
--Meanings--
(1927–86), Swedish statesman, prime minister 1969–76 and 1982–6; full name Sven Olof Joachim Palme. He was killed by an unknown assassin.

ololiuqui 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A tropical American morning glory, Turbina corymbosa (family Convolvulaceae). Also: a psychoactive drug prepared from the seeds of this plant, used traditionally for ritual purposes by the Aztecs.

--Word--
Umayyad 
--Type--
noun, adjective
--Meanings--
A member of a Muslim dynasty that ruled the Islamic world from AD 660 (or 661) to 750 and Moorish Spain 756–1031. The dynasty claimed descent from Umayya, a distant relative of Muhammad.
Relating to the Umayyad dynasty.
--Examples--

omalgia 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
Pain in the shoulder.

Oman 
--Type--

--Meanings--
A country at the eastern corner of the Arabian peninsula; population 4,500,000 (estimated 2015); official language, Arabic; capital, Muscat.

--Word--
Omar Khayyám 
--Type--
proper noun
--Meanings--
(d.1123), Persian poet, mathematician, and astronomer. His rubáiyát (quatrains), found in The Rubáiyát of Omar Khayyám (translation published 1859), are meditations on the mysteries of existence and celebrations of worldly pleasures.

ombre 
--Type--
noun, adjective
--Meanings--
A trick-taking card game for three people using a pack of forty cards, popular in Europe in the 17th–18th centuries.
Having tones of colour that shade into each other, graduating from light to dark.

Omdurman 
--Type--
proper noun
--Meanings--
A city in central Sudan, on the River Nile opposite Khartoum; population 3,151,600 (est. 2007). In 1898 it was the site of a battle which marked the final British defeat of the Mahdist forces.

--Word--
omega 
--Type--
noun
UnKnownKind
--Meanings--
The last letter of the Greek alphabet (Ω, ω), transliterated as ‘o’ or ‘ō’.
The last of a series.
The twenty-fourth star in a constellation.
Ohm(s)
Angular frequency.
--Examples--
‘the omega point’
‘Omega Scorpii’
‘a 100Ω resistor’

omni- 
--Type--
combining form
--Meanings--
All; of all things.
In all ways or places.
--Examples--
‘omniscient’
‘omnifarious’
‘omnicompetent’
‘omnipresent’
--Word--
omniactive 
--Type--
adjective
--Meanings--
Active in all ways or everywhere.
--Examples--
--Word--
omniana 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
Thoughts or scraps of information about all or many kinds of things, especially (a collection of) notes, jottings, or short pieces of writing on all or many kinds of subjects.
--Examples--
--Word--
omniarch

noun
--Meanings--

--Type--
noun

adjective

‘the belief in an omnipotent and omnibenevolent God’
--Word--
omnibus 
--Type--
noun, adjective
--Meanings--
A volume containing several books previously published separately.
A single edition of two or more consecutive television or radio programmes previously broadcast separately.
A bus.
Comprising several items.
--Examples--
‘an omnibus of her first trilogy’
‘Coronation Street's rival EastEnders was boosted by a weekend omnibus’
‘a horse-drawn omnibus’
‘omnibus editions of novels’

--Word--
ignorant 
--Type--
adjective
--Meanings--
Lacking knowledge or awareness in general; uneducated or unsophisticated.
Lacking knowledge, information, or awareness about a particular thing.
Discourteous or rude.
Angry or quick-tempered.
--Examples--
‘he was told constantly that he was ignorant and stupid’
‘I was largely ignorant of the effects of radiotherapy’
‘school-leavers were ignorant about the range of job opportunities’
‘this ignorant, pin-brained receptionist’
‘she could be very ignorant and he had no intention of getting involved in an argument just now’
‘I had to walk out before I got ignorant’

omohyoid 
--Type--
adjective, noun
--Meanings--
Designating a long slender digastric muscle which arises from the upper border of the shoulder blade and passes obliquely along the side and front of the neck to the lower border of the hyoid bone.
The omohyoid muscle.

--Type--

om 
--Type--
noun, abbreviation
--Meanings--
A mystic syllable, considered the most sacred mantra in Hinduism and Tibetan Buddhism. It appears at the beginning and end of most Sanskrit recitations, prayers, and texts.
(in the UK) Order of Merit.

--Word--
on 
--Type--
preposition, adverb, noun
--Meanings--
Physically in contact with and supported by (a surface)
Located somewhere in the general surface area of (a place)
As a result of accidental physical contact with.
Supported by (a part of the body)
On to.
In the possession of; being carried by.
Forming a distinctive or marked part of the surface of.
Having (the thing mentioned) as a topic; about.
Having (the thing mentioned) as a basis.
As a member of (a committee, jury, or other body)
Having (the thing mentioned) as a target, aim, or focus.
(often followed by a noun without a determiner) having (the thing mentioned) as a medium for transmitting or storing information.
Being broadcast by (a radio or television channel)
In the course of (a journey)
While travelling in (a public vehicle)
On to (a public vehicle) with the intention of travelling in it.
Indicating the day or part of a day during which an event takes place.
At the time of.
Engaged in.
Regularly taking (a drug or medicine)
Paid for by.
Added to.
Physically in contact with and supported by a surface.
(of clothing) being worn by a person.
Indicating continuation of a movement or action.
Further forward; in an advanced state.
(of an event) taking place or being presented.
Due to take place as planned.
(of an electrical appliance or power supply) functioning.
(of a performer) on stage.
(of an employee) working; on duty.
The leg side.

‘on the table was a water jug’
‘she was lying on the floor’
‘a sign on the front gate’
‘an internment camp on the island’
‘the house on the corner’
‘he banged his head on a beam’
‘he was lying on his back’
‘put it on the table’
‘she only had a few pounds on her’
‘a scratch on her arm’
‘a smile on her face’
‘a book on careers’
‘a constitution modelled on America's’
‘they would be allowed to serve on committees’
‘five air raids on Schweinfurt’
‘thousands marching on Washington’
‘her eyes were fixed on his dark profile’
‘put your ideas down on paper’
‘stored on the client's own computer’
‘a new twelve-part TV series on Channel 4’
‘he was on his way to see his mother’
‘John got some sleep on the plane’
‘we got on the train’
‘reported on September 26’
‘on a very hot evening in July’
‘she was booed on arriving home’
‘his attendant was out on errands’
‘he is on morphine to relieve the pain’
‘the drinks are on me’
‘a few pence on the electricity bill is nothing compared with your security’
‘make sure the lid is on’
‘sitting with her coat on’
‘she burbled on’
‘he drove on’
‘and so on’
‘I'll see you later on’

‘they always left the lights on’

--Word--
Onassis, Aristotle 
--Type--
proper noun
--Meanings--
(1906–75), Greek shipping magnate and international businessman; full name Aristotle Socrates Onassis. He owned a substantial shipping empire and founded the Greek national airline, Olympic Airways (1957).
--Examples--
--Word--
on-board 
--Type--
adjective, verb
--Meanings--
Available or situated on a ship, aircraft, or other vehicle.
Denoting or controlled from a facility or feature incorporated into the main circuit board of a computer or computerized device.
Go through procedures to effectively integrate (a new employee) into an organization or familiarize (a new customer or client) with one's products or services.
--Examples--
‘on-board catering staff’
‘the on-board computer controls all critical functions on the ship’
‘there's 8GB of onboard memory’
‘this data has tremendous value in helping to onboard new hires and manage their performance’
‘my focus has been restructuring how we do things when we onboard a client’
--Word--
on-board 
--Type--
adjective, verb
--Meanings--
Available or situated on a ship, aircraft, or other vehicle.
Denoting or controlled from a facility or feature incorporated into the main circuit board of a computer or computerized device.

‘the on-board computer controls all critical functions on the ship’
‘there's 8GB of onboard memory’

‘my focus has been restructuring how we do things when we onboard a client’

--Examples--
--Word--
once 
--Type--
adverb, conjunction
--Meanings--
On one occasion or for one time only.
On even one occasion; at all (used for emphasis)
At some time in the past; formerly.
Multiplied by one.
As soon as; when.
--Examples--
‘they deliver once a week’
‘he'd only met her the once’
‘he never once complained’
‘if she once got an idea in her head you'd never move it’
‘Gran had once been a famous singer’
‘once two is two’

--Word--
one 
--Type--
cardinal number, pronoun
--Meanings--
The lowest cardinal number; half of two; 1.
A single person or thing.
Just one as opposed to any more or to none at all; single (used for emphasis)
Denoting a particular item of a pair or number of items.
Denoting a particular but unspecified occasion or period.
Used before a name to denote a person who is not known to the reader or hearer; a certain.
A noteworthy example of (used for emphasis)
One year old.
One o'clock.
A size of garment or other merchandise denoted by one.
A domino or dice with one spot.
The same; identical.
A joke or story.
An alcoholic drink.
Alone.
Referring to a person or thing previously mentioned or easily identified.
A person of a specified kind.
A person who is remarkable in some way.
Used to refer to the speaker, or any person, as representing people in general.
--Examples--
‘there's only room for one person’
‘two could live as cheaply as one’
‘one hundred miles’
‘a one-bedroom flat’
‘they would straggle home in ones and twos’
‘her one concern is to save her daughter’
‘electronics is one of his hobbies’
‘a glass tube closed at one end’
‘one afternoon in late October’
‘he worked as a clerk for one Mr Ming’
‘the actor was one smart-mouthed troublemaker’
‘he was one hell of a snappy dresser’
‘I'll be there at one’
‘all types of training meet one common standard’
‘the one about the Englishman, the Irishman, and the Yank’
‘a cool one after a day on the water’
‘the time when you one tackled a field of cane and finished before the others had even started’
‘her mood changed from one of moroseness to one of joy’
‘her best apron, the white one’
‘do you want one?’
‘you're the one who ruined her life’
‘my friends and loved ones’
‘you never saw such a one for figures’
‘one must admire him for his willingness’
‘one gets the impression that he is ahead’

--Word--
class 
--Type--
noun, verb, adjective
--Meanings--
A set or category of things having some property or attribute in common and differentiated from others by kind, type, or quality.
A principal taxonomic grouping that ranks above order and below phylum or division, such as Mammalia or Insecta.
A division of candidates according to merit in a university examination.
A system of ordering society whereby people are divided into sets based on perceived social or economic status.
A social division based on social or economic status.
The rich or educated.
Impressive stylishness in appearance or behaviour.
A group of students or pupils who are taught together.
An occasion when pupils meet with their teacher for instruction; a lesson.
A course of instruction.
All of the college or school students of a particular year.
Assign or regard as belonging to a particular category.
Showing stylish excellence.
--Examples--
‘it has good accommodation for a hotel of this class’
‘a new class of heart drug’
‘he received a third class in literae humaniores’
‘people who are socially disenfranchised by class’
‘the class system’
‘the ruling class’
‘she's got class—she looks like a princess’
‘selected pupils act as representatives for the whole class’
‘I was late for a class’
‘I took classes in Indian music’
‘the class of 1999’
‘conduct which is classed as criminal’
‘he's a class player’

crop 
--Type--
noun, verb
--Meanings--
A cultivated plant that is grown on a large scale commercially, especially a cereal, fruit, or vegetable.
An amount of produce harvested at one time.
An abundance of something, especially a person's hair.
The total number of young farm animals born in a particular year on one farm.
A group or amount of related people or things appearing or occurring at one time.
A hairstyle in which the hair is cut very short.
A pouch in a bird's gullet where food is stored or prepared for digestion.
An organ resembling a pouch in an insect or earthworm.
The entire tanned hide of an animal.
Cut (something, especially a person's hair) very short.
(of an animal) bite off and eat the tops of (plants)
Cut the edges of (a photograph) in order to produce a better picture or to fit a given space.
Harvest (plants or their produce) from a particular area.
Sow or plant (land) with plants that will produce food or fodder, especially on a large commercial scale.
(of land or a plant) yield a harvest of plants or produce.
crop out
(of rock) appear or be exposed at the surface of the earth.
crop up
Appear, occur, or come to one's notice unexpectedly.
--Examples--
‘the main crops were oats and barley’
‘a heavy crop of fruit’
‘he had a thick crop of wiry hair’
‘failure to observe sound practice leads to a lamb crop at weaning of around 50–60 per cent’
‘the current crop of politicians’
‘she has her hair cut in a short crop’
‘the parent waxbill partially digests food in its crop’
‘she cropped her long golden hair’
‘the horse was gratefully cropping the grass’
‘you can always crop the picture afterwards’
‘hay would have been cropped several times through the summer’
‘the southern areas are cropped in cotton’
‘the parsley will need protection to continue cropping through the winter’
‘high hills are found where the igneous rocks of eastern South Uist crop out’
‘some urgent business had cropped up’

Informal (originally British regional). Especially of a town: small, inferior, inadequate, unimportant.

--Word--
fourth 
--Type--
ordinal number
--Meanings--
Constituting number four in a sequence; 4th.
The fourth finisher or position in a race or competition.
The fourth (and often highest) in a sequence of a vehicle's gears.
The fourth form of a school or college.
Fourthly (used to introduce a fourth point)
An interval spanning four consecutive notes in a diatonic scale, in particular (also perfect fourth) an interval of two tones and a semitone (e.g. C to F).
The note which is higher by a fourth than the tonic of a diatonic scale or root of a chord.
A quarter.
--Examples--
‘the fourth and fifth centuries’
‘there were three bedrooms, with potential for a fourth’
‘he could do no better than finish fourth’
‘he took the corner in fourth’
‘third, visit popular attractions during lunch; fourth, stay late’
‘nearly three fourths of that money is now gone’

O'Neill, Eugene 
--Type--
proper noun
--Meanings--
(1888–1953), American playwright; full name Eugene Gladstone O'Neill. He was awarded the Pulitzer Prize for his first full-length play, Beyond the Horizon (1920). Other notable works: The Iceman Cometh (1946) and Long Day's Journey into Night (1956, posthumously).

--Word--
leaf 
--Type--
noun, verb
--Meanings--
A flattened structure of a higher plant, typically green and blade-like, that is attached to a stem directly or via a stalk. Leaves are the main organs of photosynthesis and transpiration.
Any of a number of plant structures similar to leaves, e.g. bracts, sepals, and petals.
Foliage regarded collectively.
The state of having leaves.
The leaves of tobacco or tea.
A thing that resembles a leaf in being flat and thin.
A single thickness of paper, especially in a book with each side forming a page.
Gold, silver, or other specified metal in the form of very thin foil.
The hinged part or flap of a door, shutter, or table.
An extra section inserted to extend a table.
The inner or outer part of a cavity wall or double-glazed window.
(of a plant, especially a deciduous one in spring) put out new leaves.
Turn over (the pages of a book or the papers in a pile), reading them quickly or casually.
--Examples--
‘many of the trees had lost their leaves’
‘bay leaves’
‘an oak leaf’
‘the trees are still in leaf’
‘leaf tea’
‘gold leaf’
‘many plants need a period of dormancy before they leaf and flower’
‘he leafed through the stack of notes’

--Examples--
‘ivy-leaved toadflax’

--Word--
letter 
--Type--
noun, verb
--Meanings--
A character representing one or more of the sounds used in speech; any of the symbols of an alphabet.
The initials of a degree or other qualification.
A school or college initial as a mark of proficiency, especially in sport.
A written, typed, or printed communication, sent in an envelope by post or messenger.
A legal or formal document.
The precise terms of a statement or requirement; the strict verbal interpretation.
Literature.
Scholarly knowledge; erudition.
A style of typeface.
Inscribe letters or writing on.
Classify with letters.
Be given a school or college initial as a mark of proficiency in sport.
--Examples--
‘a capital letter’
‘your personality matters far more than letters after your name’
‘a letter jacket’
‘he sent a letter to Mrs Falconer’
‘the officer in the incident got in trouble for following the letter of the law’
‘we must keep the spirit of the law as well as the letter’
‘the world of letters’
‘her name was lettered in gold’
‘he numbered and lettered the paragraphs’
‘in high school she lettered in soccer, basketball and softball’

--Word--
lung 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
Each of the pair of organs situated within the ribcage, consisting of elastic sacs with branching passages into which air is drawn, so that oxygen can pass into the blood and carbon dioxide be removed. Lungs are characteristic of vertebrates other than fish, though similar structures are present in some other animal groups.
An open space in a town or city, where people can breathe fresher air.
--Examples--
‘the city had to be given lungs, in the shape of open spaces, squares, parks, and gardens’
--Word--
lunged 
--Type--
adjective
--Meanings--
Having lungs, especially of a specified kind.
--Examples--
‘lunged fish’
‘his big-lunged female backing singer’
