--Word--
one-pipe 
--Type--
adjective
--Meanings--
Designating a system of hot-water central heating in which radiators take water from and return it to the same pipe, which runs in a complete circuit from the boiler and back to it again.
Designating a system of plumbing in which waste from sinks, etc., is conveyed to the sewer by the same pipe as that from lavatories (i.e. the waste pipe and soil pipe are effectively combined).
--Examples--
--Word--
point 
--Type--
noun, verb
--Meanings--
The tapered, sharp end of a tool, weapon, or other object.
A pointed flake or blade, especially one that has been worked.
The tip of a person's chin as a spot for a blow.
The prong of a deer's antler.
A dot or other punctuation mark, in particular a full stop.
A decimal point.
A dot or small stroke used in Semitic languages to indicate vowels or distinguish particular consonants.
A very small dot or mark.
A particular spot, place, or position in an area or on a map, object, or surface.
A particular moment in time or stage in a process.
The critical or decisive moment.
The verge or brink of (doing or being something)
A stage or level at which a change of state occurs.
A socket in a wall for connecting a device to an electrical supply or communications network.
(in geometry) something having position but not spatial extent, magnitude, dimension, or direction, for example the intersection of two lines.
A single item or detail in an extended discussion, list, or text.
An argument or idea.
The significant or essential element of something being planned or discussed.
Advantage or purpose that can be gained from doing something.
Relevance or effectiveness.
A distinctive feature or characteristic, typically a good one, of a person or thing.
(in sports and games) a mark or unit of scoring awarded for success or performance.
A unit used in measuring value, achievement, or extent.
An advantage or success in an argument or discussion.
A unit of credit towards an award or benefit.
A percentage of the profits from a film or recording offered to certain people involved in its production.
(in piquet) the longest suit in a player's hand, containing a specified number of up to eight cards.
A unit of weight (2 mg) for diamonds.
A unit of varying value, used in quoting the price of stocks, bonds, or futures.
A value assigned to certain cards (4 points for an ace, 3 for a king, 2 for a queen, and 1 for a jack, sometimes with extra points for long or short suits) by a player in assessing the strength of their hand.
Each of thirty-two directions marked at equal distances round a compass.
A direction towards the horizon corresponding to the direction marked on a compass.
The angular interval between two successive points of a compass, i.e. one eighth of a right angle (11° 15ʹ).
Unspecified places considered in terms of their direction from a specified place.
A narrow piece of land jutting out into the sea.
A junction of two railway lines, with a pair of linked tapering rails that can be moved laterally to allow a train to pass from one line to the other.
A unit of measurement for type sizes and spacing (in the UK and US 0.351 mm, in Europe 0.376 mm).
A fielding position on the off side near the batsman.
A fielder at the point position.
Either of two areas to the left and right of the net, just inside the blue line where it meets the boards.
A position at the front of the court, usually manned by the guard who sets up the team's defence.
(in a motor vehicle) each of a set of electrical contacts in the distributor.
A small leading party of an advanced guard of troops.
The position at the head of a column or wedge of troops.
The extremities of an animal, typically a horse or cat, such as the face, paws, and tail of a Siamese cat.
A spot to which a straight run is made.
A straight run.
A tagged piece of ribbon or cord used for lacing a garment or attaching a hose to a doublet.
A short piece of cord at the lower edge of a sail for tying up a reef.
The action or position of a dog in pointing.
An important phrase or subject, especially in a contrapuntal composition.
Direct someone's attention towards something by extending one's finger or something held in one's hand.
Indicate a particular time, direction, or reading.
Direct or aim (something) at someone or something.
Face or be turned in a particular direction.
(of a dog) indicate the presence of (game) by standing rigid while looking towards it.
Cite a fact or situation as evidence of something.
(of a fact or situation) indicate that (something) is likely to happen or be the case.
Give force or emphasis to (words or actions)
Extend (the toes or feet) in line with the leg by tensing the foot and ankle in such a way as to form a point.
Fill the joints of (brickwork or masonry) with smoothly finished mortar.
Give a sharp, tapered point to.
Insert points in (written text of Semitic languages).
Mark (Psalms) with signs for chanting.
--Examples--
‘the point of his dagger’
‘a pencil point’
‘Andrews caught him on the point’
‘a fine buck of eight points’
‘fifty-five point nine’
‘the sky was studded with points of light’
‘turn left at the point where you see a sign to Appleford’
‘the furthermost point of the gallery’
‘the check-in point’
‘from this point onwards the teacher was completely won over’
‘when it came to the point he would probably do what was expected of him’
‘she was on the point of leaving’
‘local kennels are full to bursting point’
‘a power point’
‘the main points of the Edinburgh agreement’
‘he made the point that economic regulation involves controls on pricing’
‘it took her a long time to come to the point’
‘some speakers rambled and never seemed to get to the point’
‘that's not the point’
‘there was no point in denying the truth’
‘what's the point of having things I don't need?’
‘he has his good points’
‘he kicked a penalty goal to put Bangor eight points ahead’
‘the shares index was down seven points’
‘she smiled, assuming she had won her point’
‘points were allocated according to the inadequacy of the existing accommodation’
‘in Acol it is permissible to open with only twelve points’
‘they headed down Highway 401 to Ontario and points west’
‘the boat came round the point’
‘Blakeney Point’
‘the train gave a lurch as it passed over the points’
‘he walked point and I took the tail’

‘our fox made his point to Moorhill’

‘he wouldn't miss the opportunity to point a moral’

--Word--
quarter 
--Type--
noun, verb
--Meanings--
Each of four equal or corresponding parts into which something is or can be divided.
A period of three months regarded as one fourth of a year, used especially in reference to financial transactions such as the payment of bills or a company's earnings.
A period of fifteen minutes or a point of time marking the transition from one fifteen-minute period to the next.
A coin representing 25 cents, a quarter of a US or Canadian dollar.
Each of the four parts into which an animal's or bird's carcass may be divided, each including a leg or wing.
One fourth of a lunar month.
(in basketball, American football, and Australian Rules) each of four equal periods into which a game is divided.
One of four terms into which a school or university year may be divided.
One fourth of a pound weight (avoirdupois, equal to 4 ounces).
One fourth of a hundredweight (in the UK 28 lb or in the US 25lb).
A grain measure equivalent to 8 bushels.
The haunches or hindquarters of a horse.
A part of a town or city having a particular character or use.
The direction of one of the points of the compass, especially as a direction from which the wind blows.
A particular but unspecified person, group of people, or area.
Either side of a ship aft of the beam.
Rooms or lodgings, especially those allocated to people in military or domestic service.
Pity or mercy shown towards an enemy or opponent who is in one's power.
Each of four or more roughly equal divisions of a shield separated by vertical and horizontal lines.
A square charge which covers the top left (dexter chief) quarter of the field.
Divide into four equal or corresponding parts.
Cut (the body of an executed person) into four parts.
Cut (a log) into quarters, and these into planks so as to show the grain well.
Be stationed or lodged in a specified place.
Impose someone on (another person) as a lodger.
Range over or traverse (an area) in every direction.
Move at an angle; go in a diagonal or zigzag direction.
Display (different coats of arms) in quarters of a shield, especially to show arms inherited from heiresses who have married into the bearer's family.
Divide (a shield) into four or more parts by vertical and horizontal lines.
--Examples--
‘she cut each apple into quarters’
‘a page and a quarter’
‘a quarter of a mile’
‘the first quarter of the fiscal year’
‘he sat with his pint until a quarter past nine’
‘there were four scores in the opening quarter’
‘they have strong, muscular quarters’
‘a beautiful port city with a fascinating medieval quarter’
‘we have just had help from an unexpected quarter’
‘he trained his glasses over the starboard quarter’
‘they lived in RAF married quarters’
‘the riot squad gave no quarter’
‘peel and quarter the bananas’
‘the plotters were hanged, drawn, and quartered’
‘many were quartered in tents’
‘you would have had her quartered on you forever’
‘we watched a pair of kingfishers quartering the river looking for minnows’
‘his young dog quartered back and forth in quick turns’
‘Edward III quartered the French royal arms with his own’

A noteworthy example of (used for emphasis)
One year old.
One o'clock.

A domino or dice with one spot.
The same; identical.
A joke or story.
An alcoholic drink.
Alone.
Referring to a person or thing previously mentioned or easily identified.
A person of a specified kind.
A person who is remarkable in some way.
Used to refer to the speaker, or any person, as representing people in general.

‘my friends and loved ones’
‘you never saw such a one for figures’

spot 
--Type--
noun, verb
--Meanings--
A small round or roundish mark, differing in colour or texture from the surface around it.
A small mark or stain.
A pimple.
A blemish on someone's character or reputation.
A pip on a domino, playing card, or dice.
A particular place or point.
A small feature or part of something with a particular quality.
A ranking.
A place for an individual item within a show.
A small amount of something.
A small alcoholic drink.
Denoting a system of trading in which commodities or currencies are delivered and paid for immediately after a sale.
A board for working plaster before application.
A banknote of a specified value.
See, notice, or recognize (someone or something) that is difficult to detect or that one is searching for.
Recognize that (someone) has a particular talent, especially for sport or show business.
Observe and note the details of (a certain class of thing) as a hobby.
Locate an enemy's position, typically from the air.
(in weight training, gymnastics, etc.) observe (a performer) in order to minimize the risk of accidents or injuries.
Mark or become marked with spots.
Cover (a surface or area) thinly.
Stain or sully the moral character or qualities of.
Rain slightly.
Place (a ball) on its designated starting point on a billiard table.
Give or lend (money) to (someone)
Allow (an advantage) to (someone) in a game or sport.
--Examples--
‘ladybirds have black spots on their red wing covers’

--Word--
story 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
An account of imaginary or real people and events told for entertainment.
A plot or storyline.
A report of an item of news in a newspaper, magazine, or broadcast.
A piece of gossip; a rumour.
A false statement; a lie.
An account of past events in someone's life or in the development of something.
A particular person's representation of the facts of a matter.
A situation viewed in terms of the information known about it or its similarity to another.
The facts about the present situation.
The commercial prospects or circumstances of a particular company.
--Examples--
‘an adventure story’
‘I'm going to tell you a story’
‘the novel has a good story’
‘stories in the local papers’
‘there have been lots of stories going around, as you can imagine’
‘Ellie never told stories—she had always believed in the truth’
‘the story of modern farming’
‘the film is based on a true story’
‘during police interviews, Harper changed his story’
‘having such information is useful, but it is not the whole story’
‘United kept on trying but it was the same old story—no luck’
‘What's the story on this man? Is he from around here?’
‘the investors' flight to profitable businesses with solid stories’
--Word--
storied 
--Type--
adjective, adjective
--Meanings--
Celebrated in or associated with stories or legends.
--Examples--
‘the island's storied past’

--Meanings--
--Examples--

--Meanings--

--Word--
third 
--Type--
ordinal number
--Meanings--
Constituting number three in a sequence; 3rd.
The third finisher or position in a race or competition.
The third in a sequence of a vehicle's gears.
Third base.
The third form of a school or college.
Thirdly (used to introduce a third point or reason)
A place in the third grade in an examination, especially that for a degree.
Each of three equal parts into which something is or may be divided.
An interval spanning three consecutive notes in a diatonic scale, e.g. C to E (major third, equal to two tones) or A to C (minor third, equal to a tone and a semitone).
The note which is higher by a third than the tonic of a diatonic scale or root of a chord.
--Examples--
‘the third century’
‘the third of October’
‘Edward the Third’
‘Hill finished third’
‘he took the corner in third’
‘second, they are lightly regulated; and third, they do business with non-resident clients’
‘a third of a mile’

--Type--
noun
--Meanings--

one-way 
--Type--
adjective
--Meanings--
Moving or allowing movement in one direction only.
(of a ticket) allowing a person to travel to a place but not back again; single.
Denoting a mirror or glass that acts as a reflective surface on one side but that is transparent from the other.
Denoting a relationship in which all the input comes from only one member.
--Examples--
‘a one-way valve’
‘a one-way street’
‘interaction between the organism and the environment is not a one-way process’

onfall 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
An attack or onset of disease or other misfortune. In Old English perhaps: specifically †a swelling (obsolete). Now: specifically (Scottish) a sudden cold or fever.
Generally. An attack, assault, or onslaught.

--Type--
phrasal verb
--Meanings--

Talk at great length, especially tediously or angrily.

Said when encouraging someone or expressing disbelief.
Happen.
Proceed to do.
Have a specified amount of care or liking for (something)

‘go on, tell him!’

‘I heard this album last month and didn't go much on it’

Onychophora 
--Type--
plural noun
--Meanings--
A small phylum of terrestrial invertebrates which comprises the velvet worms such as peripatus. They share characteristics with the arthropods and annelids, having a long, soft segmented body with stubby legs (lobopods).
--Examples--
--Word--
onychophoran 
--Type--
noun, adjective
--Meanings--
A terrestrial invertebrate of the small phylum Onychophora, which comprises the velvet worms.
Relating to or denoting onychophorans.

noun

onlap 
--Type--
noun, verb
--Meanings--
A progressive increase in the lateral extent of conformable strata in passing upwards from older to younger strata, so that each stratum is hidden by the one above; a set of strata exhibiting this.
To cover (a stratum) so as to form an onlap.
--Examples--
--Word--
only 
--Type--
adverb, adjective, conjunction
--Meanings--
And no one or nothing more besides; solely.
No more than (implying that more was expected); merely.
No longer ago than.
Not until.
With the negative or unfortunate result that.
In an inevitable but undesirable way.
Alone of its or their kind; single or solitary.
Alone deserving consideration.
Except that; but.
--Examples--
‘there are only a limited number of tickets available’
‘only their faith sustained them’
‘deaths from heart disease have only declined by 10 per cent’
‘she was still only in her mid thirties’
‘genes that were discovered only last year’
‘a final report reached him only on January 15’
‘she turned into the car park, only to find her way blocked’
‘rebellion will only bring more unhappiness’
‘the only medal we had ever won’
‘he was an only child’
‘it's simply the only place to be seen these days’
‘he is still a young man, only he seems older because of his careworn expression’
‘the place was like school, only better’

--Word--
onshore 
--Type--
UnKnownKind, verb
--Meanings--
Situated or occurring on land (often used in relation to the oil and gas industry)
(especially of the wind) from the sea towards the land.
(of a company) transfer (a business operation that was moved overseas) back to the country from which it was originally relocated.
--Examples--
‘an onshore oilfield’
‘a slight onshore breeze’
‘we moved onshore’
‘the case study showed improvement in many key areas once the company decided to onshore its call centre activity’
--Word--
onside 
--Type--
UnKnownKind
--Meanings--
(of a player, especially in soccer, rugby, or hockey) occupying a position where playing the ball or puck is allowed; not offside.
In or into a position of agreement.
--Examples--
‘an onside position’
‘he was trying to get back onside, but Williams shoved him’
‘the assurances helped bring officials onside’

--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
Scottish and English regional (northern). The farmhouse and other buildings belonging to a farm; a farmstead. Also: specifically the outbuildings on a farm, as distinct from the farmhouse, or the farmhouse, as distinct from the outbuildings. Compare "onset"; "stead". Now rare.

--Word--
Ontario 
--Type--
proper noun, proper noun
--Meanings--
A province of eastern Canada, between Hudson Bay and the Great Lakes; population 12,160,282 (2006); capital, Toronto. It was settled by the French and English in the 17th century, ceded to Britain in 1763, and became one of the original four provinces in the Dominion of Canada in 1867.
A commercial city in south-west California, east of Los Angeles; population 171,691 (est. 2008).

ooplasm 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
Biology. The cytoplasm of an egg. Also: each of the regions of the cytoplasm of an egg which develop into distinct structures in the body.
Mycology. In an oomycete, especially one of the order Peronosporales: the central portion of the oogonial cytoplasm, which becomes the oosphere.

--Meanings--

--Word--
ooze 
--Type--
verb, noun, noun
--Meanings--
(of a fluid) slowly trickle or seep out of something.
Slowly exude or discharge a viscous fluid.
Give a powerful impression of (a quality)
The sluggish flow of a fluid.
An infusion of oak bark or other vegetable matter, used in tanning.
Wet mud or slime, especially that found at the bottom of a river, lake, or sea.
A deposit of white or grey calcareous matter largely composed of foraminiferan remains, covering extensive areas of the ocean floor.
--Examples--
‘blood was oozing from a wound in his scalp’
‘honey oozed out of the comb’
‘her mosquito bites were oozing and itching like mad’
‘she oozes a raunchy sex appeal’
‘I picked a fruit and watched the ooze of fig milk from the stem’
‘abandoned barges sunk in ooze’
--Word--
ooze 
--Type--
verb, noun, noun
--Meanings--

Slowly exude or discharge a viscous fluid.
Give a powerful impression of (a quality)
The sluggish flow of a fluid.

Wet mud or slime, especially that found at the bottom of a river, lake, or sea.

--Meanings--
(of a fluid) slowly trickle or seep out of something.
Slowly exude or discharge a viscous fluid.
Give a powerful impression of (a quality)
The sluggish flow of a fluid.
An infusion of oak bark or other vegetable matter, used in tanning.
Wet mud or slime, especially that found at the bottom of a river, lake, or sea.
A deposit of white or grey calcareous matter largely composed of foraminiferan remains, covering extensive areas of the ocean floor.
--Examples--
‘blood was oozing from a wound in his scalp’
‘honey oozed out of the comb’
‘her mosquito bites were oozing and itching like mad’
‘she oozes a raunchy sex appeal’
‘I picked a fruit and watched the ooze of fig milk from the stem’
‘abandoned barges sunk in ooze’

opacite 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
Microscopic dark grains and scales occurring in the groundmass of many igneous rocks, which are too small to be readily identified by optical means and are sometimes attributed to iron oxides or carbon.
--Examples--

Opel, Wilhelm von 
--Type--
proper noun
--Meanings--
(1871–1948), German motor manufacturer. His company was the first in Germany to introduce assembly-line production, selling over one million cars.

--Word--
opelet 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
More fully "opelet anemone". Any of several sea anemones of the genus Anemonia, characterized by long tentacles that cannot be fully retracted; especially A. sulcata, which occurs in both brown and green forms and is found in the north-east Atlantic and the Mediterranean.

--Word--
open 
--Type--
adjective, verb, noun
--Meanings--
Allowing access, passage, or a view through an empty space; not closed or blocked.
(of a container) not fastened or sealed.
(of a garment or its fastenings) not done up.
(of the mouth or eyes) with lips or lids parted.
(of a fabric) loosely knitted or woven.
(of the bowels) not constipated.
Exposed to the air or to view; not covered.
(of land) not covered with buildings or trees.
Damaged by a deep cut in the surface.
Likely to suffer from or be affected by; vulnerable or subject to.
(of a goalmouth or other object of attack in a game) unprotected by defenders.
(of a town or city) officially declared to be undefended, and so immune under international law from bombardment.
With the outer edges or sides drawn away from each other; unfolded or spread out.
(of a book or file) with the covers parted allowing it to be read.
(of a hand) not clenched into a fist.
(of a business, place of entertainment, etc.) admitting customers or visitors; available for business.
(of a bank account) available for transactions.
(of a telephone line) ready to take calls.
Freely available or accessible; unrestricted.
(of an offer or opportunity) still available.
With no restrictions on those allowed to participate.
(of a victor) having won an open competition.
(of a ticket) not restricted as to day of travel.
(of a cheque) not crossed.
(of a set) not containing any of its limit points.
Not concealing one's thoughts or feelings; frank and communicative.
Not concealed.
(of conflict) fully developed and unconcealed.
Welcoming public discussion, criticism, and enquiry.
(of a game or style of play) characterized by action which is spread out over the field.
(of a matter or decision) not finally settled; still admitting of debate.
(of the mind) accessible to new ideas.
Receptive to.
Admitting of; making possible.
(of a vowel) produced with a relatively wide opening of the mouth and the tongue kept low.
(of a syllable) ending in a vowel.
(of a string) allowed to vibrate along its whole length.
(of a pipe) unstopped at each end.
(of a note) sounded from an open string or pipe.
(of an electric circuit) having a break in the conducting path.
Move (a door or window) so as to leave a space allowing access and vision.
(of a door or window) be moved to leave a space allowing access.
Undo or remove the lid, cover, or fastening of (a container, package, letter, etc.) to get access to the contents.
Part the lips or lids of (one's mouth or eye)
(of the mouth or eyes) have the lips or lids parted.
Come apart; lose or lack its protective covering.
(of a room, door, or window) give access to.
Cause evacuation of (the bowels).
Unfold or be unfolded; spread out.
Part the covers of (a book or file) to read it.
Become wider.
(of a prospect) extend into view.
Achieve a clear view of (a place) by sailing past a headland or other obstruction.
Make or become formally ready for customers, visitors, or business.
Ceremonially declare (a building, road, etc.) to be completed and ready for use.
Make possible access to or passage through.
Formally establish or begin (a new business, movement, or enterprise)
(of an enterprise, meeting, or event) begin or be formally established.
Take the action required to begin using.
(of a piece of writing or music) begin.
(of a process) start to develop.
(of a counsel in a law court) make a preliminary statement in (a case) before calling witnesses.
Make (the first bid) in the auction.
Make available or more widely known.
Become more communicative or confiding.
Make (one's mind) more receptive or sympathetic.
Make someone vulnerable to.
Break the conducting path of (an electric circuit)
(of an electric circuit or device) suffer a break in its conducting path.
Outdoors or in the countryside.
Not subject to concealment; made public.
A championship or competition with no restrictions on who may compete.
An accidental break in the conducting path for an electric current.

--Word--
openness 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
Lack of restriction; accessibility.
Acceptance of or receptiveness to change or new ideas.
Lack of secrecy or concealment; frankness.
The quality of not being covered with buildings or trees.
(in sport) a style of play characterized by action which is spread out over the field.
--Examples--
‘our hallmark was openness to all comers’
‘the openness of the Internet makes public debate more possible’
‘it is the openness to possibilities that creates great research’
‘total openness to all points of view’
‘a democratic society committed to openness and transparency’
‘the openness of the Western landscape’
‘fitness levels have evolved to increase the speed and openness of the game’

openbill 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
Either of two snail-eating storks of the genus Anastomus, A. lamelligerus of Africa and A. oscitans of Asia, which have mandibles that only meet at the tips, leaving a wide gap in the middle of the closed bill.

noun

--Word--
coil 
--Type--
noun, verb, noun
--Meanings--
A length of something wound in a joined sequence of concentric rings.
A single ring in a coil.
An intrauterine contraceptive device in the form of a coil.
An electrical device consisting of a coiled wire, for converting the level of a voltage, producing a magnetic field, or adding inductance to a circuit.
Such a device used for transmitting high voltage to the spark plugs of an internal combustion engine.
A slow-burning spiral made from the dried paste of pyrethrum powder, which produces a smoke that deters mosquitoes.
A roll of postage stamps, especially one for use in a vending machine.
Arrange (something long and flexible) in a coil.
Move or twist into the shape of a coil.
A confusion or turmoil.
--Examples--
‘a coil of rope’
‘the snake wrapped its coils around her’
‘many women don't like the idea of having a coil fitted’
‘a relay coil’
‘he began to coil up the heavy ropes’
‘he coiled a lock of her hair around his finger’
‘smoke coiled lazily towards the ceiling’

crib 
--Type--
noun, verb
--Meanings--
A child's bed with barred or latticed sides; a cot.
A barred container or rack for animal fodder; a manger.
A model of the Nativity of Christ, with a manger as a bed.
A translation of a text for use by students, especially in a surreptitious way.
A thing that has been plagiarized.
A person's apartment or house.
The cards discarded by the players at cribbage, counting to the dealer.
A heavy timber framework used in foundations for a building or to line a mineshaft.
A light meal; a snack.
Copy (another person's work) illicitly or without acknowledgement.
Steal.
Restrain.
Grumble.
--Examples--
‘tiptoeing over to the crib, he looked down at the sleeping child’
‘a choir was singing carols by a crib’
‘an English crib of Caesar's Gallic Wars’
‘is the song a crib from Mozart's ‘Don Giovanni’?’
‘there's a chance you might not get back to your crib tonight’
‘he would play crib with zest’
‘I was carrying my crib in a paper bag’
‘he was doing an exam and didn't want anybody to crib the answers from him’

‘those guys have nothing to crib about’

--Meanings--

Figurative. Ready to take in or receive; keeping open house, hospitable.
--Examples--
--Word--
eared 
--Type--
adjective
--Meanings--
--Examples--
‘long-eared’
--Word--
open 
--Type--
adjective, verb, noun
--Meanings--
Allowing access, passage, or a view through an empty space; not closed or blocked.
(of a container) not fastened or sealed.
(of a garment or its fastenings) not done up.
(of the mouth or eyes) with lips or lids parted.
(of a fabric) loosely knitted or woven.
(of the bowels) not constipated.
Exposed to the air or to view; not covered.
(of land) not covered with buildings or trees.
Damaged by a deep cut in the surface.
Likely to suffer from or be affected by; vulnerable or subject to.
(of a goalmouth or other object of attack in a game) unprotected by defenders.
(of a town or city) officially declared to be undefended, and so immune under international law from bombardment.
With the outer edges or sides drawn away from each other; unfolded or spread out.
(of a book or file) with the covers parted allowing it to be read.
(of a hand) not clenched into a fist.
(of a business, place of entertainment, etc.) admitting customers or visitors; available for business.
(of a bank account) available for transactions.
(of a telephone line) ready to take calls.
Freely available or accessible; unrestricted.
(of an offer or opportunity) still available.
With no restrictions on those allowed to participate.
(of a victor) having won an open competition.
(of a ticket) not restricted as to day of travel.
(of a cheque) not crossed.
(of a set) not containing any of its limit points.
Not concealing one's thoughts or feelings; frank and communicative.
Not concealed.
(of conflict) fully developed and unconcealed.
Welcoming public discussion, criticism, and enquiry.
(of a game or style of play) characterized by action which is spread out over the field.
(of a matter or decision) not finally settled; still admitting of debate.
(of the mind) accessible to new ideas.
Receptive to.
Admitting of; making possible.
(of a vowel) produced with a relatively wide opening of the mouth and the tongue kept low.
(of a syllable) ending in a vowel.
(of a string) allowed to vibrate along its whole length.
(of a pipe) unstopped at each end.
(of a note) sounded from an open string or pipe.
(of an electric circuit) having a break in the conducting path.
Move (a door or window) so as to leave a space allowing access and vision.
(of a door or window) be moved to leave a space allowing access.
Undo or remove the lid, cover, or fastening of (a container, package, letter, etc.) to get access to the contents.
Part the lips or lids of (one's mouth or eye)
(of the mouth or eyes) have the lips or lids parted.
Come apart; lose or lack its protective covering.
(of a room, door, or window) give access to.
Cause evacuation of (the bowels).
Unfold or be unfolded; spread out.
Part the covers of (a book or file) to read it.
Become wider.
(of a prospect) extend into view.
Achieve a clear view of (a place) by sailing past a headland or other obstruction.
Make or become formally ready for customers, visitors, or business.
Ceremonially declare (a building, road, etc.) to be completed and ready for use.
Make possible access to or passage through.
Formally establish or begin (a new business, movement, or enterprise)
(of an enterprise, meeting, or event) begin or be formally established.
Take the action required to begin using.
(of a piece of writing or music) begin.
(of a process) start to develop.
(of a counsel in a law court) make a preliminary statement in (a case) before calling witnesses.
Make (the first bid) in the auction.
Make available or more widely known.
Become more communicative or confiding.
Make (one's mind) more receptive or sympathetic.
Make someone vulnerable to.
Break the conducting path of (an electric circuit)
(of an electric circuit or device) suffer a break in its conducting path.
Outdoors or in the countryside.
Not subject to concealment; made public.
A championship or competition with no restrictions on who may compete.
An accidental break in the conducting path for an electric current.
--Examples--
‘he climbed through the open window’
‘she was put in a cubicle with the curtains left open’
‘the pass is kept open by snowploughs’
‘the case burst open and its contents flew all over the place’
‘his tie was knotted below the open collar of his shirt’
‘his eyes were open but he could see nothing’
‘the boy's mouth dropped open in shock’
‘an open fire burned in the grate’
‘he crossed the ocean in an open boat’
‘the plans allow increasing numbers of new houses in open countryside’
‘he had his arm slashed open’
‘the system is open to abuse’
‘the trees had buds and a few open flowers’
‘she was copying verses from an open Bible’
‘the shop stays open until 9 p.m’
‘parts of the castle are open to the public’
‘I withdrew all my money except the minimum required to keep the account open’
‘our free advice line is open from 8.30 to 17.30’
‘the service is open to all students’
‘the offer is open while stocks last’
‘we need to consider what options are left open’
‘open discussion meetings’
‘each horse had won two open races’
‘an Open champion’
‘I have an open ticket, so I can travel any day I like’
‘she behaved in an open and cheerful manner’
‘I was quite open about my views’
‘his eyes showed open admiration as they swept over her’
‘the dispute erupted into open war’
‘the party's commitment to open government’
‘both sides played fast, open rugby to produce a high-scoring game’
‘students' choice of degree can be kept open until the second year’
‘I'm keeping an open mind about my future’
‘the union was open to suggestions for improvements’
‘the message is open to different interpretations’
‘she opened the door and went in’
‘‘Open up!’ he said’
‘the door opened and a man came out’
‘he opened a bottle inexpertly, spilling some of the wine’
‘can we open the presents now?’
‘she opened her mouth to argue’
‘her eyes slowly opened’
‘old wounds opened and I bled a little bit’
‘the kitchen opened into a pleasant sitting room’
‘the eagle opened its wings and circled up into the air’
‘the tail looks like a fan when it is opened out fully’
‘the flowers only open during bright weather’
‘she opened her book at the prologue’
‘the path opened out into a glade’
‘stop to marvel at the views that open out below’
‘we shall open Torbay shortly’
‘she raised $731 by opening her home and selling coffee and tea’
‘the shops didn't open until 10’
‘the Queen opened the power plant on 17 October 1956’
‘the President announced that his government would open the border’
‘she began to teach and opened her own school’
‘we opened up a branch in Madrid’
‘two new restaurants open this week’
‘they have the £10 necessary to open a savings account’
‘click twice to open a file for the software selected’
‘the chapter opens with a discussion of Anglo-Irish relations’
‘a new and dramatic phase was opening up’
‘Bernard had opened the case’
‘Comyn opened for the plaintiff’
‘West opened 2NT’
‘do not open with fewer than twelve points’
‘new technologies open up thousands of different opportunities’
‘the move may force the company to open up its plans for the future’
‘he was very reserved and only opened out to her slowly’
‘open your mind to what is going on around you’
‘the process is going to open them to a legal threat’
‘the switch opens the motor circuit’
‘the problem was caused when a switch opened at the substation’
‘guests were sitting in the open on the terrace’
‘we have never let our dislike for him come into the open’
‘his victory in the 2003 Australian Open’

open-ended 
--Type--
adjective
--Meanings--

--Word--
opener 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A device for opening something, especially a container.
The first in a series of events, games, or actions.
The first goal in a match.
A remark used as an excuse to initiate a conversation.
A batsman who opens the batting.
The player who makes the first bid in the auction.
--Examples--
‘a tin opener’
‘a letter opener’
‘Denver stuffed Buffalo 22–7 in the season opener’
‘Bannister equalized after Armstrong's opener for Palace’
‘we blurted out the obvious opener’
--Word--
opener 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A device for opening something, especially a container.
The first in a series of events, games, or actions.
The first goal in a match.
A remark used as an excuse to initiate a conversation.
A batsman who opens the batting.
The player who makes the first bid in the auction.
--Examples--
‘a tin opener’
‘a letter opener’
‘Denver stuffed Buffalo 22–7 in the season opener’
‘Bannister equalized after Armstrong's opener for Palace’
‘we blurted out the obvious opener’
--Word--
open-faced 
--Type--
adjective
--Meanings--

(of a sandwich or pie) without an upper layer of bread or pastry.
(of a watch, especially a pocket watch) having no cover other than the glass.
--Examples--
‘a quiet open-faced lawyer’
--Word--
open-faced 
--Type--
adjective
--Meanings--
Having a frank or ingenuous expression.
(of a sandwich or pie) without an upper layer of bread or pastry.
(of a watch, especially a pocket watch) having no cover other than the glass.
--Examples--
‘a quiet open-faced lawyer’
--Word--
open field 
--Type--
noun, adjective
--Meanings--
Military. A battlefield allowing unrestricted passage in all directions, as opposed to a situation in which one side is defending a stronghold. Frequently in "in (the) open field". Now chiefly historical.
Figurative. A lack of opposition or competition; an unrestricted or unchallenged opportunity.
An unenclosed field; specifically a field of arable land without physical division by hedges, ditches, etc., used in common rather than by one owner.
Of, designating, or relating to a system of agriculture characterized by open fields. Now historical.
Amer. Football. Of or relating to a field on which the players are widely distributed. Hence of a player: active in the area of the field beyond the line of defence in which the defenders are spread widely apart.
--Examples--
--Word--
open fire 
--Type--
phrase
--Meanings--
Begin to shoot.
--Examples--
‘troops opened fire on crowds armed with staves and knives’
--Word--
flowered 
--Type--
adjective
--Meanings--
Having a floral design.
(of a plant) bearing flowers of a specified kind or number.
--Examples--
‘flowered curtains’
‘yellow-flowered japonica’
--Word--
front 
--Type--
noun, adjective, verb
--Meanings--
The side or part of an object that presents itself to view or that is normally seen or used first; the most forward part of something.
The position directly ahead of someone or something; the most forward position or place.
The forward-facing part of a person's body, on the opposite side to their back.
The part of a garment covering a person's front.
A woman's bust or cleavage.
Any face of a building, especially that of the main entrance.
The foremost line or part of an armed force; the furthest position that an army has reached and where the enemy is or may be engaged.
The direction towards which a line of troops faces when formed.
A particular formation of troops for battle.
A particular situation or sphere of operation.
An organized political group.
The forward edge of an advancing mass of air.
An appearance or form of behaviour assumed by a person to conceal their genuine feelings.
A person or organization serving as a cover for subversive or illegal activities.
Boldness and confidence of manner.
A person's face or forehead.
Of or at the front.
(of a vowel sound) formed by raising the tongue, excluding the blade and tip, towards the hard palate.
(of a building or piece of land) have the front facing or directed towards.
Be or stand in front of.
Provide (something) with a front or facing of a particular type or material.
Lead or be the most prominent member in (an organization, group, or activity)
Present or host (a television or radio programme)
Act as a front or cover for illegal or secret activity.
Adopt a particular expression or form of behaviour to conceal one's genuine feelings.
Make an appearance; turn up.
Stand face to face with; confront.
Articulate (a vowel sound) with the tongue further forward.
Place (a sentence element) at the beginning of a sentence instead of in its usual position, typically for emphasis or as a feature of some dialects, as in horrible it was.
--Examples--
‘a page at the front of the book had been torn out’
‘he sealed the envelope and wrote on the front’
‘she quickly turned her head to face the front’
‘she rolled over on to her front’
‘porridge slopped from the tray on to his shirt front’
‘get your eyes off my front, meathead’
‘the west front of the Cathedral’
‘his regiment was immediately sent to the front’
‘the Spartans preserving an even and unbroken front’
‘there was some good news on the jobs front’
‘the National Progressive Patriotic Front’
‘she put on a brave front’
‘the CIA identified the company as a front for a terrorist group’
‘he's got a bit of talent and a lot of front’
‘the mark of fool set on his front’
‘the front cover of the magazine’
‘she was in the front garden’
‘the flats which fronted Crow Road’
‘both properties fronted on to the beach’
‘they reached the hedge fronting the garden’
‘a metal box fronted by an alloy panel’
‘a glass-fronted bookcase’
‘the group is fronted by two girl singers’
‘she is set to front a new BBC show’
‘he fronted for them in illegal property deals’
‘I can't front, I never really listened to much of his music’
‘parents get a bit worried if you don't front up now and then’
‘Tom fronted him with unwavering eyes’
‘the three velar consonants are normally fronted to some degree’
‘the fronting of /au/ was completed a couple of generations ago’

adjective
--Meanings--
Having a white front; (of an animal) having a white chest, breast, or forehead.

Outdoors or in the countryside.
Not subject to concealment; made public.
A championship or competition with no restrictions on who may compete.
An accidental break in the conducting path for an electric current.
--Examples--
‘he climbed through the open window’
‘she was put in a cubicle with the curtains left open’
‘the pass is kept open by snowploughs’
‘the case burst open and its contents flew all over the place’
‘his tie was knotted below the open collar of his shirt’
‘his eyes were open but he could see nothing’
‘the boy's mouth dropped open in shock’
‘an open fire burned in the grate’
‘he crossed the ocean in an open boat’
‘the plans allow increasing numbers of new houses in open countryside’

‘the system is open to abuse’
‘the trees had buds and a few open flowers’
‘she was copying verses from an open Bible’
‘the shop stays open until 9 p.m’
‘parts of the castle are open to the public’

‘our free advice line is open from 8.30 to 17.30’
‘the service is open to all students’
‘the offer is open while stocks last’
‘we need to consider what options are left open’
‘open discussion meetings’

‘an Open champion’

‘I was quite open about my views’
‘his eyes showed open admiration as they swept over her’
‘the dispute erupted into open war’
‘the party's commitment to open government’
‘both sides played fast, open rugby to produce a high-scoring game’
‘students' choice of degree can be kept open until the second year’
‘I'm keeping an open mind about my future’
‘the union was open to suggestions for improvements’
‘the message is open to different interpretations’

‘‘Open up!’ he said’
‘the door opened and a man came out’
‘he opened a bottle inexpertly, spilling some of the wine’

‘her eyes slowly opened’

‘the kitchen opened into a pleasant sitting room’
‘the eagle opened its wings and circled up into the air’
‘the tail looks like a fan when it is opened out fully’
‘the flowers only open during bright weather’

‘the path opened out into a glade’
‘stop to marvel at the views that open out below’
‘we shall open Torbay shortly’

‘the shops didn't open until 10’

‘the President announced that his government would open the border’

‘we opened up a branch in Madrid’
‘two new restaurants open this week’
‘they have the £10 necessary to open a savings account’

‘Bernard had opened the case’
‘Comyn opened for the plaintiff’
‘West opened 2NT’
‘do not open with fewer than twelve points’
‘new technologies open up thousands of different opportunities’
‘the move may force the company to open up its plans for the future’
‘he was very reserved and only opened out to her slowly’
‘open your mind to what is going on around you’
‘the process is going to open them to a legal threat’
‘the switch opens the motor circuit’
‘the problem was caused when a switch opened at the substation’
‘guests were sitting in the open on the terrace’
‘we have never let our dislike for him come into the open’
‘his victory in the 2003 Australian Open’
--Word--
open housing 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
Property that can be rented or bought without restriction on racial or ethnic grounds.

--Word--
opening 
--Type--
noun, adjective
--Meanings--
A space or gap that allows passage or access.
A beginning; an initial part.
A ceremony or celebratory gathering at which a building, show, etc. is declared to be open.
A recognized sequence of moves at the beginning of a game.
A counsel's preliminary statement of a case in a law court.
An opportunity to achieve something.
An available job.
Coming at the beginning of something; initial.
--Examples--
‘an opening in the roof would get rid of the smoke’
‘Maya started tapping out the opening of her story’
‘I covered the opening of a new computerized diagnosis unit’
‘they seem to have exploited fully the openings offered’
‘there are few openings for the ex-footballer’
‘she stole the show with her opening remark’

--Word--
joint 
--Type--
noun, adjective, verb
--Meanings--
A point at which parts of an artificial structure are joined.
A particular arrangement of parts of a structure at the point where they are joined.
A break or fracture in a mass of rock, with no relative displacement of the parts.
A piece of flexible material forming the hinge of a book cover.
A structure in the human or animal body at which two parts of the skeleton are fitted together.
Each of the distinct sections of a body or limb between the places at which they are connected.
A large piece of meat cooked whole or ready for cooking.
The part of a stem of a plant from which a leaf or branch grows.
A section of a plant stem between two joints; an internode.
An establishment of a specified kind, especially one where people meet for eating, drinking, or entertainment.
Prison.
A cannabis cigarette.
A piece of creative work, especially a musical recording.
Shared, held, or made by two or more people together.
Sharing in a position, achievement, or activity.
Applied or regarded together.
Provide or fasten (something) with joints.
Fill up the joints of (masonry or brickwork) with mortar; point.
Prepare (a board) for being joined to another by planing its edge.
Cut (the body of an animal) into joints for cooking.
--Examples--
‘seal the joint between the roof and the house wall’
‘members connected together by rigid joints’
‘she suffers from stiff joints and finds bending difficult’
‘the top two joints of his index finger’
‘a joint of ham’
‘cut just below a leaf joint’
‘a burger joint’
‘he rolled a joint’
‘listen to one of his joints nowadays and you don't even need to see the production credit’
‘a joint statement’
‘a joint winner’
‘use a sharp knife to joint the bird’

--Type--
adjective
--Meanings--
Having a joint or joints.
--Examples--
‘jointed lever arms’

kettle 
--Type--
noun, verb
--Meanings--
A container or device in which water is boiled, having a lid, spout, and handle.

--Examples--
‘activists in the kettle were protesting at being held and resisting arrest’
‘the plan was to get as close to the protest as possible without getting kettled’

--Word--
open 
--Type--
adjective, verb, noun
--Meanings--
Allowing access, passage, or a view through an empty space; not closed or blocked.
(of a container) not fastened or sealed.
(of a garment or its fastenings) not done up.
(of the mouth or eyes) with lips or lids parted.
(of a fabric) loosely knitted or woven.
(of the bowels) not constipated.
Exposed to the air or to view; not covered.
(of land) not covered with buildings or trees.
Damaged by a deep cut in the surface.
Likely to suffer from or be affected by; vulnerable or subject to.
(of a goalmouth or other object of attack in a game) unprotected by defenders.
(of a town or city) officially declared to be undefended, and so immune under international law from bombardment.
With the outer edges or sides drawn away from each other; unfolded or spread out.
(of a book or file) with the covers parted allowing it to be read.
(of a hand) not clenched into a fist.
(of a business, place of entertainment, etc.) admitting customers or visitors; available for business.
(of a bank account) available for transactions.
(of a telephone line) ready to take calls.
Freely available or accessible; unrestricted.
(of an offer or opportunity) still available.
With no restrictions on those allowed to participate.
(of a victor) having won an open competition.
(of a ticket) not restricted as to day of travel.
(of a cheque) not crossed.
(of a set) not containing any of its limit points.
Not concealing one's thoughts or feelings; frank and communicative.
Not concealed.
(of conflict) fully developed and unconcealed.
Welcoming public discussion, criticism, and enquiry.
(of a game or style of play) characterized by action which is spread out over the field.
(of a matter or decision) not finally settled; still admitting of debate.
(of the mind) accessible to new ideas.
Receptive to.
Admitting of; making possible.
(of a vowel) produced with a relatively wide opening of the mouth and the tongue kept low.
(of a syllable) ending in a vowel.
(of a string) allowed to vibrate along its whole length.
(of a pipe) unstopped at each end.
(of a note) sounded from an open string or pipe.
(of an electric circuit) having a break in the conducting path.
Move (a door or window) so as to leave a space allowing access and vision.
(of a door or window) be moved to leave a space allowing access.
Undo or remove the lid, cover, or fastening of (a container, package, letter, etc.) to get access to the contents.
Part the lips or lids of (one's mouth or eye)

(of a room, door, or window) give access to.

(of an enterprise, meeting, or event) begin or be formally established.
Take the action required to begin using.

Make (the first bid) in the auction.
Make available or more widely known.
Become more communicative or confiding.
Make (one's mind) more receptive or sympathetic.
Make someone vulnerable to.

--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
Lack of restriction; accessibility.
Acceptance of or receptiveness to change or new ideas.
Lack of secrecy or concealment; frankness.
The quality of not being covered with buildings or trees.

--Examples--

‘the openness of the Internet makes public debate more possible’

--Word--
open newel 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A central open space or well in a spiral or winding staircase; similarly "hollow newel". Now chiefly attributive, designating staircases having such a central well.

--Word--
patterned ground 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
Ground showing a pattern of stones, fissures, and vegetation, typically forming polygons, rings, or stripes caused by repeated freezing and thawing.

--Word--
phase 
--Type--
noun, verb
--Meanings--
A distinct period or stage in a series of events or a process of change or development.
A stage in a person's psychological development, especially a period of temporary difficulty during adolescence or a particular stage during childhood.
Each of the separate events in an eventing competition.
Each of the aspects of the moon or a planet, according to the amount of its illumination, especially the new moon, the first quarter, the full moon, and the last quarter.
A genetic or seasonal variety of an animal's coloration.
A distinct and homogeneous form of matter (i.e. a particular solid, liquid, or gas) separated by its surface from other forms.
The relationship in time between the successive states or cycles of an oscillating or repeating system (such as an alternating electric current or a light or sound wave) and either a fixed reference point or the states or cycles of another system with which it may or may not be in synchrony.
Each of the electrical windings or connections of a polyphase machine or circuit.
(in systemic grammar) the relationship between a catenative verb and the verb that follows it, as in she hoped to succeed and I like swimming.
A structure containing two verbs in a phase.
Carry out (something) in gradual stages.
Introduce something into (or withdraw something from) use in gradual stages.
Adjust the phase of (something), especially so as to synchronize it with something else.
--Examples--
‘the final phases of the war’
‘the draw for the qualifying phase of the tournament was held over the weekend’
‘phase two of the development’
‘most of your fans are going through a phase’
‘the invertebrate residents of the tundra pass the winter in dormant phase’
‘solid carbon dioxide passes directly into the gas phase without becoming a liquid’
‘there are two output channels, one fixed in phase and the other variable in phase between 0 and 360 degrees’
‘the work is being phased over a number of years’
‘the changes will be phased in over 10 years’
‘about 70% of the reflections were phased by this method’

--Meanings--

‘the eagle opened its wings and circled up into the air’
‘the tail looks like a fan when it is opened out fully’
‘the flowers only open during bright weather’
‘she opened her book at the prologue’
‘the path opened out into a glade’
‘stop to marvel at the views that open out below’
‘we shall open Torbay shortly’
‘she raised $731 by opening her home and selling coffee and tea’
‘the shops didn't open until 10’

‘the President announced that his government would open the border’
‘she began to teach and opened her own school’
‘we opened up a branch in Madrid’
‘two new restaurants open this week’
‘they have the £10 necessary to open a savings account’
‘click twice to open a file for the software selected’
‘the chapter opens with a discussion of Anglo-Irish relations’
‘a new and dramatic phase was opening up’
‘Bernard had opened the case’
‘Comyn opened for the plaintiff’
‘West opened 2NT’
‘do not open with fewer than twelve points’
‘new technologies open up thousands of different opportunities’
‘the move may force the company to open up its plans for the future’
‘he was very reserved and only opened out to her slowly’
‘open your mind to what is going on around you’
‘the process is going to open them to a legal threat’
‘the switch opens the motor circuit’
‘the problem was caused when a switch opened at the substation’
‘guests were sitting in the open on the terrace’
‘we have never let our dislike for him come into the open’
‘his victory in the 2003 Australian Open’
--Word--
sand 
--Type--
noun, verb
--Meanings--
A loose granular substance, typically pale yellowish brown, resulting from the erosion of siliceous and other rocks and forming a major constituent of beaches, river beds, the seabed, and deserts.
An expanse of sand, typically along a shore.
A stratum of sandstone or compacted sand.
Sediment whose particles are larger than silt (typically greater than 0.06 mm).
A light yellow-brown colour like that of sand.
Firmness of purpose.
Smooth or polish with sandpaper or a mechanical sander.
Sprinkle or overlay with sand, to give better purchase on a surface.
--Examples--
‘this magical coast boasts mile upon mile of golden sand’
‘Britain's soils are mixtures of sands, silts, and clays’
‘Goodwin Sands’
‘no one has the sand to stand against him’
‘mask off the area to be painted and sand it down’
--Word--
open shelf 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A shelf that is not in a closed or private room; specifically a bookshelf in a library which is directly accessible to readers; frequently attributive or as adjective.
--Examples--
--Word--
shelver 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
--Examples--
--Word--
open shop 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A system whereby employees in a place of work do not have to join a trade union.
A place of work following an open-shop system.
--Examples--
--Word--
open side 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
The side of the scrum on which the main line of the opponents' backs is ranged.
--Examples--
--Word--
sided 
--Type--
adjective
--Meanings--
Having sides of a specified number or type.
--Examples--
‘narrow, steep-sided canyons’

--Word--
open space 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
In early use: a space little obstructed by trees, buildings, etc.; a clearing. Later also: specifically a park, garden, etc., without buildings in the midst of an urban area; especially an area designated as such by a municipal authority, government, etc.
In plural Large tracts of unpopulated or sparsely populated countryside. Chiefly in "wide (also great, vast) open spaces".
--Examples--
--Word--
open 
--Type--
adjective, verb, noun
--Meanings--
Allowing access, passage, or a view through an empty space; not closed or blocked.
(of a container) not fastened or sealed.
(of a garment or its fastenings) not done up.
(of the mouth or eyes) with lips or lids parted.
(of a fabric) loosely knitted or woven.
(of the bowels) not constipated.
Exposed to the air or to view; not covered.
(of land) not covered with buildings or trees.
Damaged by a deep cut in the surface.
Likely to suffer from or be affected by; vulnerable or subject to.
(of a goalmouth or other object of attack in a game) unprotected by defenders.
(of a town or city) officially declared to be undefended, and so immune under international law from bombardment.
With the outer edges or sides drawn away from each other; unfolded or spread out.
(of a book or file) with the covers parted allowing it to be read.
(of a hand) not clenched into a fist.
(of a business, place of entertainment, etc.) admitting customers or visitors; available for business.
(of a bank account) available for transactions.
(of a telephone line) ready to take calls.
Freely available or accessible; unrestricted.
(of an offer or opportunity) still available.
With no restrictions on those allowed to participate.
(of a victor) having won an open competition.
(of a ticket) not restricted as to day of travel.
(of a cheque) not crossed.
(of a set) not containing any of its limit points.
Not concealing one's thoughts or feelings; frank and communicative.
Not concealed.
(of conflict) fully developed and unconcealed.
Welcoming public discussion, criticism, and enquiry.
(of a game or style of play) characterized by action which is spread out over the field.
(of a matter or decision) not finally settled; still admitting of debate.
(of the mind) accessible to new ideas.
Receptive to.
Admitting of; making possible.
(of a vowel) produced with a relatively wide opening of the mouth and the tongue kept low.
(of a syllable) ending in a vowel.
(of a string) allowed to vibrate along its whole length.
(of a pipe) unstopped at each end.
(of a note) sounded from an open string or pipe.
(of an electric circuit) having a break in the conducting path.
Move (a door or window) so as to leave a space allowing access and vision.
(of a door or window) be moved to leave a space allowing access.
Undo or remove the lid, cover, or fastening of (a container, package, letter, etc.) to get access to the contents.
Part the lips or lids of (one's mouth or eye)
(of the mouth or eyes) have the lips or lids parted.
Come apart; lose or lack its protective covering.
(of a room, door, or window) give access to.
Cause evacuation of (the bowels).
Unfold or be unfolded; spread out.
Part the covers of (a book or file) to read it.
Become wider.
(of a prospect) extend into view.
Achieve a clear view of (a place) by sailing past a headland or other obstruction.
Make or become formally ready for customers, visitors, or business.
Ceremonially declare (a building, road, etc.) to be completed and ready for use.
Make possible access to or passage through.
Formally establish or begin (a new business, movement, or enterprise)
(of an enterprise, meeting, or event) begin or be formally established.
Take the action required to begin using.
(of a piece of writing or music) begin.
(of a process) start to develop.
(of a counsel in a law court) make a preliminary statement in (a case) before calling witnesses.
Make (the first bid) in the auction.
Make available or more widely known.
Become more communicative or confiding.
Make (one's mind) more receptive or sympathetic.
Make someone vulnerable to.
Break the conducting path of (an electric circuit)
(of an electric circuit or device) suffer a break in its conducting path.
Outdoors or in the countryside.
Not subject to concealment; made public.
A championship or competition with no restrictions on who may compete.
An accidental break in the conducting path for an electric current.
--Examples--
‘he climbed through the open window’
‘she was put in a cubicle with the curtains left open’
‘the pass is kept open by snowploughs’
‘the case burst open and its contents flew all over the place’
‘his tie was knotted below the open collar of his shirt’
‘his eyes were open but he could see nothing’
‘the boy's mouth dropped open in shock’
‘an open fire burned in the grate’
‘he crossed the ocean in an open boat’
‘the plans allow increasing numbers of new houses in open countryside’
‘he had his arm slashed open’
‘the system is open to abuse’
‘the trees had buds and a few open flowers’
‘she was copying verses from an open Bible’
‘the shop stays open until 9 p.m’
‘parts of the castle are open to the public’
‘I withdrew all my money except the minimum required to keep the account open’
‘our free advice line is open from 8.30 to 17.30’
‘the service is open to all students’
‘the offer is open while stocks last’
‘we need to consider what options are left open’
‘open discussion meetings’
‘each horse had won two open races’
‘an Open champion’
‘I have an open ticket, so I can travel any day I like’
‘she behaved in an open and cheerful manner’
‘I was quite open about my views’
‘his eyes showed open admiration as they swept over her’
‘the dispute erupted into open war’
‘the party's commitment to open government’
‘both sides played fast, open rugby to produce a high-scoring game’
‘students' choice of degree can be kept open until the second year’
‘I'm keeping an open mind about my future’
‘the union was open to suggestions for improvements’
‘the message is open to different interpretations’

‘‘Open up!’ he said’

--Word--
tank 
--Type--
noun, verb
--Meanings--
A large receptacle or storage chamber, especially for liquid or gas.
The container holding the fuel supply in a motor vehicle, aircraft, etc.
A receptacle with transparent sides in which to keep fish; an aquarium.
A reservoir.
A heavy armoured fighting vehicle carrying guns and moving on a continuous articulated metal track.
A cell in a police station or jail.
Fill the tank of a vehicle with fuel.
Drink heavily; become drunk.
Fail completely, especially at great financial cost.
(in sport) deliberately lose or fail to finish (a match)
Defeat heavily.
--Examples--
‘the trucks all had a full tank of gasoline’
‘a large class of 0-6-0 tanks’
‘the cars stopped to tank up’
‘they get tanked up before the game’
‘the previous movie had tanked at the box office’
‘the powerful baseliner had tanked the match’
‘Rangers tanked the local side 8–0’
--Word--
-tide 
--Type--
combining form
--Meanings--
Denoting a specified time or season.
Denoting a festival of the Christian Church.
--Examples--
‘springtide’
‘Shrovetide’
--Word--
timber 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
Wood prepared for use in building and carpentry.
Trees grown for use in building or carpentry.
A wooden beam or board used in building a house or ship.
Used to warn that a tree is about to fall after being cut.
Personal qualities or character.
--Examples--
‘the exploitation of forests for timber’
‘a small timber building’
‘contracts to cut timber’
‘we cried ‘Timber!’ as our tree fell’
‘she is frequently hailed as presidential timber’

‘on the south it is well timbered with oak’
--Word--
timbre 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
The character or quality of a musical sound or voice as distinct from its pitch and intensity.
The distinctive quality or character of someone or something.
--Examples--
‘trumpet mutes with different timbres’
‘a voice high in pitch but rich in timbre’
‘you must demonstrate your moral timbre as a human being’

--Word--
view 
--Type--
noun, verb
--Meanings--
The ability to see something or to be seen from a particular place.
An inspection of things for sale by prospective purchasers, especially of works of art at an exhibition.
A sight or prospect, typically of attractive natural scenery, that can be taken in by the eye from a particular place.
A work of art depicting a sight of natural scenery.
The visual appearance or an image of something when looked at in a particular way.
A particular way of considering or regarding something; an attitude or opinion.
Look at or inspect.
Inspect (a house or other property) with the intention of possibly buying or renting it.
Watch (something) on television.
See (a fox) break cover.
Regard in a particular light or with a particular attitude.
--Examples--
‘the end of the tunnel came into view’
‘they stood on the bar to get a better view’
‘a fine view of the castle’
‘Matisse's view of Collioure’
‘an aerial view of the military earthworks’
‘strong political views’
‘the public can view the famous hall with its unique staircase’
‘prospective buyers are requested to make an appointment to view the house’

--Word--
weave 
--Type--
verb, noun, verb
--Meanings--
Form (fabric or a fabric item) by interlacing long threads passing in one direction with others at a right angle to them.
Interlace (threads) so as to form fabric.
Make (a complex story or pattern) from a number of interconnected elements.
Include an element in (such a story or pattern)
A particular style or manner in which something is woven.
A hairstyle created by weaving pieces of real or artificial hair into a person's existing hair, typically in order to increase its length or thickness.
Twist and turn from side to side while moving somewhere in order to avoid obstructions.
Take evasive action in an aircraft, typically by moving it from side to side.
(of a horse) repeatedly swing the head and forepart of the body from side to side (considered to be a vice).
--Examples--
‘textiles woven from linen or wool’
‘woven shawls’
‘some thick mohairs can be difficult to weave’
‘he weaves colourful, cinematic plots’
‘interpretative comments are woven into the narrative’
‘cloth of a very fine weave’
‘trailers show him with dyed blond hair and, in one scene, a flowing blond weave’
‘he had to weave his way through the crowds’
--Word--
web 
--Type--
noun, verb
--Meanings--
A network of fine threads constructed by a spider from fluid secreted by its spinnerets, used to catch its prey.
A filmy network spun by some insect larvae, especially communal caterpillars.
A complex system of interconnected elements.
The World Wide Web or the Internet.
A membrane between the toes of a swimming bird or other aquatic animal.
A thin flat part connecting thicker or more solid parts in machinery.
A roll of paper used in a continuous printing process.
The endless wire mesh in a papermaking machine on which the paper is made.
A piece of woven fabric.
Cover with or as though with a web.
--Examples--
‘he found himself caught up in a web of bureaucracy’
‘material downloaded from the Web’
‘Web publishing’
‘she noticed his tanned skin, webbed with fine creases’
--Word--
webbed 
--Type--
adjective
--Meanings--
(of the feet of a swimming bird or other aquatic animal) having the toes connected by a membrane.
(of fingers or toes) abnormally united for all or part of their length by a fold of skin.
(of a band or strip of tough material) made from webbing or similar fabric.
--Examples--
‘a heavy webbed strap’

Become wider.
(of a prospect) extend into view.
Achieve a clear view of (a place) by sailing past a headland or other obstruction.
Make or become formally ready for customers, visitors, or business.
Ceremonially declare (a building, road, etc.) to be completed and ready for use.
Make possible access to or passage through.
Formally establish or begin (a new business, movement, or enterprise)
(of an enterprise, meeting, or event) begin or be formally established.
Take the action required to begin using.
(of a piece of writing or music) begin.
(of a process) start to develop.
(of a counsel in a law court) make a preliminary statement in (a case) before calling witnesses.
Make (the first bid) in the auction.
Make available or more widely known.
Become more communicative or confiding.
Make (one's mind) more receptive or sympathetic.
Make someone vulnerable to.
Break the conducting path of (an electric circuit)
(of an electric circuit or device) suffer a break in its conducting path.
Outdoors or in the countryside.
Not subject to concealment; made public.
A championship or competition with no restrictions on who may compete.
An accidental break in the conducting path for an electric current.
--Examples--
‘he climbed through the open window’
‘she was put in a cubicle with the curtains left open’
‘the pass is kept open by snowploughs’
‘the case burst open and its contents flew all over the place’
‘his tie was knotted below the open collar of his shirt’
‘his eyes were open but he could see nothing’
‘the boy's mouth dropped open in shock’
‘an open fire burned in the grate’
‘he crossed the ocean in an open boat’
‘the plans allow increasing numbers of new houses in open countryside’
‘he had his arm slashed open’
‘the system is open to abuse’
‘the trees had buds and a few open flowers’
‘she was copying verses from an open Bible’
‘the shop stays open until 9 p.m’
‘parts of the castle are open to the public’
‘I withdrew all my money except the minimum required to keep the account open’
‘our free advice line is open from 8.30 to 17.30’
‘the service is open to all students’
‘the offer is open while stocks last’
‘we need to consider what options are left open’
‘open discussion meetings’
‘each horse had won two open races’
‘an Open champion’
‘I have an open ticket, so I can travel any day I like’
‘she behaved in an open and cheerful manner’
‘I was quite open about my views’
‘his eyes showed open admiration as they swept over her’
‘the dispute erupted into open war’
‘the party's commitment to open government’
‘both sides played fast, open rugby to produce a high-scoring game’
‘students' choice of degree can be kept open until the second year’
‘I'm keeping an open mind about my future’
‘the union was open to suggestions for improvements’
‘the message is open to different interpretations’
‘she opened the door and went in’
‘‘Open up!’ he said’
‘the door opened and a man came out’
‘he opened a bottle inexpertly, spilling some of the wine’
‘can we open the presents now?’
‘she opened her mouth to argue’
‘her eyes slowly opened’
‘old wounds opened and I bled a little bit’
‘the kitchen opened into a pleasant sitting room’
‘the eagle opened its wings and circled up into the air’
‘the tail looks like a fan when it is opened out fully’
‘the flowers only open during bright weather’
‘she opened her book at the prologue’
‘the path opened out into a glade’
‘stop to marvel at the views that open out below’
‘we shall open Torbay shortly’
‘she raised $731 by opening her home and selling coffee and tea’
‘the shops didn't open until 10’
‘the Queen opened the power plant on 17 October 1956’
‘the President announced that his government would open the border’
‘she began to teach and opened her own school’
‘we opened up a branch in Madrid’
‘two new restaurants open this week’
‘they have the £10 necessary to open a savings account’
‘click twice to open a file for the software selected’
‘the chapter opens with a discussion of Anglo-Irish relations’
‘a new and dramatic phase was opening up’
‘Bernard had opened the case’
‘Comyn opened for the plaintiff’
‘West opened 2NT’
‘do not open with fewer than twelve points’
‘new technologies open up thousands of different opportunities’
‘the move may force the company to open up its plans for the future’
‘he was very reserved and only opened out to her slowly’
‘open your mind to what is going on around you’
‘the process is going to open them to a legal threat’
‘the switch opens the motor circuit’
‘the problem was caused when a switch opened at the substation’
‘guests were sitting in the open on the terrace’
‘we have never let our dislike for him come into the open’
‘his victory in the 2003 Australian Open’

adjective

--Word--
open 
--Type--
adjective, verb, noun
--Meanings--
Allowing access, passage, or a view through an empty space; not closed or blocked.
(of a container) not fastened or sealed.
(of a garment or its fastenings) not done up.
(of the mouth or eyes) with lips or lids parted.
(of a fabric) loosely knitted or woven.
(of the bowels) not constipated.
Exposed to the air or to view; not covered.
(of land) not covered with buildings or trees.
Damaged by a deep cut in the surface.
Likely to suffer from or be affected by; vulnerable or subject to.
(of a goalmouth or other object of attack in a game) unprotected by defenders.
(of a town or city) officially declared to be undefended, and so immune under international law from bombardment.
With the outer edges or sides drawn away from each other; unfolded or spread out.
(of a book or file) with the covers parted allowing it to be read.
(of a hand) not clenched into a fist.
(of a business, place of entertainment, etc.) admitting customers or visitors; available for business.
(of a bank account) available for transactions.
(of a telephone line) ready to take calls.
Freely available or accessible; unrestricted.
(of an offer or opportunity) still available.
With no restrictions on those allowed to participate.
(of a victor) having won an open competition.
(of a ticket) not restricted as to day of travel.
(of a cheque) not crossed.
(of a set) not containing any of its limit points.
Not concealing one's thoughts or feelings; frank and communicative.
Not concealed.
(of conflict) fully developed and unconcealed.
Welcoming public discussion, criticism, and enquiry.
(of a game or style of play) characterized by action which is spread out over the field.
(of a matter or decision) not finally settled; still admitting of debate.
(of the mind) accessible to new ideas.
Receptive to.
Admitting of; making possible.
(of a vowel) produced with a relatively wide opening of the mouth and the tongue kept low.
(of a syllable) ending in a vowel.
(of a string) allowed to vibrate along its whole length.
(of a pipe) unstopped at each end.
(of a note) sounded from an open string or pipe.
(of an electric circuit) having a break in the conducting path.
Move (a door or window) so as to leave a space allowing access and vision.
(of a door or window) be moved to leave a space allowing access.
Undo or remove the lid, cover, or fastening of (a container, package, letter, etc.) to get access to the contents.
Part the lips or lids of (one's mouth or eye)
(of the mouth or eyes) have the lips or lids parted.
Come apart; lose or lack its protective covering.
(of a room, door, or window) give access to.
Cause evacuation of (the bowels).
Unfold or be unfolded; spread out.
Part the covers of (a book or file) to read it.
Become wider.
(of a prospect) extend into view.
Achieve a clear view of (a place) by sailing past a headland or other obstruction.
Make or become formally ready for customers, visitors, or business.
Ceremonially declare (a building, road, etc.) to be completed and ready for use.
Make possible access to or passage through.
Formally establish or begin (a new business, movement, or enterprise)
(of an enterprise, meeting, or event) begin or be formally established.
Take the action required to begin using.
(of a piece of writing or music) begin.
(of a process) start to develop.
(of a counsel in a law court) make a preliminary statement in (a case) before calling witnesses.
Make (the first bid) in the auction.
Make available or more widely known.
Become more communicative or confiding.
Make (one's mind) more receptive or sympathetic.
Make someone vulnerable to.
Break the conducting path of (an electric circuit)
(of an electric circuit or device) suffer a break in its conducting path.
Outdoors or in the countryside.
Not subject to concealment; made public.
A championship or competition with no restrictions on who may compete.
An accidental break in the conducting path for an electric current.

--Word--
operant 
--Type--
adjective, noun
--Meanings--
Involving the modification of behaviour by the reinforcing or inhibiting effect of its own consequences.
An item of behaviour that is not a response to a prior stimulus but something which is initially spontaneous, which may reinforce or inhibit recurrence of that behaviour.

--Word--
operate 
--Type--
verb
--Meanings--
(of a person) control the functioning of (a machine, process, or system)
(of a machine, process, or system) function in a specified manner.
Be in effect.
Manage (a business)
(of an organization) be managed in a specified way or from a specified place.
(of an armed force) conduct military activities in a specified area.
Perform a surgical operation.
--Examples--
‘the Prime Minister operates a system of divide and rule’
‘market forces were allowed to operate freely’
‘there is a powerful law which operates in politics’
‘many foreign companies operate factories in the United States’
‘neither company had operated within the terms of its constitution’
‘the mountain bases from which the guerrillas were operating’
‘surgeons operated on on his jaw yesterday morning’
‘doctors refused to operate because of the risks involved’

--Word--
operation 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
The action of functioning or the fact of being active or in effect.
An active process; a discharge of a function.
An act of surgery performed on a patient.
An organized activity involving a number of people.
A business organization; a company.
An activity in which a business is involved.
A process in which a number, quantity, expression, etc., is altered or manipulated according to set formal rules, such as those of addition, multiplication, and differentiation.
--Examples--
‘restrictions on the operation of market forces’
‘the company's first hotel is now in operation’
‘the operations of the mind’
‘I've never felt better since my bypass operation’
‘a rescue operation’
‘Operation Desert Storm’
‘he reopened his operation under a different name’
‘the company is selling most of its commercial banking operations’
--Word--
operational 
--Type--
adjective
--Meanings--
In or ready for use.
Relating to the routine functioning and activities of an organization.
Relating to active operations of the armed forces, police, or emergency services.
Relating to or in accordance with operationalism.
--Examples--
‘the new laboratory is fully operational’
‘the coffee bar's initial operational costs’
‘an operational fighter squadron’
--Word--
operationalism 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A form of positivism which defines scientific concepts in terms of the operations used to determine or prove them.
--Examples--
--Word--
