--Type--
UnKnownKind
--Meanings--
--Examples--
--Word--
operationally 
--Type--
adverb
--Meanings--
With regard to routine functioning, especially of an organization or system.
With regard to active operations of the armed forces, police, or emergency services.
--Examples--
‘hiring part-time workers will not benefit the employer operationally’
‘this organization is still not operationally effective’
‘no British service personnel have been deployed operationally’
‘highly mobile and operationally effective military equipment’

opercle 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
Zoology and Botany. An operculum.
--Examples--
--Word--
opercle 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
Zoology and Botany. An operculum.
--Examples--
--Word--
operculum 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A structure that closes or covers an aperture.
A secreted plate that closes the aperture of a gastropod mollusc's shell when the animal is retracted.
A part of the spore-containing capsule of a moss that functions as a lid or cover.
--Examples--
--Word--
opercular 
--Type--
adjective
--Meanings--
Relating to or denoting a structure that closes or covers an aperture such as a fish's gills.
--Examples--
‘age and growth of individual fish were determined from opercular bones’

adjective
--Meanings--

operetta 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A short opera, usually on a light or humorous theme and typically having spoken dialogue. Notable composers of operettas include Offenbach, Johan Strauss, Franz Lehár, and Gilbert and Sullivan.

--Word--
Ophioglossum 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A genus of small primitive ferns of the family Ophioglossaceae, consisting of an undivided sterile blade at the base of which arises a long-stalked narrow fertile blade bearing two rows of sporangia; (also ophioglossum) a fern of this genus, an adder's tongue.

--Word--
ophiophagus 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
Zoology. Formerly: †a snake of the monotypic genus Ophiophagus (family Elapidae), containing only the king cobra or hamadryad, O. hannah, which feeds almost exclusively on other snakes (obsolete). Also (now only) (in form Ophiophagus): the genus itself.

--Examples--
--Word--
Ophiuchus 
--Type--
proper noun
--Meanings--
A large constellation (the Serpent Bearer or Holder), said to represent a man in the coils of a snake. Both the celestial equator and the ecliptic pass through it, but it is not counted among the signs of the zodiac.
Used with preceding letter or numeral to designate a star in the constellation Ophiuchus.
--Examples--
‘the star Eta Ophiuchi’
--Word--
ophiuran 
--Type--
noun, adjective
--Meanings--
A brittlestar; = "ophiuroid".
Of or relating to brittlestars; = "ophiuroid".
--Examples--
--Word--
ophiurid 
--Type--
noun, adjective
--Meanings--
An echinoderm of the group comprising the brittlestars, now regarded as the class Ophiuroidea.
Of or relating to the family Ophiuridae or the class Ophiuroidea; of an ophiurid.

ophryon 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--

--Examples--
--Word--
Ophrys 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
Originally: a Linnaean genus of spurless orchids that comprised a variety of species that are now mostly placed in other genera, as the twayblades (Listera) and lady's tresses (Spiranthes). Later: specifically a genus comprising numerous, chiefly Mediterranean, orchids that typically have insect-like flowers with a thick, velvety, strikingly marked labellum; (also ophrys) an orchid of this genus.

opianic acid 
--Type--

--Examples--
--Word--
opiate 
--Type--
adjective, noun, verb
--Meanings--
Relating to, resembling, or containing opium.
A drug derived from or related to opium.
A thing which soothes or stupefies.
Impregnate with opium.
Dull the senses of (someone) with or as if with opium.
--Examples--
‘the use of opiate drugs’
‘the opiates are known to have natural counterparts called endorphins’
‘the capacity to use books as an opiate’
‘they smoked the last of his opiated dope’
‘she is not opiated with resignation’
--Word--
opiate 
--Type--
adjective, noun, verb
--Meanings--
Relating to, resembling, or containing opium.
A drug derived from or related to opium.
A thing which soothes or stupefies.
Impregnate with opium.
Dull the senses of (someone) with or as if with opium.
--Examples--
‘the use of opiate drugs’
‘the opiates are known to have natural counterparts called endorphins’
‘the capacity to use books as an opiate’
‘they smoked the last of his opiated dope’
‘she is not opiated with resignation’

--Word--
Opimian 
--Type--
adjective
--Meanings--
Designating a celebrated ancient Roman wine of the vintage of a.u.c. 633, produced when Opimius was consul. Occasionally in extended use: any wine of a premium vintage. Frequently in "Opimian wine".

--Word--
opine 
--Type--
verb
--Meanings--

--Examples--

‘the headmistress opined that the outing would make a nice change for Flora’
--Word--
opinion 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A view or judgement formed about something, not necessarily based on fact or knowledge.
The beliefs or views of a group or majority of people.
An estimation of the quality or worth of someone or something.
A statement of advice by an expert on a professional matter.
A barrister's advice on the merits of a case.
A formal statement of reasons for a judgement given.
--Examples--
‘that, in my opinion, is right’
‘the area's residents share vociferous opinions about the future’
‘the changing climate of opinion’
‘I had a higher opinion of myself than I deserved’
‘if in doubt, get a second opinion’
‘the solicitor took counsel's opinion’
‘a dissenting opinion adjudged that the government had the right to protect ‘the symbolic value of the flag’’
--Word--
opinionable 
--Type--
adjective
--Meanings--
= opinable. Also as noun: an object of opinion.
--Examples--
--Word--
opinionnaire 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A formulated series of statements, each of which members of a selected group are requested to endorse or reject, used to gather information in a survey; (also, more widely) a questionnaire.
--Examples--
--Word--
opinional 
--Type--
adjective
--Meanings--
Of the nature of or based on opinion; conjectural.
--Examples--
--Word--
opinionate 
--Type--
adjective, verb
--Meanings--
Holding obstinately to one's own opinion; opinionated.
To hold as an opinion; = "opine", "opinion"; to believe, suppose, think.
To form, hold, or give an opinion.
(refl.). To be or become possessed of a (particular) opinion. Now chiefly in past participle: see "opinionated".
To state or deliver an opinion formally; = "opine". rare.
--Examples--
--Word--
opinionated 
--Type--
adjective
--Meanings--
Characterized by conceited assertiveness and dogmatism.
--Examples--
‘an arrogant and opinionated man’
--Word--
opinionatedly 
--Type--
adverb
--Meanings--
In a manner that is opinionated or conceited.
--Examples--
--Word--
opinionatedness 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
--Examples--
--Word--
opinionately 
--Type--
adverb
--Meanings--
In an opinionated manner. In early use: †obstinately (obsolete).
--Examples--
--Word--
opinionative 
--Type--
adjective
--Meanings--
Holding obstinately to one's own opinion; opinionated.
Of the nature of an opinion; expressing opinion. rare.
--Examples--
--Word--
opinionatively 
--Type--
adverb
--Meanings--
In an opinionated manner; with obstinate adherence to one's own opinion; obstinately; conceitedly. Now rare.
--Examples--
--Word--
opinionativeness 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
The quality or character of being opinionated; obstinate adherence to one's own opinion; intellectual conceit.
--Examples--
--Word--
opinioned 
--Type--
adjective
--Meanings--
Having or expressing an opinion, especially of a specified kind; of the opinion that.
Thinking too highly of, or holding obstinately to, one's own opinion; opinionated.
--Examples--
--Word--
opinionist 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A person who holds an opinion or doctrine against the generally accepted view; a dissenter. Now historical.
The holder of any specified or implied opinion. In later use with prefixed adjective, as botanical, liberal, etc.
A person whose business is to give a professional opinion; a person who decides a controversy.
--Examples--
--Word--
opinion 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A view or judgement formed about something, not necessarily based on fact or knowledge.
The beliefs or views of a group or majority of people.
An estimation of the quality or worth of someone or something.
A statement of advice by an expert on a professional matter.
A barrister's advice on the merits of a case.
A formal statement of reasons for a judgement given.
--Examples--
‘that, in my opinion, is right’
‘the area's residents share vociferous opinions about the future’
‘the changing climate of opinion’
‘I had a higher opinion of myself than I deserved’
‘if in doubt, get a second opinion’
‘the solicitor took counsel's opinion’
‘a dissenting opinion adjudged that the government had the right to protect ‘the symbolic value of the flag’’
--Word--
opinionize 
--Type--
verb
--Meanings--
Express one's opinion about something, typically in an assertive or dogmatic way.
--Examples--
‘the introduction acts as a helpful corrective to his not infrequently violent opinionizing’
--Word--
sampler 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A piece of embroidery worked in various stitches as a specimen of skill, typically containing the alphabet and some mottoes.
A representative collection or example of something.
A person or device that takes and analyses samples.
An electronic device for sampling music and sound.
--Examples--
‘a sampler of rock plants’
--Word--
opioid 
--Type--
noun, adjective
--Meanings--
A compound resembling opium in addictive properties or physiological effects.
Relating to or denoting opioids.
--Examples--
‘opioids other than heroin’
‘opioid use’

noun
--Meanings--

--Word--
opisthorchiasis 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
Infection of humans and various other animals with parasitic trematode worms (liver flukes) of the genus Opisthorchis (family Opisthorchiidae), especially O. felineus and O. viverrini, endemic in parts of south-east and central Asia and eastern Europe, typically resulting in inflammation and scarring of the biliary tract and liver.
--Examples--
--Word--
opisthosomal 
--Type--
adjective
--Meanings--
Designating, relating to, or situated in the opisthosoma of an invertebrate.
--Examples--
--Word--
opisthotic 
--Type--
noun, adjective
--Meanings--
One of the periotic bones, situated at the back of the ear, which in fishes, reptiles, and birds is separate or fused with one of the occipital bones, and in mammals is represented by an embryonic ossification of the temporal bone.
Designating or relating to the opisthotic.
--Examples--

--Type--

--Meanings--

opisthotonos 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
Spasm of the muscles causing backward arching of the head, neck, and spine, as in severe tetanus, some kinds of meningitis, and strychnine poisoning.

noun
--Meanings--

--Type--
noun

A fragrant gum resin which is used in perfumery.

--Word--
Oppenheimer, J. Robert 
--Type--
proper noun
--Meanings--
(1904–67), American theoretical physicist; full name Julius Robert Oppenheimer. He was director of the laboratory at Los Alamos during the development of the first atom bomb, but opposed the development of the hydrogen bomb after the Second World War.

--Word--
opportunistic 
--Type--
adjective
--Meanings--
Exploiting immediate opportunities, especially regardless of planning or principle.
(of a plant or animal) able to spread quickly in a previously unexploited habitat.
(of a microorganism or an infection caused by it) affecting patients only or chiefly when the immune system is depressed.
--Examples--
‘an opportunistic political lightweight’
‘opportunistic populations colonizing new substrates’

--Word--
opposite 
--Type--
adjective, noun, adverb, preposition
--Meanings--
Situated on the other or further side when seen from a specified or implicit viewpoint; facing.
(of leaves or shoots) arising in pairs at the same level on opposite sides of the stem.
(of angles) between opposite sides of the intersection of two lines.
Completely different; of a contrary kind.
Being the other of a contrasted pair.
A person or thing that is totally different from or the reverse of someone or something else.
In a position facing a specified or implied subject.
In a position on the other side of a specific area from; facing.
(of a leading actor) in a complementary role to (another)
--Examples--
‘a crowd gathered on the opposite side of the street’
‘a word that is opposite in meaning to another’
‘currents flowing in opposite directions’
‘the opposite ends of the price range’
‘we were opposites in temperament’
‘the literal is the opposite of the figurative’
‘she was sitting almost opposite’
‘he went into the shop opposite’
‘they sat opposite one another’
‘the star was a young man playing opposite an older woman’

--Word--
opposition 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
Resistance or dissent, expressed in action or argument.
A group of opponents, especially in sport, business, or politics.
The principal parliamentary party opposed to that in office.
The apparent position of two celestial objects that are directly opposite each other in the sky, especially the position of a planet when opposite the sun.
A contrast or antithesis.
--Examples--
‘there was considerable opposition to the proposal’
‘the home team made short work of the opposition’
‘the leader of the Opposition’
‘a nature–culture opposition’
‘the opposition between practical and poetic language’

‘the suppression of oppositional critical thought’
‘the largest oppositional party in parliament’

--Word--
oppressive 
--Type--
adjective
--Meanings--
Inflicting harsh and authoritarian treatment.
Weighing heavily on the mind or spirits.
(of weather) close and sultry.
--Examples--
‘an oppressive dictatorship’
‘the offices present an oppressive atmosphere’
‘the day was sunless and oppressive’

--Word--
opprobry 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
Accusation or imputation of shameful or disgraceful conduct; vilification, insult, or reproach. As a count noun: an instance of this; an insult or reproach. Now rare (chiefly historical).
--Examples--
--Word--
opprobriate 
--Type--
verb
--Meanings--
To speak abusively or contemptuously of or to; to reproach; to vilify.
--Examples--

opprobrium 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
Harsh criticism or censure.
Public disgrace arising from shameful conduct.
An occasion or cause of reproach or disgrace.
--Examples--

‘the opprobrium of being closely associated with gangsters’

--Word--
op 
--Type--
noun, abbreviation
--Meanings--
A surgical operation.
Military operations.
A radio or telephone operator.
Observation post.
(in the theatre) opposite prompt.
Organophosphate(s).
(in the Roman Catholic Church) Order of Preachers (Dominican).
(in online forums or comment pages) original post (or poster).
--Examples--
‘a minor op’
‘the ops room’

--Word--
opt 
--Type--
verb
--Meanings--
Make a choice from a range of possibilities.
opt in
Choose to participate in something.
opt out
Choose not to participate in something.
(of a school or hospital) decide to withdraw from local authority control.
--Examples--
‘consumers will opt for low-priced goods’
‘pupils opting to continue with physics’
‘the database would not include a person's name unless he opted in’
‘you can opt out of the state pension scheme’
‘opting out might allow schools greater freedom’

--Meanings--

Optacon 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A device for enabling a blind person to recognize printed characters by touch, the fingertip being placed on an array of numerous tiny rods certain of which vibrate in accordance with the pattern of light from the characters.

adjective, noun

--Word--
optical 
--Type--
adjective, noun
--Meanings--
Relating to sight, especially in relation to the action of light.
Constructed to assist sight.
Relating to the science of optics.
Operating in or employing the visible part of the electromagnetic spectrum.
(of a device) requiring electromagnetic radiation for its operation.
A pair of glasses.
--Examples--
‘optical illusions’
‘an optical aid’
‘optical telescopes’
‘integrated optical circuits’
‘he pushed his opticals on to the bridge of his nose’

noun
--Meanings--

optics

plural noun

--Word--
optime 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A person placed in the second or third class in the Mathematical Tripos at Cambridge University (called respectively senior and junior optimes), or (in extended use) in any other subject; a degree in such a class.

--Word--
optimism 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
Hopefulness and confidence about the future or the success of something.
The doctrine, especially as set forth by Leibniz, that this world is the best of all possible worlds.
The belief that good must ultimately prevail over evil in the universe.
--Examples--
‘the talks had been amicable and there were grounds for optimism’

--Word--
optimist 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A person who tends to be hopeful and confident about the future or the success of something.
A person who believes that this world is the best of all possible worlds or that good must ultimately prevail over evil.
--Examples--
‘only an eternal optimist could expect success’
--Word--
optimistic 
--Type--
adjective
--Meanings--
Hopeful and confident about the future.
(of an estimate) unrealistically high.
--Examples--
‘the optimistic mood of the Sixties’
‘the government was optimistic that reform would take place’
‘previous estimates of whale numbers may be wildly optimistic’

optimum 
--Type--
adjective, noun
--Meanings--
Most conducive to a favourable outcome; best.
The most favourable situation or level for growth, reproduction, or success.
--Examples--
‘the optimum childbearing age’
‘the plant grows within a range of 68 and 78°F, the optimum being 74°’
‘the optimum must lie between these two values’

--Word--
option 
--Type--
noun, verb
--Meanings--
A thing that is or may be chosen.
The freedom or right to choose something.
A right to buy or sell a particular thing at a specified price within a set time.
Buy or sell an option on.
--Examples--
‘choose the cheapest options for supplying energy’
‘she was given the option of resigning or being dismissed’
‘he has no option but to pay up’
‘Columbia Pictures has an option on the script’
‘his second script will have been optioned by the time you read this’

‘a wide range of optional excursions is offered’

--Type--
adjective
--Meanings--
Of or relating to both light and sound; specifically designating or relating to an effect whereby a light beam periodically interrupted at an audio frequency produces an audible sound when made to irradiate an enclosed body of gas; photoacoustic.

--Word--
optokinetic 
--Type--
adjective
--Meanings--
Designating or relating to the action of turning of the eyes or body towards a moving object; specifically designating a physiological form of nystagmus elicited by the fixation of objects that are rapidly traversing the visual field (a response typically found in mammals).
--Examples--

--Word--
optophone 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
An instrument designed to enable a blind person to read, in which a photoelectric cell is used to scan a text and produce electric signals that are converted into audible ones corresponding to the different characters.
--Examples--

optotype 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--

Make a choice from a range of possibilities.
opt in
Choose to participate in something.
opt out
Choose not to participate in something.
(of a school or hospital) decide to withdraw from local authority control.
--Examples--
‘consumers will opt for low-priced goods’
‘pupils opting to continue with physics’
‘the database would not include a person's name unless he opted in’
‘you can opt out of the state pension scheme’
‘opting out might allow schools greater freedom’

--Word--
or 
--Type--
conjunction, noun
--Meanings--
Used to link alternatives.
Introducing a synonym or explanation of a preceding word or phrase.
Otherwise (used to introduce the consequences of something not being done or not being the case)
Introducing an afterthought, usually in the form of a question.
Either.
A logical operation which gives the value one if at least one operand has the value one, and otherwise gives a value of zero.
Denoting a gate circuit which produces an output if there is a signal on any of its inputs.
--Examples--
‘a cup of tea or coffee’
‘are you coming or not?’
‘I either take taxis or walk everywhere’
‘it doesn't matter whether the theory is right or wrong’
‘yoga is a series of postures, or asanas’
‘hurry up, or you'll miss it all’
‘John's indifference—or was it?—left her unsettled’
‘to love is the one way to know or God or man’
--Word--
-or 
--Type--
suffix, suffix, suffix
--Meanings--
(forming nouns) denoting a person or thing performing the action of a verb, or denoting another agent.
Forming adjectives expressing a comparative sense.
Forming nouns denoting a state or condition.
--Examples--
‘escalator’
‘governor’
‘resistor’
‘junior’
‘major’
‘error’
‘pallor’
‘terror’

--Word--
orache 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A plant of the goosefoot family with leaves that are sometimes covered in a white mealy substance. Several kinds are edible and can be used as a substitute for spinach or sorrel.

--Word--
oracle 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A priest or priestess acting as a medium through whom advice or prophecy was sought from the gods in classical antiquity.
A place at which divine advice or prophecy was sought.
A person or thing regarded as an infallible authority on something.
A response or message given by an oracle, especially an ambiguous one.
--Examples--
‘he reigned supreme as the Colonial Office's oracle on Africa’

--Word--
oral 
--Type--
adjective, noun
--Meanings--
Spoken rather than written; verbal.
Relating to the transmission of information or literature by word of mouth.
(of a society) not having reached the stage of literacy.
Relating to the mouth.
Done or taken by the mouth.
(of a speech sound) pronounced by the voice resonating in the mouth, as the vowels in English.
(in Freudian theory) relating to or denoting a stage of infantile psychosexual development in which the mouth is the main source of pleasure and the centre of experience.
A spoken examination or test.
--Examples--
‘they had reached an oral agreement’
‘oral literature’
‘a society with an oral tradition’
‘oral hygiene’
‘oral contraceptives’
‘a French oral’
--Word--
orally 
--Type--
adverb
--Meanings--
By means of speech; verbally.
By means of or through the mouth.
--Examples--
‘the terms were orally agreed’
‘this decision was communicated orally to the chairman’
‘drugs taken orally’

noun

--Word--
orange 
--Type--
noun, adjective, proper noun, adjective
--Meanings--
A large round juicy citrus fruit with a tough bright reddish-yellow rind.
A drink made from or flavoured with oranges.
The leathery-leaved evergreen tree that bears the orange, native to warm regions of South and SE Asia. Oranges are a major commercial crop in many warm regions of the world.
Used in names of plants with similar fruit or flowers to the orange tree, e.g. mock orange.
A bright reddish-yellow colour like that of the skin of a ripe orange.
A butterfly with mainly or partly orange wings.
Reddish yellow.
A town in southern France, on the River Rhône, home of the ancestors of the Dutch royal house.
Relating to the Orange Order.
--Examples--
‘eat plenty of oranges’
‘a slice of orange’
‘orange juice’
‘a vodka and orange’
‘tones of golden brown and orange’
‘the most shocking of pinks and oranges’
‘there was an orange glow in the sky’
‘Orange marches’

--Word--
orange 
--Type--
noun, adjective, proper noun, adjective
--Meanings--
A large round juicy citrus fruit with a tough bright reddish-yellow rind.
A drink made from or flavoured with oranges.
The leathery-leaved evergreen tree that bears the orange, native to warm regions of South and SE Asia. Oranges are a major commercial crop in many warm regions of the world.
Used in names of plants with similar fruit or flowers to the orange tree, e.g. mock orange.
A bright reddish-yellow colour like that of the skin of a ripe orange.
A butterfly with mainly or partly orange wings.
Reddish yellow.
A town in southern France, on the River Rhône, home of the ancestors of the Dutch royal house.
Relating to the Orange Order.
--Examples--
‘eat plenty of oranges’
‘a slice of orange’
‘orange juice’
‘a vodka and orange’
‘tones of golden brown and orange’
‘the most shocking of pinks and oranges’
‘there was an orange glow in the sky’
‘Orange marches’

verb
--Meanings--
Make a speech, especially pompously or at length.
--Examples--
‘Hamlet thinks, speaks, orates, and acts’
‘‘Lend me your ears,’ Fred orated’

orate 
--Type--
verb

--Word--
oration 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A formal speech, especially one given on a ceremonial occasion.
The style or manner in which an oration is given.
--Examples--
‘Pericles' famous funeral oration’
‘there is nothing quite like his messianic oration’

--Word--
orator 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A public speaker, especially one who is eloquent or skilled.
An official speaking for a university on ceremonial occasions.
--Examples--
‘a theatrically effective orator’
--Word--
oratory 
--Type--
noun, noun
--Meanings--
A small chapel, especially for private worship.
(in the Roman Catholic Church) a society of priests without vows, especially the Oratory of St Philip Neri founded in 1564.
The art or practice of formal speaking in public.
Eloquent or rhetorical language.
--Examples--
‘the gift of persuasive oratory’
‘learned discussions degenerated into pompous oratory’
--Word--
oratorial 
--Type--
adjective
--Meanings--
--Examples--
--Word--
oratorially 
--Type--
adverb
--Meanings--
In the manner of an orator; as regards oration or public speaking.
--Examples--
--Word--
Oratorian 
--Type--
noun, adjective
--Meanings--
(in the Roman Catholic Church) a member of a society of priests without vows, such as the Oratory of St Philip Neri.
Relating to or characteristic of a member of a society of priests without vows, such as the Oratory of St Philip Neri.
--Examples--
‘Oratorians will pray together twice a day’
‘he wears his Oratorian collar and cassock’
--Word--
Oratorian 
--Type--
noun, adjective
--Meanings--
(in the Roman Catholic Church) a member of a society of priests without vows, such as the Oratory of St Philip Neri.

--Word--
oratory 
--Type--
noun, noun
--Meanings--
A small chapel, especially for private worship.
(in the Roman Catholic Church) a society of priests without vows, especially the Oratory of St Philip Neri founded in 1564.
The art or practice of formal speaking in public.
Eloquent or rhetorical language.
--Examples--
‘the gift of persuasive oratory’
‘learned discussions degenerated into pompous oratory’
--Word--
oratorio 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A large-scale, usually narrative musical work for orchestra and voices, typically on a sacred theme, performed without costume, scenery, or action. Well-known examples include Bach's Christmas Oratorio, Handel's Messiah, and Haydn's The Creation.
--Examples--
--Word--
oratorio 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A large-scale, usually narrative musical work for orchestra and voices, typically on a sacred theme, performed without costume, scenery, or action. Well-known examples include Bach's Christmas Oratorio, Handel's Messiah, and Haydn's The Creation.
--Examples--

--Word--
orb 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A spherical object or shape.
A golden globe surmounted by a cross, forming part of the regalia of a monarch.
A celestial body.
An eye.
A circle of up to 10° radius around the position of a celestial object.
--Examples--
‘a pale orb of hazy reddish light’
‘a crown, an orb, and a sceptre’
‘two wild staring orbs which flashed around the room’
‘within an orb of 1° of Mars’
--Word--
orbic 
--Type--
adjective
--Meanings--
Having the form of an orb; circular, rounded, orbal.
--Examples--

--Word--
orb 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A spherical object or shape.
A golden globe surmounted by a cross, forming part of the regalia of a monarch.

--Word--
orbit 
--Type--
noun, verb
--Meanings--
The curved path of a celestial object or spacecraft round a star, planet, or moon, especially a periodic elliptical revolution.
One complete circuit round an orbited body.
The state of moving in an orbit.
The path of an electron round an atomic nucleus.
An area of activity, interest, or influence.
The cavity in the skull of a vertebrate that contains the eye; the eye socket.
The area round the eye of a bird or other animal.
(of a celestial object or spacecraft) move in orbit round (a star or planet)
Move in a circle.
Put (a satellite) into orbit.
--Examples--
‘the Earth's orbit around the sun’
‘the satellite will complete one orbit every 12 hours’
‘the earth is in orbit around the sun’
‘audiences drawn largely from outside the Party orbit’
‘Mercury orbits the Sun’
‘the discs spun and orbited slowly’
‘France has been orbiting satellites with her own launcher’
--Word--
orbital 
--Type--
adjective, noun
--Meanings--
Relating to an orbit or orbits.
(of a road) passing round the outside of a town.
An orbital road.
Each of the actual or potential patterns of electron density which may be formed in an atom or molecule by one or more electrons, and can be represented as a wave function.
--Examples--
--Word--
orbitale 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
The lowest point of the inferior margin of the orbit.
--Examples--
--Word--
orbitally 
--Type--
adverb
--Meanings--
--Examples--
--Word--
orbital 
--Type--
adjective, noun
--Meanings--
Relating to an orbit or orbits.
(of a road) passing round the outside of a town.
An orbital road.
Each of the actual or potential patterns of electron density which may be formed in an atom or molecule by one or more electrons, and can be represented as a wave function.
--Examples--

--Word--
orbitofrontal cortex 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
The area of the cerebral cortex located at the base of the frontal lobes above the orbits (or eye sockets), involved especially in social and emotional behaviour.
--Examples--
--Word--
orbitosphenoid 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A bone in the floor of the mammalian cranium, in the region of the optic nerve. In the human skull it is represented by the lesser wings of the sphenoid bone.
--Examples--

orchestic 
--Type--
adjective
--Meanings--

--Word--
orchestra 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A group of instrumentalists, especially one combining string, woodwind, brass, and percussion sections and playing classical music.
The part of a theatre where the orchestra plays, typically in front of the stage and on a lower level.
The stalls in a theatre.
The semicircular space in front of an ancient Greek theatre stage where the chorus danced and sang.
--Examples--

orchestrate 
--Type--
verb
--Meanings--
Arrange or score (music) for orchestral performance.
Plan or coordinate the elements of (a situation) to produce a desired effect, especially surreptitiously.
--Examples--
‘the song cycle was stunningly arranged and orchestrated’
‘the situation has been orchestrated by a tiny minority’

--Word--
orchestration 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
The arrangement or scoring of music for orchestral performance.
The planning or coordination of the elements of a situation to produce a desired effect, especially surreptitiously.
--Examples--
‘Prokofiev's mastery of orchestration’
‘ballads backed by lush orchestrations’
‘the orchestration of the campaign needed tightening’
‘he described the setting of tax policy as a delicate orchestration of factors’
--Word--

noun
--Meanings--

‘he described the setting of tax policy as a delicate orchestration of factors’

--Examples--
--Word--
orchid 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A plant with complex flowers that are often showy or bizarrely shaped, having a large specialized lip (labellum) and frequently a spur. Orchids occur worldwide, especially as epiphytes in tropical forests, and are valuable hothouse plants.
The flowering stem of a cultivated orchid.
--Examples--
--Word--
orchidacean 
--Type--
adjective
--Meanings--
Botany. Characteristic of orchids.
--Examples--
--Word--
orchidaceous 
--Type--
adjective
--Meanings--
Relating to or denoting plants of the orchid family (Orchidaceae ).
--Examples--
--Word--
orchidean 
--Type--
adjective
--Meanings--
Relating to or characteristic of orchids, orchidaceous; of or relating to the former family Orchideae.
--Examples--

--Word--
orchid 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A plant with complex flowers that are often showy or bizarrely shaped, having a large specialized lip (labellum) and frequently a spur. Orchids occur worldwide, especially as epiphytes in tropical forests, and are valuable hothouse plants.
The flowering stem of a cultivated orchid.

--Meanings--

--Examples--
--Word--
orchil 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A red or violet dye obtained from certain lichens, used as a source of litmus, orcinol, and other pigments.
A lichen with flattened fronds from which orchil is produced.
--Examples--
--Word--
orchilla 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A red or violet dye; = "orchil". Now historical.
More fully "orchilla weed". The lichen orchil.

orchiopexy 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
Surgical fixation of the testicle into the scrotum; an instance of this.
--Examples--
--Word--
orchis 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
An orchid of (or formerly of) a genus native to north temperate regions, characterized by a tuberous root and an erect fleshy stem bearing a spike of typically purple or pinkish flowers.
Any wild orchid occurring in temperate regions.
--Examples--
--Word--
orchis 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
An orchid of (or formerly of) a genus native to north temperate regions, characterized by a tuberous root and an erect fleshy stem bearing a spike of typically purple or pinkish flowers.
Any wild orchid occurring in temperate regions.
--Examples--
--Word--
orchitic 
--Type--
adjective
--Meanings--
†Having testicles (obsolete); of or relating to the testicles. Now rare or historical.
Of or relating to orchitis; affected by orchitis.
--Examples--
--Word--
orchitis 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
Inflammation of one or both of the testicles.
--Examples--

noun
--Meanings--
A crystalline compound extracted from certain lichens and used to make dyes.

--Word--
orc 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
(in fantasy literature and games) a member of an imaginary race of humanlike creatures, characterized as ugly, warlike, and malevolent.
--Examples--
--Word--
Orczy, Baroness Emmusca 
--Type--
proper noun
--Meanings--
(1865–1947), Hungarian-born British novelist. Her best-known novel is The Scarlet Pimpernel (1905).
--Examples--

--Type--

--Meanings--

ord. 
--Type--
abbreviation
--Meanings--
Order.
Ordinary.
--Examples--
--Word--
ordain 
--Type--
verb
--Meanings--
Make (someone) a priest or minister; confer holy orders on.
Order (something) officially.
(of God or fate) decide (something) in advance.
--Examples--
‘he was ordained a minister before entering Parliament’
‘women ordained to the diaconate’
‘an ordained clergyman’
‘equal punishment was ordained for the two crimes’
‘the king ordained that these courts should be revived’
‘the path ordained by God’
--Word--
ordainable 
--Type--
adjective
--Meanings--
Capable of being ordained; that may be ordained.
--Examples--

--Word--
ordeal 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A very unpleasant and prolonged experience.
An ancient test of guilt or innocence by subjection of the accused to severe pain, survival of which was taken as divine proof of innocence.
--Examples--
‘the ordeal of having to give evidence’
‘ordeals conducted in the twelfth century’
‘ordeal by fire’
--Word--
ordeal 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A very unpleasant and prolonged experience.
An ancient test of guilt or innocence by subjection of the accused to severe pain, survival of which was taken as divine proof of innocence.
--Examples--
‘the ordeal of having to give evidence’
‘ordeals conducted in the twelfth century’
‘ordeal by fire’
--Word--
order 
--Type--
noun, verb
--Meanings--
The arrangement or disposition of people or things in relation to each other according to a particular sequence, pattern, or method.
A state in which everything is in its correct or appropriate place.
A state in which the laws and rules regulating public behaviour are observed and authority is obeyed.
The prescribed or established procedure followed by a meeting, legislative assembly, debate, or court of law.
A stated form of liturgical service, or of administration of a rite, prescribed by ecclesiastical authority.
An authoritative command or instruction.
A verbal or written request for something to be made, supplied, or served.
A thing made, supplied, or served as a result of an order.
A written direction of a court or judge.
A written direction to pay money or deliver property.
A particular social, political, or economic system.
A social class.
A rank in the Christian ministry, especially that of bishop, priest, or deacon.
The rank of a member of the clergy or an ordained minister of the Church.
Any of the nine grades of angelic beings in the celestial hierarchy as formulated by Pseudo-Dionysius.
A society of monks, nuns, or friars living under the same religious, moral, and social regulations and discipline.
A society of knights bound by a common rule of life and having a combined military and monastic character.
An institution founded by a monarch along the lines of a medieval crusading monastic order for the purpose of honouring meritorious conduct.
The insignia worn by members of an order of honour or merit.
A Masonic or similar fraternity.
The quality or nature of something.
The overall state or condition of something.
A principal taxonomic category that ranks below class and above family.
Any of the five classical styles of architecture (Doric, Ionic, Corinthian, Tuscan, and Composite) based on the proportions of columns and the style of their decoration.
Any style of architecture subject to uniform established proportions.
Equipment or uniform for a specified purpose or of a specified type.
The position in which a rifle is held after ordering arms.
The degree of complexity of an equation, expression, etc., as denoted by an ordinal number.
The number of differentiations required to reach the highest derivative in a differential equation.
The number of elements in a finite group.
The number of rows or columns in a square matrix.
Give an authoritative instruction to do something.
Continually tell someone to do things in an overbearing way.
Command (something) to be done or (someone) to be treated in a particular way.
Request (something) to be made, supplied, or served.
Arrange (something) in a methodical way.
--Examples--
‘I filed the cards in alphabetical order’
‘she tried to put her shattered thoughts into some semblance of order’
‘the army was deployed to keep order’
‘the meeting was called to order’
‘he was not going to take orders from a mere administrator’
‘the skipper gave the order to abandon ship’
‘the firm has won an order for six tankers’
‘he would deliver special orders for the Sunday dinner’
‘she was admitted to hospital under a guardianship order’
‘they were dedicated to overthrowing the established order’
‘the upper social orders’
‘he took priest's orders’
‘the Franciscan Order’
‘the Templars were also known as the Order of Christ’
‘poetry of the highest order’
‘the house had only just been vacated and was in good order’
‘the higher orders of insects’
‘the platoon changed from drill order into PT kit’
‘she ordered me to leave’
‘‘Stop frowning,’ he ordered’
‘he ordered that the ship be abandoned’
‘the judge ordered a retrial’
‘she resented being ordered about’
‘he ordered the anchor dropped’
‘my mate ordered the tickets last week’
‘I asked the security guard to order me a taxi’
‘are you ready to order, sir?’
‘all entries are ordered by date’
‘her normally well-ordered life’
--Word--
orderable 
--Type--
adjective
--Meanings--
Capable of being ordered or directed (to an end or result); amenable to direction or control.
That may be requested or ordered; available for purchase, consumption, etc.
That may be arranged in a series.
--Examples--
--Word--
order book 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A book in which orders are entered as they are received by a business, especially regarded as a measure of the organization's success.
--Examples--
‘the company's order book stood at £5.5 m’
--Word--
order 
--Type--
noun, verb
--Meanings--
The arrangement or disposition of people or things in relation to each other according to a particular sequence, pattern, or method.
A state in which everything is in its correct or appropriate place.

The number of rows or columns in a square matrix.
Give an authoritative instruction to do something.
Continually tell someone to do things in an overbearing way.
Command (something) to be done or (someone) to be treated in a particular way.
Request (something) to be made, supplied, or served.
Arrange (something) in a methodical way.
--Examples--
‘I filed the cards in alphabetical order’
‘she tried to put her shattered thoughts into some semblance of order’
‘the army was deployed to keep order’
‘the meeting was called to order’
‘he was not going to take orders from a mere administrator’

‘her normally well-ordered life’

--Word--
orderly 
--Type--
adjective, noun
--Meanings--
Neatly and methodically arranged.
(of a person or group) well behaved.
Charged with the conveyance or execution of orders.
An attendant in a hospital responsible for the non-medical care of patients and the maintenance of order and cleanliness.
A soldier who carries out orders or performs minor tasks for an officer.
--Examples--
‘an orderly arrangement of objects’
‘the crowd was quiet and orderly’
‘the orderly sergeant’

--Type--

--Meanings--

--Examples--
--Word--
ordinary 
--Type--
adjective, noun
--Meanings--
With no special or distinctive features; normal.
Not interesting or exceptional; commonplace.
(especially of a judge or bishop) exercising authority by virtue of office and not by deputation.
What is commonplace or standard.
A judge who exercises authority by virtue of office and not by deputation.
A member of the clergy, such as an archbishop in a province or a bishop in a diocese, with immediate jurisdiction.
Those parts of a Roman Catholic service, especially the Mass, which do not vary from day to day.
A rule or book laying down the order of divine service.
Any of the simplest principal charges used in coats of arms (especially chief, pale, bend, fess, bar, chevron, cross, saltire).
A meal provided at a fixed time and price at an inn.
An inn providing a meal at a fixed time and price.
A penny-farthing bicycle.
--Examples--
‘he sets out to depict ordinary people’
‘it was just an ordinary evening’
‘she seemed very ordinary’
‘their clichés were vested with enough emotion to elevate them above the ordinary’

ordinate 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--

ordinator 
--Type--

--Meanings--
A person who ordains. rare.
God or a god regarded as the originator of the universe and the governing power.
--Examples--
--Word--
ordination 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
The action of ordaining someone in holy orders.
A ceremony in which someone is ordained.
A statistical technique in which data from a large number of sites or populations are represented as points in a multidimensional space.
The action of decreeing or ordaining.
--Examples--
‘the ordination of women’
‘they travel to Exeter for an ordination’

--Word--
Oreodon 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A former genus (now included in the genus Merycoidodon) of extinct pig-sized ruminant mammals of the family Oreodontidae, having four toes on each foot and selenodont teeth, the remains of which are found in Middle Tertiary rocks in the western United States; (also) an animal of this genus. Later chiefly in "Oreodon beds": strata containing fossils of these animals.
--Examples--
--Word--
oreodont 
--Type--
noun, adjective
--Meanings--
An extinct ruminant mammal of the family Oreodontidae, known from fossils of the Middle Tertiary period.
Of, relating to, or characteristic of the family Oreodontidae.
--Examples--
--Word--
Oreopithecus 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
An extinct ape, Oreopithecus bambolii, known from numerous late Miocene fossil remains found chiefly in Italy, and dated to about eight million years ago.

--Word--
Orion 
--Type--
proper noun
--Meanings--
A giant and hunter who was changed into a constellation at his death.
A conspicuous constellation (the Hunter), said to represent a hunter holding a club and shield. It lies on the celestial equator and contains many bright stars, including Rigel, Betelgeuse, and a line of three that form Orion's Belt.
Used with preceding letter or numeral to designate a star in the constellation Orion.
--Examples--
‘the multiple star Theta Orionis’

--Word--
organ 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A part of an organism which is typically self-contained and has a specific vital function.
Used euphemistically to refer to the penis.
A region of the brain formerly held to be the seat of a particular faculty.
A large musical instrument having rows of pipes supplied with air from bellows (now usually electrically powered), and played using a keyboard or by an automatic mechanism. The pipes are generally arranged in ranks of a particular type, each controlled by a stop, and often into larger sets linked to separate keyboards.
An electronic keyboard instrument that produces sounds similar to those of a pipe organ.
A department or organization that performs a specified function.
A newspaper or periodical which promotes the views of a political party or movement.
--Examples--
‘the internal organs’
‘the male organ’
‘the organs of local government’
‘he repositioned the journal as a leading organ of neoconservatism’

--Word--
organic 
--Type--
adjective, noun
--Meanings--
Relating to or derived from living matter.
Relating to or denoting compounds containing carbon (other than simple binary compounds and salts) and chiefly or ultimately of biological origin.
(of food or farming methods) produced or involving production without the use of chemical fertilizers, pesticides, or other artificial chemicals.
Relating to a bodily organ or organs.
(of a disease) affecting the structure of an organ.
Denoting or characterized by a harmonious relationship between the elements of a whole.
Characterized by gradual or natural development.
A food produced by organic farming.
An organic chemical compound.
--Examples--
‘organic soils’
‘organic farming’
‘organic meat’
‘the organic unity of the integral work of art’
‘the organic growth of community projects’
--Word--
organicity 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
The quality or state of being organic.
--Examples--
--Word--
organically 
--Type--
adverb
--Meanings--
From or in connection with living matter.
Without the use of chemical fertilizers, pesticides, or other artificial chemicals.
In a way that relates to a bodily organ or organs.
As elements of an organized whole.
In the course of gradual or natural development.
--Examples--
‘organically enriched soil’
‘organically grown crops’
‘incentives offered to farmers to farm organically’
‘it's not a definable illness; there is nothing organically wrong’
‘workers in both parts of the new economy are organically connected’
‘little subplots which fit organically into the overall picture’
‘the market grew organically from its modest beginnings’
‘national identity develops organically’

--Word--
organize 
--Type--
verb
--Meanings--
Arrange systematically; order.
Coordinate the activities of (a person or group) efficiently.
Form (a number of people) into a trade union or other political group.
Arrange or form into a living being or tissue.
Make arrangements or preparations for (an event or activity)
Take responsibility for providing or arranging.
--Examples--
‘organize lessons in a planned way’
‘she was unsuited to anything where she had to organize herself’
‘we all believed in the need to organize women’
‘the soul doth organize the body’
‘social programmes are organized by the school’
‘Julie organized food and drink for the band’
--Word--
organized 
--Type--
adjective
--Meanings--
Arranged or structured in a systematic way.
Able to plan one's activities efficiently.
Having formed a trade union or other political group.
--Examples--
‘about 100 cyclists took part in the ride as part of organized protests over the dangers cyclists face on the road’
‘without rules an organized society cannot hold together’
‘she used to be so organized’
‘a repressive regime which crushed organized labour’

--Meanings--
--Examples--
--Word--
organismically 
--Type--
adverb
--Meanings--
Like an organism; in relation to an organism; at an organismic level.
--Examples--
--Word--
organism 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
An individual animal, plant, or single-celled life form.
The material structure of an organism.
A system or organization consisting of interdependent parts, compared to a living being.
--Examples--
‘fish and other organisms have been destroyed over large areas of the creek’
‘the heart's contribution to the maintenance of the human organism’
‘the Church is a divinely constituted organism’
--Word--
organismically 
--Type--
adverb
--Meanings--
Like an organism; in relation to an organism; at an organismic level.
--Examples--
--Word--
organist 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A person who plays the organ.
--Examples--
--Word--
organistic 
--Type--
adjective
--Meanings--
Of or relating to organists or the organ. Now also: (of a different musical instrument) resembling an organ in its sound.
Of or relating to an organism or organized structure.
--Examples--
--Word--
organistrum 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
An early form of a hurdy-gurdy, originally played by two players.

--Meanings--

--Meanings--

adjective
--Meanings--

--Word--
organization 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
An organized group of people with a particular purpose, such as a business or government department.
The action of organizing something.
The way in which the elements of a whole are arranged.
The quality of being systematic and efficient.
--Examples--
‘a research organization’
‘the organization of conferences’
‘the spatial organization of the cells’
‘his lack of organization’
--Word--
organizational 
--Type--
adjective
--Meanings--
Relating to an organization or the way it is set up.
Relating to the action of organizing something.
--Examples--
‘organizational heads’
‘a company's organizational structure’
‘the need for organizational change’
‘she has great organizational skills’
--Word--
organizationally 
--Type--
adverb
--Meanings--
--Examples--
--Word--
organizationist 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
Originally: a person who is an organizer for or an advocate of charity organizations. Only in "charity organizationist". Now also: a person whose primary commitment is to the organization for which he or she works.
--Examples--

--Examples--
--Word--
organize 
--Type--
verb
--Meanings--
Arrange systematically; order.
Coordinate the activities of (a person or group) efficiently.
Form (a number of people) into a trade union or other political group.
Arrange or form into a living being or tissue.
Make arrangements or preparations for (an event or activity)
Take responsibility for providing or arranging.
--Examples--
‘organize lessons in a planned way’
‘she was unsuited to anything where she had to organize herself’
‘we all believed in the need to organize women’
‘the soul doth organize the body’
‘social programmes are organized by the school’
‘Julie organized food and drink for the band’
--Word--
organized 
--Type--
adjective
--Meanings--
Arranged or structured in a systematic way.
Able to plan one's activities efficiently.
Having formed a trade union or other political group.
--Examples--
‘about 100 cyclists took part in the ride as part of organized protests over the dangers cyclists face on the road’
‘without rules an organized society cannot hold together’
‘she used to be so organized’
‘a repressive regime which crushed organized labour’
--Word--
organizer 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A person who arranges an event or activity.
A thing used for organizing.
--Examples--
‘the organizers of the demonstration’

--Word--
organology 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
The theory that the human brain is composed of numerous superficial organs that are responsible for propensities, intellect, character, etc.; phrenology. Compare "organ". Now historical.
Biology. The scientific study of the anatomy and physiology of the organs of animals or plants. Now rare.
The study of the history of musical instruments.
--Examples--
--Word--
organological 
--Type--
adjective
--Meanings--
Of or relating to phrenology; of or relating to the study of the organs of plants or animals. Compare organology 3. Now rare or historical.
Of or relating to the study of musical instruments.
--Examples--
--Word--
organological 
--Type--
adjective
--Meanings--
Of or relating to phrenology; of or relating to the study of the organs of plants or animals. Compare organology 3. Now rare or historical.
Of or relating to the study of musical instruments.

organosol 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A dispersion of a colloid in an organic liquid; (now usually) specifically a dispersion of particles of synthetic resin in a liquid consisting of a plasticizer and volatile components, which can be converted into a solid plastic simply by heating.

--Word--
organ 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A part of an organism which is typically self-contained and has a specific vital function.
Used euphemistically to refer to the penis.
A region of the brain formerly held to be the seat of a particular faculty.
A large musical instrument having rows of pipes supplied with air from bellows (now usually electrically powered), and played using a keyboard or by an automatic mechanism. The pipes are generally arranged in ranks of a particular type, each controlled by a stop, and often into larger sets linked to separate keyboards.
An electronic keyboard instrument that produces sounds similar to those of a pipe organ.
A department or organization that performs a specified function.
A newspaper or periodical which promotes the views of a political party or movement.
--Examples--
‘the internal organs’
‘the male organ’
‘the organs of local government’
‘he repositioned the journal as a leading organ of neoconservatism’
--Word--
organed 
--Type--
adjective
--Meanings--
Having bodily organs or faculties, especially of a specified kind.
Having a musical organ or organs, especially of a specified kind. Chiefly as the second element in compounds. rare.
--Examples--

orgasm 
--Type--
noun, verb
--Meanings--
The climax of sexual excitement, characterized by intensely pleasurable feelings centred in the genitals and (in men) experienced as an accompaniment to ejaculation.
Have an orgasm.
--Examples--
‘she managed to achieve an orgasm’
‘they don't know what it is to reach orgasm’
--Word--
orgasmic 
--Type--
adjective
--Meanings--
Relating to orgasm.
(of a person) able to achieve orgasm.
Very enjoyable.
--Examples--
‘orgasmic shudders’
‘only orgasmic individuals served as subjects in this research’
‘an orgasmic new drink’

--Meanings--

--Word--
-ory 
--Type--
suffix, suffix
--Meanings--
(forming nouns) denoting a place for a particular function.
Forming adjectives (and occasionally nouns) relating to or involving a verbal action.
--Examples--
‘dormitory’
‘repository’
‘compulsory’
‘directory’
‘mandatory’
--Word--
-orial 
--Type--
suffix
--Meanings--
Forming adjectives corresponding to nouns ending in -ory (such as accusatorial corresponding to accusatory).
--Examples--
--Word--
oribatid 
--Type--
adjective, noun
--Meanings--
Of or relating to the family Oribatidae or order Oribatida of small, dark, oval-bodied free-living mites, which have a thickened integument giving them a leathery appearance.
An oribatid mite.

--Word--
orient 
--Type--
noun, adjective, verb
--Meanings--
The countries of the East, especially East Asia.
The special lustre of a pearl of the finest quality (with reference to fine pearls from the East).
A pearl of the finest quality.
Situated in or belonging to the east; oriental.
(of the sun, daylight, etc.) rising.
(especially of precious stones) lustrous.
Align or position (something) relative to the points of a compass or other specified positions.
Find one's position in relation to unfamiliar surroundings.
Guide (someone) in a specified direction.
Tailor or adapt (something) to specified circumstances.
--Examples--
‘the treasures of the Orient’
‘orient kings’
‘the orient moon’
‘the fires are oriented in direct line with the midsummer sunset’
‘there were no street names to enable her to orient herself’
‘we were oriented towards the building’
‘magazines oriented to the business community’
‘market-oriented economic reforms’
--Word--
oriental 
--Type--
adjective, noun
--Meanings--
Of, from, or characteristic of Asia, especially East Asia.
Relating to or denoting a zoogeographical region comprising Asia south of the Himalayas and Indonesia west of Wallace's line. Distinctive animals include pandas, gibbons, tree shrews, tarsiers, and moonrats.
(of a pearl or other jewel) orient.
A person of East Asian descent.
--Examples--
‘oriental countries’
‘oriental rugs’
--Word--
orientalia 
--Type--
plural noun
--Meanings--
Books and other items relating to or characteristic of the Orient.
--Examples--
--Word--

--Meanings--

--Examples--
‘the young band orientalizes indie music’
‘an orientalized modern city’

--Word--
orientalism 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
Style, artefacts, or traits considered characteristic of the peoples and cultures of Asia.
The representation of Asia in a stereotyped way that is regarded as embodying a colonialist attitude.

--Word--
orientation 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
The action of orienting someone or something relative to the points of a compass or other specified positions.
The relative position or direction of something.
The faculty by which birds and other animals find their way back to a place after going or being taken to a place distant from it.
A person's basic attitude, beliefs, or feelings in relation to a particular subject or issue.
Familiarization with something.
A course giving information to newcomers to a university or other institution.
--Examples--
‘studies of locational awareness and orientation in young children’
‘using the orientation of a building to capture energy from the sun’
‘recent research in animal orientation’
‘his book is well worth reading, regardless of your political orientation’
‘many judges give instructions to assist jury orientation’
--Word--
orientational 
--Type--
adjective
--Meanings--
--Examples--
--Word--
orientationally 
--Type--
adverb
--Meanings--
In terms of orientation.
--Examples--
--Word--
orientation 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
The action of orienting someone or something relative to the points of a compass or other specified positions.
The relative position or direction of something.
The faculty by which birds and other animals find their way back to a place after going or being taken to a place distant from it.
A person's basic attitude, beliefs, or feelings in relation to a particular subject or issue.
Familiarization with something.
A course giving information to newcomers to a university or other institution.
--Examples--
‘studies of locational awareness and orientation in young children’
‘using the orientation of a building to capture energy from the sun’
‘recent research in animal orientation’
‘his book is well worth reading, regardless of your political orientation’
‘many judges give instructions to assist jury orientation’

orientationally 
--Type--
adverb
--Meanings--
In terms of orientation.

orientator 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A person who or thing which orientates..

orientator 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--

--Examples--
--Word--
orient 
--Type--
noun, adjective, verb
--Meanings--
The countries of the East, especially East Asia.
The special lustre of a pearl of the finest quality (with reference to fine pearls from the East).
A pearl of the finest quality.
Situated in or belonging to the east; oriental.
(of the sun, daylight, etc.) rising.
(especially of precious stones) lustrous.
Align or position (something) relative to the points of a compass or other specified positions.
Find one's position in relation to unfamiliar surroundings.
Guide (someone) in a specified direction.
Tailor or adapt (something) to specified circumstances.
--Examples--
‘the treasures of the Orient’
‘orient kings’
‘the orient moon’
‘the fires are oriented in direct line with the midsummer sunset’
‘there were no street names to enable her to orient herself’
‘we were oriented towards the building’
‘magazines oriented to the business community’
‘market-oriented economic reforms’
--Word--
orienteering 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A competitive sport in which runners have to find their way across rough country with the aid of a map and compass.

orificial 
--Type--
adjective

Of or relating to an orifice or orifices; ostial.

--Word--
Origen 
--Type--
proper noun
--Meanings--
(c.185–c.254), Christian scholar and theologian, probably born in Alexandria. His most famous work was the Hexapla, an edition of the Old Testament with six or more parallel versions. His Neoplatonist theology was ultimately rejected by Church orthodoxy.
--Examples--
--Word--

--Type--

--Meanings--
= Origenistrare.
= Origenist.

Origenism 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
The doctrines held by or attributed to Origen.
--Examples--
--Word--
Origenist 
--Type--
noun, adjective
--Meanings--
A person holding any of the doctrines and ideas attributed to the Alexandrian biblical scholar and theologian Origen (185–254), especially the belief that all moral beings, including the fallen angels, will ultimately be saved.
Of or relating to Origen, his doctrines, or his followers.
--Examples--
--Word--
origin 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
The point or place where something begins, arises, or is derived.
A person's social background or ancestry.
The more fixed end or attachment of a muscle.
A place where a nerve or blood vessel begins or branches from a main nerve or blood vessel.
A fixed point from which coordinates are measured.
--Examples--
‘his theory of the origin of life’
‘the name is Norse in origin’
‘the terminology has its origins in America’
‘a family of peasant origin’
‘a voice that betrays his Welsh origins’
--Word--
origin 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
The point or place where something begins, arises, or is derived.
A person's social background or ancestry.

--Word--
original 
--Type--
adjective, noun
--Meanings--
Present or existing from the beginning; first or earliest.
Created personally by a particular artist, writer, musician, etc.; not a copy.
Not dependent on other people's ideas; inventive or novel.
The earliest form of something, from which copies may be made.
The language in which something was first written.
A person or place on which a character or location in a literary work is based.
A book or recording that has not been previously made available in a different form.
A garment made to order from a design specially prepared for a fashion collection.
An eccentric or unusual person.
--Examples--
‘the original owner of the house’
‘the plasterwork is probably original’
‘original Rembrandts’
‘a subtle and original thinker’
‘the portrait may be a copy of the original’
‘one set of originals and four photocopies’
‘the study of Russian texts in the original’
‘the house is reputed to be the original of Mansfield Park’
‘paperback originals’
‘the designer has donated one of her amazing originals, a frothy pink evening dress’
‘he was one of the true originals’
--Word--
originalist

noun
--Meanings--
A person who acts, thinks, or otherwise behaves in an original way. Now rare.
US. An advocate or proponent of originalism.
--Examples--

--Meanings--

‘she's a writer of great originality’
‘he congratulated her on the originality of her costume’

Orinoco 
--Type--
proper noun
--Meanings--
A river in northern South America, which rises in south-eastern Venezuela and flows 2,060 km (1,280 miles), entering the Atlantic Ocean through a vast delta. For part of its length it forms the border between Colombia and Venezuela.

--Word--
Orion 
--Type--
proper noun
--Meanings--
A giant and hunter who was changed into a constellation at his death.
A conspicuous constellation (the Hunter), said to represent a hunter holding a club and shield. It lies on the celestial equator and contains many bright stars, including Rigel, Betelgeuse, and a line of three that form Orion's Belt.
Used with preceding letter or numeral to designate a star in the constellation Orion.
--Examples--
‘the multiple star Theta Orionis’

Orkney Islands 
--Type--
proper noun
--Meanings--
A group of more than 70 islands off the north-eastern tip of Scotland, constituting an administrative region of Scotland; population 20,100 (est. 2009); chief town, Kirkwall. They came into Scottish possession in 1472, having previously been ruled by Norway and Denmark.

Orleans 
--Type--
proper noun
--Meanings--
The capital city of Centre region in central France, on the River Loire; population 116,256 (2006). In 1429 it was the scene of Joan of Arc's first victory over the English during the Hundred Years War. French name Orléans /ɔʀleɑ̃/.

Quine, Willard Van Orman 
--Type--
proper noun
--Meanings--
(1908–2000), American philosopher and logician. A radical critic of modern empiricism, Quine took issue with the philosophy of language proposed by Rudolf Carnap, arguing that ‘no statement is immune from revision’ and that even the principles of logic themselves can be questioned and replaced.

--Word--
Ormandy, Eugene 
--Type--
proper noun
--Meanings--
(1899–1985), US conductor; born in Hungary; born Jeno Blau. He was conductor of the Philadelphia Orchestra from 1938 to 1980, the longest directorship of an orchestra in US history.

--Word--
ornament 
--Type--
noun, verb
--Meanings--
A thing used or serving to make something look more attractive but usually having no practical purpose, especially a small object such as a figurine.
Decoration added to embellish something.
A quality or person adding grace, beauty, or honour to something.
Embellishments made to a melody.
The accessories of worship, such as the altar, chalice, and sacred vessels.
Make (something) look more attractive by adding decorative items.
--Examples--
‘tables covered with ornaments and books’
‘Gothic buildings notable for their finely detailed ornament’
‘sense of humour is an ornament to character’
‘the composer marked the vocal part with many aspirations, accents, and other ornaments’
‘a jewel to ornament your wife's lovely throat’

noun

--Word--
ornamentation 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
Decorative elements added to something to enhance its appearance.
The action of decorating something or making it more elaborate.
--Examples--
‘a baroque chandelier with plasterwork ornamentation’
‘the rhetorical ornamentation of text’
--Word--
ornament 
--Type--
noun, verb
--Meanings--
A thing used or serving to make something look more attractive but usually having no practical purpose, especially a small object such as a figurine.
Decoration added to embellish something.
A quality or person adding grace, beauty, or honour to something.
Embellishments made to a melody.
The accessories of worship, such as the altar, chalice, and sacred vessels.
Make (something) look more attractive by adding decorative items.
--Examples--
‘tables covered with ornaments and books’
‘Gothic buildings notable for their finely detailed ornament’
‘sense of humour is an ornament to character’
‘the composer marked the vocal part with many aspirations, accents, and other ornaments’
‘a jewel to ornament your wife's lovely throat’
--Word--
ornamenter 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A person who or thing which ornaments something; specifically an artisan skilled in decoration.
--Examples--

--Word--
Orobanche 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
Any plant of the genus Orobanche, of the family Scrophulariaceae (or Orobanchaceae), comprising the broomrapes, herbaceous root-parasites with fleshy stems, scaly leaves that lack chlorophyll, and tubular flowers; (in early use) especially greater broomrape, O. rapum-genistae, which parasitizes gorse and other shrubby leguminous plants. Also (in form Orobanche): the genus itself.

--Word--
Orontes 
--Type--
proper noun
--Meanings--
A river in south-western Asia which rises near Baalbek in northern Lebanon and flows 571 km (355 miles) through western and northern Syria before turning west through southern Turkey to enter the Mediterranean. It is an important source of water for irrigation, especially in Syria.

--Word--
Orphean 
--Type--
adjective
--Meanings--
Relating to or characteristic of the poet Orpheus, especially in being melodious or entrancing.
Resembling or reminiscent of Orpheus' journey into the underworld.
--Examples--
‘they were entranced by the Orphean skill he displayed’
‘an Orphean journey into a kind of underworld of sin’
--Word--
Orpheus 
--Type--
proper noun
--Meanings--
A poet who could entrance wild beasts with the beauty of his singing and lyre playing. He went to the underworld after the death of his wife Eurydice and secured her release from the dead, but lost her because he failed to obey the condition that he must not look back at her until they had reached the world of the living.
--Examples--
--Word--

--Word--
Orphicism 
--Type--

--Examples--
--Word--
Orphism 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A mystic religion of ancient Greece, originating in the 7th or 6th century BC and based on poems (now lost) attributed to Orpheus, emphasizing the necessity for individuals to rid themselves of the evil part of their nature by ritual and moral purification throughout a series of reincarnations.
A short-lived art movement (c.1912) within cubism, pioneered by a group of French painters (including Robert Delaunay, Sonia Delaunay-Terk, and Fernand Léger) and emphasizing the lyrical use of colour rather than the austere intellectual cubism of Picasso, Braque, and Gris.
--Examples--
--Word--
Orphist 
--Type--
noun, adjective
--Meanings--
Art. A member or adherent of the Cubist movement of Orphism.
Art. Of, relating to, or characteristic of Orphism.
--Examples--
--Word--

Orr, Bobby 
--Type--
proper noun
--Meanings--
(born 1948), Canadian hockey player; full name Robert Gordon Orr. He signed with the Boston Bruins at the age of eighteen in 1966 and played for them until 1976. He played for the Chicago Blackhawks before retiring in 1978. Hockey Hall of Fame (1979).

--Examples--
--Word--
or 
--Type--
conjunction, noun
--Meanings--
Used to link alternatives.
Introducing a synonym or explanation of a preceding word or phrase.
Otherwise (used to introduce the consequences of something not being done or not being the case)
Introducing an afterthought, usually in the form of a question.
Either.
A logical operation which gives the value one if at least one operand has the value one, and otherwise gives a value of zero.
Denoting a gate circuit which produces an output if there is a signal on any of its inputs.
--Examples--
‘a cup of tea or coffee’
‘are you coming or not?’
‘I either take taxis or walk everywhere’
‘it doesn't matter whether the theory is right or wrong’
‘yoga is a series of postures, or asanas’
‘hurry up, or you'll miss it all’
‘John's indifference—or was it?—left her unsettled’
‘to love is the one way to know or God or man’
--Word--
-or 
--Type--
suffix, suffix, suffix
--Meanings--
(forming nouns) denoting a person or thing performing the action of a verb, or denoting another agent.
Forming adjectives expressing a comparative sense.
Forming nouns denoting a state or condition.
--Examples--
‘escalator’
‘governor’
‘resistor’
‘junior’
‘major’
‘error’
‘pallor’
‘terror’
--Word--
orsellic acid 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
Any of a group of related acids obtained from orchil and other lichens; specifically = orsellinic acid.

--Type--

--Word--
orsellinic acid 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A crystalline phenolic acid found in some lichens and fungi, chiefly in the form of depsides such as lecanoric acid; 2,4-dihydroxy-6-methylbenzoic acid, C₈H₈O₄.
--Examples--

Orsk 
--Type--
proper noun
--Meanings--
A city in southern Russia, in the Ural Mountains, on the Ural River, near the border with Kazakhstan; population 245,500 (est. 2008).
--Examples--
--Word--
Welles, Orson 
--Type--
proper noun
--Meanings--
(1915–85), American film director and actor; full name George Orson Welles. His realistic radio dramatization in 1938 of H. G. Wells's The War of the Worlds persuaded many listeners that a Martian invasion was really happening. Notable films as director and actor include Citizen Kane (1941) and as actor The Third Man (1949).

--Meanings--
A citrus fruit which is a cross between an orange and a tangerine, developed in Jamaica in the 1920s.
--Examples--
--Word--
Ortega, Daniel 
--Type--
proper noun
--Meanings--
(1945), Nicaraguan statesman, president 1985–90 and since 2007; full name Daniel Ortega Saavedra. He became the leader of the Sandinista National Liberation Front (FSLN) in 1966 and first served as president after the Sandinista election victory in 1984. He was re-elected president in 2007.

orthic 
--Type--
adjective
--Meanings--
Of a polyhedron: composed of pairs of equal parallel faces of which equivalent points are connected by lines perpendicular to the faces. Now rare.
Designating the triangle whose vertices are the feet of the altitudes of a given triangle.
Soil Science. Of a soil: having the median characteristics of its type.

--Examples--
--Word--
orthoceratite 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A fossil shell of a nautiloid cephalod mollusc of the Palaeozoic or early Mesozoic eras, having a long, straight (or nearly straight) chambered shell; specifically a member of the former genus Orthoceratites or family Orthoceratidae; compare orthoceras. Also in Latin form Orthoceratites (in later use only as the name of a genus).
--Examples--
--Word--
orthochromatic 
--Type--
adjective
--Meanings--
(of black-and-white photographic film) sensitive to all visible light except red. Orthochromatic film can therefore be handled in red light in the darkroom but does not produce black-and-white tones that correspond very closely to the colours seen by the eye.
--Examples--
--Word--
orthoclase 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A common rock-forming mineral occurring typically as white or pink crystals. It is a potassium-rich alkali feldspar and is used in ceramics and glass-making.

orthodox 
--Type--
adjective
--Meanings--
Following or conforming to the traditional or generally accepted rules or beliefs of a religion, philosophy, or practice.
(of a person) not independent-minded; conventional and unoriginal.
Of the ordinary or usual type; normal.
Relating to Orthodox Judaism.
Relating to the Orthodox Church.
--Examples--
‘Burke's views were orthodox in his time’
‘orthodox medical treatment’
‘orthodox Hindus’
‘a relatively orthodox artist’
‘they avoided orthodox jazz venues’
‘Orthodox Jewish boys’
‘everyone I knew was Orthodox’

--Word--
orthopter 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
--Examples--
--Word--
Orthoptera 
--Type--
plural noun
--Meanings--
An order of insects that comprises the grasshoppers, crickets, and their relatives. They have a saddle-shaped thorax, hind legs that are typically long and modified for jumping, and a characteristic song which the male produces by stridulation.
Insects of the order Orthoptera.
--Examples--
‘the wings of living orthoptera’
--Word--
orthopteran 
--Type--
noun, adjective
--Meanings--
An insect of the order Orthoptera, such as a grasshopper or cricket.
Relating to or denoting orthopterans.
--Examples--
--Word--
orthopterist 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
An expert in or student of the orthoptera.
--Examples--
--Word--
orthopteroid 
--Type--
adjective
--Meanings--
Relating to a group of insect orders that are related to the grasshoppers and crickets, including also the stoneflies, stick insects, earwigs, cockroaches, mantises, and termites.
--Examples--
--Word--
orthopterology 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
The branch of entomology concerned with the Orthoptera.
--Examples--
--Word--
orthopterological 
--Type--
adjective
--Meanings--
Of or relating to orthopterology.
--Examples--
--Word--
orthopteron 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--

--Examples--
--Word--
orthopterous 
--Type--
adjective
--Meanings--

orthoptic 
--Type--
adjective
--Meanings--
--Examples--
--Word--
orthoptics 
--Type--
plural noun
--Meanings--

--Examples--
--Word--
orthorhombic 
--Type--
adjective
--Meanings--
Of or denoting a crystal system or three-dimensional geometrical arrangement having three unequal axes at right angles.
--Examples--
--Word--
orthorrhaphous 
--Type--
adjective
--Meanings--
Relating to or designating the more primitive groups of dipteran flies (formerly constituting the suborder Orthorrhapha), which are characterized by the emergence of the adult from the pupa through a longitudinal or T-shaped split.
--Examples--
--Word--
ortho- 
--Type--
combining form
--Meanings--
Straight; rectangular; upright.
Right; correct.
Denoting substitution at two adjacent carbon atoms in a benzene ring, e.g. in 1,2 positions.
Denoting a compound from which a meta-compound is formed by dehydration.
--Examples--
‘orthodontics’
‘orthoepy’
‘orthodichlorobenzene’
‘orthophosphoric acid’
--Word--
orthoscopic 
--Type--
adjective, noun
--Meanings--
Having or producing normal vision; yielding an image free from optical distortion; specifically of binocular vision: without the reversal of convexity and concavity produced by pseudoscopic instruments.
Optics. An orthoscopic eyepiece.
--Examples--
--Word--
orthose 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A mineral which is the common form of potash feldspar.
--Examples--
--Word--
orthoselection 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
Natural selection operating in one direction continuously over a relatively long period of time.
--Examples--
--Word--
orthosilicate 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A salt containing the anion SiO₄ 4−; the anion itself; a salt or ester of orthosilicic acid; any mineral or other compound containing discrete tetrahedral SiO₄ anions.
--Examples--
--Word--
orthosilicic acid 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
The acid H₄SiO₄, a weak acid made in solution by acidifying solutions of silicates.
--Examples--
--Word--
orthosymmetric 
--Type--
adjective
--Meanings--
Mathematics. Designating a symmetric determinant or matrix in which all the constituents in the secondary diagonal (running from top right to bottom left), and likewise all those in each of the oblique rows parallel to it, are equal.
--Examples--

adjective, noun

Astronomy. Of or relating to the rising of a celestial object. Usually in "ortive amplitude": the angular distance of an object at its rising measured from the eastern point of the horizon.

Orton, Joe 
--Type--
proper noun
--Meanings--
(1933–67), English playwright; born John Kingsley Orton. He wrote a number of unconventional black comedies, examining corruption, sexuality, and violence; they include Entertaining Mr Sloane (1964) and Loot (1965). Orton was murdered by his homosexual lover, who then committed suicide.
