--Word--
Douglas, William Orville 
--Type--
proper noun
--Meanings--
(1898–1980), US Supreme Court associate justice 1939–75. Appointed to the Court by President Franklin D. Roosevelt, he worked to uphold the New Deal programs and was a strong advocate of free speech. He also was noted for defending the environment.
--Examples--
--Word--
Orwell, George 
--Type--
proper noun
--Meanings--
(1903–50), British novelist and essayist, born in India; pseudonym of Eric Arthur Blair. Orwell's work is characterized by his concern for social injustice. His most famous works are Animal Farm (1945), a satire on Communism as it developed under Stalin, and Nineteen Eighty-Four (1949), a dystopian account of a future state in which every aspect of life is controlled by Big Brother.
--Examples--
--Word--
Orwellian 
--Type--
adjective
--Meanings--
Characteristic of the writings of George Orwell, especially with reference to his dystopian account of a future totalitarian state in Nineteen Eighty-Four.
--Examples--
‘a frightening view of an Orwellian future’

--Word--
O 
--Type--
noun, abbreviation
UnKnownKind, exclamation
--Meanings--
The fifteenth letter of the alphabet.
Denoting the next after N in a set of items, categories, etc.
A human blood type (in the ABO system) lacking both the A and B antigens. In blood transfusion, a person with blood of this group is a potential universal donor.
Nought or zero (in a sequence of numerals, especially when spoken)
A shape like that of a capital O; a circle.
Ohio.
(on scorecards) over(s).
The chemical element oxygen.
Used before a name in direct address, as in prayers and poetry.
--Examples--
‘two seven o seven point six’
‘he made an O with his mouth’
‘give peace in our time, O Lord’

Osborne, John 
--Type--
proper noun
--Meanings--
(1929–94), English playwright; full name John James Osborne. His first play, Look Back in Anger (1956), ushered in a new era of kitchen-sink drama; its hero Jimmy Porter personified contemporary disillusioned youth, the so-called ‘angry young man’.

Osceola 
--Type--
proper noun
--Meanings--
(circa 1804–38), leader of the Seminole Indians; born Billy Powell. Resisting all government efforts to remove his people from their homeland in Florida, he led them in the Seminole Wars, which began in 1835. He was captured in 1837 while bearing a flag of truce.

oscillate 
--Type--
verb
--Meanings--
Move or swing back and forth in a regular rhythm.
Vary or fluctuate between two states, limits, opinions, etc.
Vary in magnitude or position in a regular manner about a central point.
(of a circuit or device) cause the electric current or voltage running through it to vary in magnitude or position in a regular manner about a central point.
--Examples--
‘the grain pan near the front of the combine oscillates back and forth’
‘he was oscillating between fear and bravery’

oscillation 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
Movement back and forth in a regular rhythm.

‘the oscillations of a pendulum’

‘electromagnetic oscillations’

Oscillatoria 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A genus of cyanobacteria (blue-green algae), the members of which form dark slimy unbranched filaments, capable of a gliding or undulating motion, in various fresh and salt water habitats; (also) an organism of this genus. In pluralOscillatoriae also: a former natural order containing the genus Oscillatoria (corresponding in part to the modern order Oscillatoriales).

Osco-Umbrian 
--Type--
noun, adjective
--Meanings--
A group of ancient Italic languages including Oscan and Umbrian, spoken in Italy in the 1st millennium BC, before the emergence of Latin as a standard language.
A member of any of the peoples who spoke a language in the Osco-Umbrian group.
Relating to the Osco-Umbrians or their languages.

osier 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A small Eurasian willow which grows mostly in wet habitats. It is usually coppiced, being a major source of the long flexible shoots (withies) used in basketwork.
A shoot of a willow.
Any willow tree.

Osirian 
--Type--
adjective
--Meanings--

--Examples--

--Word--
Osiride 
--Type--
adjective
--Meanings--
Of, relating to, or depicting the Egyptian god Osiris; = "Osirian".
--Examples--
--Word--
Osiris 
--Type--
proper noun
--Meanings--
A god originally connected with fertility, husband of Isis and father of Horus. He is known chiefly through the story of his death at the hands of his brother Seth and his subsequent restoration to a new life as ruler of the afterlife.
--Examples--
--Word--
Osirism 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
In ancient Egypt: the cult or ritual associated with Osiris.

--Word--
-osity 
--Type--
suffix
--Meanings--
Forming nouns from adjectives ending in -ose (such as verbosity from verbose) and from adjectives ending in -ous (such as pomposity from pompous).
--Examples--
--Word--
Schindler, Oskar 
--Type--
proper noun
--Meanings--
(1908–74), German industrialist. He saved more than 1,200 Jews from concentration camps by employing them first in his enamelware factory in Cracow and then in an armaments factory that he set up in Czechoslovakia in 1944.
--Examples--
--Word--
Oslo 
--Type--
proper noun
--Meanings--
The capital and chief port of Norway, on the south coast at the head of Oslofjord; population 839,423 (2007). Founded in the 11th century, it was known as Christiania (or Kristiania) from 1624 until 1924 in honour of Christian IV of Norway and Denmark (1577–1648).
--Examples--
--Word--
Osman I 
--Type--
proper noun
--Meanings--
(1259–1326), Turkish conqueror, founder of the Ottoman (Osmanli) dynasty and empire. Osman reigned as sultan of the Seljuk Turks from 1288, conquering north-western Asia Minor. He assumed the title of emir in 1299.

Osmanthus 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A genus of the family Oleaceae comprising evergreen shrubs and small trees native to eastern Asia, the Middle East, and southern North America, usually having fragrant white or cream flowers; (also osmanthus) any plant of this genus.

noun
--Meanings--

osmole 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
The amount of a solute that contains or produces one mole of osmotically active particles when in solution. Also (in plural): osmotically active particles.
--Examples--
--Word--
osmolal 
--Type--
adjective
--Meanings--
Of the concentration of a solution: expressed in osmoles of solute per kilogram of solvent. Also: designating a solution that contains one osmole, or a specified number of osmoles, per kilogram of solvent, or the solute present in such a solution.
--Examples--
--Word--
osmolality 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
The concentration of a solution expressed as the total number of solute particles per kilogram.
--Examples--
--Word--
osmolar 
--Type--
adjective
--Meanings--
Of the concentration of a solution: expressed in terms of the quantity of osmotically active solute particles per unit; specifically expressed in osmoles of solute per litre of solution. Also: designating a solution that contains one osmole, or a specified number of osmoles, per litre of solution, or the solute present in such a solution; of or relating to osmotically active particles.
--Examples--
--Word--
osmolarity 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
The concentration of a solution expressed as the total number of solute particles per litre.

--Word--
osmosis 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A process by which molecules of a solvent tend to pass through a semipermeable membrane from a less concentrated solution into a more concentrated one.
The process of gradual or unconscious assimilation of ideas, knowledge, etc.
--Examples--
‘by some strange political osmosis, private reputations became public’
--Word--
osmotherapy 
--Type--
noun, noun
--Meanings--
The administration of osmotically active agents such as mannitol or hypertonic saline in order to produce dehydration of tissues, especially in the treatment of cerebral oedema and increased intracranial pressure.
Treatment or therapy aimed at restoring the sense of smell. rare.
The use of odours to govern mood and promote well-being; treatment for stress, anxiety, etc., involving such use. [A trademark in the United Kingdom.]

--Meanings--

osselet 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
Zoology and Anatomy. Originally: any of the small bones of the carpus or tarsus of a horse. Later also: any of various other types of small bone or ossicle. Now rare or historical.
In plural A game like knuckle-bones or jacks, played with the carpal or tarsal bones of a quadruped (or objects of similar size). rare.
Veterinary Medicine. A hard or bony growth on a joint of a horse; specifically such a growth on the fetlock. Also (in plural): the condition of having such a growth or growths; periostitis in the region of the fetlock.

Ossetia 
--Type--
proper noun
--Meanings--
A region of the central Caucasus. It is divided by the boundary between Russia and Georgia into two parts, North Ossetia and South Ossetia, and between 1989 and 1992 was the scene of ethnic conflict.

Ossian 
--Type--
proper noun
--Meanings--
A legendary Irish warrior and bard, whose name became well known in 1760–3 when the Scottish poet James Macpherson (1736–96) published his own verse as an alleged translation of 3rd-century Gaelic tales.

ostariophysan 
--Type--
noun, adjective
--Meanings--

--Word--
ostension 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
The action of showing, exhibiting, or making manifest; exhibition, display, manifestation; an instance of this. Now rare.
Philosophy= ostensive definition.
Christian Church. The showing of the consecrated elements to the congregation at the Eucharist; (also) a similar display of some other object of veneration. Now rare (historical).

ostentate 
--Type--
verb
--Meanings--
To make a show of; to show off; to display ostentatiously or boastfully.
--Examples--
--Word--
ostentation 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
The pretentious or showy display of wealth and luxury, designed to impress.
--Examples--
‘the office was spacious, but without any trace of ostentation’
--Word--
ostentation 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
The pretentious or showy display of wealth and luxury, designed to impress.
--Examples--
‘the office was spacious, but without any trace of ostentation’
--Word--
ostentatious 
--Type--
adjective
--Meanings--
Characterized by pretentious or showy display; designed to impress.
--Examples--
‘a simple design that is glamorous without being ostentatious’
--Word--
ostentatiously 
--Type--
adverb
--Meanings--
In a pretentious or showy way designed to impress.
--Examples--
‘she was known for dressing ostentatiously in designer clothes’
‘he ostentatiously announced on national television that he was leaving’

--Word--
osteoarthritic 
--Type--
adjective
--Meanings--
--Examples--
--Word--
osteoarthritis 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
Degeneration of joint cartilage and the underlying bone, most common from middle age onward. It causes pain and stiffness, especially in the hip, knee, and thumb joints.
--Examples--
--Word--
osteoarthropathy 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
Any disorder that affects both bones and joints; especially in "hypertrophic pulmonary osteoarthropathy"noun a syndrome characterized by periosteal new bone formation involving the long bones and phalanges, a variable degree of arthritis, and often clubbing of the fingers, seen in association with pulmonary and various other diseases.

osteochondritis 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
Inflammation of bone and cartilage; especially any of several conditions in which there is avascular necrosis of, or chronic trauma to, a specific epiphysis or apophysis in a child or adolescent.

noun
--Meanings--

osteodystrophy 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
Any of a diverse group of disorders characterized by generalized or localized abnormality in the structure of bone; especially that caused by hyperparathyroidism (also called osteitis fibrosa, osteitis fibrosa cystica).

--Word--
osteopetrosis 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
Any of a group of inherited disorders (in humans and other mammals) characterized by thickening of the bones due to defective bone resorption by osteoclasts. Also: a proliferative bone disorder caused by retroviral infection (avian leukosis complex) in birds.
--Examples--
--Word--

--Meanings--
An abnormal appetite for bones, especially as a response to dietary calcium and phosphorus imbalance in herbivores.

Ostia 
--Type--
proper noun
--Meanings--
An ancient city and harbour which was situated on the western coast of Italy at the mouth of the River Tiber. It was the first colony founded by ancient Rome and was a major port and commercial centre.

--Type--
noun, adjective
--Meanings--
A member of a people of the Ob River basin in Western Siberia. Now usually called Khanty.
The Ob-Ugrian language of this people; = "Khanty".
Of, relating to, or designating the Ostyaks or their language.

ostracean 
--Type--
adjective, noun
--Meanings--

ostracion 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A boxfish; (later) specifically one of the genus Ostracion. Now only (in form Ostracion): the genus itself.
--Examples--
--Word--
ostracize 
--Type--
verb
--Meanings--
Exclude from a society or group.
(in ancient Greece) banish (an unpopular or overly powerful citizen) from a city for five or ten years by popular vote.
--Examples--
‘she was declared a witch and ostracized by the villagers’
‘Themistocles was indeed out of favour at Athens by the end of the 470s, when he was ostracized’
--Word--

noun
--Meanings--
Exclusion from a society or group.
(in ancient Greece) temporary banishment from a city by popular vote.
--Examples--
‘the family suffered social ostracism’
‘the ostracism of Thucydides’

ostrich 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A flightless swift-running African bird with a long neck, long legs, and two toes on each foot. It is the largest living bird, with males reaching a height of up to 2.75 m.
A person who refuses to face reality or accept facts.

--Word--
Ostwald, Wilhelm 
--Type--
proper noun
--Meanings--
(1853–1932), German physical chemist; full name Friedrich Wilhelm Otswald. He established physical chemistry as a separate discipline and contributed to pioneering work on catalysis, chemical affinities, and the development of a new quantitative colour theory. Nobel Prize for Chemistry (1909).
--Examples--
--Word--
O'Sullivan, Maureen 
--Type--
proper noun
--Meanings--
(1911–98), US actress; born in Ireland; mother of Mia Farrow. She starred as Jane to Johnny Weissmuller's Tarzan in such movies as Tarzan the Ape Man (1932), Tarzan and His Mate (1934), and Tarzan's Secret Treasure (1941). She also starred in The Big Clock (1948) and appeared in Peggy Sue Got Married (1986) and Hannah and Her Sisters (1986).
--Examples--
--Word--
Spengler, Oswald 
--Type--
proper noun
--Meanings--
(1880–1936), German philosopher. In his book The Decline of the West (1918–22) he argues that civilizations undergo a seasonal cycle of a thousand years and are subject to growth and decay analogous to biological species.
--Examples--
--Word--
Oswego 
--Type--
proper noun
--Meanings--
An industrial port city in north central New York, on Lake Ontario and the Oswego River; population 17,351 (est. 2008).

--Word--
-ot 
--Type--
suffix, suffix
--Meanings--
Forming nouns which were originally diminutives.
(forming nouns) denoting a person of a particular type.
Denoting a native of a place.

‘parrot’

Otaheite 
--Type--
adjective, noun
--Meanings--
Tahitian. Now only with reference to plants associated with Tahiti.
= Otaheite cane.

--Word--
otarioid 
--Type--
adjective, noun
--Meanings--
Resembling or related to the eared seals; (specifically) of or relating to the superfamily Otarioidea, which comprises otariids together with walruses.
An otarioid mammal.

Othello 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A trademark for: a type of full-bodied red wine from Cyprus.
A trademark for: a version of the two-player board game reversi, in which a player attempts to place pieces so that they enclose his or her opponent's pieces and hence reverse their colour.

--Word--
otheoscope 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A modification of Crookes's radiometer in which the black or driving surface is stationary, whilst the cooling surface is movable.
--Examples--
--Word--
other 
--Type--
UnKnownKind, verb
--Meanings--
Used to refer to a person or thing that is different or distinct from one already mentioned or known about.
Alternative of two.
Those remaining in a group; those not already mentioned.
Further; additional.
Used euphemistically to refer to sexual intercourse.
That which is distinct from, different from, or opposite to something or oneself.
View or treat (a person or group of people) as intrinsically different from and alien to oneself.
--Examples--
‘stick the camera on a tripod or some other means of support’
‘other people found her difficult’
‘a language unrelated to any other’
‘the other side of the street’
‘my other brother’
‘she flung up first one arm and then the other’
‘one or other of his parents’
‘they took the other three away in an ambulance’
‘Freddie set off and the others followed’
‘one other word of advice’
‘Labour would have 49 MPs plus ten others’
‘a bit of the other’
‘she needs to escape the tyranny of the Other’
‘a critique of the ways in which the elderly are othered by society’
--Word--
other-directed 
--Type--
adjective
--Meanings--
(of a person or their behaviour) governed by external circumstances and the behaviour and standards of others.
--Examples--
‘post-war sociologists who saw American society as full of other-directed men’
--Word--
other-directedness 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
The quality or state of being other-directed.
--Examples--
--Word--
other-direction 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
Orientation of a person's behaviour and standards by the influence of the expectations and example of others. Opposed to inner-direction and tradition-direction.
--Examples--
--Word--
othergates 
--Type--
adverb
--Meanings--
In another way, otherwise, differently. Also (Scottish and Irish English (northern)): elsewhere.

otherwise 
--Type--
adverb, adjective
--Meanings--

In other respects; apart from that.
In a different way.
As an alternative.

--Examples--

‘an otherwise totally black cat with a single white whisker’
‘he means mischief—it's no good pretending otherwise’
‘all the staff were otherwise engaged’
‘the Cosa Nostra, otherwise known as the Brotherhood’
‘I would that it were otherwise’

--Type--

--Word--
Otho, Marcus Salvius 
--Type--
proper noun
--Meanings--
(AD 32–69), Roman emperor January–April 69. He was proclaimed emperor after he had procured the death of Galba in a conspiracy of the praetorian guard, but the German legions, led by their imperial candidate, Vitellius, defeated his troops and Otho committed suicide.

otitis 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
Inflammation of the ear, usually distinguished as otitis externa (of the passage of the outer ear), otitis media (of the middle ear), and otitis interna (of the inner ear; labyrinthitis).

Otoe 
--Type--
noun, adjective
--Meanings--
A member of a Sioux people formerly living along the Missouri River in eastern Nebraska and now in Oklahoma, where they are one component of the people formally known as the Otoe-Missouria Tribe.
The Siouan Chiwere language of this people.
Of or designating the Otoe people or their language.

Otomi 
--Type--

--Meanings--

--Examples--
--Word--
Otomian 
--Type--
noun, adjective
--Meanings--
A group of related central Mexican languages, including Otomi and Mazahua, belonging to the Oto-Manguean family. Also (occasionally) specifically: the language of the Otomi people.
Of, relating to, or designating this group or its languages.

--Word--
Ottawa 
--Type--
proper noun
--Meanings--
The federal capital of Canada, in south-eastern Ontario, on the Ottawa River (a tributary of the St Lawrence River); population 812,129 (2006). From its founding in 1827 until 1854, it was named Bytown after Colonel John By (1779–1836).
--Examples--
--Word--
Ottawa 
--Type--
proper noun
--Meanings--
The federal capital of Canada, in south-eastern Ontario, on the Ottawa River (a tributary of the St Lawrence River); population 812,129 (2006). From its founding in 1827 until 1854, it was named Bytown after Colonel John By (1779–1836).

ottoman 
--Type--
noun, adjective, noun
--Meanings--
A low upholstered seat without a back or arms that typically serves also as a box, with the seat hinged to form a lid.
A heavy ribbed fabric made from silk and either cotton or wool.
Relating to the Ottoman Empire.
Relating to the Turkish dynasty of Osman I (Othman I), or to the branch of the Turks to which he belonged.
Turkish.
A Turk, especially of the period of the Ottoman Empire.

ottoman

Turkish.
A Turk, especially of the period of the Ottoman Empire.
--Examples--
--Word--
Ottonian 
--Type--
noun, adjective
--Meanings--
Each of the rulers comprising the East Frankish dynasty of kings of Germany and emperors of the Holy Roman Empire founded by Otto I (912–73), which ruled from 936 (962 in the Holy Roman Empire) to 1002.
Of or relating to this dynasty.
Specifically (a) Art of, characteristic of, or designating the styles in painting, sculpture, metalwork, etc., found in Germany under the Ottonian emperors and into the 11th cent., partly a revival of Carolingian art, but also with a strong Byzantine influence; (b) Architecture of, characteristic of, or designating the style of Romanesque architecture developed under the early Ottonians and found in Germany from the mid 10th to the mid 11th cent.

proper noun
--Meanings--

Oudenarde, Battle of 
--Type--
proper noun
--Meanings--
A battle which took place in 1708 during the War of the Spanish Succession, near the town of Oudenarde in eastern Flanders, Belgium. A force of allied British and Austrian troops defeated the French.

--Word--
Oudh 
--Type--
proper noun
--Meanings--
A region of northern India. In 1877 it joined with Agra and in 1902 it formed the United Provinces of Agra and Oudh. This was renamed Uttar Pradesh in 1950.

ough 
--Type--
exclamation
--Meanings--
In early use: used in imitation of a sound denoting various sentiments, some also expressed by och, oh, ooh, etc. In later use specifically as an exclamation expressing disgust.

--Word--
ought 
--Type--
modal verb, noun, pronoun
--Meanings--
Used to indicate duty or correctness, typically when criticizing someone's actions.
Used to indicate a desirable or expected state.
Used to give or ask for advice.
Used to indicate something that is probable.
--Examples--
‘they ought to respect the law’
‘thanks for your letter which I ought to have answered sooner’
‘he ought to be able to take the initiative’
‘you ought to go’
‘what ought I to do?’
‘five minutes ought to be enough time’

noun, noun

--Word--
our 
--Type--
possessive determiner
--Meanings--
Belonging to or associated with the speaker and one or more other people previously mentioned or easily identified.
Belonging to or associated with people in general.
Used in formal contexts by a royal person or a writer or editor to refer to something belonging to or associated with himself or herself.
Used with a name to refer to a relative, friend, or colleague of the speaker.
--Examples--
‘Jo and I had our hair cut’
‘when we hear a sound, our brains identify the source quickly’
‘we want to know what you, our readers, think’
‘really, she is a one, our Gillian’

--Word--
ourself 
--Type--
pronoun
--Meanings--
Used instead of ‘ourselves’ typically when ‘we’ refers to people in general rather than a definite group of people.
Used instead of ‘myself’ by a sovereign or other person in authority.
--Examples--
‘we must choose which aspects of ourself to express to the world’
‘this is our affair—we deal with it ourself’
‘witnessed ourself at Southampton this thirteenth day of October’
--Word--
ourselves 
--Type--
pronoun
--Meanings--
Used as the object of a verb or preposition when this is the same as the subject of the clause and the subject is the speaker and one or more other people considered together.
We or us personally (used to emphasize the speaker and one or more other people considered together)
--Examples--
‘since we're here, we might as well enjoy ourselves’
‘we invented it ourselves’

Ouse 
--Type--
proper noun
--Meanings--
A river of eastern England, which rises in Northamptonshire and flows 257 km (160 miles) eastwards then northwards through East Anglia to the Wash near King's Lynn.
A river of north-eastern England, formed at the confluence of the Ure and Swale Rivers in North Yorkshire and flowing 92 km (57 miles) south-eastwards through York to the Humber Estuary.
A river of south-eastern England, which rises in the Weald of West Sussex and flows 48 km (30 miles) south-eastwards to the English Channel.
A river of East Anglia, which forms a tributary of the Great Ouse.

--Word--
out 
--Type--
adverb, preposition, adjective, noun, verb
--Meanings--
Moving or appearing to move away from a particular place, especially one that is enclosed or hidden.
Situated or operating in the open air, away from buildings.
No longer detained in prison.
Situated far or at a particular distance from somewhere.
To sea, away from the land.
(of the tide) falling or at its lowest level.
Indicating a specified distance away from the goal line or finishing line.
Away from home.
In or to a public place for purposes of pleasure or entertainment.
So as to be revealed or known.
Aloud; so as to be heard.
At or to an end.
So as to be finished or complete.
In various other completive uses.
(of a light or fire) so as to be extinguished or no longer burning.
(of a stain or mark) no longer visible; removed.
No longer involved in a situation, competition, or activity.
(of a jury) considering its verdict in secrecy.
Non-standard contraction of out of.
Not at home or at one's place of work.
Revealed or made public.
(of a flower) in bloom; open.
Published.
In existence or use.
(of a young upper-class woman) introduced into society.
Open about one's homosexuality.
No longer alight; extinguished.
At an end.
No longer in fashion.
Not possible or worth considering.
In a state of unconsciousness.
Unable to rise from the floor.
Mistaken; in error.
(of the ball in tennis and similar games) outside the designated playing area.
No longer batting or at bat; having had one's innings or at bat ended by the fielding side.
A way of escaping from a problem or dilemma.
An act of putting a player out.
The political party not in office.
Knock (someone) out.
Reveal the homosexuality of (a prominent person).
Extinguish.
Expel, reject, or dismiss.
--Examples--
‘he walked out into the street’
‘watch the stars come out’
‘the search-and-rescue team have been out looking for you’
‘they would be out on bail in no time’
‘an old farmhouse right out in the middle of nowhere’
‘they lived eight miles out of town’
‘a cold front hundreds of miles out in the Atlantic’
‘the Persian fleet put out from Cyprus’
‘the tide was going out’
‘he scored from 70 metres out’
‘he's gone out’
‘an evening out at a restaurant’
‘find out what you can’
‘Miss Beard cried out in horror’
‘the romance fizzled out’
‘I'll leave them to fight it out’
‘I typed out the poem’
‘the crowd had thinned out’
‘he crossed out a word’
‘at ten o'clock the lights went out’
‘try to get the stain out’
‘Oxford United are out of the FA Cup’
‘he ran out the door’
‘if he called, she'd pretend to be out’
‘the secret was soon out’
‘the book should be out before the end of the month’
‘it works as well as any system that's out’
‘where is the use of having a lot of dresses when she isn't out yet?’
‘I had been out since I was 17’
‘the fire was nearly out’
‘school was out for the summer’
‘grunge is out’
‘a trip to the seaside is out for a start’
‘he was slightly out in his calculations’
‘England were all out for 159’
‘he was desperately looking for an out’
‘out the lamp when you're ready’
‘they had outed Asquith quite easily’

--Word--
ask 
--Type--
verb, noun
--Meanings--
Say something in order to obtain an answer or some information.
Talk to different people in order to find out something.
Enquire about the health or well-being of.
Say to (someone) that one wants them to do or give something.
Say that one wants permission to do something.
Say that one wants to speak to.
Say that one wants (a specified amount) as a price for selling something.
Expect or demand (something) of someone.
Invite (someone) to one's home or a function.
Invite someone to join one on a group outing.
Invite someone out on a date.
A demand or situation that requires a specified degree of effort or commitment.
A request, especially for a donation.
The price at which an item, especially a financial security, is offered for sale.
--Examples--
‘I asked her what she meant’
‘people are always asking questions’
‘‘How much further?’ I asked’
‘the old man asked about her job’
‘there are fine meals to be had if you ask around’
‘if I see him I'll tell him you were asking after him’
‘Mary asked her father for money’
‘I asked him to call the manager’
‘don't be afraid to ask for advice’
‘she asked if she could move in’
‘he asked to see the officer involved’
‘you should have asked my permission first’
‘when I arrived I asked for Katrina’
‘he was asking £250 for the guitar’
‘it's asking a lot, but could you look through Billy's things?’
‘it's about time we asked Pam to dinner’
‘she asked him round for a drink’
‘do you want to ask him along?’
‘a few boys asked her out but never the right ones’
‘it is a big ask for him to go and play 90 minutes’
‘it was a tough ask, but they delivered’
‘it was an awkward ask for more funding’
‘ask prices for bonds’

--Word--
Babylon 
--Type--
proper noun, noun
--Meanings--
An ancient city in Mesopotamia, the capital of Babylonia in the 2nd millennium BC. The city (of which only ruins now remain) lay on the River Euphrates and was noted by classical writers for its luxury, its fortifications, and its legendary Hanging Gardens.
(chiefly among Rastafarians) a contemptuous or dismissive term for aspects of white culture seen as degenerate or oppressive, especially the police.
--Examples--
‘praise them for bringing a new rectitude to Babylon’

outboard 
--Type--
UnKnownKind, noun
--Meanings--
On, towards, or near the outside of a ship or aircraft.
(of a motor) portable and attachable to the outside of the stern of a boat.
(of an electronic accessory) in a separate container from the device with which it is used.
An outboard motor.
A boat with an outboard motor.
--Examples--
‘the outboard wing panels’
‘the chart table faces outboard’
‘the computer resides in a single cabinet plus some outboard boxes for disk drives’
--Word--
outborn 
--Type--
adjective, noun
--Meanings--
Born outside the country, foreign. Formerly also: (Scottish) †born in another estate or burgh (obsolete).
A person born outside the country; a foreigner.
--Examples--
--Word--
outbound 
--Type--
UnKnownKind
--Meanings--
Travelling away from a particular place, especially on the first leg of a return journey.
--Examples--
‘an outbound flight’
‘flying outbound’

noun

--Word--
out- 
--Type--
prefix
--Meanings--
To the point of surpassing or exceeding.
External; separate; from outside.
Away from; outward.
--Examples--
‘outfight’
‘outperform’
‘outbuildings’
‘outpatient’
‘outbound’
‘outpost’
--Word--
outbox 
--Type--
noun, verb
--Meanings--
A box or tray on a person's desk for letters and documents that have been dealt with.
A folder in which emails written by an individual are held before being sent.
Defeat (an opponent) by superior boxing ability.
--Examples--
‘I don't think he could stand back and try to outbox Leonard; he wasn't big enough to do that’

outbreaking

noun, adjective
--Meanings--

Breaking or bursting out, erupting; departing or lapsing from moral or religious rectitude.

--Word--
outbuy 
--Type--
verb
--Meanings--
To ransom (a prisoner), to buy out of slavery; to buy out of (a state of sin) through the purchase of indulgences; to get rid of by buying. Compare to buy out.
To outdo in buying, buy more than. Formerly also: †to pay more for (something) than it is worth (obsolete).
--Examples--

noun

--Word--
out-clearing 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
The action or practice of clearing something or clearing something out; specifically the system whereby a bank sends bills and cheques drawn on other banks to a clearing house, in order to have them cleared; bills and cheques collectively sent out to be cleared.

--Word--
college 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
An educational institution or establishment, in particular one providing higher education or specialized professional or vocational training.
Any of the independent institutions into which certain universities are separated, each having its own teaching staff, students, and buildings.
A private secondary school.
A university offering a limited curriculum or teaching only to a bachelor's degree.
The teaching staff and students of a college considered collectively.
An organized group of professional people with particular aims, duties, and privileges.
--Examples--
‘colleges of further education’
‘I'm at college, studying graphic design’
‘the Oxford colleges’
‘Trinity College, Cambridge’
‘Eton College’
‘Harvard College’
‘the college was shocked by his death’
‘the Royal College of Physicians’

noun
--Meanings--
In Ghana: a traditional ceremony in which a baby is brought outside for the first time (usually occurring eight days after the birth). Also: a formal installation ceremony, as of a person in office; the occasion on which a person in office is seen in public for the first time. Frequently attributive, especially in "outdooring ceremony".
--Examples--
--Word--
outdoors 
--Type--
adverb, noun
--Meanings--
In or into the open air; outside a building or shelter.
Any area outside buildings or shelter, typically that far away from human habitation.
--Examples--
‘it was warm enough to eat outdoors’
‘a lover of the great outdoors’
--Word--
outdoorsy 
--Type--
adjective
--Meanings--
Of, associated with, or fond of the outdoors.
--Examples--
‘Bill is such an outdoorsy kind of guy’
--Word--
outdoorsman 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A man who spends a lot of time outdoors or doing outdoor activities.
--Examples--

--Word--
outdrive 
--Type--
verb, noun
--Meanings--
Drive a golf ball further than (another player)
Drive a vehicle better or faster than (someone else)
(on a motorboat) an inboard motor connected to an outboard unit containing the gears, shaft, and propeller.
--Examples--
‘Buck outdrove him by forty yards’
‘he knew he couldn't outdrive the police’

--Word--
out 
--Type--
adverb, preposition, adjective, noun, verb
--Meanings--
Moving or appearing to move away from a particular place, especially one that is enclosed or hidden.
Situated or operating in the open air, away from buildings.
No longer detained in prison.
Situated far or at a particular distance from somewhere.
To sea, away from the land.
(of the tide) falling or at its lowest level.
Indicating a specified distance away from the goal line or finishing line.
Away from home.
In or to a public place for purposes of pleasure or entertainment.
So as to be revealed or known.
Aloud; so as to be heard.
At or to an end.
So as to be finished or complete.
In various other completive uses.
(of a light or fire) so as to be extinguished or no longer burning.
(of a stain or mark) no longer visible; removed.
No longer involved in a situation, competition, or activity.
(of a jury) considering its verdict in secrecy.
Non-standard contraction of out of.
Not at home or at one's place of work.
Revealed or made public.
(of a flower) in bloom; open.
Published.
In existence or use.
(of a young upper-class woman) introduced into society.
Open about one's homosexuality.
No longer alight; extinguished.
At an end.
No longer in fashion.
Not possible or worth considering.
In a state of unconsciousness.
Unable to rise from the floor.
Mistaken; in error.
(of the ball in tennis and similar games) outside the designated playing area.
No longer batting or at bat; having had one's innings or at bat ended by the fielding side.
A way of escaping from a problem or dilemma.
An act of putting a player out.
The political party not in office.
Knock (someone) out.
Reveal the homosexuality of (a prominent person).
Extinguish.
Expel, reject, or dismiss.
--Examples--
‘he walked out into the street’
‘watch the stars come out’
‘the search-and-rescue team have been out looking for you’
‘they would be out on bail in no time’
‘an old farmhouse right out in the middle of nowhere’
‘they lived eight miles out of town’
‘a cold front hundreds of miles out in the Atlantic’
‘the Persian fleet put out from Cyprus’
‘the tide was going out’
‘he scored from 70 metres out’
‘he's gone out’
‘an evening out at a restaurant’
‘find out what you can’
‘Miss Beard cried out in horror’
‘the romance fizzled out’
‘I'll leave them to fight it out’
‘I typed out the poem’
‘the crowd had thinned out’
‘he crossed out a word’
‘at ten o'clock the lights went out’
‘try to get the stain out’
‘Oxford United are out of the FA Cup’
‘he ran out the door’
‘if he called, she'd pretend to be out’
‘the secret was soon out’
‘the book should be out before the end of the month’
‘it works as well as any system that's out’
‘where is the use of having a lot of dresses when she isn't out yet?’
‘I had been out since I was 17’
‘the fire was nearly out’
‘school was out for the summer’
‘grunge is out’
‘a trip to the seaside is out for a start’
‘he was slightly out in his calculations’
‘England were all out for 159’
‘he was desperately looking for an out’
‘out the lamp when you're ready’
‘they had outed Asquith quite easily’
--Word--
outen 
--Type--
verb, adjective, preposition
--Meanings--
To extinguish, put out, erase.
To come out with, utter.
Coming from outside, foreign, alien. Now English regional (Lincolnshire).
Regional (Scottish, English regional (northern), and United States regional (chiefly southern)). Out of; out from.
--Examples--
--Word--
outer 
--Type--
adjective, noun
--Meanings--
Outside; external.
Further from the centre or inside.
(especially in place names) more remote.
Objective or physical; not subjective.
An outer garment or part of one.
(in archery and shooting) the division of a target furthest from the bullseye.
A shot that strikes the outer.
A container in which packaged objects are placed for transport or display.
The part of a racecourse outside the enclosure.
--Examples--
‘the outer layer of the skin’
‘the outer door’
‘the outer city bypass’
‘Outer Mongolia’
‘boots with stiff leather outers’

--Meanings--

--Meanings--

‘the outermost layer of the earth’
‘the orbit of the outermost of these eight planets’

outerness

noun

--Word--

--Type--

--Examples--
--Word--
outfangthief 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
The right of a lord of a private jurisdiction, more extensive than that of infangthief, to claim for trial a thief, especially one who is the lord's tenant, captured outside the jurisdiction, and to keep any forfeited chattels on conviction; occasionally used to denote the thief so apprehended. Also, more widely: the right of a lord to try any thief apprehended within that lord's jurisdiction, regardless of the accused person's place of origin.
--Examples--
--Word--
out-fast 
--Type--
verb
--Meanings--
To outdo in fasting, to fast longer than.
--Examples--
--Word--
outfeed 
--Type--
adjective
--Meanings--
Of, relating to, or involved in the feeding out of wood from a machine after cutting (or occasionally other treatment); of or relating to that part of a table-saw or other machine worktop that is behind the blade or cutter.
--Examples--

--Type--
noun
--Meanings--

--Word--
outfit 
--Type--
noun, verb
--Meanings--
A set of clothes worn together, especially for a particular occasion or purpose.
A complete set of equipment needed for a particular purpose.
A group of people undertaking a particular activity together, especially a group of musicians, a team, or a business concern.
Provide with a set of clothes.
Provide with equipment.
--Examples--
‘her wedding outfit’
‘a first-aid outfit’
‘an obscure 1970s country rock outfit’
‘warders outfitted in special suits’
‘planes outfitted with sophisticated electronic gear’

outfrown

verb
--Meanings--

outgang 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
The way or passage out; an outlet, an exit; specifically a track or route used by cattle going out to pasture.
--Examples--
--Word--
outgas 
--Type--
verb
--Meanings--
Release or give off (a substance) as a gas or vapour.
--Examples--
‘glue may outgas smelly volatile organic compounds’
‘the outgassed products of volcanoes’
‘samples are heated and begin to outgas’

noun

outgeneral

verb

--Word--
outgiving 
--Type--
noun, adjective
--Meanings--
The action or fact of giving something out. Also: the thing given out; specifically (a) (in plural) payments, disbursements; (b) an utterance.
Open-hearted, generous.

--Word--
outgo 
--Type--
noun, verb
--Meanings--
The outlay of money.
Go faster than.
--Examples--
‘the secret of success lies in the relation of income to outgo’
‘he on horseback outgoes him on foot’
--Word--
outgoer 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A person who or animal that goes out; specifically a person who goes out of a place, office, occupation, or tenancy; (Cricket) a dismissed batsman (now rare).
--Examples--
--Word--
outgo 
--Type--

--Meanings--

--Word--
outgoing 
--Type--
adjective, noun
--Meanings--
Friendly and socially confident.
Leaving an office or position.
Going out or away from a particular place.
A person's regular expenditure.
An instance of going out.
--Examples--
‘she's always been very outgoing and she's got heaps of friends’
‘the outgoing Prime Minister’
‘incoming and outgoing calls’
‘if your outgoings regularly exceed your incomings, you have a problem’
‘the inward deliveries and outgoings of raw materials’
--Word--

--Word--
outgrow 
--Type--
verb
--Meanings--
Grow too big for.
Stop doing or having an interest in (something) as one matures.
Grow faster or taller than.
--Examples--
‘the cradle which Patrick had outgrown’
‘by this time, I had outgrown my adolescent appetite for being shocked’
‘the more vigorous plants outgrow their weaker neighbours’
--Word--
outgross 
--Type--
verb
--Meanings--
Surpass in gross takings or profit.
--Examples--
‘the film has outgrossed all other movie comedies’
--Word--
out-ground 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
Outlying ground.
--Examples--
--Word--
out-group 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
Those people who do not belong to a specific in-group.
A group of organisms not belonging to the group whose evolutionary relationships are being investigated. Such a group is used for comparison, to assess which characteristics of the group being studied are more widely distributed and may therefore be older in origin.
--Examples--
--Word--

noun

--Word--
outgrowth 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
Something that grows out of something else.
The process of growing out.
A natural development or result of something.
--Examples--
‘the eye first appears as an outgrowth from the brain’
‘with further outgrowth the radius and ulna develop’
‘the book is an imaginative outgrowth of practical criticism’
--Word--

out-guard 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A guard placed at a distance from the main body of an army; an advance guard, an outpost; the action of serving as such a guard.

--Type--
verb
--Meanings--
Have better or more weaponry than.
Shoot better than.

--Examples--

‘the correspondents proudly outgunned the army sharpshooters’
‘the team were outgunned by the joint title favourites’

outhauler 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--

outher 
--Type--
pronoun, adjective, adverb
--Meanings--
Each (of two): = "either".
One or other (of two); either.
Following an alternative clause introduced by or.
--Examples--
--Word--
out-Herod 
--Type--
verb
--Meanings--
Originally (in "to out-Herod Herod"): to outdo (Herod) in cruelty, evil, extravagance, etc. Later (in weakened use): to be more extreme or outrageous than (sometimes without the implication of viciousness). Chiefly with allusion to Shakespeare's use.
--Examples--
--Word--

verb
--Meanings--

--Examples--
‘we outscored them for the Series, 55–27, and outhit them, 91–60’

--Word--
outing 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A trip taken for pleasure, especially one lasting a day or less.
A brief journey from home.
An appearance in something, especially a sporting event or film.
The practice of revealing the homosexuality of a prominent person.
--Examples--
‘a family outing to Weston-super-Mare’
‘her daily outing to the shops’
‘Madonna's first screen outing in three years’
‘the outing of gays by the press’
--Word--
outing 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A trip taken for pleasure, especially one lasting a day or less.
A brief journey from home.
An appearance in something, especially a sporting event or film.
The practice of revealing the homosexuality of a prominent person.
--Examples--
‘a family outing to Weston-super-Mare’
‘her daily outing to the shops’
‘Madonna's first screen outing in three years’
‘the outing of gays by the press’

weak-kneed 
--Type--
adjective
--Meanings--
Weak and shaky as a result of fear or excitement.
Lacking in resolve or courage; cowardly.
--Examples--
‘she still felt weak-kneed whenever he came towards her’
‘no one could say that our news programmes have been weak-kneed in their coverage’
‘the other two, a couple of weak-kneed cowards, had run off’

--Word--
outlash 
--Type--
noun, verb
--Meanings--
The action of lashing out; an instance of this.
To lash out; to strike out violently. In earliest use figurative: to break out into excess; to be extravagant, exaggerate. Compare "overlash". Now rare.
--Examples--

--Word--
outlaw 
--Type--
noun, verb
--Meanings--
A person who has broken the law, especially one who remains at large or is a fugitive.
A person deprived of the benefit and protection of the law.
Ban or make illegal.
Deprive (someone) of the benefit and protection of the law.
--Examples--
‘bands of outlaws held up trains’
‘the outlaw Ned Kelly’
‘secondary picketing has been outlawed’
‘he lost the estate in 1626, having been outlawed for non-payment of debts’
--Word--
outlawed 
--Type--
adjective
--Meanings--
Made illegal; banned.
--Examples--
‘an outlawed extremist group’
‘an international treaty forbidding private production of outlawed drugs’
--Word--

‘the outlaw Ned Kelly’
‘secondary picketing has been outlawed’
‘he lost the estate in 1626, having been outlawed for non-payment of debts’

outlet 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A pipe or hole through which water or gas may escape.
The mouth of a river.
An output socket in an electrical device.
A point from which goods are sold or distributed.
A market for goods.
A shop that sells goods made by a particular manufacturer at discounted prices.
A means of expressing one's talents, energy, or emotions.
--Examples--
‘a fast-food outlet’
‘the state system provided an outlet for farm produce’
‘a designer outlet’
‘an outlet store’
‘writing became the main outlet for his energies’

--Word--
outlier 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A person or thing situated away or detached from the main body or system.
A person or thing differing from all other members of a particular group or set.
A younger rock formation isolated among older rocks.
A data point on a graph or in a set of results that is very much bigger or smaller than the next nearest data point.
--Examples--
‘a western outlier in the Andaman archipelago’
‘an outlier in Faulkner's body of work’
‘then there are the corporate outliers, people who just don't fit into the culture of the company’
‘the Jurassic outlier west of Carlisle’

outline 
--Type--
noun, verb
--Meanings--
A line or set of lines enclosing or indicating the shape of an object in a sketch or diagram.
The contours or bounds of an object.
A representation of a word in shorthand.
A general description or plan showing the essential features of something but not the detail.
Draw, trace, or define the outer edge or shape of.
Give a summary of.
--Examples--
‘the chalked outline of a human body’
‘the outlines of dockside warehouses standing sharp on the skyline’
‘an outline of parliamentary procedure’
‘an outline proposal’
‘her eyes were darkly outlined with kohl’
‘she outlined the case briefly’

Machiavelli, Niccolò 
--Type--
proper noun
--Meanings--
(1469–1527), Italian statesman and political philosopher; full name Niccolò di Bernardo dei Machiavelli. His best-known work is The Prince (1532), which advises rulers that the acquisition and effective use of power may necessitate unethical methods.
A person perceived as prepared to use unethical means to gain an advantage.

Nero 
--Type--
proper noun
--Meanings--
(AD 37–68), Roman emperor 54–68; full name Nero Claudius Caesar Augustus Germanicus. Infamous for his cruelty, he wantonly executed leading Romans. His reign witnessed a fire which destroyed half of Rome in 64.

--Word--
out of 
--Type--
phrase
--Meanings--
Indicating the source or derivation of something; from.
Having (the thing mentioned) as a motivation.
Indicating the dam of a pedigree animal, especially a horse.
From among (a number)
Not having (a particular thing)
--Examples--
‘a bench fashioned out of a fallen tree trunk’
‘I get a lot of enjoyment out of teaching’
‘he was acting out of spite’
‘nine times out of ten, companies are the source of such information’
‘they had run out of cash’
‘you're out of luck, mate, there's none left’
--Word--
out of bounds 
--Type--
phrase
--Meanings--
Outside the part of a sports field or court in which play is conducted.
Outside the limits of where one is permitted to be.
Beyond what is acceptable.
--Examples--
‘he hit his third shot out of bounds at the 17th’
‘his kitchen was out of bounds to me at mealtimes’
‘Paul felt that this conversation was getting out of bounds’

phrase

--Examples--
‘we're too out of the way for mains electricity’
‘an out-of-the-way rural district’
‘economic recovery will begin once the election is out of the way’
‘why did Josie want her out of the way?’
‘he'd seen nothing out of the way’
‘something very out of the way had happened’

--Examples--
--Word--
in (or out of) tune 
--Type--
phrase
--Meanings--
With correct (or incorrect) pitch or intonation.
(of a motor engine or other machine) properly (or poorly) adjusted.
In (or not in) agreement or harmony.
--Examples--
‘they couldn't sing a note in tune’
‘he was out of tune with conventional belief’
--Word--
out of 
--Type--
phrase
--Meanings--
Indicating the source or derivation of something; from.
Having (the thing mentioned) as a motivation.
Indicating the dam of a pedigree animal, especially a horse.
From among (a number)
Not having (a particular thing)
--Examples--
‘a bench fashioned out of a fallen tree trunk’
‘I get a lot of enjoyment out of teaching’
‘he was acting out of spite’
‘nine times out of ten, companies are the source of such information’
‘they had run out of cash’
‘you're out of luck, mate, there's none left’
--Word--
out of turn 
--Type--
phrase
--Meanings--
At a time when it is not one's turn.
--Examples--
‘he played out of turn’
--Word--
vogue 
--Type--
noun, adjective, verb
--Meanings--
The prevailing fashion or style at a particular time.
General acceptance or favour; popularity.
Popular; fashionable.
Dance to music in such a way as to imitate the characteristic poses struck by a model on a catwalk.
--Examples--
‘the vogue is to make realistic films’
‘crochet garments are in vogue this season’
‘‘citizenship’ was to be the government's vogue word’
--Word--
outpace 
--Type--
verb
--Meanings--
Go, rise, or improve faster than.
--Examples--
‘he outpaced all six defenders’
‘import growth outpaced export growth in the second quarter’

out-parish 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--

--Word--
outpart 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
An outer, outlying, or exterior part or place. In later use chiefly in plural: the parts of a town lying outside its walls or municipal boundaries; the outskirts.
--Examples--

--Word--
outplace 
--Type--
verb
--Meanings--
To displace, oust.
Originally US. To assist (a redundant employee) in finding new employment, especially through an outplacement service. Hence (euphemism): to discharge through redundancy.

--Type--
adjective
--Meanings--

--Word--
outport 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A subsidiary port built near an existing one.
Any British port other than London.
(especially in Newfoundland) a small remote fishing village.
--Examples--
‘larger ships and cargoes made it necessary to create a new port, or outport, at Avonmouth’
--Word--
outporter 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A native or inhabitant of an outport.

--Word--
outpost 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A small military camp or position at some distance from the main army, used especially as a guard against surprise attack.
A remote part of a country or empire.
An isolated or remote branch of something.
--Examples--
‘troops in some outposts have surrendered’
‘a few scattered outposts along the west coast’
‘the community is the last outpost of civilization in the far north’

--Word--
output 
--Type--
noun, verb
--Meanings--
The amount of something produced by a person, machine, or industry.
The action or process of producing something.
The power, energy, or other results supplied by a device or system.
A place where power or information leaves a system.
(of a computer or other device) produce, deliver, or supply (data)
--Examples--
‘output from the mine ceased in May’
‘efficiency can lead to higher outputs’
‘the output of certain hormones under stress’
‘high voltage output: 50–250 amps’
‘you can output the image directly to a video recording system’
--Word--

--Word--
Don Quixote 
--Type--
proper noun
--Meanings--
The hero of a romance (1605–15) by Cervantes, a satirical account of chivalric beliefs and conduct. The character of Don Quixote is typified by a romantic vision and naive, unworldly idealism.
--Examples--

--Word--
outrage 
--Type--
noun, verb
--Meanings--
An extremely strong reaction of anger, shock, or indignation.
An action or event causing outrage.
Arouse fierce anger, shock, or indignation in (someone)
Flagrantly violate or infringe (a principle, law, etc.)
--Examples--
‘her voice trembled with outrage’
‘the massacre was one of the worst outrages in the whole of our history’
‘the decision was an outrage’
‘the public were outraged at the brutality involved’
‘their behaviour outraged all civilized standards’
--Word--
outrage 
--Type--
noun, verb
--Meanings--
An extremely strong reaction of anger, shock, or indignation.
An action or event causing outrage.
Arouse fierce anger, shock, or indignation in (someone)
Flagrantly violate or infringe (a principle, law, etc.)

‘the decision was an outrage’

‘their behaviour outraged all civilized standards’
--Word--
outrager 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A person who subjects another to outrage or gross violence; a violator; an affronter or offender of other people, their feelings, laws, morals, etc.
--Examples--
--Word--
outrageous 
--Type--
adjective
--Meanings--
Shockingly bad or excessive.
Wildly exaggerated or improbable.
Very bold and unusual and rather shocking.
--Examples--
‘an outrageous act of bribery’
‘the outrageous claims made by the previous government’
‘her outrageous leotards and sexy routines’
--Word--
outrageously 
--Type--
adverb
--Meanings--
In a shockingly bad or excessive way.
In a very bold and slightly shocking way.
--Examples--
‘I think Caroline has behaved outrageously’
‘the food was outrageously priced’
‘outrageously rich people’
‘he flirted outrageously with his girlfriend's mother’
‘the Carnival queens are outrageously dressed’
--Word--
outrageousness 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
--Examples--

--Word--
outreach 
--Type--
noun, verb
--Meanings--
The extent or length of reaching out.
An organization's involvement with or influence in the community, especially in the context of religion or social welfare.
Reach further than.
Stretch out one's arms.
--Examples--
‘the loving outreach of God to the world’
‘the growth of evangelistic outreach’
‘outreach centres’
‘their pack outreached and outwitted the Welsh team’
‘they stood with earnest eyes, and arms outreaching’

--Type--
proper noun
--Meanings--
A name applied to the medieval French crusader states, including Armenia, Antioch, Tripoli, and Jerusalem.
--Examples--
--Word--
outréness 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
The quality of being outré; singularity; eccentricity, peculiarity.

--Word--
outrider 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A person in a motor vehicle or on horseback who goes in front of or beside a vehicle as an escort or guard.
A mounted official who escorts racehorses to the starting post.
A mounted herdsman who prevents cattle from straying beyond a certain limit.
--Examples--

--Word--
outrigger 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A beam, spar, or framework projecting from or over a boat's side.
A float or secondary hull fixed parallel to a canoe or small boat to stabilize it.
A boat fitted with an outrigger.
A projecting support similar to an outrigger in another structure or vehicle.
--Examples--
--Word--
outriggered 
--Type--
adjective
--Meanings--
Fitted with an outrigger; outrigged.
--Examples--
--Word--
outriggerless 
--Type--
adjective
--Meanings--
Having no outrigger.

outright 
--Type--
adverb, adjective
--Meanings--
Wholly and completely.
Directly or openly.
Immediately or instantly.
Not by degrees or instalments.
Open and direct.
Total.
Clear and undisputed.
--Examples--
‘logging has been banned outright’
‘she couldn't ask him outright’
‘the impact killed four horses outright’
‘they decided to buy the company outright’
‘an outright refusal’
‘the outright abolition of the death penalty’
‘an outright victory’

--Word--
outrun 
--Type--
verb
--Meanings--
Run or travel faster or further than.
Escape from.
Go beyond or exceed.
--Examples--
‘their one chance was to outrun their pursuers’
‘it's harder than anyone imagines to outrun destiny’
‘his courage outran his prudence’
--Word--
outrunner 
--Type--
noun, noun
--Meanings--
A person who or animal which runs along the outside or outer side of something, as an attendant who runs ahead of or beside a carriage, a dog leading a team of sledge dogs, etc. Also figurative: one who goes about gathering or spreading intelligence; a forerunner, an advance party (now chiefly historical).
A projection or outshoot of a forest, mountain range, or some other physical feature.
A person who or thing which outruns something.
--Examples--
--Word--
outrun 
--Type--
verb
--Meanings--

Go beyond or exceed.
--Examples--
‘their one chance was to outrun their pursuers’
‘it's harder than anyone imagines to outrun destiny’
‘his courage outran his prudence’

--Word--
outrush 
--Type--
noun, verb
--Meanings--
A rushing out of something; a violent outflow.
Carry the ball further forward than (another player or team); surpass in rushing.
--Examples--
‘he saw an outrush of water as the tide went out’
‘Williams might outrush Okoeye’
--Word--
outrush 
--Type--
noun, verb
--Meanings--
A rushing out of something; a violent outflow.
Carry the ball further forward than (another player or team); surpass in rushing.
--Examples--
‘he saw an outrush of water as the tide went out’
‘Williams might outrush Okoeye’
--Word--
out 
--Type--
adverb, preposition, adjective, noun, verb
--Meanings--
Moving or appearing to move away from a particular place, especially one that is enclosed or hidden.
Situated or operating in the open air, away from buildings.
No longer detained in prison.
Situated far or at a particular distance from somewhere.
To sea, away from the land.
(of the tide) falling or at its lowest level.
Indicating a specified distance away from the goal line or finishing line.
Away from home.
In or to a public place for purposes of pleasure or entertainment.
So as to be revealed or known.
Aloud; so as to be heard.
At or to an end.
So as to be finished or complete.
In various other completive uses.
(of a light or fire) so as to be extinguished or no longer burning.
(of a stain or mark) no longer visible; removed.
No longer involved in a situation, competition, or activity.
(of a jury) considering its verdict in secrecy.
Non-standard contraction of out of.
Not at home or at one's place of work.
Revealed or made public.
(of a flower) in bloom; open.
Published.
In existence or use.
(of a young upper-class woman) introduced into society.
Open about one's homosexuality.
No longer alight; extinguished.
At an end.
No longer in fashion.
Not possible or worth considering.
In a state of unconsciousness.
Unable to rise from the floor.
Mistaken; in error.
(of the ball in tennis and similar games) outside the designated playing area.
No longer batting or at bat; having had one's innings or at bat ended by the fielding side.
A way of escaping from a problem or dilemma.
An act of putting a player out.
The political party not in office.
Knock (someone) out.
Reveal the homosexuality of (a prominent person).
Extinguish.
Expel, reject, or dismiss.
--Examples--
‘he walked out into the street’
‘watch the stars come out’
‘the search-and-rescue team have been out looking for you’
‘they would be out on bail in no time’
‘an old farmhouse right out in the middle of nowhere’
‘they lived eight miles out of town’
‘a cold front hundreds of miles out in the Atlantic’
‘the Persian fleet put out from Cyprus’
‘the tide was going out’
‘he scored from 70 metres out’
‘he's gone out’
‘an evening out at a restaurant’
‘find out what you can’
‘Miss Beard cried out in horror’
‘the romance fizzled out’
‘I'll leave them to fight it out’
‘I typed out the poem’
‘the crowd had thinned out’
‘he crossed out a word’
‘at ten o'clock the lights went out’
‘try to get the stain out’
‘Oxford United are out of the FA Cup’
‘he ran out the door’
‘if he called, she'd pretend to be out’
‘the secret was soon out’
‘the book should be out before the end of the month’
‘it works as well as any system that's out’
‘where is the use of having a lot of dresses when she isn't out yet?’
‘I had been out since I was 17’
‘the fire was nearly out’
‘school was out for the summer’
‘grunge is out’
‘a trip to the seaside is out for a start’
‘he was slightly out in his calculations’
‘England were all out for 159’
‘he was desperately looking for an out’
‘out the lamp when you're ready’
‘they had outed Asquith quite easily’

--Word--
outside 
--Type--
noun, adjective
UnKnownKind
--Meanings--
The external side or surface of something.
The part of a path nearer to a road or further from a wall.
The side of a bend or curve where the edge or surface is longer in extent.
The outer sheets of a ream of paper.
The external appearance of someone or something.
Situated on or near the exterior or external surface of something.
(in hockey, soccer, and other sports) denoting positions nearer to the sides of the field.
Not belonging to or coming from within a particular group.
Beyond one's own immediate personal concerns.
Situated or moving beyond the confines or boundaries of.
Not being a member of (a particular group)
(in soccer, rugby, and other sports) closer to the side of the field than (another player)
Beyond the limits or scope of.
--Examples--
‘record the date on the outside of the file’
‘was he as straight as he appeared on the outside?’
‘Anne put the outside lights on’
‘he played at outside left’
‘the use of outside contractors will speed up the process’
‘I was able to face the outside world again’
‘there was a boy outside the door’
‘I stepped outside the marquee for a breather’
‘the dog was still barking outside’
‘we ran outside’
‘critics outside the government’
‘Swift appeared outside him with the powerful Fallon overlapping on his left’
‘the switchboard is not staffed outside normal office hours’

--Word--
outsider 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A person who does not belong to a particular organization or profession.
A person who is not accepted by or who isolates themselves from society.
A competitor, applicant, etc. thought to have little chance of success.
--Examples--
‘to the outsider, glitzy fashion shows may seem an outrageous extravagance’
‘she felt that his friends despised her as an outsider’
‘the winner was Beech Road, a fifty-to-one outsider’
‘he started as a rank outsider’
--Word--
outsiderness 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
The condition or state of being an outsider.

outside 
--Type--
noun, adjective
UnKnownKind
--Meanings--
The external side or surface of something.
The part of a path nearer to a road or further from a wall.
The side of a bend or curve where the edge or surface is longer in extent.
The outer sheets of a ream of paper.
The external appearance of someone or something.
Situated on or near the exterior or external surface of something.
(in hockey, soccer, and other sports) denoting positions nearer to the sides of the field.
Not belonging to or coming from within a particular group.
Beyond one's own immediate personal concerns.
Situated or moving beyond the confines or boundaries of.
Not being a member of (a particular group)
(in soccer, rugby, and other sports) closer to the side of the field than (another player)
Beyond the limits or scope of.
--Examples--
‘record the date on the outside of the file’
‘was he as straight as he appeared on the outside?’
‘Anne put the outside lights on’
‘he played at outside left’
‘the use of outside contractors will speed up the process’
‘I was able to face the outside world again’
‘there was a boy outside the door’
‘I stepped outside the marquee for a breather’
‘the dog was still barking outside’
‘we ran outside’
‘critics outside the government’
‘Swift appeared outside him with the powerful Fallon overlapping on his left’
‘the switchboard is not staffed outside normal office hours’

verb

To sleep longer than.

soul 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
The spiritual or immaterial part of a human being or animal, regarded as immortal.
A person's moral or emotional nature or sense of identity.
Emotional or intellectual energy or intensity, especially as revealed in a work of art or an artistic performance.
Black American culture or ethnic pride.
The essence or embodiment of a specified quality.
An individual person.
A person regarded with affection or pity.
--Examples--
‘in the depths of her soul, she knew he would betray her’
‘their interpretation lacked soul’
‘he was the soul of discretion’
‘brevity is the soul of wit’
‘I'll never tell a soul’
‘it was bad news for some poor soul’
‘she's a nice old soul’

‘they outspanned at the hotel’
‘we used to outspan for five or six hours in the heat of the day’

--Word--
outstand 
--Type--
verb
--Meanings--
To stand or endure longer than; to stay to or beyond the end of.
To continue in existence or remain undetermined; especially (of a sum of money, debt, etc.) to be unsettled or unpaid. Chiefly. as pres. pple. Compare earlier "outstanding".
To stand out prominently, to project. Also in extended use: to be conspicuous, noteworthy, or superior.
--Examples--
--Word--
outstander 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A person who or thing which outstands; a dissenter; (Scottish History) an opponent of the National Covenant or its adherents.
--Examples--
--Word--

‘the team's outstanding performance’
‘works of outstanding banality’
‘much of the work is still outstanding’
‘Julian's outstanding debts’

--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A branch of an organization situated at some distance from its headquarters.

To outdo in swearing; to swear more or more coarsely than; to overcome or get the better of by swearing.
--Examples--

--Word--
out-throw 
--Type--
noun, verb
--Meanings--
That which is thrown out; an ejection or emission; output or production.
An act or the action of throwing something out; an instance of this.
Chiefly poetic. To throw or thrust out or outwards; to cast out or expel. Now usually in pass.
To surpass in throwing; to throw further than.
--Examples--
--Word--

noun, verb

--Word--
out- 
--Type--
prefix
--Meanings--
To the point of surpassing or exceeding.
External; separate; from outside.
Away from; outward.
--Examples--
‘outfight’
‘outperform’
‘outbuildings’
‘outpatient’
‘outbound’
‘outpost’

--Word--
Tory 
--Type--
noun, adjective
--Meanings--
(in the UK) a member or supporter of the Conservative Party.
A member of the English political party opposing the exclusion of James II from the succession. It remained the name for members of the English, later British, parliamentary party supporting the established religious and political order until the emergence of the Conservative Party in the 1830s.
A colonist who supported the British side during the War of American Independence.
Relating to the British Conservative Party or its supporters.
--Examples--
‘a poll showed the Tories thirteen points behind Labour’
‘the Tory party’
‘Tory voters’

--Word--
outward 
--Type--
adjective, adverb
--Meanings--
Of, on, or from the outside.
Relating to the external appearance of something rather than its true nature.
Outer.
Going out or away from a place.
Outwards.
--Examples--
‘outward pressure’
‘an outward display of friendliness’
‘the outward physical body’
‘the outward voyage’
--Word--
outward bound 
--Type--
adjective, noun
--Meanings--
(of a ship or passenger) going away from home.
An organization that provides naval and adventure training and other outdoor activities for young people.
--Examples--
‘they were outward bound for the Great Barrier Reef’
‘an outward-bound crude oil carrier’
--Word--
outward-bounder 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
An outward-bound vessel. Now historical.
Frequently in form Outward Bounder. A person attending an Outward Bound school, course, etc., or advocating the methods of such schools; (in extended use) a person enjoying or practised in outdoor pursuits.
--Examples--

outwork 
--Type--
noun, verb
--Meanings--
A section of a fortification or system of defence which is in front of the main part.
Work done outside the factory or office that provides it.
Work harder, faster, or longer than (someone else)
--Examples--
‘he was tireless in the field, able to outwork almost everyone around him’

oval 
--Type--
adjective, noun
--Meanings--
Having a rounded and slightly elongated outline or shape like that of an egg.

A ground for Australian Rules football.
--Examples--
‘her smooth oval face’
‘cut out two small ovals from the felt’

--Type--
adjective, adjective
--Meanings--
Feeling weary and impatient because one is unoccupied or lacks interest in one's current activity.
(of a gun) having a specified bore.
--Examples--
‘she got bored with staring out of the window’
‘they hung around all day, bored stiff’
‘bored teenagers’
‘John was soon bored to tears with the work’
‘she's bored out of her mind’
‘large-bored guns’

oval 
--Type--
adjective, noun
--Meanings--
Having a rounded and slightly elongated outline or shape like that of an egg.
A body, object, or design with an oval shape or outline.
An oval sports field or racing track.
A ground for Australian Rules football.
--Examples--
‘her smooth oval face’
‘cut out two small ovals from the felt’

ovalize 
--Type--
verb
--Meanings--
To make oval in shape; specifically to make the metal tubes of the frame of a bicycle oval in cross-section for extra rigidity. Also without object: to become oval in shape.

--Word--
truncate 
--Type--
verb, adjective
--Meanings--
Shorten (something) by cutting off the top or the end.
Replace (an edge or an angle) by a plane, typically so as to make equal angles with the adjacent faces.
(of a leaf, feather, or other part) ending abruptly as if cut off across the base or tip.
--Examples--
‘a truncated cone shape’
‘discussion was truncated by the arrival of tea’

--Word--
over 
--Type--
preposition, adverb, noun
--Meanings--
Extending directly upwards from.
Above so as to cover or protect.
Extending above (an area) from a vantage point.
At a higher level or layer than.
Higher in rank than.
Expressing authority or control.
Expressing preference.
Expressing majority.
Higher in volume or pitch than.
Higher or more than (a specified number or quantity)
Expressing passage or trajectory across.
Beyond and falling or hanging from.
At the other side of; beyond.
Expressing duration.
Expressing the medium by which something is done; by means of.
On the subject of.
Expressing passage or trajectory across an area.
In or to the place indicated.
Beyond and falling or hanging from a point.
Used to express action and result.
Finished.
Used to express repetition of a process.
A sequence of six balls bowled by a bowler from one end of the pitch, after which another bowler takes over from the other end.
--Examples--
‘I saw flames over Berlin’
‘cook the sauce over a moderate heat’
‘an oxygen tent over the bed’
‘ladle this sauce over fresh pasta’
‘views over Hyde Park’
‘his flat was over the shop’
‘over him is the financial director’
‘editorial control over what is included’
‘I'd choose the well-known brand over that one’
‘there was a slight predominance of boys over girls’
‘he shouted over the noise of the taxis’
‘over 40 degrees C’
‘they've been married for over a year’
‘she trudged over the lawn’
‘he toppled over the side of the boat’
‘over the hill is a small village’
‘you've given us a lot of heartache over the years’
‘she told me over coffee’
‘a voice came over the loudspeaker’
‘a long and heated debate over unemployment’
‘he leant over and tapped me on the hand’
‘I'm over here’
‘she knocked the jug over’
‘the car flipped over’
‘hand the money over’
‘the match is over’
‘message understood, over and out’
‘the jukebox plays every song twice over’

--Word--
overall 
--Type--
adjective, adverb, noun
--Meanings--
Taking everything into account.
Taken as a whole; in all.
A loose-fitting coat or one-piece garment worn over ordinary clothes for protection against dirt or heavy wear.
Close-fitting trousers formerly worn as part of an army uniform, now only on ceremonial or formal occasions.
Dungarees.
--Examples--
‘the governors and head have overall responsibility for managing the school’
‘the overall effect is impressive’
‘overall, 10,000 jobs will go’
‘men in grubby blue overalls’
‘a pair of overalls’

--Type--
adjective
--Meanings--
--Examples--
--Word--
overall 
--Type--
adjective, adverb, noun
--Meanings--
Taking everything into account.
Taken as a whole; in all.
A loose-fitting coat or one-piece garment worn over ordinary clothes for protection against dirt or heavy wear.
Close-fitting trousers formerly worn as part of an army uniform, now only on ceremonial or formal occasions.
Dungarees.
--Examples--
‘the governors and head have overall responsibility for managing the school’
‘the overall effect is impressive’
‘overall, 10,000 jobs will go’
‘men in grubby blue overalls’
‘a pair of overalls’

overalled 
--Type--
adjective
--Meanings--
--Examples--

overambitious 
--Type--
adjective
--Meanings--
Excessively ambitious.
--Examples--

‘an overambitious expansion programme’

--Word--
overbake 
--Type--
verb
--Meanings--
Bake too much or for too long.
Do (something) to excess; exaggerate.
--Examples--
‘take care not to overbake them; their centres should remain soft and chewy’
‘are we in the national news media overbaking this thing just a bit?’
--Word--
overbaked 
--Type--
adjective
--Meanings--
(of food) baked too much or for too long.
Done to excess; exaggerated.
--Examples--
‘an overbaked cake’
‘a laughably overbaked conclusion’
‘overbaked gothic melodramatics’

--Word--
overbalance 
--Type--
verb, noun
--Meanings--
Fall or cause to fall over from loss of balance.
Outweigh.
An excess of weight, value, or amount.
--Examples--
‘he overbalanced and fell against the wall’
‘their combined weight had overbalanced them’
‘the days of unhappiness were far overbalanced by days of wild expressions of love’
‘an overbalance of propriety’

--Word--
overballast 
--Type--
verb
--Meanings--
To overload (a ship) with ballast; to provide (a vehicle, etc.) with excessive weight of ballast.
--Examples--
--Word--
overbank 
--Type--
noun, adjective, verb, verb
--Meanings--
The action or an act of overbanking.
That is over or above the bank (of a river, etc.); that overflows or has overflowed the edge of a river bank.
Gunnery. Designating or relating to a kind of gun carriage for muzzle-loading guns which enables the gun to be fired over a parapet. Now historical and rare.
To bank (an aircraft) too much when making a turn; to bank too much in the performance of (a turn).
Of an aircraft or its pilot: to bank too much.
To found or provide too many banks or banking facilities in (a place).
--Examples--
--Word--
overbanked 
--Type--
adjective
--Meanings--
Of a place: provided with an excessive number of banks or banking facilities.
--Examples--
--Word--
over-bark 
--Type--
adjective
--Meanings--
Of a measurement of the volume or diameter of timber: taken before the bark has been removed; including the bark. Abbreviated o.b.
--Examples--
--Word--
overbear 
--Type--
verb
--Meanings--
Overcome by emotional pressure or physical force.
--Examples--
‘his will had not been overborne by another's influence’

--Word--
over-belief 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
(A) Belief which goes beyond the evidence; a level of belief and faith beyond what is usually required of members of a certain religion or sect. (b) A belief which determines other beliefs; an overriding belief or guiding principle, frequently arising out of a person's own emotional and spiritual experiences. (c) A belief or superstition surviving from the past.
--Examples--
--Word--
overbend 
--Type--
noun, verb
--Meanings--
The curved stretch of pipe above the point of inflection in an S-shaped length of pipeline being lowered on to the seabed from a barge. Compare "sagbend".
To bend (something) too much.
Equestrianism. Of a horse: to hold its head in an unnaturally low position. Also with object (of a rider): to cause (a horse) to do this.
--Examples--
--Word--
overberg 
--Type--
noun, adjective
--Meanings--
Any region situated beyond mountains, especially (with capital initial) such a region in the Western Cape or in KwaZulu-Natal.
That is situated or comes from beyond a mountain or mountains; from the Overberg.
--Examples--
--Word--
overby 
--Type--
adverb
--Meanings--
Over or across the way; at or to a place a short distance away; at or to the house or place opposite.
--Examples--
--Word--
overbias 
--Type--
verb
--Meanings--
To bias excessively; to influence too much in one direction.
Electronics. To supply with a bias current at a level greater than that which would result in peak output voltage.
--Examples--
--Word--
overbid 
--Type--
verb, noun
--Meanings--
(in an auction) make a higher bid than a previous bid.
(in competitive tendering, the auction at bridge, etc.) bid more than is warranted or manageable.
A bid that is higher than another or higher than is justified.
--Examples--
‘I'd once seen him blithely overbid for a tiny James I miniature portrait’

overbill

verb
--Meanings--
To publicize excessively or extravagantly. rare.
