--Meanings--
(refl.) and without object. Of a plant or tree: to bloom or flower excessively, especially so as to undermine its strength.
--Examples--
--Word--
overblouse 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A blouse designed to be worn without being tucked into a skirt or trousers.
--Examples--
--Word--
overblow 
--Type--
noun, verb
--Meanings--
An instance of overblowing something; Metallurgy) a period or instance of overblowing a charge in a blast furnace.
Of the wind, etc.: to blow over the surface of. Of snow, sand, etc.: to cover (an animal, area, etc.) by blowing or being blown over.
To blow (an instrument) too hard or too loudly; to supply wind at too great a pressure to (an organ pipe).
To manipulate the behaviour of the column of air in (a wind instrument, or an organ pipe) in such a way as to produce a harmonic or overtone instead of the fundamental note. Also (of the instrument or pipe): to produce (a harmonic or overtone) by this means. Also without object or (occasionally) refl.
Metallurgy. To subject (a charge in a blast furnace) to an excessive length of blast. Also without object. Compare "overblown".
To exaggerate, overplay.
--Examples--
--Word--
overblowing 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A technique for playing high notes on a wind instrument by producing harmonics.
--Examples--
--Word--
overblown 
--Type--
adjective
--Meanings--
Made to seem more impressive or important than is the case; exaggerated or pretentious.
(of a flower) past its prime.
--Examples--
‘his most rhetorically overblown screenplay’
‘an overblown rose’
--Word--
overblow 
--Type--
noun, verb
--Meanings--
An instance of overblowing something; Metallurgy) a period or instance of overblowing a charge in a blast furnace.
Of the wind, etc.: to blow over the surface of. Of snow, sand, etc.: to cover (an animal, area, etc.) by blowing or being blown over.
To blow (an instrument) too hard or too loudly; to supply wind at too great a pressure to (an organ pipe).
To manipulate the behaviour of the column of air in (a wind instrument, or an organ pipe) in such a way as to produce a harmonic or overtone instead of the fundamental note. Also (of the instrument or pipe): to produce (a harmonic or overtone) by this means. Also without object or (occasionally) refl.
Metallurgy. To subject (a charge in a blast furnace) to an excessive length of blast. Also without object. Compare "overblown".
To exaggerate, overplay.
--Examples--

--Meanings--
From a ship into the water.

‘the severe storm washed a man overboard’

overbound 
--Type--
verb
--Meanings--
Mathematics. To set an upper bound to (a result, function, etc.).
Chiefly Geography. To set the bounds of something larger than is appropriate, or larger than the minimum necessary; to draw a boundary so as to include too large an area, category, etc.

--Word--
overburden 
--Type--
verb, noun
--Meanings--
Load (someone) with too many things to carry.
Give (someone) more work or pressure than they can deal with.
Rock or soil overlying a mineral deposit, archaeological site, or other underground feature.
An excessive burden.
--Examples--
‘they were overburdened with luggage’
‘ministers are overburdened with engagements’
‘the kaolin is mined by removing the overburden and digging a pit’
‘an overburden of costs’

verb, noun
--Meanings--
Make a higher bid than an opponent's bid.

‘an overcall of two no trumps alerts partner to the good news’

overcall 
--Type--
verb, noun
--Meanings--
Make a higher bid than an opponent's bid.
An act or instance of overcalling.
--Examples--
‘at my table West had overcalled in diamonds’
‘after North had overcalled two diamonds, East jumped to four spades’
‘an overcall of two no trumps alerts partner to the good news’
--Word--
overcall 
--Type--
verb, noun
--Meanings--
Make a higher bid than an opponent's bid.
An act or instance of overcalling.
--Examples--
‘at my table West had overcalled in diamonds’
‘after North had overcalled two diamonds, East jumped to four spades’
‘an overcall of two no trumps alerts partner to the good news’

--Type--

--Meanings--
--Examples--
--Word--
over-canopy 
--Type--
verb
--Meanings--
To form a canopy over; to extend over or cover with or as with a canopy; to overhang. Frequently in pass. Now archaic or echoing Shakespeare.
--Examples--
--Word--
overcapacity 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
The situation in which an industry or factory cannot sell as much as its plant is designed to produce.
--Examples--
‘margins were squeezed by overcapacity in the market’

--Word--
overcarry 
--Type--
verb
--Meanings--
To carry (action or proceedings) too far, to overdo; to carry (a point, etc.) too forcibly or to unnecessary length. Also without object: to carry on too long.
To carry or convey physically beyond the proper point, or further than required.
--Examples--
--Word--
overcarry 
--Type--
verb
--Meanings--

--Examples--
--Word--
overcast 
--Type--
adjective, noun, verb
--Meanings--
(of the sky or weather) marked by a covering of grey cloud; dull.
(of the edge of a piece of fabric) sewn with long slanting stitches to prevent fraying.
Cloud covering a large part of the sky.
Cover with clouds or shade.
Stitch over (a raw edge) to prevent fraying.
--Examples--
‘a chilly, overcast day’
‘the planes found the target obscured by overcast’
‘the pebbled beach, overcast with the shadows of the high cliffs’
‘finish off the raw edge of the hem by overcasting it’
--Word--
overcast 
--Type--
adjective, noun, verb

(of the sky or weather) marked by a covering of grey cloud; dull.

noun

--Word--
over-centralize 
--Type--
verb
--Meanings--
To introduce too high a degree of centralization; especially to concentrate too much power or too many administrative functions in one place. Also with object: to centralize (administrative functions, etc.) excessively.

adjective
--Meanings--

--Word--
overcharge 
--Type--
verb, noun
--Meanings--
Charge (someone) too high a price for goods or a service.
Charge someone (a sum) beyond the correct amount.
Put too much electric charge into (a battery)
An excessive charge for goods or a service.
--Examples--
‘send your bill to the Law Society if you think you've been overcharged’
‘customers have been overcharged £12 million in the last year’
‘large generators can overcharge batteries’
‘an overcharge of £40’

--Word--
overclose 
--Type--
verb
--Meanings--
To close beyond a certain limit, angle, or alignment. Cf overclosure. Also without object rare.
Astronomy. Of cosmological models and physical theories, or assumptions affecting them: to cause (the modelled universe) to have a greater mass than is estimated to be contained in it in reality or that can be reconciled with its observed expansion.

--Word--
overcompound 
--Type--
adjective, verb
--Meanings--
= over-compounded.
To provide (a dynamo) with so many series turns (compared with the number of shunt turns) that the voltage which is generated increases as the load increases. Also (occasionally) without object.
--Examples--

--Examples--
--Word--
overcool 
--Type--
verb
--Meanings--

--Examples--
--Word--
overcorrect 
--Type--
verb
--Meanings--
Optics. To correct (a lens or sight defect) so that there is an aberration opposite to that of the uncorrected lens or defect; specifically to correct for chromatic aberration to such an extent that violet light is focused beyond red light.
To make an excessive correction to; to correct (an error, etc.) in excess of that required, so as to cause error in the opposite direction.
To correct excessively; to make too great a correction for an error, etc., so as to cause error in the opposite direction; to overcompensate.
--Examples--
--Word--
overcorrect 
--Type--
verb
--Meanings--
Optics. To correct (a lens or sight defect) so that there is an aberration opposite to that of the uncorrected lens or defect; specifically to correct for chromatic aberration to such an extent that violet light is focused beyond red light.
To make an excessive correction to; to correct (an error, etc.) in excess of that required, so as to cause error in the opposite direction.
To correct excessively; to make too great a correction for an error, etc., so as to cause error in the opposite direction; to overcompensate.
--Examples--
--Word--
overcorrected 
--Type--
adjective
--Meanings--
That has been overcorrected.

overcorrect 
--Type--
verb
--Meanings--
Optics. To correct (a lens or sight defect) so that there is an aberration opposite to that of the uncorrected lens or defect; specifically to correct for chromatic aberration to such an extent that violet light is focused beyond red light.

To correct excessively; to make too great a correction for an error, etc., so as to cause error in the opposite direction; to overcompensate.
--Examples--
--Word--
overcorrection 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
Optics. Correction of a lens or sight defect so that there is an aberration opposite to that of the uncorrected lens or defect.
Excessive correction; correction which results in error or excess in the opposite direction; an instance of this.
Linguistics. = "hypercorrection".

adjective
--Meanings--
Inclined to find fault too readily.
--Examples--
‘she'd been overcritical of Margaret’
‘one couldn't help being overcritical of one's own performance’
--Word--

--Type--
adjective
--Meanings--
Inclined to find fault too readily.
--Examples--
‘she'd been overcritical of Margaret’
‘one couldn't help being overcritical of one's own performance’

adjective

--Word--
overcross 
--Type--
noun, verb, preposition
--Meanings--
An overpass, a flyover.
To lie or pass across; to move or travel across. Also without object: to intersect.
Across, over; from side to side of. Now archaic and rare.
--Examples--
--Word--

--Meanings--

overcrowd 
--Type--
verb
--Meanings--
Fill (accommodation or a space) beyond what is comfortable, safe, or permissible.
House (people or animals) in accommodations that are too confined.
--Examples--
‘overcrowded conditions’
‘my family weren't bad, we were just overcrowded’

--Word--
overcup 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
More fully "overcup oak". Either of two North American oaks in which the acorn is almost completely enclosed by the cup or its scales: (a) the mossy-cup oak, Quercus macrocarpa (also "overcup white oak"); (b) the swamp white oak, Q. lyrata, of the southern U.S.
--Examples--
--Word--
overcure 
--Type--
noun, verb
--Meanings--
The process or result of overcuring; overvulcanization.
To cure for longer than the optimal or usual period; to over-vulcanize.
To undergo overcuring. rare.
--Examples--

adjective

--Word--
overcurrent 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
Electricity. An electric current in excess of that which is normal, safe, or allowed for. Usually attributive, as "overcurrent device", "overcurrent protection", "overcurrent trip", etc.
--Examples--
--Word--
overcut 
--Type--
noun, adjective, verb
--Meanings--
Mining. A cut at or near roof level in a seam.
Engineering. In electrochemical machining: the distance between the outside surface of the cathode and the side of the cut in the part being machined.
That has been cut too much; overharvested; (of text) excessively abridged.
To cut or engrave so as to cover or efface (an earlier mark).
Forestry. To harvest (timber) at an unsustainably high rate.
US. To accumulate an excessive number of unexcused absences from classes, chapel services, etc., especially in violation of an institution's attendance policy. Also with object. Now rare.
Mining. To cut (a seam) at or near roof level.
To cut or produce a groove in a gramophone record with such amplitude as to run into an adjacent groove.
To cut or trim more than is usual or desirable.
--Examples--
--Word--

--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A machine for overcutting a seam.
--Examples--

--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
The action or process of overcut; an instance of this.

overdeepen 
--Type--
verb
--Meanings--
To erode (a valley) more deeply by glacial action than would occur by water erosion alone.
More generally: to deepen excessively or abnormally; especially to further deepen by erosion.

overdo 
--Type--
verb
--Meanings--
Do, use, or carry to excess; exaggerate.
Exhaust oneself by overwork or overexertion.
Overcook.
--Examples--
‘she rather overdoes the early cockney scenes’
‘I'd overdone the garlic in the curry’
‘I'd simply overdone it in the gym’

overdischarge 
--Type--
noun, verb
--Meanings--
Excessive discharge, especially of electricity; specifically the discharge of an accumulator or storage battery beyond a certain limit, especially so as to cause damage to it.
To discharge (an accumulator or storage battery) beyond a certain limit.
Of an accumulator or storage battery: to discharge beyond a certain limit.

--Word--
overdominance 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
Excessive dominance.
Genetics. A condition in which a heterozygote (having a copy of two different alleles of a gene) has a phenotype which falls beyond the extremes of the range represented by the corresponding homozygotes (having two copies of one or other of the alleles).
--Examples--
--Word--
overdominant 
--Type--
adjective
--Meanings--
Excessively dominant.
Genetics. Exhibiting or characterized by overdominance.
--Examples--

--Word--
overdose 
--Type--
noun, verb
--Meanings--
An excessive and dangerous dose of a drug.
Take an overdose of a drug.
Give an overdose to.
--Examples--
‘a fatal overdose of painkillers’
‘I took an overdose of sleeping pills and ended up in hospital’
‘he was admitted to hospital after overdosing on cocaine’
‘I think he had a quack doctor who overdosed him’

--Word--
overdraw 
--Type--
verb
--Meanings--
Draw money from (one's bank account) in excess of what the account holds.
(of a person) have taken money out of an account in excess of what it holds.
Exaggerate in describing or depicting (someone or something)
--Examples--
‘you only pay interest if your account is overdrawn’
‘I'm already overdrawn this month’
‘some of the characters were overdrawn’

--Word--
overdrive 
--Type--
noun, verb
--Meanings--
A gear in a motor vehicle providing a gear ratio higher than that of direct drive (the usual top gear), so that the engine speed can be reduced at high road speeds to lessen fuel consumption or to allow further acceleration.
A mechanism which permits the exceeding of some normal operating level in a piece of equipment, especially the amplifier of an electric guitar.
A state of great or excessive activity.
Drive or work to exhaustion.
Give (an electric guitar) a distorted sound.
--Examples--
‘the city's worried public relations group went into overdrive’
‘an overdriven mother of ten children’
‘pounding drums and overdriven electric guitars’
--Word--
overdrive 
--Type--
noun, verb
--Meanings--
A gear in a motor vehicle providing a gear ratio higher than that of direct drive (the usual top gear), so that the engine speed can be reduced at high road speeds to lessen fuel consumption or to allow further acceleration.
A mechanism which permits the exceeding of some normal operating level in a piece of equipment, especially the amplifier of an electric guitar.
A state of great or excessive activity.
Drive or work to exhaustion.
Give (an electric guitar) a distorted sound.
--Examples--
‘the city's worried public relations group went into overdrive’
‘an overdriven mother of ten children’
‘pounding drums and overdriven electric guitars’
--Word--
overdrive 
--Type--
noun, verb
--Meanings--
A gear in a motor vehicle providing a gear ratio higher than that of direct drive (the usual top gear), so that the engine speed can be reduced at high road speeds to lessen fuel consumption or to allow further acceleration.
A mechanism which permits the exceeding of some normal operating level in a piece of equipment, especially the amplifier of an electric guitar.
A state of great or excessive activity.
Drive or work to exhaustion.
Give (an electric guitar) a distorted sound.
--Examples--
‘the city's worried public relations group went into overdrive’
‘an overdriven mother of ten children’
‘pounding drums and overdriven electric guitars’
--Word--
overdrive 
--Type--
noun, verb
--Meanings--
A gear in a motor vehicle providing a gear ratio higher than that of direct drive (the usual top gear), so that the engine speed can be reduced at high road speeds to lessen fuel consumption or to allow further acceleration.
A mechanism which permits the exceeding of some normal operating level in a piece of equipment, especially the amplifier of an electric guitar.
A state of great or excessive activity.
Drive or work to exhaustion.
Give (an electric guitar) a distorted sound.
--Examples--
‘the city's worried public relations group went into overdrive’
‘an overdriven mother of ten children’
‘pounding drums and overdriven electric guitars’
--Word--
overdrive 
--Type--
noun, verb
--Meanings--
A gear in a motor vehicle providing a gear ratio higher than that of direct drive (the usual top gear), so that the engine speed can be reduced at high road speeds to lessen fuel consumption or to allow further acceleration.
A mechanism which permits the exceeding of some normal operating level in a piece of equipment, especially the amplifier of an electric guitar.
A state of great or excessive activity.
Drive or work to exhaustion.
Give (an electric guitar) a distorted sound.
--Examples--
‘the city's worried public relations group went into overdrive’
‘an overdriven mother of ten children’
‘pounding drums and overdriven electric guitars’
--Word--
overdrink 
--Type--
verb
--Meanings--
Drink too much alcohol.
--Examples--
‘overeating and overdrinking have become major problems for Western society’
--Word--
overdub 
--Type--
verb, noun
--Meanings--
Record (additional sounds) on an existing recording.
An instance of overdubbing.
--Examples--
‘he overdubbed vocals in the US’
‘a guitar overdub’

--Word--
overdue 
--Type--
adjective
--Meanings--
Not having arrived, happened, or been done by the expected time.
(of a woman) not having had a menstrual period at the expected time.
(of a baby) not having been born by the expected time.
(of a library book) retained longer than the period allowed.
Having been needed for some time.
Having deserved or needed something for some time.
--Examples--
‘the rent was nearly three months overdue’
‘overdue bills’
‘I was already a week-and-a-half overdue’
‘our daughter was six days overdue’
‘reform is now overdue’
‘she was overdue for some leave’

‘they were encouraged by overeager lenders’

--Word--
over- 
--Type--
prefix
--Meanings--
Excessively; to an unwanted degree.
Completely; utterly.
Upper; outer; extra.
Over; above.
--Examples--
‘overambitious’
‘overcareful’
‘overawe’
‘overjoyed’
‘overcoat’
‘overtime’
‘overcast’
‘overhang’

--Word--
overexpose 
--Type--
verb
--Meanings--
Expose too much, especially to the public eye or to risk.
Expose (film or a part of an image) for too long a time.
--Examples--
‘many UK banks were overexposed to overseas lending risks’
‘the sunlit background is overexposed’
‘you'll need to overexpose by a stop or more to stop whites being reproduced as grey’

--Word--
overexposure 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
Excessive exposure, especially to something harmful.
Excessive media coverage, especially to the point that people lose interest.
Exposure of a film or a part of an image to light for too long a time.
--Examples--
‘people are urged to avoid overexposure to the sun’
‘she suffered from overexposure to noxious air’
‘at certain times, a celebrity may suffer from overexposure’
‘Louis feared media overexposure might damage his career’
‘the deleted scenes suffer from overexposure and print defects’
--Word--
overexpress 
--Type--
verb
--Meanings--
To express (feelings, an opinion, etc.) to an excessive extent or in an exaggerated manner.
Genetics. To synthesize the product of (a gene) in abnormally large amounts; to produce abnormally large amounts of (a gene product).
--Examples--
--Word--

‘he should not overextend himself on the mortgage’

overfall 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A turbulent stretch of open water caused by a strong current or tide over a submarine ridge, or by a meeting of currents.
A place where surplus water overflows from a dam, weir, or pool.

--Word--
overfish 
--Type--
verb
--Meanings--
Deplete the stock of fish in (a body of water) by excessive fishing.
Deplete the stock of (a fish)
--Examples--
‘this part of the Mediterranean is terribly overfished’
‘yellowfin tuna has been overfished’

--Word--
overfit 
--Type--
noun, adjective, verb
--Meanings--
An analysis which corresponds too closely or exactly to a particular set of data.
Designating or relating to a stream which, on the basis of its current flow, would have eroded a larger valley than it occupies.
Statistics. To produce or represent an analysis which corresponds too closely or exactly to (a particular set of data); to make (a model) fit a particular set of data too precisely. Also without object: to provide too close a fit.
--Examples--
--Word--
overfly 
--Type--
verb
--Meanings--
Fly over (a place)
Fly beyond (a place or object)
--Examples--
‘Nato is sending a surveillance plane to overfly the city’
‘overfly the radio beacon by approximately 15 seconds’

--Word--
overflow 
--Type--
verb, noun
--Meanings--
(especially of a liquid) flow over the brim of a receptacle.
(of a container) be so full that the contents go over the sides.
(of a space) be so crowded that people spill out.
Flood or flow over (a surface or area)
Be very full of (an emotion or quality)
The flowing over of a liquid.
The excess or surplus not able to be accommodated by an available space.
(in a bath or sink) an outlet for excess water.
The generation of a number or other data item which is too large for the assigned location or memory space.
--Examples--
‘chemicals overflowed from a storage tank’
‘the river overflowed its banks’
‘boxes overflowing with bright flowers’
‘the waiting area was overflowing’
‘her hair overflowed her shoulders’
‘her heart overflowed with joy’
‘there was some overflow after heavy rainfall’
‘an overflow of sewage’
‘to accommodate the overflow five more offices have been built’
--Word--
overflowing 
--Type--
adjective
--Meanings--
Flooding or flowing over a surface or area.
(of a container) so full that the contents go over the sides.
--Examples--
‘an overflowing river swamped dozens of villages’
‘an overflowing ashtray’

--Word--
gear 
--Type--
noun, verb
--Meanings--
A toothed wheel that works with others to alter the relation between the speed of a driving mechanism (such as the engine of a vehicle) and the speed of the driven parts (the wheels)
A particular setting of engaged gears.
Used in reference to the level of effort or intensity expended in an activity or undertaking.
Equipment or apparatus that is used for a particular purpose.
Clothing, especially of a specified kind.
Personal possessions and clothes.
Illegal drugs.
Design or adjust the gears in a machine to give a specified speed or power output.
--Examples--
‘a racing bike with ten-speed gears’
‘he was belting along in fifth gear’
‘from this weekend, the campaign is expected to step up a gear’
‘now the champions moved up a gear’
‘the play moves down a gear whenever he walks off stage’
‘camping gear’
‘designer gear’
‘I told her to come back to my place with all her gear’
‘Murray got him some gear’
‘the vehicle's geared too high for serious off-road use’

--Word--
overhair 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A component of the fur in many mammals which consists of relatively long hairs (guard hairs) extending beyond the shorter fur (underfur or undercoat) to form a sparser outer layer. Also occasionally: one of these hairs; a guard hair.

overhaul 
--Type--
verb, noun
--Meanings--
Take apart (a piece of machinery or equipment) in order to examine it and repair it if necessary.
Analyse and improve (a system)
Overtake (someone), especially in a sporting event.
A thorough examination of machinery or a system, with repairs or changes made if necessary.
--Examples--
‘the steering box was recently overhauled’
‘moves to overhaul the income tax system’
‘Jodami overhauled his chief rival’
‘a major overhaul of environmental policies’
--Word--
overhaul 
--Type--
verb, noun
--Meanings--
Take apart (a piece of machinery or equipment) in order to examine it and repair it if necessary.
Analyse and improve (a system)
Overtake (someone), especially in a sporting event.

‘a major overhaul of environmental policies’

‘the steering box was recently overhauled’
‘moves to overhaul the income tax system’
‘Jodami overhauled his chief rival’
‘a major overhaul of environmental policies’
--Word--
overhaul 
--Type--
verb, noun
--Meanings--
Take apart (a piece of machinery or equipment) in order to examine it and repair it if necessary.
Analyse and improve (a system)
Overtake (someone), especially in a sporting event.
A thorough examination of machinery or a system, with repairs or changes made if necessary.
--Examples--
‘the steering box was recently overhauled’
‘moves to overhaul the income tax system’
‘Jodami overhauled his chief rival’
‘a major overhaul of environmental policies’
--Word--
overhead 
--Type--
adverb, adjective, noun
--Meanings--
Above the level of the head; in the sky.
Situated above the level of the head.
(of a driving mechanism) above the object driven.
(of a cost or expense) incurred in the upkeep or running of a plant, premises, or business and not attributable to individual products or items.
An overhead cost or expense.
A transparency designed for use with an overhead projector.
An overhead compartment, especially on an aircraft.
--Examples--
‘a helicopter buzzed overhead’
‘the sun was directly overhead’
‘an overhead cam four-cylinder engine’
‘government departments generally baulk at paying full overhead costs’
‘overheads, such as lighting, equipment, and any little extras, are paid for out of a centralized fund’
‘software for producing slides, charts, and overheads’
‘passengers get up to fiddle with their luggage in the overheads’
--Word--
overhead 
--Type--
adverb, adjective, noun
--Meanings--
Above the level of the head; in the sky.
Situated above the level of the head.
(of a driving mechanism) above the object driven.
(of a cost or expense) incurred in the upkeep or running of a plant, premises, or business and not attributable to individual products or items.
An overhead cost or expense.
A transparency designed for use with an overhead projector.
An overhead compartment, especially on an aircraft.
--Examples--
‘a helicopter buzzed overhead’
‘the sun was directly overhead’
‘an overhead cam four-cylinder engine’
‘government departments generally baulk at paying full overhead costs’
‘overheads, such as lighting, equipment, and any little extras, are paid for out of a centralized fund’
‘software for producing slides, charts, and overheads’
‘passengers get up to fiddle with their luggage in the overheads’

--Word--
overheat 
--Type--
verb
--Meanings--
Make or become too hot.
Make or become too excited.
(of a country's economy) show marked inflation when increased demand results in rising prices rather than increased output.
--Examples--
‘her car started to overheat’
‘it's vital not to overheat the liquid’
‘we don't want wild stories circulating, they only overheat things’
‘in 1987 the Treasury had allowed the economy to overheat’
--Word--
overheated 
--Type--
adjective
--Meanings--
Having become or been made too hot.
Too excited or agitated.
Showing marked economic inflation.
--Examples--
‘let the overheated engine cool off’
‘his overheated imagination’
‘the overheated market for homes’

overjump 
--Type--
verb
--Meanings--
To jump over (a thing). Now chiefly figurative: to transcend, overleap. Also (occasionally) without object.
And without object. Especially of a horse: to jump too far or too high over (a fence, etc.). Also with object (refl.): to jump further than one's strength allows.

--Word--
overlay 
--Type--
verb, noun
UnKnownKind
--Meanings--
Cover the surface of (something) with a coating.
Lie on top of.
(of a quality or feeling) become more prominent than (a previous quality or feeling)
Something laid as a covering over something else.
A transparent sheet placed over artwork or something such as a map, giving additional information or detail.
A graphical computer display which can be superimposed on another.
The process of transferring a block of program code or other data into internal memory, replacing what is already stored.
A block of code or other data transferred during the overlay process.
--Examples--
‘their fingernails were overlaid with silver or gold’
‘a third screen which will overlay the others’
‘his openness had been overlaid by his new self-confidence’
‘a durable, cost-effective floor overlay’
‘full-colour aerial photographs with overlays showing suggested routes’
--Word--
overlaid 
--Type--
UnKnownKind
--Meanings--
--Examples--

--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A top or covering layer.
--Examples--
‘overlayers of paint and varnish had been added to the tables in later years’

--Word--
overlap 
--Type--
verb, noun
--Meanings--
Extend over so as to cover partly.
Cover part of the same area of interest, responsibility, etc.
Partly coincide in time.
A part or amount which overlaps.
A common area of interest, responsibility, etc.
A period of time in which two events or activities happen together.
--Examples--
‘the canopy overlaps the house roof at one end’
‘the curtains overlap at the centre when closed’
‘the union's commitments overlapped with those of NATO’
‘two new series overlapped’
‘an overlap of about half an inch’
‘there are many overlaps between the approaches’
‘there is some overlap in requirements’
‘an overlap of shifts’
--Word--

--Word--
overlard 
--Type--
verb
--Meanings--
Figurative. To intersperse or garnish (speech, writing, etc.) with an excessive number of words, ideas, etc.
--Examples--
--Word--
overlarge 
--Type--
adjective
--Meanings--
Too large.
--Examples--
‘an overlarge meal’
--Word--
overlargely 
--Type--
adverb
--Meanings--
Too largely; to too great an extent; excessively. Formerly also: †too boldly or extravagantly (obsolete).
--Examples--

overlargeness 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
Excessive largeness; immoderate size or magnitude.

--Word--
overleap 
--Type--
verb
--Meanings--
Jump over or across.
Omit or ignore.
--Examples--
‘a stream that any five-years' child might overleap’
‘whatever objection made by us, he finds too heavy to remove, he overleaps it’

--Word--
overlearn 
--Type--
verb
--Meanings--
To learn more than adequately or sufficiently; to learn or study excessively; (Psychology and Education) to learn to the point where a response becomes instinctive, especially by repeated study or practice.
--Examples--
--Word--
overlearned 
--Type--
adjective
--Meanings--
Excessively learned or well-educated; too scholarly or academic.
Psychology and Education. That has been learned to a point where a response becomes instinctive.
--Examples--
--Word--
overlearnedness 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
Psychology and Education. The fact of having been overlearned.
--Examples--

overlearnedness 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
Psychology and Education. The fact of having been overlearned.

overlend 
--Type--
verb
--Meanings--
To lend more (money) than is advisable or economically viable; especially of a bank.
--Examples--

--Word--
overlift 
--Type--
noun, verb
--Meanings--
The action or an act of overlifting something.
To lift too high; to raise beyond the proper point. Chiefly used with reference to a tumbler or detector in a lock.
--Examples--
--Word--
overlight 
--Type--
noun, adjective, verb
--Meanings--
An excess of light.
Too light, excessively light; too insubstantial or frivolous; too easy.
Chiefly poetic. To shed light over; to shine over.
To illuminate too brightly.
--Examples--

--Meanings--

noun, verb

--Word--
overload 
--Type--
verb, noun
--Meanings--
Load with too great a burden or cargo.
Give excessive work, responsibility, or information to.
Put too great a demand on (an electrical system)
An excessive amount of something.
--Examples--
‘both boats were overloaded and low in the water’
‘the staff are heavily overloaded with casework’
‘the wiring had been overloaded’
‘an overload of stress’
--Word--
overloaded 
--Type--
adjective
--Meanings--
Loaded with too great a burden or cargo.
Having been given an excessive amount of work, responsibility, or information.
(of an electrical system) having too great a demand put upon it.
--Examples--
‘overloaded vehicles’
‘employees are feeling overloaded’
‘overloaded emergency departments’
‘they were fed up with frequent electricity cuts to the building due to overloaded circuits’

--Word--
overlook 
--Type--
verb, noun
--Meanings--
Fail to notice.
Ignore or disregard (something, especially a fault or offence)
Pass over (someone) in favour of another.
Have a view of from above.
(of a place) be open to view and so lack privacy.
Supervise.
Bewitch with the evil eye.
A commanding position or view.
--Examples--
‘he seems to have overlooked one important fact’
‘she was more than ready to overlook his faults’
‘he was overlooked by the Nobel committee’
‘the chateau overlooks fields of corn and olive trees’
‘it's better if the property isn't overlooked’
‘he was overlooking his harvest men’
‘they told them they were overlooked by some unlucky Person’
‘the overlook to the townsite’

--Word--
overlord 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A ruler, especially a feudal lord.
A person of great power or authority.
--Examples--
‘Charles was overlord of vast territories in Europe’
‘the Jews rebelled against their Roman overlords’
‘the undisputed overlord of the crime family’

overmature 
--Type--
adjective
--Meanings--
Having passed beyond the state of maturity; beginning to age or deteriorate.
Forestry. Of a tree: having reached a developmental stage at which growth has slowed down or virtually ceased, or at which the tree has begun to lose commercial value as timber.
--Examples--

--Word--
overmodulation 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
Distortion occurring during amplitude modulation as a result of an excessively large modulating signal; specifically distortion whereby the amplitude of the carrier becomes zero for a significant part of each cycle of the modulating wave.
--Examples--
--Word--
overmore 
--Type--
adverb
--Meanings--
In addition; furthermore, moreover.
--Examples--
--Word--
overmount 
--Type--
verb
--Meanings--
Horse Riding. To provide (a rider) with a horse which is beyond his or her skill to control.
--Examples--
--Word--
overmount 
--Type--
verb
--Meanings--
Horse Riding. To provide (a rider) with a horse which is beyond his or her skill to control.
--Examples--

overmourn 
--Type--
verb
--Meanings--
To mourn (a person, a person's death, etc.) excessively.
--Examples--
--Word--
overmuch 
--Type--
UnKnownKind
--Meanings--
Too much.
--Examples--
‘I would not worry overmuch’
‘the police may have overmuch regard for public order considerations’
‘she was requiring overmuch from him’
--Word--

noun
--Meanings--

noun
--Meanings--

--Word--
all-overness 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
With reference to a pattern or design: the quality of being composed of elements that are repeated over the whole extent. In art: the abstract style of painting in which the composition is dispersed with almost equal intensity over the whole picture.
--Examples--
--Word--
overnet 
--Type--
verb
--Meanings--
To overfish (an area or fish population) by excessive use of nets.

--Word--
overnight 
--Type--
adverb, adjective, verb, noun
--Meanings--
For the duration of a night.
During the course of a night.
Instantly or very quickly.
Done, happening, or for use overnight.
Instant.
Stay for the night in a particular place.
Convey (goods) at night, so that they arrive the next day.
A stop or stay lasting one night.
--Examples--
‘they refused to stay overnight’
‘you can recharge the battery overnight’
‘the picture made Wallis famous overnight’
‘an overnight stay’
‘an overnight bag’
‘Tom became an overnight celebrity’
‘I overnighted at the Beverly Wilshire’
‘Forster overnighted the sample to headquarters by courier’
‘overnights can be arranged in Kathmandu’
--Word--
overnighter 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A person who stops at a place overnight.
An overnight bag.
An overnight trip or stay.
--Examples--
‘there were no overnighters asleep on bedrolls’
‘an overnighter at a nearby campsite’
--Word--

--Meanings--

overpick 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
In the design of a loom: an arrangement in which the picking arm is placed above the shuttle box, or the shuttle-driving arrangement is placed above the loom. Frequently attributive, especially in "overpick loom".
--Examples--
--Word--

verb

--Word--
overpress 
--Type--
noun, verb
--Meanings--
Excessive pressure; an excessive burden.
To overburden, overload. Now: specifically to expose (a vessel) to too great a force of wind by using too much sail.
To press or insist on (a point, etc.) unduly.
To put too much pressure on (a person); to overwork or overburden.
--Examples--
--Word--
overpressure 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
Specifically. Fluid or gas pressure in excess of that which is normal or allowed for; an instance of this.
Physics. The difference between the (highest) instantaneous pressure at a point subjected to a shock wave and the ambient atmospheric pressure.
--Examples--

overprint 
--Type--
verb, noun
--Meanings--
Print additional matter on (a stamp or other surface already bearing print)
Print too many copies of.
Make (a print or other positive) darker than intended.
Words or other matter printed on to something already bearing print.
An overprinted postage stamp.
--Examples--
‘menus will be overprinted with company logos’
‘some stamps are cheaper with the overprint’
‘the Great Britain overprints remained valid for postage’

overproduce 
--Type--
verb
--Meanings--
Produce more of (a product or commodity) than is wanted or needed.
Record or arrange (a song or piece of music) in such an elaborate way that the spontaneity or artistry of the original material is lost.
--Examples--
‘our unplanned manufacturing system continually overproduces consumer products’
‘a series of overproduced albums’

--Word--
overproduction 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
Production of more of a product, commodity, or substance than is wanted or needed.
The recording or arrangement of a song or piece of music in such an elaborate way that the spontaneity or artistry of the original material is lost.
--Examples--
‘there was a crisis of overproduction in traditional manufacturing’
‘certain foods cause overproduction of bacteria in the stomach’
‘so many tracks suffer from overproduction’
--Word--
overproduction 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
Production of more of a product, commodity, or substance than is wanted or needed.
The recording or arrangement of a song or piece of music in such an elaborate way that the spontaneity or artistry of the original material is lost.
--Examples--
‘there was a crisis of overproduction in traditional manufacturing’
‘certain foods cause overproduction of bacteria in the stomach’
‘so many tracks suffer from overproduction’
--Word--
overpromise 
--Type--
verb
--Meanings--
Promise more than one is able to do or give.
--Examples--
‘if you overpromise and under-deliver, you frustrate your customer’
‘they'll overpromise on jobs’
‘he's careful not to overpromise the benefits’

overpromise

--Meanings--
Promise more than one is able to do or give.
--Examples--
‘if you overpromise and under-deliver, you frustrate your customer’
‘they'll overpromise on jobs’
‘he's careful not to overpromise the benefits’

--Word--
overreach 
--Type--
verb, noun
--Meanings--
Reach out too far.
Try to do more than is possible.
(of a horse or dog) bring the hind feet so far forward that they fall alongside or strike the forefeet.
Get the better of by cunning; outwit.
An injury to a forefoot of a horse resulting from its having overreached.
--Examples--
‘never lean sideways from a ladder or overreach’
‘the Church overreached itself in securing a territory that would prove impossible to hold’
‘the horse overreached jumping the first hurdle’
‘Faustus's lunacy in thinking he can overreach the devil’

--Word--
override 
--Type--
verb, noun
--Meanings--
Use one's authority to reject or cancel (a decision, view, etc.)
Be more important than.
Interrupt the action of (an automatic device), typically in order to take manual control.
Extend over; overlap.
Travel or move over.
A device for suspending an automatic function on a machine.
An excess or increase on a budget, salary, or cost.
A cancellation of a decision by exertion of authority or winning of votes.
--Examples--
‘the courts will ultimately override any objections’
‘this commitment should override all other considerations’
‘you can override the cut-out by releasing the switch’
‘the external rendering should not override the damp-proof membrane’
‘overriding by vehicles is implicated in over half the cases of footway damage’
‘the flash has to have a manual override to be useful’
‘commission overrides give established carriers an unfair advantage’
‘the House vote in favour of the bill was 10 votes short of the requisite majority for an override’

overrise

verb
--Meanings--
North American. Of dough, bread, etc.: to rise too high, so as to spoil. Compare earlier overrisen.

overrisen 
--Type--
adjective
--Meanings--
That has risen too high, especially of dough, bread, etc.; (figurative) overweening, despotic. Also of a ship: floating too high in the water, so as to become unstable.

--Word--
round 
--Type--
adjective, noun, adverb, preposition, verb
--Meanings--
Shaped like a circle or cylinder.
Having a curved shape like part of the circumference of a circle.
(of a person's shoulders) bent forward from the line of the back.
Shaped like a sphere.
(of a person's body) plump.
Having a curved surface with no sharp projections.
(of a voice) rich and mellow; not harsh.
(of a number) expressed in convenient units rather than exactly, for example to the nearest whole number or multiple of ten.
Used to show that a figure has been completely and exactly reached.
(of a sum of money) considerable.
Not omitting or disguising anything; frank.
A circular piece of something.
A thick disc of beef cut from the haunch as a joint.
An act of visiting a number of people or places in turn.
A regular tour of inspection in which the well-being of those visited is checked.
A journey along a fixed route delivering goods as part of one's job or a job involving such journeys.
Each of a sequence of sessions in a process, typically characterized by development between one session and another.
A division of a contest such as a boxing or wrestling match.
Each of a succession of stages in a competition, in each of which more candidates are eliminated.
An act of playing all the holes in a golf course once.
A regularly recurring sequence of activities.
A set of drinks bought for all the members of a group, typically as part of a sequence in which each member in turn buys such a set.
A song for three or more unaccompanied voices or parts, each singing the same theme but starting one after another, at the same pitch or in octaves; a simple canon.
A slice of bread.
The quantity of sandwiches made from two slices of bread.
The amount of ammunition needed to fire one shot.
A fixed number of arrows shot from a fixed distance.
So as to rotate or cause rotation; with circular motion.
So as to cover or take in the whole area surrounding a particular centre.
So as to reach everyone in a particular group or area.
So as to rotate and face in the opposite direction.
So as to lead in another direction.
Used in describing the position of something, typically with regard to the direction in which it is facing or its relation to other items.
Used to describe a situation in terms of the relation between people, actions, or events.
So as to surround someone or something.
Used in stating the girth of something.
So as to reach a new place or position, typically by moving to the other side of something.
Used to convey an ability to navigate or orientate oneself.
Used to convey the idea of visiting someone else.
Used to suggest idle and purposeless motion or activity.
So as to give support and companionship.
On every side of (a focal point)
(of something abstract) having (the thing mentioned) as a focus.
So as to encircle (someone or something)
(of a person's arm or arms) partially encircling (another person) as a gesture of affection.
Following an approximately circular route past (a corner or obstacle)
On the other side of (a corner or obstacle)
So as to hit (something) in passing.
So as to cover or take in the whole area of (a place)
Pass and go round (something) so as to move on in a changed direction.
Alter (a number) to one less exact but more convenient for calculations.
Give a round shape to.
Become circular in shape.
Pronounce (a vowel) with the lips narrowed and protruded.
--Examples--
‘she was seated at a small, round table’
‘round brackets’
‘a round glass ball’
‘the grapes are small and round’
‘he could move quickly despite his round physique’
‘the boulders look round and smooth’
‘his rich, round voice went down well with the listeners’
‘the size of the fleet is given in round numbers’
‘the batsman made a round 100’
‘a round dozen’
‘his business is worth a round sum to me’
‘she berated him in good round terms’
‘cut the pastry into rounds’
‘she did the rounds of her family to say goodbye’
‘the doctor is just making his rounds in the wards’
‘I did a newspaper round’
‘the two sides held three rounds of talks’
‘the FA Cup first round’
‘Eileen enjoys the occasional round of golf’
‘their lives were a daily round of housework and laundry’
‘it's my round’
‘two rounds of toast’
‘the gun can fire 30 rounds a second’
‘a plane circled round overhead’
‘she turned her glass round and round’
‘she paused to glance round admiringly at the décor’
‘he passed round a newspaper cutting’
‘he swung round to face her’
‘it was the last house before the road curved round’
‘the picture shows the pieces the wrong way round’
‘it was he who was attacking her, not the other way round’
‘everyone crowded round’
‘a pool with banks all the way round’
‘the trunk is nine feet round’
‘he made his way round to the back of the building’
‘they went the long way round by the main road’
‘I like pupils to find their own way round’
‘why don't you come round to my flat?’
‘he was driving round aimlessly’
‘if one girl is distraught the others will rally round’
‘the area round the school’
‘with shifting sands all round me’
‘the text is built round real practical examples’
‘he wrapped the blanket round him’
‘she drew a red circle round his name’
‘Angus put an arm round Flora and kissed her’
‘a bus appeared round the corner’
‘Steven parked the car round the corner’
‘if he didn't shut up he might get a clip round the ear’
‘she went round the house and saw that all the windows were barred’
‘the ship rounded the cape and sailed north’
‘we'll round the weight up to the nearest kilo’
‘the committee rounded down the figure’
‘a lathe that rounded chair legs’
‘her eyes rounded in dismay’
‘the actor's uneven attempt to round the vowels of his midwestern twang’
--Word--
overruff 
--Type--
verb, noun
--Meanings--
(in bridge, whist, and similar card games) play a trump that is higher than one already played in the same trick.
An act of overruffing.
--Examples--
‘there was a danger that West would be able to overruff’
‘when you see the chance of an easy overruff, don't be in too much of a hurry to take it’
--Word--
overruff 
--Type--
verb, noun
--Meanings--
(in bridge, whist, and similar card games) play a trump that is higher than one already played in the same trick.
An act of overruffing.
--Examples--
‘there was a danger that West would be able to overruff’
‘when you see the chance of an easy overruff, don't be in too much of a hurry to take it’
--Word--
overruff 
--Type--
verb, noun
--Meanings--
(in bridge, whist, and similar card games) play a trump that is higher than one already played in the same trick.
An act of overruffing.
--Examples--
‘there was a danger that West would be able to overruff’
‘when you see the chance of an easy overruff, don't be in too much of a hurry to take it’
--Word--
overruff 
--Type--
verb, noun
--Meanings--
(in bridge, whist, and similar card games) play a trump that is higher than one already played in the same trick.
An act of overruffing.
--Examples--
‘there was a danger that West would be able to overruff’
‘when you see the chance of an easy overruff, don't be in too much of a hurry to take it’
--Word--
overrule 
--Type--
verb
--Meanings--
Reject or disallow by exercising one's superior authority.
Reject the decision or opinion of.
--Examples--
‘Chief Judge Moran overruled the government's objections’
‘welfare staff overruled an experienced detective’

--Word--
overrun 
--Type--
verb, noun
--Meanings--
Spread over or occupy (a place) in large numbers.
Move or extend over or beyond.
Run over or beyond.
Rotate faster than (another part of a machine)
Continue beyond or above an expected or allowed time or cost.
An instance of something exceeding an expected or allowed time or cost.
The movement or extension of something beyond an expected or allotted position.
A clear area beyond the end of a runway.
The movement of a vehicle at a speed greater than is imparted by the engine.
--Examples--
‘the Mediterranean has been overrun by tourists’
‘the northern frontier was overrun by invaders’
‘let the text overrun the right-hand margin’
‘Rufus overran third base’
‘an overrunning clutch’
‘he allowed the match to overrun by 2 minutes’
‘he mustn't overrun his budget’
‘the cost overrun caused the company's share price to fall’
‘the system acts as a brake to prevent cable overrun’
‘the pilot thinks he is braking as hard as possible but has the risk of an overrun’
‘the aircraft crossed the overrun and rolled down an embankment’
‘the engines have overrun fuel cut-off’
--Word--
overrunner 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A person who or thing which overruns something; specifically an invader, a despoiler.
--Examples--
--Word--

--Word--
over 
--Type--
preposition, adverb, noun
--Meanings--
Extending directly upwards from.
Above so as to cover or protect.
Extending above (an area) from a vantage point.
At a higher level or layer than.
Higher in rank than.
Expressing authority or control.
Expressing preference.
Expressing majority.
Higher in volume or pitch than.
Higher or more than (a specified number or quantity)
Expressing passage or trajectory across.
Beyond and falling or hanging from.
At the other side of; beyond.
Expressing duration.
Expressing the medium by which something is done; by means of.
On the subject of.
Expressing passage or trajectory across an area.
In or to the place indicated.
Beyond and falling or hanging from a point.
Used to express action and result.
Finished.
Used to express repetition of a process.
A sequence of six balls bowled by a bowler from one end of the pitch, after which another bowler takes over from the other end.
--Examples--
‘I saw flames over Berlin’
‘cook the sauce over a moderate heat’
‘an oxygen tent over the bed’
‘ladle this sauce over fresh pasta’
‘views over Hyde Park’
‘his flat was over the shop’
‘over him is the financial director’
‘editorial control over what is included’
‘I'd choose the well-known brand over that one’
‘there was a slight predominance of boys over girls’
‘he shouted over the noise of the taxis’
‘over 40 degrees C’
‘they've been married for over a year’
‘she trudged over the lawn’
‘he toppled over the side of the boat’
‘over the hill is a small village’
‘you've given us a lot of heartache over the years’
‘she told me over coffee’
‘a voice came over the loudspeaker’
‘a long and heated debate over unemployment’
‘he leant over and tapped me on the hand’
‘I'm over here’
‘she knocked the jug over’
‘the car flipped over’
‘hand the money over’
‘the match is over’
‘message understood, over and out’
‘the jukebox plays every song twice over’

oversaturate 
--Type--
verb
--Meanings--

--Examples--

oversaturated 
--Type--
adjective
--Meanings--
Excessively saturated; supersaturated.
Geology. Designating a rock or magma in which there is free silica or other specified oxide.

overseas

adverb, adjective
--Meanings--

--Examples--

--Word--
overseam 
--Type--
noun, verb
--Meanings--
A seam in which raw edges are joined together on the outside of the work, using an oversewing stitch.
To sew together (two edges) with an overseam; = "oversew".
--Examples--

--Word--
overshading 
--Type--
adjective
--Meanings--
That overshades.
--Examples--
--Word--
overshadow 
--Type--
verb
--Meanings--
Tower above and cast a shadow over.
Cast gloom over.
Appear more prominent or important than.
Be more impressive or successful than (another person)
--Examples--
‘an enormous oak tree stood overshadowing the cottage’
‘it is easy to let this feeling of tragedy overshadow his story’
‘his competitive nature often overshadows the other qualities’
‘he was always overshadowed by his brilliant elder brother’

--Word--
overshoot 
--Type--
verb, noun
--Meanings--
Go past (an intended stopping or turning point) inadvertently.
Exceed (a financial target or limit)
An act of overshooting something.
--Examples--
‘they overshot their intended destination’
‘he had overshot by fifty yards but backed up to the junction’
‘the department may overshoot its cash limit’

oversman 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
Law. An arbiter; specifically a person appointed to decide on the outcome of an arbitrated dispute where the arbiters previously appointed have been unable to agree on a settlement. Compare "overman").
Specifically. A foreman or supervisor in a mine or colliery.

oversow 
--Type--
verb
--Meanings--
To sow (seed) over seed, or over a previously sown crop.
To sow (ground) with seed, or additional seed. Frequently figurative: to strew with, to besprinkle.
And without object. To sow (seed) too densely; to sow too many (seeds).

--Word--
overspeed 
--Type--
noun, verb
--Meanings--
Excessive speed; especially the operation of an engine, vehicle, etc., at a speed higher than is safe or appropriate; an instance of this.
To travel too quickly, especially to travel faster than permitted by law or by another authority. Also with object: to cause (a vehicle) to travel more quickly than is safe. Now chiefly in African and S. Asian use.
Chiefly Mechanics. To operate (an engine or other machine) at a speed higher than is safe for its gearing or other components.

--Word--
overstand 
--Type--
verb, verb
--Meanings--
To stand over (formerly especially so as to guard or intimidate); to stand higher than or above.
Oxford University"to be overstanding for honours": to be ineligible for honours in an examination because more than the permitted number of terms (normally twelve) has elapsed since one's matriculation.
Sailing. To sail past (a line or mark indicating the course of a race) by staying on a tack for too long.
And without object. To understand. Now used (especially in Caribbean and African-American usage) to avoid the negative connotations of under, perceived as incompatible with the positive meaning of the verb.
And without object. Contrasted with understand in other ways, as: to understand more than is necessary or desirable; to analyse excessively; to understand fully.
--Examples--
--Word--
overstand 
--Type--
verb, verb
--Meanings--
To stand over (formerly especially so as to guard or intimidate); to stand higher than or above.
Oxford University"to be overstanding for honours": to be ineligible for honours in an examination because more than the permitted number of terms (normally twelve) has elapsed since one's matriculation.
Sailing. To sail past (a line or mark indicating the course of a race) by staying on a tack for too long.
And without object. To understand. Now used (especially in Caribbean and African-American usage) to avoid the negative connotations of under, perceived as incompatible with the positive meaning of the verb.
And without object. Contrasted with understand in other ways, as: to understand more than is necessary or desirable; to analyse excessively; to understand fully.

To take longer strides than is natural, usual, or advisable.

noun
--Meanings--
The superimposing of one printed character or one coin design on another.
A coin showing one design superimposed on another.
--Examples--
--Word--
overstriking 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
--Examples--
--Word--
overstringing 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
In the construction of pianos and similar keyboard instruments: an arrangement of strings at two (rarely, three) levels, the bass strings passing obliquely over the others, so as to make more effective use of available space.
--Examples--
--Word--
over-strong 
--Type--
adjective
--Meanings--
Excessively strong.
--Examples--
--Word--
over-strongly 
--Type--
adverb
--Meanings--
Too strongly.
--Examples--
--Word--
overstruck 
--Type--
adjective
--Meanings--
That is or has been overstruck.
--Examples--
--Word--
overstrung 
--Type--
adjective
--Meanings--
(of a piano) having strings in sets crossing each other obliquely.
(of a person) extremely nervous or tense.
--Examples--
‘at two in the morning the overstrung youth finally ran out of questions’

--Word--
oversubscribe 
--Type--
verb
--Meanings--
To make the subject of excessive demand for subscriptions; to apply for (tickets, copies of a book, places on a course, etc.) in greater quantities than are available.
--Examples--
--Word--
oversubscribe 
--Type--
verb
--Meanings--

--Examples--
--Word--
oversubscribed 
--Type--
adjective
--Meanings--
(of something for sale) applied for in greater quantities than are available.
(of a course or institution) having more applications than available places.
--Examples--
‘shares on sale in Europe were oversubscribed’
‘the school is already oversubscribed, despite its fees’

--Word--
oversway 
--Type--
verb
--Meanings--
To take precedence over by virtue of superior authority; to overrule, countermand (an order, ruling, action, etc.).
To cause (a person, his or her actions, conduct, or thoughts) to be directed in a particular way; to influence with regard to some decision or course of action; to persuade or prevail upon.
To overpower by being of greater strength, intensity, etc.; to dominate, overwhelm.
To cause to lean or swing over, or to overturn; to sway over or beyond (something). Also without object: to lean over or downwards.
--Examples--
--Word--

verb
--Meanings--
To swarm over or across; to cover (a place) with a swarm or profusion of something. Also (occasionally) without object.

--Word--
overswell 
--Type--
verb
--Meanings--
And with object. To swell excessively.
Especially of a body of water: to swell so as to spill over or beyond (a bank, barrier, limit, etc.). Also occasionally without object. Now rare (poetic in later use).
--Examples--

--Word--
overswing 
--Type--
noun, verb
--Meanings--
Golf. The action or practice of using excessive backswing or follow-through when swinging the club; an instance of this.
Gymnastics. A movement in which the body swings or turns over.
Generally. The action or an act of swinging too far. Also in extended use: an excessive reversal or correction; an overreaction.
Sport (chiefly Golf and Baseball). To swing too hard when hitting a ball, employing excessive backswing or follow-through.
--Examples--
--Word--
overswing 
--Type--
noun, verb
--Meanings--
Golf. The action or practice of using excessive backswing or follow-through when swinging the club; an instance of this.
Gymnastics. A movement in which the body swings or turns over.
Generally. The action or an act of swinging too far. Also in extended use: an excessive reversal or correction; an overreaction.
Sport (chiefly Golf and Baseball). To swing too hard when hitting a ball, employing excessive backswing or follow-through.

--Examples--
--Word--
overtake 
--Type--
verb
--Meanings--
Catch up with and pass while travelling in the same direction.
Become greater or more successful than.
(especially of misfortune) come suddenly or unexpectedly upon.
(of a feeling) affect (someone) suddenly and powerfully.
--Examples--
‘the driver overtook a line of vehicles’
‘he overtook in the face of oncoming traffic’
‘Germany rapidly overtook Britain in industrial output’
‘disaster overtook the town in AD 296’
‘weariness overtook him and he retired to bed’
--Word--

--Examples--
--Word--
overthrow 
--Type--
verb, noun
--Meanings--
Remove forcibly from power.
Put an end to (something) by the use of force.
Knock or throw to the ground.
Throw (a ball) further than the intended distance.
Throw a ball beyond (a receiving player)
A removal from power.
(in cricket, baseball, and other games) a throw which sends a ball past its intended recipient or target.
A score made because the ball has been overthrown.
A panel of decorated wrought-iron work above an arch or gateway.
--Examples--
‘military coups which had attempted to overthrow the King’
‘their subversive activities are calculated to overthrow parliamentary democracy’
‘one who is already prostrate cannot be overthrown’
‘he grips the ball too tight and overthrows it’
‘Dodge overthrew a receiver in the end zone’
‘plotting the overthrow of the government’
‘his throw missed the stumps and went for four overthrows’
--Word--

--Word--
overthrust 
--Type--
noun, verb
--Meanings--
The thrust of one series of rock strata over another, especially along a fault line at a shallow angle to the horizontal.
Force (a body of rock) over another.
--Examples--
‘the increased overburden resulting from overthrusting’
--Word--
overthwart 
--Type--
preposition, adverb
--Meanings--
From side to side of; so as to cross; across, athwart. Now archaic and English regional.
From side to side; so as to cross something; across, athwart; crosswise, transversely. Now English regional.
--Examples--

--Word--
overtime 
--Type--
noun, adverb
--Meanings--
Time worked in addition to one's normal working hours.
Payment for overtime.
Extra time played at the end of a game that is tied at the end of the regulation time.
In addition to normal working hours.
--Examples--
‘fewer opportunities for overtime’
‘the company could not afford to pay overtime’
‘they lost in overtime’
‘we worked overtime to fulfil a big order’
‘his brain was working overtime’

--Word--
Overton window 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
The spectrum of ideas on public policy and social issues considered acceptable by the general public at a given time.
--Examples--
‘I suppose the Overton window is shifting, but slowly’
--Word--
overtone 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A musical tone which is a part of the harmonic series above a fundamental note, and may be heard with it.
A component of any oscillation whose frequency is an integral multiple of the fundamental frequency.
A subtle or subsidiary quality, implication, or connotation.
--Examples--
‘the decision may have political overtones’

--Word--
overtake 
--Type--
verb
--Meanings--
Catch up with and pass while travelling in the same direction.
Become greater or more successful than.
(especially of misfortune) come suddenly or unexpectedly upon.
(of a feeling) affect (someone) suddenly and powerfully.
--Examples--
‘the driver overtook a line of vehicles’
‘he overtook in the face of oncoming traffic’
‘Germany rapidly overtook Britain in industrial output’
‘disaster overtook the town in AD 296’
‘weariness overtook him and he retired to bed’
--Word--
overtop 
--Type--
verb
UnKnownKind
--Meanings--
Exceed in height.
(especially of water) rise over the top of (a barrier)
Be superior to.
Over.
--Examples--
‘no building is allowed to overtop the cathedral’
‘the old sea wall is regularly overtopped by high tides’
‘none can overtop him in goodness’
‘sprinkle the mixture overtop the batter’

--Word--
overture 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
An orchestral piece at the beginning of an opera, play, etc.
An independent orchestral composition in one movement.
An introduction to something more substantial.
An approach or proposal made to someone with the aim of opening negotiations or establishing a relationship.
--Examples--
‘the overture to Mozart's ‘Don Giovanni’’
‘Overture and Incidental Music for ‘A Midsummer Night's Dream’’
‘Tchaikovsky's ‘1812 Overture’’
‘the talks were no more than an overture to a long debate’
‘he began making overtures to British merchant banks’

--Word--
overturn 
--Type--
verb, noun
--Meanings--
Tip (something) over so that it is on its side or upside down.
Turn over and come to rest upside down.
Abolish, invalidate, or reverse (a previous system, decision, situation, etc.)
An act of overturning something.
The occasional (typically twice yearly) mixing of the water of a thermally stratified lake.
--Examples--
‘the crowd proceeded to overturn cars and set them on fire’
‘a coach hit a car and overturned’
‘the results overturned previous findings’
‘he fought for eight years to overturn a conviction for armed robbery’

--Type--
adjective
--Meanings--

--Word--
over-under 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A bet on whether the outcome of an event (usually the combined score of a sports game) will be above or below a number established in advance by the bookmaker.
The number (usually the combined score of a sports game) on which bettors place wagers in an over-under bet.
A gun having barrels arranged one above the other rather than side by side.
--Examples--
‘the over-under in hockey gives you less chance of losing’
‘oddsmakers had set the over-under at 53, higher than any other game this week’
‘what's the over-under on how many fanatics will camp out?’
‘if shooting an over-under, have the upper barrel pointing over and the lower barrel under the bird’

overvoltage 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
Chemistry. The extra potential above the value for theoretical, reversible conditions which must be applied to an electrolytic cell to liberate a substance at an electrode in practical, irreversible conditions.
A voltage in excess of some threshold value, or of that which is normal, safe, or allowed for.

overwash 
--Type--
noun, verb
--Meanings--
The action or process of washing over; (Physical Geography) (a) the deposition over or beyond the marginal moraine of material carried by running water from a glacier; the material so deposited; (b) the flow of water from a lake, the sea, etc., over a low spit, berm, or other obstacle; water carried or left behind by such a flow.
To flow or wash over; to inundate. Chiefly in pass.

--Word--
overweight 
--Type--
adjective, noun, verb
--Meanings--
Above a weight considered normal or desirable.
Above an allowed weight.
Excessive or extra weight.
Put too much weight on; overload.
--Examples--
‘she was a stone overweight’
‘an overweight lorry’
‘surgical procedures for overweight’
‘he toppled back like an overweighted mannequin’
--Word--

--Word--
overwhelm 
--Type--
verb
--Meanings--
Bury or drown beneath a huge mass of something, especially water.
Give too much of something to; inundate.
Have a strong emotional effect on.
Defeat completely.
Be too strong for; overpower.
--Examples--
‘floodwaters overwhelmed hundreds of houses’
‘they were overwhelmed by farewell messages’
‘I was overwhelmed with guilt’
‘the Irish side was overwhelmed 15–3 by Scotland’
‘the Stilton doesn't overwhelm the flavour of the trout’
--Word--
overwhelm 
--Type--
verb
--Meanings--
Bury or drown beneath a huge mass of something, especially water.
Give too much of something to; inundate.

‘I was overwhelmed with guilt’

--Word--
overwhelmer 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A person who or thing which overwhelms; a conqueror.
--Examples--

overwhelming 
--Type--
adjective
--Meanings--
Very great in amount.
(especially of an emotion) very strong.
--Examples--
‘his party won overwhelming support’
‘she felt an overwhelming desire to giggle’
--Word--
overwhelmingly 
--Type--
adverb
--Meanings--
To a very great degree or with a great majority.
--Examples--
‘the country voted overwhelmingly for independence’
‘the reaction has been overwhelmingly positive’

--Word--
overwood 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
US Woodworking. Originally: extra or excess wood, especially the additional allowance needed when making a joint. Now: the amount of wood by which a floorboard of an uneven floor exceeds its neighbour in height; the condition of irregularity in a set of adjacent floorboards; also called lippage.
Forestry. = "overstorey".
--Examples--
--Word--
overword 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A repeated word or phrase, especially the burden or refrain of a song; a word or phrase frequently used by an individual.
--Examples--

--Examples--
--Word--
overwork 
--Type--
verb, noun
--Meanings--
Exhaust with too much work.
Work too hard.
Make excessive use of.
Use (a word or idea) too much and so make it weaker in meaning or effect.
Excessive work.
--Examples--
‘tired, overworked, demoralized staff’
‘the doctor advised a complete rest because he had been overworking’
‘our lifts are overworked’
‘‘Breathtaking’ is an overworked brochure cliché’
‘his health broke down under the strain of overwork’

--Word--
overworn 
--Type--
adjective
--Meanings--
Worn by excessive use; much worn; shabby, threadbare.
Figurative. Of a word, phrase, etc.: spoilt by too much use; hackneyed, stale.
Especially of a person: worn out or exhausted by age, work, etc.

--Word--
overwrite 
--Type--
verb
--Meanings--
Write on top of (other writing)
Destroy (data) by entering new data in its place.
Write too elaborately or ornately.
(in insurance) accept more risk than the premium income limits allow.
--Examples--
‘many names had been scratched out or overwritten’
‘an entry stating who is allowed to overwrite the file’
‘there is a tendency to overwrite their parts and fall into cliché’

--Word--
Ovibos 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A genus of mammals of the family Bovidae whose only living representative is the musk ox, Ovibos moschatus; (also ovibos) a mammal of this genus, a musk ox (rare).
--Examples--
--Word--
ovibovine 
--Type--
adjective, noun
--Meanings--
Of, relating to, or designating a group of goat-antelopes comprising the tribe Ovibovini, whose living members are the musk ox, Ovibos moschatus, and the takin, Budorcas taxicolor.
An ovibovine animal.
--Examples--
--Word--
ovicell 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
Zoology. A rounded chamber, projecting from the wall of a zooecium, in which the early embryos of some bryozoans develop.
--Examples--
--Word--
ovicellular 
--Type--
adjective
--Meanings--
Of or relating to an ovicell.
--Examples--
--Word--
ovicidal 
--Type--
adjective, adjective
--Meanings--
That kills sheep; of or relating to the killing of sheep.
Of, relating to, or effective in the killing or destroying of eggs or ova, especially those of insects, mites, or other pests or parasites.
--Examples--
--Word--
ovicide 
--Type--
noun, noun, noun
--Meanings--
The killing of sheep.
An agent that kills or destroys eggs or ova, especially those of insects, mites, or other pests or parasites.
The killing or destroying of eggs or ova.

--Word--
Ovid 
--Type--
proper noun
--Meanings--
(43 BC–c.17 AD), Roman poet; full name Publius Ovidius Naso. He is particularly known for his elegiac love poems (such as the Amores and the Ars Amatoria) and for the Metamorphoses, a hexametric epic which retells Greek and Roman myths.
--Examples--
--Word--

--Type--
adjective
--Meanings--

--Examples--
‘Ovidian tales of the loves of the gods’

ovism 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
The theory that the ovum holds all the material necessary for development of the embryo, the sperm providing only a stimulus to initiate the process.

--Word--
ovomucoid 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
Originally: a water-soluble proteoglycan found in egg white (now usually more fully "ovomucoid α"). In later use also (more fully "ovomucoid β"): = ovomucin.
--Examples--
--Word--
ovonic 
--Type--
adjective
--Meanings--
Relating to, involving, or utilizing the property of certain amorphous semiconductors of making a rapid, reversible transition from a non-conducting to a conducting state on the application of an electric field above a threshold value (the Ovshinsky effect).
--Examples--
--Word--
ovonics 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
The study and application of ovonic effects and devices; devices that employ ovonic effects.
--Examples--
--Word--
ovoplasm 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
= ooplasm.
--Examples--

--Word--
Ovula 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A genus of gastropod molluscs related to the cowries (family Ovulidae), native especially to the tropical Pacific Ocean, some species of which have a pure white oval shell; (also ovula) a member of this genus. Chiefly attributive in "ovula shell".
--Examples--
--Word--
ovular 
--Type--
adjective
--Meanings--
--Examples--
--Word--
ovulary 
--Type--
adjective, noun
--Meanings--
Chiefly Botany= "ovular".
Botany. In a flowering plant: the structure that contains an ovule or ovules.
--Examples--
--Word--
ovularian 
--Type--
adjective
--Meanings--
Of or relating to an ovulary; ovarian.
--Examples--
--Word--
ovulate 
--Type--
verb
--Meanings--
Discharge ova or ovules from the ovary.
--Examples--
‘women who ovulate but cannot conceive’
‘all the eggs that will be ovulated are present at birth’

‘all the eggs that will be ovulated are present at birth’

--Word--
owe 
--Type--
verb
--Meanings--
Have an obligation to pay or repay (something, especially money) in return for something received.
Owe something, especially money, to.
Be under a moral obligation to give someone (gratitude, respect, etc.)
Have something because of.
--Examples--
‘they have denied they owe money to the company’
‘you owe me £19.50 for the electricity bill’
‘I owe you for the taxi’
‘I owe it to him to explain what's happened’
‘I owe you an apology’
‘champagne houses owe their success to brand image’
‘I owe my life to you’

--Word--
own 
--Type--
UnKnownKind, verb
--Meanings--
Used with a possessive to emphasize that someone or something belongs or relates to the person mentioned.
Done or produced by and for the person mentioned.
Particular to the person or thing mentioned; individual.
Have (something) as one's own; possess.
Admit or acknowledge that something is the case or that one feels a certain way.
Take or acknowledge full responsibility for (something)
Acknowledge paternity, authorship, or possession of.
Utterly defeat (an opponent or rival); completely get the better of.
--Examples--
‘they can't handle their own children’
‘I was an outcast among my own kind’
‘the Church would look after its own’
‘I used to design all my own clothes’
‘they claimed the work as their own’
‘the style had its own charm’
‘the film had a quality all its own’
‘his father owns a restaurant’
‘a state-owned company’
‘she owned to a feeling of profound jealousy’
‘he was reluctant to own that he was indebted’
‘I emphasize the importance of owning our anger and finding ways to control it’
‘he has published little, trivial things which he will not own’
‘yeah right, she totally owned you, man’

--Type--

--Meanings--
Of or relating to oxaloacetic acid. "oxaloacetic acid"noun a dicarboxylic acid, HOOC·CO·CH₂·COOH, which is an intermediate metabolite in the Krebs cycle and the C₄ pathway of photosynthesis; (also) the enol form of this acid, HOOC·C(OH)=CH·COOH, which exists in cis and trans isomers.

oxazine 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
Any of a class of compounds whose molecules contain a ring of one nitrogen, one oxygen, and four carbon atoms, some of which are used as dyes; specifically a monocyclic compound with this structure and the formula C₄H₅NO.

noun
--Meanings--
Any of various waders, especially the dunlin, Calidris alpina, the sanderling, Calidris alba, the ringed plover Charadrius hiaticula, and the common sandpiper, Actitis hypoleucos. Compare "ox-eye". Now regional.
Any of several African birds often seen in the company of cattle: †(a) the cattle egret, Bubulcus ibis (obsolete).
--Examples--
--Word--
oxbird 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
Any of various waders, especially the dunlin, Calidris alpina, the sanderling, Calidris alba, the ringed plover Charadrius hiaticula, and the common sandpiper, Actitis hypoleucos. Compare "ox-eye". Now regional.
Any of several African birds often seen in the company of cattle: †(a) the cattle egret, Bubulcus ibis (obsolete).
--Examples--
--Word--
oxblood 
--Type--
noun, adjective
--Meanings--
The blood of an ox.
A deep red, tinged with brown, resembling the colour of oxblood.
Of the colour of oxblood; specifically of a deep red colour tinged with brown.
--Examples--

--Word--
Oxford 
--Type--
proper noun, noun
--Meanings--
A city in central England, on the River Thames, the county town of Oxfordshire; population 146,100 (est. 2009). Oxford University is located there.
A thick cotton fabric chiefly used to make shirts.
A type of lace-up shoe with a low heel.
--Examples--
‘an Oxford shirt’
‘suede Oxfords are the essential shoes for autumn’
--Word--
Oxfordian 
--Type--
adjective, noun
--Meanings--
Relating to or denoting an age in the Upper Jurassic period, lasting from about 157 to 155 million years ago.
Relating to or denoting the theory that Edward de Vere (1550–1604), Earl of Oxford, wrote the plays attributed to Shakespeare.
The Oxfordian age or the system of rocks (chiefly coral-derived limestones) deposited during it.
A supporter of the Oxfordian theory.
--Examples--
--Word--
Oxford 
--Type--
proper noun, noun
--Meanings--
A city in central England, on the River Thames, the county town of Oxfordshire; population 146,100 (est. 2009). Oxford University is located there.
A thick cotton fabric chiefly used to make shirts.
A type of lace-up shoe with a low heel.
--Examples--
‘an Oxford shirt’
‘suede Oxfords are the essential shoes for autumn’
--Word--
Oxford 
--Type--
proper noun, noun
--Meanings--
A city in central England, on the River Thames, the county town of Oxfordshire; population 146,100 (est. 2009). Oxford University is located there.
A thick cotton fabric chiefly used to make shirts.
A type of lace-up shoe with a low heel.

‘suede Oxfords are the essential shoes for autumn’

--Word--
harrow 
--Type--
noun, verb
--Meanings--
An implement consisting of a heavy frame set with teeth or tines which is dragged over ploughed land to break up clods, remove weeds, and cover seed.
Draw a harrow over (land)
Cause distress to.
--Examples--
‘they ploughed and harrowed the heavy clay’
‘Todd could take it, whereas I'm harrowed by it’
--Word--
ox-head 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
The head of an ox, especially as an article of food; a representation of the head of an ox.
A stupid person; a dolt, a blockhead. Now chiefly archaic.
A hogshead. rare.
--Examples--
--Word--
ox-head 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
The head of an ox, especially as an article of food; a representation of the head of an ox.
A stupid person; a dolt, a blockhead. Now chiefly archaic.
A hogshead. rare.

--Examples--
--Word--
ox-heart 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
The heart of an ox, especially as an article of food.
Any of various varieties of fruit or vegetable characteristically forming a heart-shaped fruit, head, root, etc.
Now chiefly North American. More fully "ox-heart cherry". Any of several large, heart-shaped varieties of cherry; the tree bearing such fruit.
In full "ox-heart clam", "ox-heart shell". Any of several large, heart-shaped bivalve molluscs, especially the heart cockle, Glossus humanus.

oxybaphon 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
Greek History. A measure of capacity, varying from place to place in the ancient world, but usually approximately equal to 2 to 2.5 fluid ounces (60–70 ml).
Greek Archaeology. A bell-shaped cup or vase, used for holding wine or vinegar or for making mixtures of these liquids with water.
--Examples--
--Word--
oxybromide 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A compound containing both oxygen and bromine; specifically (a) a combined oxide and bromide; (b) = "bromate".

oxycellulose
